eu6p4el1" data-testid="stElementContainer" data-stale="false" width="auto"><div class="stMarkdown" data-testid="stMarkdown"><div data-testid="stMarkdownContainer" class="st-emotion-cache-1104ytp e1icttdg0"><p>Respiratory rhythmicity centre
in medulla oblongata
Glossopharyngeal nerve
Vagus nerve
Carotid body in carotid artery
Nerve impulses
Figure 10.26 Some of the structures involved in control of respiration.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="exercise-and-respiration">Exercise and respiration<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#exercise-and-respiration" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Physical exercise increases both the rate and the depth of respiration to supply the increased oxygen requirements of the exercising muscles. Exercising muscle produces higher quantities of CO 2 , which stimulates central and peripheral chemoreceptors. The increased respiratory effort persists even after exercise stops, in order to supply enough oxygen to repay the 'oxygen debt'. This represents mainly the oxygen needed to get rid of wastes, including lactic acid.
expelled from the respiratory tract. There may be complete involuntary cessation of breathing (apnoea) for more extended periods, e.g. if the face is submerged in water or the air contains high concentrations of dust, smoke or other noxious substances; this has an obvious protective function.</p>
<p>The Hering-Breuer reflex prevents over-inflation of the lungs. Stretch receptors in the lung, linked to the respiratory centre by the vagus nerve, inhibit respiration when lung volume approaches maximum.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="other-factors-that-influence-respiration">other factors that influence respiration<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#other-factors-that-influence-respiration" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Breathing may be modified via the higher centres in the brain by speech, singing, emotional displays (e.g. crying, laughing, fear), drugs (e.g. sedatives, alcohol) and sleep.</p>
<p>Body temperature influences breathing. In fever, respiration is increased due to higher metabolic rate, while in hypothermia respiration and metabolism are depressed. Respiration is briefly inhibited when swallowing, to prevent the inhalation of food or drink, and inspiration is also inhibited during sneezing and coughing, while irritants are</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="spot-check">- SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol start="13">
<li>
<p>Describe the muscular effort required for quiet inspiration.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The vital capacity can be calculated by adding together the tidal volume plus which two other lung volumes?</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>How do chemoreceptors in the blood vessels and central nervous system regulate breathing?</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="effects-of-ageing-on-the-respiratory-system">Effects of ageing on the respiratory system<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#effects-of-ageing-on-the-respiratory-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Learning outcome
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe the main consequences of ageing on respiratory structure and function.</li>
</ul>
<p>Respiratory performance declines with age, beginning in the mid-20s. General loss of elastic tissue in the lungs increases the likelihood that small airways will collapse during expiration and decreases the functional lung volume. Varying degrees of emphysema (p. 286) are normal in older people, usually without symptoms.</p>
<p>Cartilage in general becomes less flexible with age and there is an increased risk of arthritic joint changes. The
ribcage therefore becomes stiffer, which, along with the general age-related reduction in muscle function, reduces the respiratory minute volume.</p>
<p>The risk of respiratory infections rises because of age-related immune decline and decreased mucus production in the airways. The respiratory chemoreceptor reflexes that increase respiratory effort in response to rising blood CO 2 /falling blood O 2 levels become less efficient, so older people may respond less well to adverse changes in blood gases.</p>
<p>Age-related respiratory compromise is greatly enhanced in smokers.</p>
<ul>
<li>SPOT CHECK</li>
</ul>
<ol start="16">
<li>What are the two main factors that reduce minute volume in healthy older age?</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="disorders-of-the-upper-respiratory-tract">Disorders of the upper respiratory tract<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disorders-of-the-upper-respiratory-tract" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Learning outcome
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe the common inflammatory and infectious disorders of the upper respiratory tract.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="infectious-and-inflammatory-disorders">Infectious and inflammatory disorders<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#infectious-and-inflammatory-disorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Inflammation of the upper respiratory tract can be caused by inhaling irritants, such as cigarette smoke or air pollutants, but is commonly due to infection. Such infections are usually caused by viruses that lower the resistance of the respiratory tract to other infections. This allows bacteria to invade the tissues. Such infections are only life-threatening if they spread to the lungs or other organs, or if inflammatory swelling and exudate block the airway.</p>
<p>Pathogens are usually spread by droplet infection (tiny droplets containing infectious material suspended in the air), by dust or by contaminated equipment and dressings. If not completely resolved, acute infection may become chronic.</p>
<p>Viral infections cause acute inflammation of the mucous membrane, leading to tissue congestion and profuse exudate of watery fluid. This can predispose to secondary bacterial infection, particularly likely in vulnerable groups such as children and older adults.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="common-cold-and-influenza">Common cold and influenza<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#common-cold-and-influenza" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The common cold (coryza) is usually caused by the rhinoviruses and is a highly infectious, normally mild illness characterised mainly by a runny nose (rhinorrhoea), sneezing, sore throat and sometimes slight fever. Normally, a cold runs its course over a few days. Influenza is caused mainly by an influenza virus and produces far more severe symptoms than a cold, including very high temperatures and muscle pains; complete recovery can take weeks and secondary bacterial infections are more common than with a simple cold. In healthy adults, most strains of influenza are incapacitating but rarely fatal, unless infection spreads to the lungs. It can, however, be a lethal illness in the elderly or immunocompromised, who may succumb to secondary bacterial pneumonia.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="sinusitis">Sinusitis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sinusitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is usually caused by spread of microbes from the nose and pharynx to the mucous membrane lining the paranasal sinuses. The primary viral infection is usually followed by bacterial infection. The congested mucosa may block the
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-a0d9148a.jpeg" alt="img-0.jpeg"></p>
<p>Infected palatine tonsils</p>
<p>Collection of pus
Inflamed and narrowed pharynx
Figure 10.27 Streptococcal tonsillitis. (Dr P Marazzi/Science Photo Library. Reproduced with permission.)
openings between the nose and the sinuses, preventing drainage of mucopurulent discharge. Symptoms include facial pain and headache. If there are repeated attacks or if recovery is not complete, the infection may become chronic.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="tonsillitis">Tonsillitis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tonsillitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Viruses and Streptococcus pyogenes are common causes of inflammation of the palatine tonsils, palatine arches and walls of the pharynx (Fig. 10.27). Severe infection may lead to suppuration and abscess formation (quinsy). Occasionally the infection spreads into the neck, causing cellulitis. Following acute tonsillitis, swelling subsides and the tonsil returns to normal, but repeated infection may lead to chronic inflammation, fibrosis and permanent enlargement. Endotoxins from tonsillitis caused by Streptococcus pyogenes are associated with the development of rheumatic fever (p. 133) and glomerulonephritis (p. 383). Repeated infection of the nasopharyngeal tonsil (adenoids, see Fig. 10.3) can leave them enlarged and fibrotic, and can cause airway obstruction, especially in children.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pharyngitis-laryngitis-and-tracheitis">Pharyngitis, laryngitis and tracheitis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pharyngitis-laryngitis-and-tracheitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The pharynx, larynx and trachea may become infected secondary to other upper respiratory tract infections, e.g. the common cold or tonsillitis.</p>
<p>Laryngotracheobronchitis (croup in children) is a rare but serious complication of upper respiratory tract infections. The airway is obstructed by marked swelling around the larynx and epiglottis, accompanied by wheeze and breathlessness (dyspnoea).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="diphtheria">Diphtheria<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diphtheria" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is a bacterial infection of the pharynx, which may extend to the nasopharynx and trachea; it is caused by Corynehacterium diphtheriae. A thick, fibrous membrane forms over the area and may obstruct the airway. The pathogen produces powerful exotoxins that may severely damage cardiac and skeletal muscle, the liver, kidneys and adrenal glands. In countries where immunisation is widespread, diphtheria is rare.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="chronic-bronchitis">Chronic bronchitis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chronic-bronchitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="hay-fever-allergic-rhinitis">Hay fever (allergic rhinitis)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hay-fever-allergic-rhinitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>In this condition, atopic ('immediate') hypersensitivity (p. 417) develops to foreign proteins (antigens), e.g. pollen, mites in pillow feathers and animal dander. Acute inflammation of nasal mucosa and conjunctiva causes rhinorrhoea (excessive watery exudate from the nose), redness of the eyes and excessive tear production. Atopic hypersensitivity tends to run in families but no single genetic factor has yet been identified; it is likely to involve multiple genes. Other forms of atopic hypersensitivity include childhood-onset asthma (see next section), eczema (p. 403) in infants and young children, and food allergies.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="spot-check">- SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol start="17">
<li>What is the difference between a cold and influenza?</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="obstructive-lung-disorders">Obstructive lung disorders<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#obstructive-lung-disorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>compare the causes and pathology of chronic and acute bronchitis</li>
<li>discuss the pathologies of the main forms of emphysema</li>
<li>discuss the causes and disordered physiology of asthma</li>
<li>explain the main physiological abnormality in bronchiectasis</li>
<li>describe the effect of cystic fibrosis on lung function.</li>
</ul>
<p>Obstructive lung disorders are characterised by blockage of airflow through the airways. Obstruction may be acute or chronic.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bronchitis-acute-bronchitis">Bronchitis Acute bronchitis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bronchitis-acute-bronchitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is usually a secondary bacterial infection of the bronchi, preceded by a common cold or influenza, and may also complicate measles and whooping cough in children. Viral infection depresses normal defence mechanisms, allowing pathogenic bacteria already present in the respiratory tract to multiply. Downward spread of infection may lead to bronchiolitis and/or bronchopneumonia, especially in children and in debilitated or older adults.</p>
<p>This common disorder becomes increasingly debilitating as it progresses. Chronic bronchitis is defined clinically when an individual has had a cough with sputum for 3 months in 2 successive years. It is a progressive inflammatory disease resulting from prolonged irritation of the bronchial epithelium, often worsened by damp or cold conditions.</p>
<p>It is often a consequence of cigarette smoking but can also follow episodes of acute bronchitis (often caused by Haemophilus influenzae or Streptococcus pneumoniae) and chronic exposure to airborne irritants such as urban fog, vehicular exhaust fumes or industrial pollutants.</p>
<p>It develops mostly in middle-aged men who are chronic heavy smokers and may have a familial predisposition. Acute exacerbations are common, and often associated with infection. The changes occurring in the bronchi are described here.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="increased-size-and-number-of-mucus-glands">Increased size and number of mucus glands<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#increased-size-and-number-of-mucus-glands" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The increased volume of mucus may block small airways and overwhelm the ciliary escalator, leading to reduced clearance, a persistent cough and infection.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="oedema-and-other-inflammatory-changes">Oedema and other inflammatory changes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#oedema-and-other-inflammatory-changes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These cause swelling of the airway wall, narrowing the passageway and obstructing airflow.</p>
<p>Ciliated epithelium is progressively destroyed and replaced by a different type of epithelium with no cilia. This may precede neoplastic (cancerous) change. As ciliary efficiency is reduced, the problem of mucus accumulation is worsened, further increasing the risk of infection.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fibrosis-of-the-airways">Fibrosis of the airways<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fibrosis-of-the-airways" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Inflammatory changes lead to fibrosis and stiffening of airway walls, further reducing airflow.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="breathlessness-dyspnoea">Breathlessness (dyspnoea)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#breathlessness-dyspnoea" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is worse with physical exertion and increases the work of breathing.
Ventilation of the lungs becomes severely impaired, causing breathlessness and leading to hypoxia, pulmonary hypertension and right-sided heart failure. As respiratory failure develops, arterial blood PO 2 is reduced (hypoxaemia) and is accompanied by a rise in arterial blood PCO 2 (hypercapnia). When the condition becomes more severe, the respiratory centre in the medulla responds to hypoxaemia rather than to hypercapnia. In the later stages, the inflammatory changes begin to affect the smallest bronchioles and the alveoli themselves, and emphysema develops (see next section). The term chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is sometimes used to describe this situation.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="reduction-in-number-and-function-of-ciliated-cells">Reduction in number and function of ciliated cells<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reduction-in-number-and-function-of-ciliated-cells" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-854d171d.jpeg" alt="img-1.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 10.28 Emphysenna.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-f3790084.jpeg" alt="img-2.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 10.29 Coloured scanning electron micrograph of lung tissue with emphysema. (Dr Tony Britain/Science Photo Library. Reproduced with permission.)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="emphysema">Emphysema<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#emphysema" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>See Figs 10.28 and 10.29 .</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pulmonary-emphysema">Pulmonary emphysema<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pulmonary-emphysema" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Pulmonary emphysema, generally referred to simply as emphysema, usually develops as a result of long-term inflammatory conditions or irritation of the airways, e.g. in smokers or coal miners. Occasionally, it may be due to a genetic deficiency in the lung of an antiproteolytic enzyme, ai-antitrypsin. These conditions lead to progressive destruction of supporting elastic tissue in the lung, and the lungs progressively expand (barrel chest) because their ability to recoil is lost. In addition, there is irreversible distension of the respiratory bronchioles, alveolar ducts and alveoli, reducing the surface area for the exchange of gases.</p>
<p>On microscopic examination, the lung tissue is full of large, irregular cavities created by the destruction of alveolar walls (Fig. 10.29; compare with Fig. 10.19). There are two main types and both are usually present.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="panacinar-emphysema">Panacinar emphysema<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#panacinar-emphysema" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The walls between adjacent alveoli break down, the alveolar ducts dilate and interstitial elastic tissue is lost. The lungs become distended and their capacity is increased. As the volume of air in each breath remains unchanged, it constitutes a smaller proportion of the total volume of air in the distended alveoli, reducing the partial pressure of oxygen. This reduces the concentration gradient of O 2 across the alveolar membrane, decreasing diffusion of O 2 into the blood. Merging of alveoli reduces the surface area for exchange of gases. In the early stages of the disease, normal arterial blood O 2 and CO 2 levels are maintained at rest by hyperventilation. As the disease progresses, the combined effect of these changes may lead to hypoxia, pulmonary hypertension and eventually right-sided heart failure.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="centrilobular-emphysema">Centrilobular emphysema<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#centrilobular-emphysema" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In this form there is irreversible dilation of the respiratory bronchioles supplying lung lobules. When inspired air reaches the dilated area the pressure falls, leading to a reduction in alveolar air pressure, reduced ventilation efficiency and reduced partial pressure of oxygen. As the disease progresses, the resultant hypoxia leads to pulmonary hypertension and right-sided heart failure.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="interstitial-emphysema">Interstitial emphysema<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#interstitial-emphysema" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Interstitial emphysema means the presence of air in the thoracic interstitial tissues, and this may happen in one of the following ways:</p>
<ul>
<li>from the outside, by injury, e.g. fractured rib, stab wound</li>
<li>from the inside, when an alveolus ruptures through the pleura, e.g. during an asthmatic attack, in bronchiolitis, or coughing as in whooping cough.</li>
</ul>
<p>The air in the tissues usually tracks upwards to the soft tissues of the neck, where it is gradually absorbed, causing no damage. A large quantity in the mediastinum may, however, limit heart movement.</p>
<p>It is important to distinguish between interstitial emphysema and pneumothorax (p. 293), where the air is trapped between the pleura.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="asthma">Asthma<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#asthma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Asthma (Fig. 10.30) is a common inflammatory disease of the airways associated with episodes of reversible over-reactivity of the airway smooth muscle. The mucous
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-f6f97f20.jpeg" alt="img-3.jpeg"></p>
<p>Thickened
basement
membrane</p>
<p>Dilated blood vessel</p>
<p>Oedema</p>
<p>Smooth muscle</p>
<p>Blood vessel</p>
<p>A</p>
<p>Ciliated</p>
<p>Goblet cell
epithelium</p>
<p>Basement Thickened, membrane over-reactive
smooth muscle</p>
<p>Adventitia</p>
<p>Damaged
epithelium</p>
<p>Eosinophils</p>
<p>Inflammatory exudate</p>
<p>Inflammatory cells</p>
<p>Mucus plug
Figure 10.30 Cross-section of the airway wall in asthma. (A) Normal airway. (B) Asthmatic airway.
membrane and muscle layers of the bronchi and bronchioles become thickened and the mucous glands enlarge, reducing airflow in the lower respiratory tract. The walls swell and thicken with inflammatory exudate and an influx of inflammatory cells, especially eosinophils. During an asthmatic attack, spasmodic contraction of bronchiolar muscle (bronchospasm) constricts the airways and there is excessive secretion of thick, sticky mucus, which further narrows the airway. Only partial expiration is achieved, so the lungs become hyperinflated and there is severe dyspnoea and wheezing. The duration of attacks usually varies from a few minutes to hours. In severe acute attacks the bronchi may be obstructed by mucus plugs, blocking airflow and leading to acute respiratory failure, hypoxia and possibly death.</p>
<p>Non-specific factors that may precipitate asthma attacks include cold air, cigarette smoking, air pollution, upper respiratory tract infection, emotional stress and strenuous exercise.</p>
<p>There are two clinical categories of asthma, which generally give rise to identical symptoms and are treated in the same way. Important differences include typical age of onset and the contribution of an element of allergy. Asthma, whatever the aetiology, can usually be well controlled with inhaled anti-inflammatory and bronchodilator agents, enabling people to live a normal life.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="atopic-childhood-onset-extrinsic-asthma">Atopic (childhood-onset, extrinsic) asthma<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#atopic-childhood-onset-extrinsic-asthma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This occurs in children and young adults who have atopic (type I) hypersensitivity (p. 417) to foreign protein, e.g. pollen, dust containing mites from carpets, feather pillows.
animal dander or fungi. A history of infantile eczema or food allergies is common and there are often close family members with a history of allergy.</p>
<p>As in hay fever, antigens (allergens) are inhaled and absorbed by the bronchial mucosa. This stimulates the production of immunoglobulin E (IgE) antibodies, which bind to the surface of mast cells and basophils round the bronchial blood vessels. When the allergen is encountered again, the antigen/antibody reaction results in the release of histamine and other related substances that stimulate mucus secretion and muscle contraction, narrowing the airways. Attacks tend to become less frequent and less severe with age.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="non-atopic-adult-onset-intrinsic-asthma">Non-atopic (adult-onset, intrinsic) asthma<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#non-atopic-adult-onset-intrinsic-asthma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This type occurs later in adult life and there is no history of childhood allergic reactions. It can be associated with chronic inflammation of the upper respiratory tract, e.g. chronic bronchitis or nasal polyps. Other trigger factors include exercise and occupational exposure, e.g. inhaled paint fumes. Aspirin triggers an asthmatic reaction in some people. Attacks tend to increase in severity over time and lung damage may be irreversible. Eventually, impaired lung ventilation leads to hypoxia, pulmonary hypertension and right-sided heart failure.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="bronchiectasis">Bronchiectasis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bronchiectasis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is permanent abnormal dilation of bronchi and bronchioles. It is associated with chronic bacterial infection, and sometimes with a history of childhood bronchiolitis and bronchopneumonia, cystic fibrosis or bronchial tumour. The
bronchi become obstructed by mucus, pus and inflammatory exudate and the alveoli distal to the blockage collapse as trapped air is absorbed. Interstitial elastic tissue degenerates and is replaced by fibrous adhesions that attach the bronchi to the parietal pleura. The pressure of inspired air in these damaged bronchi leads to dilation proximal to the blockage. The persistent severe coughing to remove copious purulent sputum causes intermittent increases in pressure in the blocked bronchi, leading to further dilation.</p>
<p>The lower lobe of the lung is usually affected. Suppuration is common. If a blood vessel is eroded, haemoptysis may occur, or septicaemia, leading to abscess formation elsewhere in the body, commonly the brain. Progressive fibrosis of the lung leads to hypoxia, pulmonary hypertension and right-sided heart failure.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cystic-fibrosis-mucoviscidosis">Cystic fibrosis (mucoviscidosis)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cystic-fibrosis-mucoviscidosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is one of the most common hereditable diseases, affecting 1 in 2500 babies. It is estimated that almost <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>5</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">5 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">5%</span></span></span></span></span> of people carry the abnormal recessive gene, which must be present in both parents to cause the disease.</p>
<p>The secretions of all exocrine glands are abnormally thick because of chloride transport across the secretory epithelia, but the most severely affected are those of the lungs, pancreas, intestines, biliary tract, and the reproductive system in the male. Sweat glands secrete abnormally large amounts of salt during excessive sweating. In the pancreas, highly viscous mucus is secreted by the walls of the ducts and causes obstruction, parenchymal cell damage, the formation of cysts and defective enzyme secretion. In the newborn, intestinal obstruction may be caused by a plug of meconium (fetal faeces) and viscid mucus, leading to perforation of the alimentary canal wall and meconium peritonitis, which is often fatal. In less acute cases there may be impairment of protein and fat digestion, resulting in malabsorption, steatorrhoea and failure to thrive in infants. In older children, common consequences include:</p>
<ul>
<li>impaired digestion of food and absorption of nutrients</li>
<li>possible obstruction of bile ducts in the liver, causing cirrhosis</li>
<li>bronchitis, bronchiectasis and pneumonia.</li>
</ul>
<p>The lifespan of affected individuals is around 50 years. The main treatments offered are aimed at maintaining effective respiratory function and preventing infection. Chronic lung and heart disease are common complications.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-spot-check">I # SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol start="18">
<li>Why do blood carbon dioxide levels rise in obstructive airways disease?</li>
<li>What does the term 'interstitial emphysema' mean?</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="restrictive-disorders">Restrictive disorders<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#restrictive-disorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe the main pneumoconioses</li>
<li>outline the main causes and consequences of chemically induced lung disease.</li>
</ul>
<p>Restrictive lung disorders are characterised by increasing stiffness (low compliance) of lung tissue, making it harder to inflate the lung and increasing the work of breathing. Chronic restrictive disease is often associated with progressive fibrosis caused by repeated and ongoing inflammation of the lungs.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pneumoconioses">Pneumoconioses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pneumoconioses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This group of lung diseases is caused by prolonged exposure to inhaled organic dusts, which triggers a generalised inflammation and progressive fibrosis of lung tissues. Inhalation of work-related pollutants was a major cause of lung disease prior to the introduction of legislation that limits workers' exposure to them. To cause disease, particles must be so small that they are carried in inspired air to the level of the respiratory bronchioles and alveoli, where they can be cleared only by phagocytosis. Larger particles are trapped by mucus higher up the respiratory tract and expelled by ciliary action and coughing. The risk increases with the duration and concentration of exposure, and in cigarette smokers.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="coal-worker-s-pneumoconiosis">Coal worker's pneumoconiosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#coal-worker-s-pneumoconiosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Inhalation of coal dust over a prolonged period leads to varying degrees of respiratory impairment; many miners develop little or no disease but others suffer massive progressive fibrosis that is ultimately fatal. The inhaled dust collects in the lung and is phagocytosed by macrophages, which collect around airways and trigger varying degrees of fibrosis. If the fibrosis remains restricted to these small collections of macrophages and there is no significant reduction in lung function, the disorder is referred to as simple coal worker's pneumoconiosis, and is unlikely to progress once exposure to dust stops. For reasons that are unclear, the fibrotic changes in the lungs progress much more aggressively in some people, with formation of large, dense fibrotic nodules, destruction and cavitation of lung tissue, and potentially fatal respiratory impairment.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="silicosis">Silicosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#silicosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This may be caused by long-term exposure to dust containing silicon compounds. High-risk industries include quarrying.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="liasing-asbestos">Liasing asbestos<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#liasing-asbestos" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>mining of minerals, stone masonry, sand blasting, glass making and pottery production.</p>
<p>Inhaled silica particles accumulate in the alveoli and are ingested by macrophages, to which silica is toxic. The inflammatory reaction triggered when the macrophages die causes significant fibrosis.</p>
<p>Silicosis appears to predispose to the development of tuberculosis, which rapidly progresses to tubercular bronchopneumonia and possibly miliary tuberculosis. Gradual destruction of lung tissue leads to progressive reduction in pulmonary function, pulmonary hypertension and right-sided heart failure.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="asbestosis">Asbestosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#asbestosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Asbestosis, caused by inhaling asbestos fibres, usually develops after 10-20 years' exposure, but sometimes after only 2 years. Asbestos miners and workers involved in making and using some products containing asbestos are at risk. There are different types of asbestos but blue asbestos is associated with the most serious disease.</p>
<p>In spite of their large size, asbestos particles penetrate to the level of respiratory bronchioles and alveoli. Macrophages accumulate in the alveoli and ingest shorter fibres. The larger fibres form asbestos bodies, consisting of fibres surrounded by macrophages, protein material and iron deposits. Their presence in sputum indicates exposure to asbestos but not necessarily asbestosis. The macrophages that have engulfed fibres migrate out of the alveoli and accumulate around respiratory bronchioles and blood vessels, stimulating the formation of fibrous tissue. Lung tissue is progressively destroyed, with the development of dyspnoea, chronic hypoxia, pulmonary hypertension and right-sided heart failure. The link between inhaled asbestos and fibrosis is not clear. It may be that asbestos stimulates the macrophages to secrete enzymes that promote fibrosis or that it stimulates an immune reaction, causing fibrosis. Asbestos is linked to the development of mesothelioma (p. 292).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="extrinsic-allergic-alveolitis">Extrinsic allergic alveolitis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#extrinsic-allergic-alveolitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This group of conditions is caused by inhaling organic dusts, including those in Table 10.3. The contaminants act as antigens, causing a type III hypersensitivity reaction (p. 417) in the walls of the alveoli.</p>
<p>Table 10.3 Conditions caused by organic dusts</p>
<p>Disease</p>
<p>Farmer's lung</p>
<p>Bagassosis</p>
<p>Bird handler's lung</p>
<p>Malt worker's lung</p>
<p>Byssinosis</p>
<p>Contaminant</p>
<p>Mouldy hay</p>
<p>Mouldy sugar waste</p>
<p>Moulds in bird droppings</p>
<p>Mouldy barley</p>
<p>Cotton fibres</p>
<p>Initially, the allergy causes bronchiolitis, dyspnoea, cough, accumulation of inflammatory cells and formation of granulomas (collections of macrophages). If the exposure is brief the inflammatory response may resolve, but on repeated exposures pulmonary fibrosis develops.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pulmonary-toxins">Pulmonary toxins<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pulmonary-toxins" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Lung disease can be triggered by a range of toxins and drugs.
Paraquat
This weedkiller causes pulmonary oedema, irreversible pulmonary fibrosis and renal damage; ingestion can be fatal.</p>
<p>Drugs
The mechanism and severity of drug-induced pulmonary damage varies, depending on the drug and the general condition of the patient. Some drugs used to treat cancer, including bleomycin and methotrexate, can trigger progressive fibrotic changes. Other common drugs, including angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors (used in hypertension and other cardiovascular conditions), phenytoin (an anticonvulsant) and hydralazine (used in hypertension), can also have pulmonary side-effects.</p>
<p>High-concentration oxygen therapy
Premature babies may require oxygen treatment while their lung function matures, but the high concentrations used can cause permanent fibrotic damage to the lungs, as well as to the retina of the eye (p. 215). People of any age who require highconcentration oxygen therapy may also develop pulmonary fibrosis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5205029c">â–  SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5205029c" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol start="20">
<li>Why do asbestos fibres cause permanent lung</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="lung-infections">Lung infections<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lung-infections" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Learning outcome
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe the causes and effects of lung infection, including pneumonia, abscess and tuberculosis.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pneumonia">Pneumonia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pneumonia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Pneumonia (Fig. 10.31) means infection of the alveoli. This occurs when pulmonary defence mechanisms fail to prevent inhaled or blood-borne microbes reaching and colonising the lungs. Some predisposing factors are listed here.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-5e8c5678.jpeg" alt="img-4.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 10.31 Distribution of infected tissue. (A) Lobar pneumonia. (B) Bronchopneumonia.</p>
<p>Impaired coughing
Coughing is an effective cleaning mechanism, but if it is impaired or lost by, for example, damage to respiratory muscles or the nerves supplying them, or by painful coughing, then respiratory secretions may accumulate and become infected.</p>
<p>Damage to the epithelial lining of the tract
Ciliary action may be impaired or the epithelium destroyed by, for example, tobacco smoking, inhaling noxious gases or infection.</p>
<p>Impaired alveolar phagocytosis
Depressed macrophage activity may be caused by tobacco smoking, alcohol or anoxia.</p>
<p>Hospitalisation</p>
<p>Hospitalisation can be a predisposing factor, especially when mechanically assisted ventilation is required, partly because of exposure to a wide range of potentially antibioticresistant pathogenic organisms.</p>
<p>Other factors
The risk of pneumonia is increased in extremes of age, leukopenia, chronic disease (e.g. heart failure, cancer, chronic renal failure, alcoholism), suppression of immunity caused by, for example, ionising radiation, corticosteroid drugs and hypothermia.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="causative-organisms">Causative organisms<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#causative-organisms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A wide variety of organisms, including bacteria, viruses, mycoplasma, protozoa and fungi, can cause pneumonia under appropriate conditions. The most common pathogen, especially in lobar pneumonia, is the bacterium Streptococcus pneumoniae. Others include Staphylococcus aureus and Haemophilus influenzae. Legionella pneumophila spreads through water distribution systems, e.g. air conditioning systems, and is transmitted via droplet inhalation. Klebsiella pneumoniae and Pseudomonas aeruginosa are common causes of hospital-acquired pneumonia.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="lobar-pneumonia">Lobar pneumonia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lobar-pneumonia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is infection of one or more lobes (Fig. 10.31A), usually by Streptococcus pneumoniae, leading to production of watery inflammatory exudate in the alveoli. This accumulates and fills the lobule, which then overflows into and infects adjacent lobules. It is of sudden onset and pleuritic pain accompanies inflammation of the visceral pleura. If not treated with antibiotics the disease follows its course and resolves within 2-3 weeks. This form of pneumonia is most common in previously healthy young adults.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bronchopneumonia">Bronchopneumonia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bronchopneumonia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In bronchopneumonia (Fig. 10.31B), distribution of infection is patchy throughout the lung. Infection spreads from the bronchi to terminal bronchioles and alveoli. As these become inflamed, fibrous exudate accumulates and there is an influx of leukocytes. Small foci of consolidation (fluid-filled alveoli) develop. There is frequently incomplete resolution with fibrosis. Bronchiectasis is a common complication, leading to further acute attacks, lung fibrosis and progressive destruction of lung substance. Bronchopneumonia occurs most commonly in infancy and old age, and death is fairly common, especially when the condition complicates debilitating diseases. Predisposing factors include:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>debility due to, for example, cancer, uraemia, cerebral haemorrhage, congestive heart failure, malnutrition, hypothermia</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>lung disease, e.g. bronchiectasis, cystic fibrosis or acute viral infection</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>general anaesthesia, which depresses respiratory and ciliary activity</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>inhalation of gastric contents (aspiration pneumonia) in, for example, unconsciousness or very deep sleep, or following excessive alcohol consumption or drug overdose</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>inhalation of infected material from the paranasal sinuses or upper respiratory tract.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="lung-abscess">Lung abscess<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lung-abscess" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is localised suppuration and necrosis within the lung substance. The abscess may develop from local infection:</p>
<ul>
<li>if pneumonia is inadequately treated</li>
<li>as a result of trauma, e.g. rib fracture, stab wound or surgery</li>
<li>when this affects adjacent structures, e.g. oesophagus, spine or pleural cavity, or there is a subphrenic abscess.</li>
</ul>
<p>Occasionally, this develops when infected material travelling in the bloodstream, a septic embolus, arrives and lodges in the lung. Such material usually originates from a thrombophlebitis (p. 127) or infective endocarditis (p. 133).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="outcomes">Outcomes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Recovery from lung abscess may either be complete or lead to complications, such as:</p>
<ul>
<li>chronic suppuration</li>
<li>septic emboli spreading to other parts of the body, e.g. the brain, causing cerebral abscess or meningitis</li>
<li>subpleural abscesses spreading and causing empyema and, in some cases, a bronchopleural fistula</li>
<li>erosion of a pulmonary blood vessel, leading to haemorrhage.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="tuberculosis">Tuberculosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tuberculosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Tuberculosis (TB) is a major health problem worldwide, particularly in low-income countries that cannot afford effective prevention or treatment, and in countries where HIV infection is common. It is caused by one of two similar forms of mycobacteria, the main one being Mycohacterium tuberculosis. Humans are the main host. The microbes are spread by inhalation, either by aerosol droplet infection from an individual with active tuberculosis, or in dust contaminated by infected sputum.</p>
<p>TB is less common in developed countries because of pasteurisation of milk, but can be caused by Mycohacterium hovis, from cows.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pulmonary-tuberculosis">Pulmonary tuberculosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pulmonary-tuberculosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="primary-tuberculosis">Primary tuberculosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#primary-tuberculosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Initial infection usually involves the apex of the lung. Inflammatory cells, including macrophages and lymphocytes, are recruited in defence, sealing off the infected lesions in Ghon foci. The centres of Ghon foci are filled with a cheese-like necrotic material that may contain significant numbers of active bacteria that have survived inside macrophages. If infection spreads to the regional lymph
nodes, the Ghon foci and these infected nodes together are called the primary complex. At this stage, the disease is likely to have caused few, if any, clinical symptoms and in the great majority of people progresses no further, although calcified primary complexes are clearly identifiable on X-ray. Exposure to the bacterium causes sensitisation, which leads to a strong T-cell-mediated immune reaction (p. 412) if the infection becomes reactivated.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="secondary-tuberculosis">Secondary tuberculosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#secondary-tuberculosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is usually due to reactivation of disease from latent bacteria surviving primary TB , and can occur decades after the initial exposure in response to factors such as stress, ageing, immunocompromise or malnutrition. The infection is now much more likely to progress than it was at the primary stage, with significant destruction and cavitation of lung tissues. Symptoms include fever, cough, malaise, haemoptysis, weight loss and night sweats. Nearly half of patients with secondary TB develop non-pulmonary involvement.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="non-pulmonary-tuberculosis">Non-pulmonary tuberculosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#non-pulmonary-tuberculosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Primary TB rarely affects tissues other than the lung but non-pulmonary involvement in secondary TB is very common. Widely disseminated TB is nearly always fatal unless adequately treated.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="miliary-tuberculosis">Miliary tuberculosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#miliary-tuberculosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Blood-borne spread from the lungs leads to widespread dissemination of the bacilli throughout body tissues, and foci of infection can establish in any organ, including the bone marrow, liver, spleen, kidneys and central nervous system. Numerous tiny nodules develop in the lungs, which on X-ray look like sprinkled millet seeds (hence 'miliary'). Rapid treatment is essential to prevent further spread.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="lymph-node-tuberculosis">Lymph node tuberculosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lymph-node-tuberculosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is the second most common site of infection after the lung. Lymph nodes in the mediastinum, neck, axilla and groin are most likely to be affected. Infection causes swelling and central necrosis of the node. It is usually painless.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="joint-and-bone-tuberculosis">Joint and bone tuberculosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#joint-and-bone-tuberculosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The intervertebral, hip and knee joints are most commonly affected, and in children this is usually a consequence of primary TB. Infection of the intervertebral disc or synovial membrane of a synovial joint is followed by extensive destruction of cartilage and adjacent bone, which in turn can progress to tuberculous osteomyelitis.</p>
<p>The pericardium, skin and gastrointestinal tract may all become involved. One in five people with extrapulmonary</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="other-affected-tissues">other affected tissues<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#other-affected-tissues" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>disease develop central nervous system infection, which requires urgent treatment; if it is not fatal, it can leave survivors with permanent neurological damage.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="95c381b4">) <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>â‹…</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\cdot</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4445em;"></span><span class="mord">â‹…</span></span></span></span></span> SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#95c381b4" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol start="21">
<li>What is the difference between lobar pneumonia and bronchopneumonia?</li>
<li>What is secondary tuberculosis?</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="lung-tumours">Lung tumours<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lung-tumours" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Learning outcome
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe the pathology of the common lung tumours.</li>
</ul>
<p>Benign tumours of the lung are rare.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="bronchial-carcinoma">Bronchial carcinoma<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bronchial-carcinoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Primary bronchial carcinoma is a very common malignancy. The vast majority of cases (up to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>90</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">90 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">90%</span></span></span></span></span> ) occur in smokers or those who inhale other people's smoke (passive smokers). Other risk factors include exposure to airborne dusts and the presence of lung fibrosis. The primary tumour has usually spread by the time of diagnosis, and therefore the prognosis of this type of cancer is usually extremely poor.</p>
<p>The tumour usually develops in a main bronchus, forming a large friable mass projecting into the lumen, sometimes causing obstruction. Mucus then collects and predisposes to infection. As the tumour grows, it may erode a blood vessel, causing haemoptysis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="spread-of-bronchial-carcinoma">Spread of bronchial carcinoma<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spread-of-bronchial-carcinoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This does not follow any particular pattern or sequence. Spread is by infiltration of local tissues and the transport of tumour fragments in blood and lymph. If blood or lymph vessels are eroded, fragments may spread while the tumour is still quite small. A metastatic tumour may, therefore, cause symptoms before the primary in the lung has been detected.</p>
<p>Local spread
This may be within the lung or to mediastinal structures, e.g. blood vessels, nerves and oesophagus.</p>
<p>Lymphatic spread
Tumour fragments spread along lymph vessels to successive lymph nodes, in which they may cause metastatic tumours. Fragments may enter lymph draining from a tumour or gain access to a larger vessel if its walls have been eroded by a growing tumour.</p>
<p>Blood spread
Tumour cells can enter the blood if a blood vessel is eroded by a growing tumour. The most common sites of blood-borne metastases are the liver, brain, adrenal glands, bones and kidneys.</p>
