<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pleural-mesothelioma">Pleural mesothelioma<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pleural-mesothelioma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This malignant tumour of the pleura is usually associated with previous exposure to asbestos dust, e.g. asbestos workers and people living near asbestos mines and factories. Smoking multiplies the risk of mesothelioma several-fold in people exposed to asbestos. Mesothelioma may develop after a widely varying duration of asbestos exposure, from 3 months to 60 years, and is usually associated with crocidolite fibres (blue asbestos). The tumour involves both layers of pleura and, as it grows, it obliterates the pleural cavity, compressing the lung. Lymph- and bloodspread metastases are commonly found in the hilar and mesenteric lymph nodes, the other lung, liver, thyroid and adrenal glands, bone, skeletal muscle and the brain. The prognosis is usually very poor.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-spot-check">I # SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol start="23">
<li>Where is the most common site for the development of primary bronchial carcinoma?</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="lung-collapse">Lung collapse<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lung-collapse" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>list the main causes of lung collapse</li>
<li>describe the effects of lung collapse.</li>
</ul>
<p>The clinical effects of collapse (atelectasis) of all or part of a lung (Fig. 10.32) depend on how much of the lung is affected. Fairly large sections of a single lung can be out of action without obvious symptoms. There are four main causes of this condition:</p>
<ul>
<li>obstruction of an airway (absorption collapse)</li>
<li>impaired surfactant function</li>
<li>pressure collapse</li>
<li>alveolar hypoventilation.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="obstruction-of-an-airway-absorption-collapse">Obstruction of an airway (absorption collapse)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#obstruction-of-an-airway-absorption-collapse" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The amount of lung affected depends on the size of the obstructed air passage. Distal to the obstruction, air is trapped and absorbed, the lung collapses and secretions collect</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-4559c01b.jpeg" alt="img-5.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 10.32 Collapse of a lung. (A) Absorption collapse. (B) Pressure collapse.
(Fig. 10.32A). These may cause infection and sometimes abscess formation. Shortterm obstruction is usually followed by reinflation of the lung without lasting illeffects. Prolonged obstruction leads to progressive fibrosis and permanent collapse. Sudden obstruction may be due to inhalation of a foreign body (usually into the (right) primary bronchus, which is wider and more steeply angled than the left) or to a mucus plug formed during an asthmatic attack or in chronic bronchitis. Gradual obstruction may be due to a bronchial tumour or pressure on a bronchus by, for example, enlarged mediastinal lymph nodes or aortic aneurysm.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="impaired-surfactant-function">Impaired surfactant function<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#impaired-surfactant-function" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Premature babies, born before the 34th week, may be unable to expand their lungs by their own respiratory effort because their lungs are too immature to produce surfactant (p. 274). These babies may need to be mechanically ventilated until their lungs begin to produce surfactant. This is called neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS).</p>
<p>In acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), dilution of surfactant by fluid collecting in the alveoli (pulmonary
oedema) leads to atelectasis. These patients are nearly always gravely ill already, and collapse of substantial areas of lung contributes to the mortality rate of around one-third.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pressure-collapse">Pressure collapse<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pressure-collapse" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>When air or fluid enters the pleural cavity, the negative pressure becomes positive, preventing lung expansion. Fluids settle in the lung bases, whereas collections of</p>
<p>air are usually found towards the lung apex (Fig. 10.32B). The collapse usually affects only one lung and may be partial or complete. There is no obstruction of the airway.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pneumothorax">Pneumothorax<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pneumothorax" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>In this condition there is air in the pleural cavity. It may occur spontaneously or be the result of trauma.</p>
<p>Spontaneous pneumothorax
This may be either primary or secondary. Primary spontaneous pneumothorax is of unknown cause, is often recurrent, and occurs in fit and healthy people, usually males between 20 and 40 years of age. Secondary spontaneous pneumothorax occurs when air enters the pleural cavity after the visceral pleura ruptures due to lung disease, e.g. emphysema, asthma, pulmonary tuberculosis or bronchial cancer.</p>
<p>Traumatic pneumothorax
This is due to a penetrating injury that breaches the pleura, e.g. a compound fracture of a rib, stab or gunshot wound, or surgery.</p>
<p>Tension pneumothorax
Tension pneumothorax (Fig. 10.33) occurs as a complication when a flap or oneway valve develops between the lungs and the pleural cavity. Air enters the pleural cavity during inspiration but cannot escape on expiration and steadily, sometimes rapidly, accumulates. This expansion of the affected lung pushes the mediastinum towards the unaffected side, compressing its contents, including the unaffected lung and great vessels. Without prompt treatment, severe respiratory distress precedes cardiovascular collapse.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="haemothorax">Haemothorax<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#haemothorax" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is blood in the pleural cavity. It may be caused by a penetrating chest injury involving blood vessels, a ruptured aortic aneurysm or erosion of a blood vessel by a malignant tumour.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pleural-effusion">Pleural effusion<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pleural-effusion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is excess fluid in the pleural cavity. It may be caused by:</p>
<ul>
<li>increased hydrostatic pressure, e.g. heart failure (p. 131), increased blood volume</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="section-3-intake-of-raw-materials-and-elimination-of-waste">SECTION 3 Intake of raw materials and elimination of waste<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#section-3-intake-of-raw-materials-and-elimination-of-waste" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-3542ebb4.jpeg" alt="img-6.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="parietal-pleura">Parietal pleura<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#parietal-pleura" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Breach in visceral pleura
t
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-19a5f2a8.jpeg" alt="img-7.jpeg"></p>
<p>Tissue flap sealing breach
Visceral pleura
Accumulating air in pleural space
Parietal pleura
A Inhalation. Air is sucked into the
pleural space through the breach in the visceral pleura
Airflow
Mediastinal shift
Exhalation. Air trapped in the pleural space cannot return to the affected alveoli because the breach is sealed by the tissue flap acting as a one-way valve</p>
<p>Figure 10.33 Tension pneumothorax. (A) Inhalation. (B) Exhalation.</p>
<ul>
<li>increased capillary permeability due to local inflammation, e.g. lobar pneumonia, pulmonary TB, bronchial cancer, mesothelioma</li>
<li>decreased plasma osmotic pressure, e.g. nephrotic syndrome (p. 384), liver cirrhosis (p.363)</li>
<li>impaired lymphatic drainage, e.g. malignant tumour involving the pleura.</li>
</ul>
<p>Following haemothorax and pleural effusion, fibrous adhesions that limit reinflation may form between the layers of pleura.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="alveolar-hypoventilation">Alveolar hypoventilation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#alveolar-hypoventilation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>In the normal individual breathing quietly at rest, there are always some collapsed lobules within the lungs because of the low tidal volume. These lobules re-expand without difficulty at the next deep inspiration. Non-physiological causes of hypoventilation collapse include postoperative collapse, particularly after chest and upper abdominal surgery, when pain restricts thoracic expansion. This predisposes to chest infections because mucus collects in the under-ventilated airways and is not coughed up.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-spot-check">I # SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol start="24">
<li>Why does prematurity increase the risk of respiratory difficulty at birth?</li>
<li>What is traumatic pneumothorax?</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="review-and-revise">Review and revise<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#review-and-revise" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="1">1<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="introduction-to-nutrition">Introduction to nutrition<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction-to-nutrition" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The balanced diet 297
Nutrients 300
Carbohydrates 300
Proteins 301
Fats 301
Vitamins 302
Minerals, trace elements and water 304
Non-starch polysaccharide 305
Ageing and nutrition 306
Nutritional disorders in older adults 306
Disorders of nutrition 307
Protein-energy malnutrition 307
Malabsorption 307
Obesity 307
Conditions with dietary implications 308
References and further reading 309
Review and revise 309
Before exploring the digestive system and its functions in Chapter 12, it is useful to understand the body's nutritional needs. The importance of a balanced diet to good health is increasingly recognised, as this provides the correct amounts of nutrients; counteracts the increasing prevalence of obesity; and reduces the risk of other</p>
<p>significant conditions, such as cardiovascular disease and some cancers, as well as conferring many health benefits.</p>
<p>Food provides nutrients, some of which are broken down to provide energy while others are needed for growth, repair and other cellular activities. The main nutrient groups are:</p>
<ul>
<li>carbohydrates</li>
<li>proteins</li>
<li>fats</li>
<li>vitamins</li>
<li>mineral salts, trace elements and water.</li>
</ul>
<p>Food usually contains a combination of nutrients; for example, potatoes and bread are mainly carbohydrate but both also contain protein and some vitamins. Dietary fibre, more correctly known as non-starch polysaccharide (NSP), consists of indigestible material. Although it is not a nutrient, as it is neither a source of energy nor essential for cellular metabolism, NSP is an important dietary constituent that has many beneficial effects on the body.</p>
<p>A balanced diet is essential for health and provides appropriate amounts of all nutrients in the correct proportions to meet body requirements. An essential nutrient is a substance that cannot be made by the body and, for the maintenance of health, must therefore be eaten in the diet.</p>
<p>The first parts of this chapter explore the balanced diet and its constituents. The impact of healthy eating during early and middle life on the health of older adults is then explored, as many health problems arise as the result of poor diet. In developed countries obesity is increasingly common, while in other countries malnutrition is widespread. The final section considers some consequences of poor nutrition.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-balanced-diet">The balanced diet<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-balanced-diet" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>list the constituent food groups of a balanced diet</li>
<li>calculate body mass index from an individual's weight and height.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="chapter">CHAPTER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chapter" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Box 11.1 Body mass index (WHO, 2017a)
Calculation of BMI
Body mass index <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">M</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">I</mi></mrow><mo>=</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">=\mathrm{BMI}=</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">BMI</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span></span></span></span></span>
Weight <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(\mathrm{kg})</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">kg</span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> Height <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo fence="true">(</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">âˆ§</mo></msup><mo fence="true">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\left(\mathrm{m}^{\wedge}\right)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0019em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">m</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7519em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">âˆ§</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">)</span></span></span></span></span></span>
Table captionInternational classification of BMI</p>
<p>BMI Nutritional status
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&lt;</mo><mn>18.5</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&lt;18.5</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&lt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">18.5</span></span></span></span></span> Underweight
18.5-24.9 Normal weight
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo><mn>25.0</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;25.0</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">25.0</span></span></span></span></span> Overweight
25.0-29.9 Pre-obese
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo><mn>30</mn><mspace width="1em"></mspace></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;30 \quad</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">30</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 1em;"></span></span></span></span></span> Obese
30.0-34.9 Obese class I
35.0-39.9 Obese class II
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo><mn>40</mn><mspace width="1em"></mspace></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;40 \quad</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">40</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 1em;"></span></span></span></span></span> Obese class III</p>
<p>A balanced diet contains appropriate proportions of all the nutrients required for health. This is normally achieved by eating a variety of foods because no single food, with the exception of breast milk, contains the correct proportions of the essential nutrients. If any nutrient is eaten in excess or is deficient, health may be adversely affected. For example, a high-energy diet can lead to obesity, and an iron-deficient one to anaemia.</p>
<p>A balanced diet is highly important in maintaining a healthy body weight, which can be assessed by calculating body mass index (BMI; Box 11.1).</p>
<p>Healthy eating, i.e. eating a balanced diet, requires knowledge and planning. An important dietary consideration is the amount of energy required, which should meet individual requirements. Daily energy requirements depend on several factors, including metabolic rate (p. 342), age, gender and activity levels. For healthy adults, the recommended average daily energy intake is:</p>
<ul>
<li>women: <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>2000</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>8400</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">j</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2000 \mathrm{kcal}=8400 \mathrm{kj}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">2000</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">kcal</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">8400</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">kj</span></span></span></span></span></span></li>
<li>men: <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>2500</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mn>500</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">J</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2500 \mathrm{kcal}=10,500 \mathrm{~kJ}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">2500</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">kcal</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">10</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">500</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">kJ</span></span></span></span></span></span>.</li>
</ul>
<p>Dietary carbohydrates, fats and proteins are the principal energy sources and fat is the most concentrated form. Dietary energy is correctly expressed in joules or kilojoules (kJ), although the older terms calories and kilocalories (kcal or Cal) are also still used in the UK.</p>
<p>This section is based on the recommendations of the British Nutrition Foundation (2016a, 2016b, 2016c). Recommendations for daily food intake sort foods of similar origins and nutritional values into food groups, and advise that from the age of 2 years a certain proportion from each group should be eaten daily (Fig. 11.1). If this plan is followed, the resulting dietary intake is likely to be well balanced. The five food groups are:</p>
<ul>
<li>fruit and vegetables</li>
<li>potatoes, bread, rice, pasta and other starchy carbohydrates</li>
<li>dairy and dairy alternatives</li>
<li>beans, pulses, fish, eggs, meat and other proteins</li>
<li>oils and spreads.</li>
</ul>
<p>A sixth group is shown in the bottom left-hand corner of Fig. 11.1. These foods should be eaten less often and only in small amounts because they are high in saturated fat, salt and sugar; they are not needed as part of a healthy diet.</p>
<p>The first two groups just listed should form most of the diet, with the other groups forming the remainder.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="fruit-and-vegetables">Fruit and vegetables<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fruit-and-vegetables" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>At least five portions per day are recommended; fruit and vegetables should make up around a third of the diet. This group includes fresh, frozen and canned products, and provides carbohydrate, fibre, vitamins A and C, and folic acid.</p>
<p>Unsweetened 100% fruit or vegetable juice and smoothies ( 150 mL ) count as only one of the 'five a day', irrespective of how much is taken (Box 11.2).</p>
<p>Potatoes, bread, rice, pasta and other starchy carbohydrates
The British Nutrition Foundation recommends that this group should make up about one-third of the diet and that each meal should be based around one food from this group. Potatoes, yams and plantains are classified as 'starchy carbohydrates' and are, therefore, considered within this group rather than as fruit and vegetables. Other foods in this group include breakfast cereals, rice and noodles. These foods are sources of carbohydrate and fibre that provide sustained energy release. Some also contain iron and B-group vitamins, including folic acid (p. 304).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="dairy-and-dairy-alternatives">Dairy and dairy alternatives<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#dairy-and-dairy-alternatives" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Foods in this group provide protein and minerals, including calcium, iodine and zinc; some are also a source of vitamins A, B 2 and B 12 . They include milk, cheese, fromage frais and yoghurt, and often contain considerable amounts of fat. Intake should therefore be limited to three servings per day and options with less fat and sugar considered. When dairy alternatives are used, e.g. in cases of cows' milk allergy or lactose intolerance, unsweetened calcium-fortified products are recommended (Box 11.3).</p>
<p>Box 11.2 'Five a day': 80 g portion equivalents
1 piece of medium fruit, e.g. apple, orange, banana
3 tablespoons of cooked vegetables
1 bowl of mixed salad
150 mL of fruit juice or fruit smoothie
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-0dd7ecc9.jpeg" alt="img-8.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="eatwell-guide">Eatwell Guide<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#eatwell-guide" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

Figure 11.1 The eatwell guide. The main food groups and their recommended proportions within a balanced diet. (Public Health England in association with the Welsh Government, Food Standards Scotland and the Food Standards Agency in Northern Ireland. (C Crown copyright 2016. Reproduced with permission.)</p>
<p>Box 11.3 Dairy and dairy alternatives: 1 serving
200 mL milk 150 g yoghurt 30 g cheese</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="beans-pulses-fish-eggs-meat-and-other-proteins">Beans, pulses, fish, eggs, meat and other proteins<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#beans-pulses-fish-eggs-meat-and-other-proteins" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In addition to the food shown in Fig. 11.1, this group includes processed meat products such as bacon, sausages, beefburgers, salami and pate. Intake of red and processed meat should not exceed 70 g per day. Moderate amounts are recommended because many have a high fat content. It is suggested that fish, including one portion of oily fish such as salmon, trout, sardines or fresh tuna, is eaten twice weekly. This food group provides protein, iron, vitamins B and D, and sometimes minerals. Vegetarian alternatives include tofu, nuts, beans and pulses, e.g. lentils. Beans and
pulses are also a good source of fibre, although only one 80 g portion counts as one of the 'five a day'.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="oils-and-spreads">Oils and spreads<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#oils-and-spreads" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Dietary fat is an essential part of the diet, as it provides the essential fatty acids and enables absorption of the fat-soluble vitamins. As fats are high in energy, only small amounts are required. Fats are classified as saturated or unsaturated and the differences are explained on page 301; unsaturated products, which generally come from plants, are the recommended option.</p>
<p>Items in this group should be eaten only sparingly. They are not required in the diet and can have adverse health consequences, as they are high in energy and have little additional nutritional value; low-salt and low-fat/sugar alternatives are recommended. Examples include sugar and sugary soft drinks, syrup, chocolate and sweets, cakes, biscuits, ice cream and savoury snacks, e.g. crisps. Fried food, including chips, and mayonnaise, butter and ghee are also included in this group.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="eatwell-guide">Eatwell Guide<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#eatwell-guide" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-72972270.jpeg" alt="img-9.jpeg"></p>
<p>Box 11.4 Equivalents of 1 unit of alcohol
125 mL (small glass) of wine
300 mL (half-pint) of standard-strength beer, lager or cider
25 mL of spirits</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="additional-recommendations">Additional recommendations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#additional-recommendations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The British Nutrition Foundation makes other specific recommendations about salt (p. 304) and fluid intake (1.5-2 litres per day). This includes water, tea, coffee, squash and fruit juice. Alcohol intake should not exceed 3-4 units per day for men and 2-3 units per day for women (Box 11.4).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="groups-of-people-with-specific-dietary-requirements">Groups of people with specific dietary requirements<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#groups-of-people-with-specific-dietary-requirements" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Certain groups of people require a diet different from the principles outlined above. For example, pregnant and lactating women have higher energy requirements to support the growing baby and milk production. Menstruating women need more iron in their diet than non-menstruating women to compensate for blood loss during menstruation. Babies and growing children have higher energy requirements than adults because they have relatively higher growth and metabolic rates. In some gastrointestinal disorders, e.g. coeliac disease (p. 360), there is intolerance of certain foods, which restricts dietary choices.</p>
<p>Digestion, absorption and use of nutrients are explained in Chapter 12. Structures of carbohydrates, proteins and fats are described in Chapter 2.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="5205029c">â–  SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5205029c" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>What are the recommended daily energy intakes for healthy adults?</li>
<li>List the nutrient groups found in a balanced diet.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="nutrients">Nutrients<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nutrients" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe the functions of dietary carbohydrate, protein and fat</li>
<li>outline the sources and functions of fat- and watersoluble vitamins</li>
<li>outline the sources and functions of minerals, trace elements and water.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="carbohydrates">Carbohydrates<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#carbohydrates" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Carbohydrates are mainly sugars and starches, which are found in a wide variety of foods, e.g. sugar, jam, cereals, bread, biscuits, pasta, convenience foods, fruit and vegetables. Chemically, they consist of carbon, hydrogen and oxygen, the hydrogen and oxygen being in the same proportion as in water (Ch. 2). Carbohydrates are classified according to the complexity of the chemical substances from which they are formed:</p>
<ul>
<li>monosaccharides, e.g. glucose (see Fig. 2.7)</li>
<li>disaccharides, e.g. sucrose (see Fig. 2.7)</li>
<li>polysaccharides, complex molecules built from large numbers of monosaccharides, some of which are digestible, e.g. glycogen, while others are not, e.g. NSP (p. 322).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="glycaemic-index">Glycaemic index<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#glycaemic-index" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The type of carbohydrate eaten is important in a healthy diet. The rate of carbohydrate absorption from the alimentary tract depends on the complexity of carbohydrate structure. Monosaccharides such as glucose are quickly absorbed and cause blood glucose levels to rise sharply. Foods high in glucose and other monosaccharides therefore rapidly increase blood glucose levels and are said to have a high glycaemic index (GI). They tend not to satisfy hunger for long because the rapid rise in blood glucose stimulates insulin secretion, which in turn reduces blood glucose levels. More complex carbohydrates such as starches require</p>
<p>digestion before absorption, and so cause a slower and more sustained rise in blood glucose levels. They are referred to as low-GI foodstuffs and include unprocessed wholegrain and high-fibre foods. They satisfy hunger for longer because they release carbohydrates over a more extended period. Low-GI foods are important in weight control and in managing diabetes mellitus.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="functions-of-digestible-carbohydrates">Functions of digestible carbohydrates<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions-of-digestible-carbohydrates" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Provision of energy and heat: the breakdown of monosaccharides, preferably in the presence of oxygen, releases heat and chemical energy for metabolic work. Glucose is the main fuel molecule used by body cells.</li>
<li>'Protein sparing': when there is adequate carbohydrate in the diet, protein does not need to be used to provide energy and heat, and is used for its main purpose namely, building new and replacement body proteins.</li>
<li>Provision of energy stores when carbohydrate is eaten in excess of the body's needs as it is converted to:</li>
<li>glycogen - as a short-term energy store in the liver and skeletal muscles (p. 129)</li>
<li>fat - stored in adipose tissue, e.g. under the skin.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="learning-outcomes">Learning outcomes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#learning-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="proteins">Proteins<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#proteins" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>During digestion, proteins are broken down into their constituent amino acids and it is in this form that they are absorbed into the bloodstream. A constant supply of amino acids is needed to build new proteins, e.g. structural proteins, enzymes and some hormones.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="amino-acids">Amino acids<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#amino-acids" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Amino acids (see Fig. 2.8) are composed of the elements carbon, hydrogen, oxygen and nitrogen. Some contain minerals such as iron, copper, zinc, iodine, sulphur and phosphate. Amino acids are divided into two categories: essential and nonessential.</p>
<p>Essential amino acids cannot be synthesised in the body and therefore they must be included in the diet. Non-essential amino acids are those that can be synthesised in the body. The essential and non-essential amino acids are shown in Box 11.5.</p>
<p>Nitrogen balance</p>
<p>Excess amino acids are broken down. The amino group ( NH 2 ) is converted to the nitrogenous waste product urea</p>
<p>Box 11.5 Essential and non-essential amino acids
Essential amino acids
Histidine (in infants only)
Isoleucine
Leucine
Lysine
Methionine
Phenylalanine
Threonine
Tryptophan
Valine
Non-essential amino acids
Alanine
Arginine
Asparagine
Aspartic acid
Cysteine
Cystine
Glutamic acid
Glutamine
Glycine
Hydroxyproline
Proline</p>
<p>Serine</p>
<p>Tyrosine
and excreted by the kidneys. The remainder of the molecule is converted to either glucose or a ketone body (see ketosis, p. 129), depending on the amino acid. Negative nitrogen balance occurs when amino acid supply does not meet body needs. This situation may arise either when dietary protein intake is inadequate, e.g. deficiency or absence of amino acids, or protein requirement is increased, e.g. during growth spurts and following injury or surgery.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="biological-value-of-protein">Biological value of protein<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#biological-value-of-protein" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The nutritional value of a protein, its biological value, is determined by how well it meets the nutritional needs of the body. Protein of high biological value is usually of animal origin; it is easily digested and contains all the essential amino acids in the proportions required by the body.</p>
<p>A balanced diet, containing all the amino acids required, may also be achieved by eating a range of foods containing proteins of lower biological values, provided that deficiencies in amino acid content of any one of the constituent proteins is supplied by another. A vegetarian diet contains proteins with lower biological values, e.g. from vegetables, cereals and pulses. When proteins from different plant sources are combined, they complement each other, providing higher biological values than a single plant source. Through this complementary action the biological value of vegetarian diets can be similar to those based on animal protein.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="functions-of-proteins">Functions of proteins<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions-of-proteins" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Amino acids are used for:</p>
<ul>
<li>growth and repair of body cells and tissues</li>
<li>synthesis of enzymes, plasma proteins, antibodies (immunoglobulins) and some hormones</li>
<li>provision of energy - normally a secondary function, this becomes important only when there is not enough carbohydrate in the diet and fat stores are depleted.</li>
</ul>
<p>When protein is eaten in excess of the body's needs, the nitrogenous amino group is detached, i.e. it is deaminated, and excreted by the kidneys (p. 345). The remainder is converted to fat for storage in the fat depots, e.g. in the fat cells of adipose tissue (p. 51).</p>
<p>Fats</p>
<p>Fats consist of carbon, hydrogen and oxygen, but they differ from carbohydrates in that the hydrogen and oxygen are not in the same proportions as in water. There are several groups of fats and lipids that are important in nutrition.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="fats-triglycerides">Fats (triglycerides)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fats-triglycerides" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Commonly known as 'fat', a triglyceride molecule consists of three fatty acids linked to a glycerol molecule (see Fig. 2.9). Depending on the type and relative amounts of fatty acids they contain, fats are classified as saturated or unsaturated.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-9991f0b8.jpeg" alt="img-10.jpeg"></p>
<p>In general, saturated fats are solid at room temperature and originate from animal sources, while unsaturated fats are oils, usually derived from vegetables or plants. A high intake of saturated fat can predispose to coronary heart disease (Ch. 5).</p>
<p>Linoleic, linolenic and arachidonic acids are essential fatty acids, which cannot be synthesised by the body in significant amounts but are needed for synthesis of prostaglandins, phospholipids and leukotrienes. These fatty acids are found in oily fish.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cholesterol">Cholesterol<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cholesterol" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Unlike other lipids, whose molecules are composed of chains of atoms, this molecule contains four rings, which give it the characteristic steroid structure. It can be synthesised by the body (around 20%), with the remainder coming from saturated fats in the diet as a constituent of full-fat dairy products, fatty meat and egg yolk. Cholesterol is needed for synthesis of steroid hormones, e.g. glucocorticoids and mineralocorticoids (Ch. 9), and is an important constituent of cell membranes.</p>
<p>Cholesterol is transported in the blood combined with proteins, forming lipoproteins. Two examples are:</p>
<ul>
<li>Low-density lipoprotein (LDL): this carries cholesterol from the liver to the body cells. Excessive blood LDL levels are harmful to health, as LDL can build up
in arterial walls, leading to atherosclerosis. LDL is sometimes known as 'bad cholesterol'.</li>
<li>High-density lipoprotein (HDL): this carries cholesterol back from body cells to the liver, where it is either broken down or excreted. This may be referred to
as 'good cholesterol' and raised HDL levels are cardioprotective.
High blood cholesterol levels are associated with an increased risk of atherosclerosis (p. 125), hypertension (high blood pressure, p. 136) and diabetes mellitus (p. 255).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="functions-of-fats">Functions of fats<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions-of-fats" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These include:</p>
<ul>
<li>a concentrated source of chemical energy and heat</li>
<li>support of some organs, e.g. the kidneys, the eyes</li>
<li>absorption, transport and storage of the fat-soluble vitamins: A, D, E and K</li>
<li>a constituent of myelin sheaths (p. 156) and of sebum
(p. 396)</li>
<li>formation of steroid hormones from cholesterol</li>
<li>an energy store in adipose tissue under the skin and in the mesentery</li>
<li>insulation - as a subcutaneous layer it reduces heat loss through the skin</li>
<li>satiety value - the emptying time of the stomach is prolonged after eating food that is high in fat, postponing the return of hunger.</li>
</ul>
<p>As the body stores excess fat, it is important not to eat too much, as this will lead to weight gain and becoming overweight or obese (p.306).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vitamins">Vitamins<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vitamins" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Vitamins are chemicals required in very small quantities for essential metabolic processes. As most cannot be made by the body, they are an essential part of the</p>
<p>diet and insufficiency may lead to a deficiency disease. They are found in a wide range of foods and are divided into two groups:</p>
<ul>
<li>fat-soluble vitamins: A, D, E and K</li>
<li>water-soluble vitamins: B complex and C .</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="fat-soluble-vitamins">Fat-soluble vitamins<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fat-soluble-vitamins" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Bile is needed for absorption of these vitamins from the small intestine. The presence of mineral oils in the intestine and malabsorption impair their absorption.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vitamin-a-retinol">Vitamin A (retinol)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vitamin-a-retinol" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This vitamin is found in foods such as cream, egg yolk, liver, fish oil, milk, cheese and butter. It is not found in vegetable fats and oils but is added to margarine during manufacture. In addition, vitamin A can be formed in the body from certain carotenes, the main dietary sources of which are green vegetables, orange-coloured fruit (e.g. mangoes, apricots) and carrots. The main functions of vitamin A are:</p>
<ul>
<li>generation of the light-sensitive pigment rhodopsin (visual purple) in the retina of the eye (Ch. 8)</li>
<li>cell growth and differentiation, which is especially important in fast-growing cells, such as bone and the epithelial cells covering both internal and external body surfaces</li>
<li>immunity and defence against infection.</li>
</ul>
<p>The first sign of vitamin A deficiency is night blindness due to formation of abnormal retinal pigment. Other consequences include xerophthalmia (drying and thickening of the conjunctiva), which ultimately ulcerates and destroys the conjunctiva. This is a common cause of blindness in developing countries. Atrophy and keratinisation of other epithelial tissues lead to an increased incidence of infections of the ear and the respiratory, genitourinary and alimentary tracts. Immunity is compromised and bone development may be abnormal and delayed.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vitamin-d">Vitamin D<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vitamin-d" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Vitamin D is found mainly in animal fats such as eggs, butter, cheese and fish liver oils. Humans can synthesise this vitamin by the action of the ultraviolet rays in sunlight on a form of cholesterol (7-dehydrocholesterol) in the skin, although this requires exposure to sunlight. Advice from</p>
<p>Public Health England (2016) is that all UK residents should consider taking vitamin D supplements in autumn and winter when sunlight is limited. Individuals at greater risk of deficiency - namely, those from African, African-Caribbean and</p>
<p>South Asian backgrounds, and people seldom exposed to sunlight - should consider doing this throughout the year.</p>
<p>Vitamin D increases calcium and phosphate absorption from the gut and stimulates their retention by the kidneys. It therefore promotes the calcification of bones and teeth.</p>
<p>Deficiency causes rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults (p. 469), due to impaired absorption and use of calcium and phosphate.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="vitamin-e">Vitamin E<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vitamin-e" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Also known as tocopherol, this is found in nuts, egg yolk, wheat germ, whole cereal, milk and butter.</p>
<p>Vitamin E is an antioxidant, which means that it protects body constituents such as membrane lipids from being destroyed in oxidative reactions caused by free radicals. Vitamin E has been shown to protect against coronary heart disease.</p>
<p>Deficiency is rare because this vitamin is present in many foods, and is usually seen only in premature babies and in conditions associated with impaired fat absorption, e.g. cystic fibrosis (p. 288).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vitamin-k">Vitamin K<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vitamin-k" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The sources of vitamin K are liver, some vegetable oils and leafy green vegetables. It is also synthesised by bacteria in the large intestine and significant amounts are absorbed. A small amount is stored in the liver. Vitamin K is required by the liver for the production of prothrombin and factors VII, IX and X, all essential for blood clotting (p. 71). Deficiency therefore prevents normal blood coagulation and increases bleeding times. It may occur in adults when there is obstruction to the flow of bile, severe liver damage and malabsorption, e.g. in coeliac disease. Premature babies may be given vitamin K to prevent haemorrhagic disease of the newborn. This is because their intestines are sterile and require several weeks to become colonised with vitamin K-producing bacteria, allowing normal blood clotting.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="water-soluble-vitamins">Water-soluble vitamins<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#water-soluble-vitamins" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Water-soluble vitamins are lost in the urine, so body stores are usually limited.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vitamin-b-complex">Vitamin B complex<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vitamin-b-complex" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This group of water-soluble vitamins promotes activity of enzymes involved in the chemical breakdown (catabolism) of nutrients to release energy.</p>
<p>Vitamin Bi (thiamin)</p>
<p>This is present in nuts, yeast, egg yolk, liver, legumes, meat and the germ of cereals. It is rapidly destroyed by heat. Thiamin is essential for the complete aerobic release of energy from carbohydrate. Absence or deficiency leads to accumulation of lactic and pyruvic acids, which may cause a build-up of tissue fluid (oedema) and heart failure. Thiamin is also important for nervous system function because of the dependency of these tissues on glucose for fuel.</p>
<p>Deficiency causes beriberi, which occurs mainly in countries where polished rice (rice with the outer coverings and germ removed) is the chief constituent of the diet. In beriberi there is:</p>
<ul>
<li>severe muscle wasting</li>
<li>delayed growth in children</li>
<li>polyneuritis, causing degeneration of motor, sensory and some autonomic nerves</li>
<li>susceptibility to infections.</li>
</ul>
<p>If it is untreated, death from cardiac failure or severe microbial infection may occur.</p>
<p>The main cause of thiamin deficiency in developed countries is alcoholism, where the diet is usually poor. The central nervous system is affected, causing neurological symptoms, which are usually irreversible. These include memory loss, ataxia and visual disturbances, known as Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome.</p>
<p>Vitamin Bz (riboflavin)
Riboflavin is found in yeast, green vegetables, milk, liver, eggs, cheese and fish roe. Only small amounts are stored in the body and it is destroyed by light and alkalis. It is involved in carbohydrate and protein metabolism, especially in the eyes and skin. Deficiency leads to cracking of the skin, commonly around the mouth (angular stomatitis), and inflammation of the tongue (glossitis).</p>
<p>Vitamin B3 (niacin)
This is present in liver, cheese, yeast, whole cereals, eggs and dairy products; in addition, the body can synthesise it from the amino acid tryptophan. It is central to energy release from carbohydrates in cells. In fat metabolism it inhibits the production of cholesterol and assists in fat breakdown.</p>
<p>Deficiency is rare and occurs mainly in areas where maize is the chief constituent of the diet. This is because niacin in maize is in an unusable form. Pellagra develops within 6-8 weeks of severe deficiency. It is characterised by:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>dermatitis - sunburn-like skin sensitivity affecting areas exposed to sunlight</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>confusion and dementia.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Vitamin Bg (pyridoxine)
This stable vitamin is found in egg yolk, peas, beans, soya beans, yeast, poultry, white fish and peanuts. Dietary deficiency is very rare. Vitamin B6 is associated with amino
acid metabolism, including the synthesis of non-essential amino acids and important molecules such as haem and nucleic acids (Ch. 2).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="vitamin-b12-cobaiamin">Vitamin B12 (cobaiamin)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vitamin-b12-cobaiamin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is a group of cobalt-containing compounds that are found in almost all foods of animal origin, and are destroyed by heat.</p>
<p>Vitamin B 12 is essential for DNA synthesis, and deficiency leads to megaloblastic anaemia (p. 74), which is correctable with supplements. However, vitamin B 12 is also required for formation and maintenance of myelin, the fatty substance that surrounds and protects some nerves. Deficiency accordingly causes irreversible damage, such as peripheral neuropathy and/or subacute spinal cord degeneration. The presence of intrinsic factor in the stomach is essential for absorption of vitamin B 12 in the terminal ileum. Deficiency is usually associated with insufficient intrinsic factor, which is fairly common in older adults. Dietary deficiency is uncommon but it is sometimes associated with a vegan diet.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="folic-acid-folate">Folic acid (folate)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#folic-acid-folate" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is found in liver, leafy green vegetables, brown rice, beans, nuts and milk. It is synthesised by bacteria in the large intestine, and much of it is absorbed. It is destroyed by heat and moisture. As only a small amount is stored in the body, deficiency quickly becomes evident. Like vitamin B 12 , folic acid is also essential for DNA synthesis, and when it is lacking, mitosis (cell division) is impaired. This manifests particularly in rapidly dividing tissues such as blood, and folate deficiency therefore leads to megaloblastic anaemia (p. 74), which is reversible with folate supplements. It is involved in development of the embryonic neural tube, which later becomes the spinal cord and skull. Folate deficiency at conception and during early pregnancy is linked to spina bifida (p. 202).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pantothenic-acid">Pantothenic acid<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pantothenic-acid" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is found in many foods and is associated with energy-yielding carbohydrate metabolism. No deficiency diseases have been identified. It is destroyed by excessive heat and freezing.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="biotin">Biotin<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#biotin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is found in a wide range of foods, including yeast, egg yolk, liver, kidney and tomatoes, and is synthesised by microbes in the intestine. It is associated with the metabolism of carbohydrates, lipids and some amino acids; deficiency is very rare.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="vitamin-c-ascorbic-acid">Vitamin C (ascorbic acid)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vitamin-c-ascorbic-acid" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is found in fresh fruit, especially blackcurrants, oranges, grapefruit and lemons, and also in rosehips and green vegetables. The vitamin is very watersoluble and is easily
destroyed by heat, ageing, chopping, salting and drying. These processes may predispose to the development of scurvy (deficiency). Deficiency becomes apparent after 4-6 months.</p>
<p>Vitamin C is associated with protein metabolism, especially the laying down of collagen fibres in connective tissue. Vitamin C, like vitamin E, acts as an antioxidant, protecting body molecules from damaging oxidative reactions caused by free radicals. When scurvy affects collagen production, there is fragility of blood vessels, delayed wound healing and poor bone repair. Gums become swollen and spongy, and the teeth loosen in their sockets. Systemic effects include fatigue, weakness and aching joints and muscles.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="minerals-trace-elements-and-water">Minerals, trace elements and water<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#minerals-trace-elements-and-water" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
