<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="minerals-and-trace-elements">Minerals and trace elements<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#minerals-and-trace-elements" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Minerals are inorganic substances needed in small amounts for normal cellular functioning. Some minerals, e.g. calcium, phosphate, sodium and potassium, are needed in larger amounts than others. Those required in only tiny quantities are known as trace elements or trace minerals, e.g. iron, iodine, zinc, copper, cobalt, selenium and fluoride. The main minerals and trace elements are outlined here.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="calcium">Calcium<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#calcium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is found in milk, cheese, eggs, green vegetables and some fish, e.g. sardines. An adequate supply should be obtained from a well-balanced diet, although requirements are higher in pregnant women and growing children. The most abundant of the minerals, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>99</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">99 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">99%</span></span></span></span></span> of calcium (about 1 kg in adults) is found in the bones and teeth, where it is an essential structural component. Calcium is also involved in blood clotting and in nerve and muscle function. Deficiency of calcium causes rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults (p. 469).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="phosphate">Phosphate<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#phosphate" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Sources include milk and dairy products, red meat, fish, poultry, bread and rice. If there is sufficient calcium in the diet, it is unlikely that there will be phosphate deficiency.</p>
<p>Phosphate is associated with calcium and vitamin D in the hardening of bones and teeth; <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>85</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">85 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">85%</span></span></span></span></span> of body phosphate is found in these sites. Phosphates are an essential part of nucleic acids (DNA and RNA, Ch. 17), cell membranes and energy storage molecules such as adenosine triphosphate (ATP, see Fig. 2.10).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="sodium">Sodium<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sodium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Sodium is found in most foods, especially in processed foods and Tast food'. It is also frequently added during cooking or as table salt. Intake of sodium chloride usually exceeds
the recommended 6 g daily, although excess is normally excreted in the urine. High sodium intake is associated with hypertension (p. 136), which is a risk factor for ischaemic heart disease (p. 132) and stroke (p. 194). Food is usually labelled with sodium content, and to convert this to salt, the sodium content is multiplied by 2.5 .</p>
<p>Sodium is the most common extracellular cation and is essential for muscle contraction and transmission of nerve impulses.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="potassium">Potassium<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#potassium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is found widely distributed in almost all foods, especially fruit and vegetables, and intake usually exceeds requirements.</p>
<p>It is the most common intracellular cation and, like sodium, is involved in muscle contraction and transmission of nerve impulses.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iron">Iron<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iron" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Iron, as a soluble compound, is found in liver, red meat, pulses, nuts, eggs, dried fruit, wholemeal bread and leafy green vegetables. In normal adults about 1 mg of iron is lost from the body daily. The normal daily diet contains more, i.e. <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>9</mn><mo>âˆ’</mo><mn>15</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">9-15 \mathrm{mg}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">9</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">âˆ’</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8389em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">15</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">mg</span></span></span></span></span></span>, but only <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>5</mn><mo>âˆ’</mo><mn>15</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">5-15 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">5</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">âˆ’</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">15%</span></span></span></span></span> of this is in a form that can be absorbed. Iron is essential for the formation of haemoglobin in red blood cells. It is also necessary for carbohydrate metabolism and synthesis of some hormones and neurotransmitters. Menstruating and pregnant women have increased iron requirements, as do young people experiencing growth spurts.</p>
<p>Iron deficiency anaemia (p. 73) is the most common nutritional deficiency worldwide and occurs when iron stores become depleted. Iron deficiency anaemia may also arise from chronic bleeding, e.g. in peptic ulcer disease.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iodine">Iodine<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iodine" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Iodine is found in seafoods and in vegetables grown in soil rich in iodine. In parts of the world where iodine is deficient in soil, very small quantities are added to table salt to prevent goitre (p. 251).</p>
<p>It is essential for the formation of thyroxine and tri-iodothyronine, two hormones secreted by the thyroid gland, which regulate metabolic rate and physical and mental development.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="water">Water<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#water" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Water is the most abundant constituent of the human body, accounting for around <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>60</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">60 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">60%</span></span></span></span></span> of the body weight in an adult (see Fig. 2.17).</p>
<p>A large amount of water is lost each day in urine, sweat and faeces. This is normally balanced by intake in food and fluids, to satisfy thirst. The recommended daily intake is
about 1.5-2 litres (6-8 glasses) for adults. Water requirements are increased by physical activity and high environmental temperatures. Dehydration, with serious consequences, may occur if intake does not balance loss. Water balance is finely regulated by the action of hormones on the kidney tubules (Ch. 13).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="functions-of-water">Functions of water<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions-of-water" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These include:</p>
<ul>
<li>providing the solvent and medium for the metabolic processes of the body</li>
<li>moistening food for swallowing (see saliva, p. 321)</li>
<li>regulating body temperature - as a constituent of sweat, which is secreted on to the skin, it evaporates, cooling the body surface (Ch. 14)</li>
<li>as the major constituent of blood and tissue fluid, transporting substances round the body and allowing exchange between the blood, tissue fluid and body cells</li>
<li>diluting waste products and toxins in the body</li>
<li>providing the medium for excretion of waste products, e.g. urine and faeces.</li>
<li>SPOT CHECK</li>
</ul>
<ol start="3">
<li>What does the term 'essential amino acid' mean?</li>
<li>Name the fat-soluble vitamins.</li>
<li>Which is the most abundant mineral in the body?</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="non-starch-polysaccharide">Non-starch polysaccharide<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#non-starch-polysaccharide" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Learning outcome
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe the sources and functions of non-starch polysaccharide.</li>
</ul>
<p>Non-starch polysaccharide (NSP) is the correct term for dietary fibre, although the latter term continues to be more commonly used in the UK. It is the indigestible part of the diet and consists of bran, cellulose and other polysaccharides found in fruit, vegetables and cereals. Dietary fibre is partly digested by microbes in the large intestine and is associated with gas (flatus) formation. The recommended daily intake is contained within five portions of fruit or vegetables (Tive a day'. Box 11.2).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="functions-of-nsp-dietary-fibre">Functions of NSP (dietary fibre)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions-of-nsp-dietary-fibre" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Dietary fibre:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="learning-outcome">Learning outcome<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#learning-outcome" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>prevents constipation
provides bulk to the diet and helps to satisfy the appetite stimulates peristalsis (p.315)
attracts water, increasing faecal bulk
protects against some gastrointestinal disorders, e.g. colorectal cancer and diverticular disease (p. 357).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-spot-check">I # SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol start="6">
<li>List two functions of dietary fibre.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="ageing-and-nutrition">Ageing and nutrition<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ageing-and-nutrition" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Learning outcome
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe the factors affecting diet and nutrition in older adults.</li>
</ul>
<p>The importance of good nutrition to health and well-being at all stages of the lifespan is well established. The relationship between nutrition, diet and ageing is complex, as many diseases arise from poor diet; for example, atherosclerosis is associated with a diet high in saturated fat and this condition predisposes to coronary heart disease (p. 132). Good nutrition during early and middle life can significantly reduce the risk of problems in later life; for example, there is evidence that young women who limit their dairy intake when trying to lose weight, or drink lots of fizzy drinks (which impair calcium absorption), have an increased risk of osteoporosis (p. 468) in later life.</p>
<p>The senses of smell and taste decline with age (Ch. 8), which can reduce appetite and enjoyment of eating.</p>
<p>Basal metabolic rate (BMR, p. 342) gradually declines with age from the fourth or fifth decades of life. This is mainly due to a reduction in muscle mass and a corresponding increase in body fat; BMR is higher in those with more muscle, as muscle is more metabolically active than adipose tissue (fat). Physical activity generally lessens with age, further reducing BMR in older adults.</p>
<p>UK dietary recommendations for older adults are the same as those for other adults, although energy requirements gradually reduce as the BMR falls, especially when physical activity is limited. As for other age groups, it is important for older adults to eat a balanced diet with sufficient fibre and vitamins.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="nutritional-disorders-in-older-adults">Nutritional disorders in older adults<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nutritional-disorders-in-older-adults" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Malnutrition and obesity are both prevalent in older adults, as well as other conditions considered here. Malnutrition is
more prevalent in those living in institutions, whereas being overweight or obese tends to be more common in people living at home.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="malnutrition">Malnutrition<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#malnutrition" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Being underweight (BMI below 18.5) predisposes to health problems, e.g. development of pressure ulcers, which take longer to heal in older adults. In the oldest adults, anorexia and weight loss become increasingly common and the incidence of protein-energy malnutrition (PEM, p. 307) increases. Malnutrition in healthcare settings is considered in the following section.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="obesity">Obesity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#obesity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>It is common for body weight to increase between the ages of 40 and 65 ('middle age spread'). This is generally attributed to a reduction in physical activity and BMR rather than increased dietary energy intake. Overweight is defined as BMI above 25 and obesity when BMI is above 30 (see Box 11.1). After 65 years, there is usually weight loss accompanied by a lower dietary intake, a decline in muscle mass and an increasing risk of malnutrition. Being overweight or obese at any age carries many health risks (see Box 11.6).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vitamin-deficiency">Vitamin deficiency<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vitamin-deficiency" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Some vitamin deficiencies become more common in older adults. Vitamin D deficiency (p. 302) is more closely linked to older adults who live in institutions or are housebound. It is recommended that vitamin D intake be maintained by eating oily fish and fortified cereals regularly and that those over 65 years take supplements ( 10 jiig per day).</p>
<p>Vitamin B 12 deficiency, perhaps due to decreased absorption of intrinsic factor, is also more common in older adults and may result in pernicious anaemia (p. 74).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="constipation">Constipation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#constipation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Constipation becomes more common as muscle tone and peristaltic activity of the colon lessen with age. This is exacerbated by a lower fluid and/or fibre intake, taking less exercise and reduced mobility. If there is difficulty with activities related to nutrition, e.g. mobility problems that prevent shopping, impaired</p>
<p>cognitive function or loss of the manual dexterity required to prepare and eat food and drinks, this further predisposes to constipation.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="5205029c">â–  SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5205029c" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol start="7">
<li>Which vitamin supplement is recommended yearround in all older adults living in the UK?</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="learning-outcome">Learning outcome<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#learning-outcome" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="disorders-of-nutrition">Disorders of nutrition<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disorders-of-nutrition" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Learning outcome
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe the main consequences of malnutrition and obesity.</li>
</ul>
<p>The importance of nutrition is increasingly recognised as essential for health, and illness often alters nutritional requirements.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="protein-energy-malnutrition">Protein-energy malnutrition<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#protein-energy-malnutrition" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Protein-energy malnutrition (PEM) is the result of inadequate intake of protein, carbohydrate and fat. It occurs during periods of starvation and when dietary intake is insufficient to meet increased requirements, e.g. in trauma, fever and illness. Malnutrition is relatively rare in developed countries except when there is an underlying condition, e.g. sepsis, trauma, surgery or a concurrent illness. Poor nutrition is seen where poverty is prevalent and is usually the result of a diet that is not adequately balanced. In the UK, many older adults admitted to hospitals and care homes have signs of under-nutrition, which often worsens after admission. Anorexia (loss of appetite) from any cause may lead to malnutrition. People with advanced cancer or some chronic illnesses can experience loss of appetite accompanied by profound weight loss and muscle wasting as a symptom of cachexia (p. 59).</p>
<p>If dietary intake is inadequate, it is not uncommon for vitamin deficiency to develop at the same time. Poor nutrition reduces the ability to combat other illness and infection. The degree of malnutrition can be assessed from measurement of body mass index (see Box 11.1).</p>
<p>Infants and young children are particularly susceptible, as their nutritional requirements for normal growth and development are high. In developing countries where people experience long periods of near-total starvation, the following two conditions described are found in children under 5 years.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="kwashiorkor">Kwashiorkor<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#kwashiorkor" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-ff5086e5.jpeg" alt="img-11.jpeg"></p>
<p>A Kwashiorkor
B Marasmus
Figure 11.2 Features of protein-energy malnutrition.
(A) Kwashiorkor. (B) Marasmus.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="marasmus">Marasmus<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#marasmus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This type of malnutrition with severe muscle wasting is characterised by emaciation due to breakdown (catabolism) of muscle and fat (Fig. 11.2B). There is no oedema. Growth milestones are delayed and the skin becomes wrinkled due to absence of subcutaneous fat; hair is lost.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="malabsorption">Malabsorption<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#malabsorption" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The causes of malabsorption vary widely, from short-term problems such as gastrointestinal infections (p.354) to chronic conditions such as cystic fibrosis (p. 288). Malabsorption may be specific for one nutrient, e.g. vitamin Bi 2 in pernicious anaemia (p. 74), or it may apply across a spectrum of nutrients, e.g. tropical sprue (p.360).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="obesity">Obesity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#obesity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is malnutrition with oedema that typically occurs when breast feeding stops and is often precipitated by infections such as measles or gastroenteritis. Severe liver damage significantly reduces the production of plasma proteins, leading to ascites and oedema in the lower limbs that mask emaciation (Fig. 11.2 A).</p>
<p>Growth stops and there is loss of weight and loss of pigmentation of skin and hair, accompanied by listlessness, apathy and irritability. There is susceptibility to infection, and recovery from injury and infection takes longer.</p>
<p>In developed countries, this is increasingly common, although it is also prevalent in some developing countries. The WHO defines obesity as a BMI of 30 or above (see Box 11.1). It occurs when energy intake exceeds energy expenditure, e.g. in inactive individuals whose food intake exceeds daily energy requirements.</p>
<p>Obesity (Fig. 11.3) is a growing public health challenge worldwide that affects people of all ages and predisposes to many other conditions (Box 11.6). Worldwide, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>39</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">39 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">39%</span></span></span></span></span> of adults aged 18 years and over were overweight in 2014, and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>13</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">13 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">13%</span></span></span></span></span></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="learning-outcome">Learning outcome<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#learning-outcome" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="section-3-intake-of-raw-materials-and-elimination-of-waste">SECTION 3 Intake of raw materials and elimination of waste<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#section-3-intake-of-raw-materials-and-elimination-of-waste" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-6eb208dc.jpeg" alt="img-12.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 11.3 Obese woman (thermogram). (Tony McConnell/ Science Photo Library. Reproduced with permission.)</p>
<p>Box 11.6 Conditions for which obesity is a predisposing factor
Cardiovascular diseases, e.g. hypertension (p. 136), ischaemic heart disease (p. 132)</p>
<p>Type 2 diabetes (p. 256)
Some cancers Gallstones (p. 364)
Osteoarthritis (p. 471)
Varicose veins (p. 128)
Increased risk of postoperative complications
Box 11.7 Conditions that require dietary modification
Obesity
Malnutrition
Diabetes mellitus (p. 255)
Diverticular disease (p. 357)
Coeliac disease (p. 360)
Phenylketonuria (p. 484)
Acute kidney injury (p. 385)
Chronic kidney disease (p. 386)
Liver failure (p. 363)
Lactose intolerance
The hormone leptin is associated with obesity. It has several functions, one of which is control of appetite. After eating, this hormone is released by adipose tissue and acts on the hypothalamus, resulting in a feeling of satiety (fullness), which suppresses the appetite. In obesity, there are usually high blood levels of leptin and the negative feedback system, which usually suppresses the appetite, no longer operates normally.</p>
<p>Another function of leptin is involvement in the synthesis of gonadotrophin releasing hormone and gonadotrophins at puberty (Ch. 18). As it is secreted by fat tissue, levels are low in thin individuals, which explains why:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>thin girls with little body fat reach puberty later than their peers of normal weight</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>very thin women may have difficulty in conceiving</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>menstruation stops in females with very little body fat.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="i-spot-check">I # SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol start="8">
<li>What is the body mass index range for normal body weight?
were obese (WHO, 2016). There were more than 40 million overweight or obese children aged under 5 worldwide, of whom <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>75</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">75 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">75%</span></span></span></span></span> live in urban areas of developing countries (WHO, 2016). Childhood obesity is of particular concern, especially in developing countries (where malnutrition can also be widespread), because this preventable condition is likely to continue into and during adulthood with its associated health risks, especially diabetes and cardiovascular disease.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="conditions-with-dietary-implications">Conditions with dietary implications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#conditions-with-dietary-implications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-digestive-system">The digestive system<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-digestive-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="chapter">CHAPTER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chapter" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

12.5 Small intestine 330
12.6 Large intestine 333
12.7 Hepatic portal circulation 337
12.8 Factors influencing metabolic rate 342
12.9 Citric acid cycle 344
12.10 Oesophageal varices 350
12.11 Diverticulosis and diverticulitis 357</p>
<p>The digestive system describes the alimentary canal, its accessory organs and a variety of digestive processes that prepare food eaten in the diet for absorption. The alimentary canal begins at the mouth, passes through the thorax, abdomen and pelvis, and ends at the anus (Fig. 12.1). It has a basic structure that is modified at different levels to provide for the processes occurring at each level (Fig. 12.2). The digestive processes gradually break down the foods eaten until they are in a form suitable for absorption. For example, meat, even when cooked, is chemically too complex to be absorbed from the alimentary canal. Digestion releases its constituents: amino acids, mineral salts, fat and vitamins. Digestive enzymes (p. 34) responsible for these changes are secreted into the canal by specialised glands,</p>
<p>some of which are in the walls of the canal, and some outside the canal but with ducts leading into it.</p>
<p>After absorption, nutrients provide the raw materials for the manufacture of new cells, hormones and enzymes. The chemical energy needed for these and other processes, and for the disposal of waste materials, is generated from the products of digestion.</p>
<p>The activities of the digestive system can be grouped under five main headings.
Ingestion
This is the taking of food into the alimentary tract, i.e. eating and drinking.
Propulsion
This mixes the contents and moves them along the alimentary tract.
Digestion
This consists of:</p>
<ul>
<li>mechanical breakdown of food by, for example, mastication (chewing)</li>
<li>chemical digestion of food into small molecules by the action of enzymes present in secretions produced by glands and accessory organs of the digestive system.</li>
</ul>
<p>Absorption
This is the process by which the products of digestion pass through the walls of some organs of the alimentary canal into the blood and lymph capillaries for circulation and use by body cells.
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">â–¡</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\square</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.675em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">â–¡</span></span></span></span></span></p>
<p>Small intestine Large intestine
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-3676c54c.jpeg" alt="img-14.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-6bd64f2a.jpeg" alt="img-15.jpeg"></p>
<p>Liver
Gall bladder Duodenum
Ascending colon Ileum Caecum Appendix
Rectum
Oesophagus
Diaphragm
Stomach
Pancreas
Transverse colon Jejunum
Descending colon
Sigmoid colon Anus
Figure 12.1 The digestive system. The head is turned to the right.
Elimination
Food that has been eaten but cannot be digested and absorbed is excreted from the alimentary canal in faeces by the process of defaecation.</p>
<p>The fate of absorbed nutrients and how they are used by the body are explored and the effects of ageing on the digestive system are considered. In the final section, common disorders of the digestive system are explained.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="organs-of-the-digestive-system">Organs of the digestive system<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#organs-of-the-digestive-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These are shown in Fig. 12.1.
Learning outcomes</p>
<p>After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>identify the main organs of the alimentary canal</li>
<li>list the accessory organs of digestion.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-657e8e49.jpeg" alt="img-16.jpeg"></li>
</ul>
<p>Peritoneum
Myenteric plexus
Submucosal plexus Mucosa
Figure 12.2 General structure of the alimentary canal.
itudinal muscle layer
Circular muscle layer
Submucosa</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="alimentary-canal">Alimentary canal<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#alimentary-canal" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Also known as the gastrointestinal (GI) tract, this is essentially a long tube through which food passes. It commences at the mouth and terminates at the anus, and in adults is around 5 metres in length. The various organs along its length have different functions, although structurally they are remarkably similar. The parts are:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>mouth</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>pharynx</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>oesophagus</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>stomach</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>small intestine</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>large intestine</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>rectum and anal canal.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="accessory-organs">Accessory organs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#accessory-organs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Various secretions are released into the alimentary tract, some by glands in the membrane lining certain organs, e.g. gastric juice secreted by glands in the lining of the stomach, and some by glands situated outside the tract. The latter are the accessory organs of digestion and their secretions pass through ducts to enter the tract. They consist of:</p>
<ul>
<li>three pairs of salivary glands</li>
<li>the pancreas</li>
<li>the liver and biliary tract.</li>
</ul>
<p>The organs and glands are linked physiologically as well as anatomically, in that digestion and absorption occur in stages, each stage being dependent on the previous stage or stages.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5205029c">â–  SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5205029c" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Name the accessory organs of the alimentary canal.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="basic-structure-of-the-alimentary-canal">Basic structure of the alimentary canal<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#basic-structure-of-the-alimentary-canal" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is shown in Fig. 12.2.
Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe the distribution of the peritoneum</li>
<li>explain the function of smooth muscle in the walls of the alimentary canal</li>
<li>discuss the structures of the alimentary mucosa</li>
<li>outline the nerve supply of the alimentary canal.</li>
</ul>
<p>The layers of the walls of the alimentary canal follow a consistent pattern from the oesophagus onwards. This basic structure does not apply so obviously to the mouth and the pharynx, which are considered later in the chapter.</p>
<p>In the organs from the oesophagus onwards, structural modifications are associated with specific functions. The basic structure is described here and any modifications in structure and function are described in the appropriate section.</p>
<p>The walls of the alimentary tract are formed by four layers of tissue:</p>
<ul>
<li>adventitia or serosa - outer covering</li>
<li>muscle layer</li>
<li>submucosa</li>
<li>mucosa - mucosal lining.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="adventitia-or-serosa">Adventitia or serosa<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#adventitia-or-serosa" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is the outermost layer. In the thorax it consists of loose fibrous tissue, and in the abdomen the organs are covered by a serous membrane (serosa) called peritoneum.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="peritoneum">Peritoneum<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#peritoneum" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The peritoneum is the largest serous membrane of the body (Fig. 12.3A). It is a single membrane, forming a closed sac and containing a small amount of serous fluid, within the abdominal cavity. It is richly supplied with blood and lymph vessels, and contains many lymph nodes. It provides a physical barrier to local spread of infection and can isolate an infective focus such as appendicitis, preventing involvement of other abdominal structures. It has two layers:</p>
<ul>
<li>the parietal peritoneum, which lines the abdominal wall</li>
<li>the visceral peritoneum, which covers the organs (viscera) within the abdominal and pelvic cavities.</li>
</ul>
<p>The parietal peritoneum lines the anterior abdominal wall.
The two layers of peritoneum are in close contact, and friction between them is prevented by the presence of peritoneal fluid, a serous fluid secreted by the peritoneal cells; the peritoneal cavity is only a potential cavity. A similar arrangement is seen with the membranes covering the lungs, the pleura (p. 272). The abdominal organs are covered to varying degrees by the loops and folds of the visceral peritoneum, which attaches them firmly to the abdominal wall. If the organ is almost completely covered by the visceral peritoneum, it is said to be intraperitoneal. If the organ is covered on its anterior side only, it is said to be retroperitoneal (meaning behind the peritoneum). This means that:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Pelvic organs are covered only on their superior surface.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The stomach and intestines are almost completely surrounded by peritoneum and have a double fold (the mesentery) that attaches them to the posterior abdominal
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-820b9041.jpeg" alt="img-17.jpeg"></p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Diaphragm
Peritoneum
Epiploic foramen (of Winslow)
Peritoneal cavity
Transverse colon
Pancreas
Duodenum
Aorta
Greater
omentum
Mesentery
Sigmoid
colon
Small intestine</p>
<p>Bladder-
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>âˆ’</mo><mo>âˆ’</mo><mn>4</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">--4 \mathrm{~V}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">âˆ’</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">âˆ’</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">4</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">V</span></span></span></span></span></span></p>
<p>Rectum</p>
<p>Uterus</p>
<p>B</p>
<p>Figure 12.3 The peritoneum and associated structures. (A) The peritoneal cavity (blue), the abdominal organs of the digestive system and the pelvic organs. (B) The greater omentum.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-3b765f04.jpeg" alt="img-18.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Liver Stomach</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Greater omentum
â€” Small intestine
wall. The fold of peritoneum enclosing the stomach extends beyond the greater curvature of the stomach, and hangs down in front of the abdominal organs like an apron (Fig. 12.3B). This is the greater omentum, which stores fat that provides both insulation and a long-term energy store.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The anterior surfaces of the pancreas, spleen, kidneys and adrenal glands is covered, so these organs are retroperitoneal (lie behind the peritoneum).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The liver is almost completely covered by peritoneum, which attaches it to the inferior surface of the diaphragm.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The main blood vessels and nerves pass close to the posterior abdominal wall and send branches to the organs between folds of peritoneum.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="muscle-layer">Muscle layer<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#muscle-layer" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>With some exceptions, this consists of two layers of smooth (involuntary) muscle. The muscle fibres of the outer layer are arranged longitudinally, and those of the inner layer are circular. Between these two muscle layers are blood vessels.
lymph vessels and a plexus (network) of sympathetic and parasympathetic nerves, called the myenteric plexus (see Fig. 12.2). These nerves supply the adjacent smooth muscle and blood vessels.</p>
<p>Contraction and relaxation of these muscle layers occur in waves, which push the contents of the tract onwards. This type of rhythmical contraction of smooth muscle is called peristalsis (Fig. 12.4) and is under the influence of sympathetic and parasympathetic nerves. Muscle contraction also mixes food with the digestive juices.</p>
<p>Onward movement of the contents of the tract is controlled at various points by sphincters, which are thickened rings of circular muscle. They also act as valves, preventing backflow in the tract. This control allows time for digestion and absorption to take place.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="submucosa">Submucosa<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#submucosa" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This layer consists of loose areolar connective tissue containing collagen and some elastic fibres, which binds the muscle layer to the mucosa. Within it are blood vessels, nerves, lymph vessels and varying amounts of lymphoid</p>
<p>Contraction of smooth muscle
Relaxation of smooth muscle
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-4afcccbe.jpeg" alt="img-19.jpeg"></p>
<p>Bolus of food
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-c1404565.jpeg" alt="img-20.jpeg"></p>
<p>A
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-cfeabf19.jpeg" alt="img-21.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 12.4 Movement of a bolus by peristalsis.
tissue. The blood vessels are arterioles, venules and capillaries. The nerve plexus is the submucosal plexus (see Fig. 12.2), which contains sympathetic and parasympathetic nerves that supply the mucosal lining. B
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-4a87cc0c.jpeg" alt="img-22.jpeg"></p>
<p>Mucus
Goblet cell
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-e7eac83a.jpeg" alt="img-23.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="mucosa">Mucosa<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mucosa" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The mucosa is the lining of the tract. Its most superficial layer is the mucous membrane, which is made from columnar epithelium and has three main functions: protection, secretion and absorption. Below this lies a thin layer of loose connective tissue that supports the blood vessels and the protective and lymphatic tissue. The deepest layer is a thin layer of smooth muscle that provides features of the tract wall, e.g. gastric glands (p.326) and villi (p.330).</p>
<p>Mucous membrane
In parts of the tract that are subject to great wear and tear or mechanical injury, this innermost layer consists of stratified squamous epithelium with mucus-secreting glands just below the surface. In areas where the food is already soft and moist, and where secretion of digestive juices and absorption occur, the mucous membrane consists of columnar epithelial cells interspersed with mucus-secreting goblet cells (Fig. 12.5). Mucus lubricates the walls of the tract and provides a physical barrier that protects them from the damaging effects of digestive enzymes. At several points along the tract, specialised subepithelial glands release secretions into the lumen, including:</p>
<ul>
<li>saliva from the salivary glands</li>
<li>gastric juice from the gastric glands</li>
</ul>
<p>Figure 12.5 Columnar epithelium with a goblet cell. (A) Diagram. (B) Coloured transmission eleotron miorograph of a section through a goblet cell (pink and blue) of the small intestine. (B, Steve G Schmeissner/Science Photo Library. Reproduced with permission.)</p>
<ul>
<li>intestinal juice from the intestinal glands</li>
<li>pancreatic juice from the pancreas</li>
<li>bile from the liver.</li>
</ul>
<p>These are digestive juices and most contain enzymes that chemically break down food. Under the epithelial lining are varying amounts of lymphoid tissue that protect against ingested microbes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="nerve-supply">Nerve supply<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nerve-supply" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The alimentary canal and its related accessory organs are supplied by nerves from both divisions of the autonomic nervous system, i.e. both parasympathetic and sympathetic parts (Fig. 12.6). Their actions are generally antagonistic to each other and, at any particular time, one has a greater influence than the other, according to body needs. Increased parasympathetic activity to the digestive organs promotes digestive processes, and increased sympathetic activity inhibits them.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="717bfc68"><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>âˆ™</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\bullet</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4445em;"></span><span class="mord">âˆ™</span></span></span></span></span><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#717bfc68" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Spinal
cord
I Cranial nerve numbers <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>j</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">j</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.854em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05724em;">j</span></span></span></span></span>
Lateral chain of ganglia</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="jl">JL<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#jl" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-parasympathetic-supply">The parasympathetic supply<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-parasympathetic-supply" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>One pair of cranial nerves, the vagus nerves, supplies most of the alimentary canal and the accessory organs. Sacral nerves supply the most distal part of the GI tract. The effects of parasympathetic stimulation on the digestive system are:</p>
<ul>
<li>increased muscular activity, especially peristalsis, stimulated by increased activity of the myenteric plexus</li>
<li>increased glandular secretion, through increased activity of the submucosal plexus (see Fig. 12.2).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-sympathetic-supply">The sympathetic supply<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-sympathetic-supply" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is provided by numerous nerves that emerge from the spinal cord in the thoracic and lumbar regions. These form
plexuses (ganglia) in the thorax, abdomen and pelvis, from which nerves pass to the organs of the alimentary tract. The effects of sympathetic stimulation on the digestive system are to:</p>
<ul>
<li>decrease muscular activity, especially peristalsis, because there is reduced stimulation of the myenteric plexus</li>
<li>decrease glandular secretion, as there is less stimulation of the submucosal plexus.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3e111293">â–  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>â‹…</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\cdot</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4445em;"></span><span class="mord">â‹…</span></span></span></span></span> SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3e111293" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol start="2">
<li>Identify the layers within the wall of the alimentary tract.</li>
</ol>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-df92d74f.jpeg" alt="img-25.jpeg"></p>
<p>Upper lip

arch</p>

<p>Figure 12.7 Structures seen in the wide-open nnouth.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="mouth">Mouth<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mouth" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>list the principal structures associated with the mouth</li>
<li>describe the structure of the mouth</li>
<li>describe the structure and function of the tongue</li>
<li>describe the structure and function of the teeth</li>
<li>outline the arrangement of normal primary and secondary dentition.</li>
</ul>
<p>The mouth (Fig. 12.7) or oral cavity is formed by muscles and bones:
Anteriorly - by the lips
Posteriorly - it is continuous with the oropharynx Laterally - by the muscles of the cheeks Superiorly - by the bony hard palate and muscular soft palate</p>
<p>Inferiorly - by the muscular tongue and the soft tissues of the floor of the mouth.
The oral cavity is lined throughout with mucous membrane, consisting of sturdy, stratified squamous epithelium containing small mucus-secreting glands.</p>
<p>The part of the mouth between the gums and the cheeks is the vestibule, and the remainder of its interior is the oral cavity. The mucous membrane lining of the cheeks and the lips is reflected on to the gums or alveolar ridges and is continuous with the skin of the face.</p>
<p>Figure 12.8 The inferior surface of the tongue.
The palate forms the roof of the mouth and is divided into the anterior hard palate and the posterior soft palate (see Fig. 12.1). The hard palate is formed by the maxilla and the palatine bones. The soft palate, which is muscular, curves downwards from the posterior end of the hard palate and blends with the walls of the pharynx at the sides.</p>
<p>The uvula is a curved fold of muscle covered with mucous membrane, hanging down from the middle of the free border of the soft palate. Originating from the upper end of the uvula are four folds of mucous membrane, two passing downwards at each side to form membranous arches. The posterior folds, one on each side, are the palatopharyngeal arches, and the two anterior folds are the</p>
<p>palatoglossal arches. On each side, between the arches, is a collection of lymphoid tissue called the palatine tonsil.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="tongue">Tongue<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tongue" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The tongue is composed of voluntary muscle. It is attached by its base to the hyoid bone (see Fig. 10.4) and by a fold of its mucous membrane covering, called the frenulum, to the floor of the mouth (Fig. 12.8). The superior surface consists of stratified squamous epithelium, with numerous papillae (little projections). Many of these contain sensory receptors (specialised nerve endings) for the sense of taste in the taste buds (see Fig. 8.25).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="blood-supply">Blood supply<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blood-supply" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The main arterial blood supply to the tongue is by the lingual branch of the external carotid artery. Venous drainage is by the lingual vein, which joins the internal jugular vein.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-30e06149.jpeg" alt="img-27.jpeg"></p>
<p>Nerve supply
The nerves involved are:</p>
<ul>
<li>the hypoglossal nerves (12th cranial nerves), which supply the voluntary muscle</li>
<li>the lingual branch of the mandibular nerves, which arise from the 5th cranial nerves, the nerves of somatic (ordinary) sensation, i.e. pain, temperature and touch</li>
<li>the facial and glossopharyngeal nerves (7th and 9th cranial nerves), the nerves of taste.</li>
</ul>
<p>Functions
The tongue plays an important part in:</p>
<ul>
<li>chewing (mastication)</li>
<li>swallowing (deglutition)</li>
<li>speech (p. 267)</li>
<li>taste (p. 224).</li>
</ul>
<p>Nerve endings of the sense of taste are present in the papillae and widely distributed in the epithelium of the tongue.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="teeth">Teeth<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#teeth" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The teeth are embedded in the alveoli, or sockets, of the alveolar ridges of the mandible and the maxilla (Fig. 12.9). Babies are born with two sets, or dentitions: the temporary or deciduous (baby) teeth and the permanent teeth (Fig. 12.10). The teeth of both dentitions are present, in immature form, in the mandible and maxilla at birth.</p>
<p>There are 20 temporary teeth, 10 in each jaw. They begin to erupt at about 6 months of age, and should all be present by 24 months (Table 12.1).</p>
<p>The permanent teeth begin to replace the deciduous teeth between the ages of 6 and 13 years. This dentition, consisting of 32 teeth, is usually complete by the age of 20. The third molars (wisdom teeth) are the last to erupt.
structure
Although the shapes of the different teeth vary, the structure (Fig. 12.11) is the same and consists of:
the crown - the part that protrudes from the gum the root - the part embedded in the bone the neck - the slightly narrowed region where the crown merges with the root.</p>
<p>In the centre of the tooth is the pulp cavity, containing blood vessels, lymph vessels and nerves, and surrounding this is a hard, ivory-like substance called dentine. The dentine of the crown is covered by a thin layer of a very hard substance, enamel. The root of the tooth, on the other hand, is covered with a substance resembling bone, called cementum, which secures the tooth in its socket. Blood vessels and nerves pass to the tooth through a small foramen (hole) at the apex of each root.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="blood-supply">Blood supply<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blood-supply" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Most of the arterial blood supply to the teeth is by branches of the maxillary arteries. The venous drainage is by a number of veins that empty into the internal jugular veins.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-11a38baa.jpeg" alt="img-28.jpeg"></p>
<p>Mandible</p>
<p>Incisors</p>
<p>Canines</p>
<p>Premolars</p>
<p>Molars
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-831de19c.jpeg" alt="img-29.jpeg"></p>
<p>A Mandible</p>
<p>Incisors Canines D Molars
Figure 12.9 The permanent teeth. (A) Lateral view. (B) Locations in the upper and lower jaw.</p>
