Blood vessels and nerves
Figure 12.11 Section of a tooth.
Functions</p>
<p>Teeth have different shapes, depending on their functions. Incisors and canine teeth are the cutting teeth and are used for biting off pieces of food, whereas the premolar and molar teeth, with broad, flat surfaces, are used for grinding or chewing food (Fig. 12.12).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="95c381b4">) <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>â‹…</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\cdot</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4445em;"></span><span class="mord">â‹…</span></span></span></span></span> SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#95c381b4" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol start="3">
<li>Outline the functions of the tongue.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="salivary-glands">Salivary glands<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#salivary-glands" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe the structure and the function of the principal salivary glands</li>
<li>explain the role of saliva in digestion.</li>
</ul>
<p>Incisor</p>
<p>Canine</p>
<p>Premolar</p>
<p>Molar</p>
<p>Figure 12.12 The shapes of the permanent teeth.
The salivary glands (Fig. 12.13) release their secretions into ducts that lead into the mouth. There are three main pairs: the parotid glands, the submandibular glands and the sublingual glands. There are also numerous smaller salivary glands scattered around the mouth.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="parotid-glands">Parotid glands<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#parotid-glands" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These are situated one on each side of the face, just below the external acoustic meatus (see Fig. 8.1). Each gland has a parotid duct opening into the mouth at the level of the second upper molar tooth.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="nerve-supply">Nerve supply<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nerve-supply" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The nerve supply to the upper teeth is by branches of the maxillary nerves and that to the lower teeth by branches of the mandibular nerves. These are both branches of the trigeminal nerves (5th cranial nerves; see Fig. 7.42).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="submandibular-glands">Submandibular glands<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#submandibular-glands" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These lie one on each side of the face under the angle of the jaw. The two submandibular ducts open on the floor of the mouth, one on each side of the frenulum of the tongue (Fig. 12.13).
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-caf240f8.jpeg" alt="img-31.jpeg"></p>
<p>Parotid gland and its duct
Sublingual gland
A Submandibular gland</p>
<p>Ductules</p>
<p>Acini</p>
<p>B</p>
<p>Secretory cells</p>
<p>Figure 12.13 Salivary glands. (A) The position of the salivary glands. (B) Enlargement of part of a gland.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="sublingual-glands">Sublingual glands<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sublingual-glands" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These glands lie under the mucous membrane of the floor of the mouth in front of the submandibular glands. They have numerous small ducts that open into the floor of the mouth.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="structure">Structure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#structure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The glands are all surrounded by a fibrous capsule. They consist of a number of lobules made up of small acini lined with secretory cells (Fig. 12.13B). Saliva is released into ductules that join up to form larger ducts leading into the mouth.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="blood-supply">Blood supply<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blood-supply" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Arterial supply is by various branches from the external carotid arteries, and venous drainage is into the external jugular veins.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="composition-of-saliva">Composition of saliva<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#composition-of-saliva" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Saliva is the combined secretions from the salivary glands and the small mucussecreting glands of the oral mucosa. About 1.5 litres of saliva is produced daily and it consists of:</p>
<ul>
<li>water</li>
<li>mineral salts</li>
<li>salivary amylase - a digestive enzyme</li>
<li>mucus</li>
<li>antimicrobial substances - immunoglobulins (antibodies) and the enzyme lysozyme.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="secretion-of-saliva">Secretion of saliva<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#secretion-of-saliva" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Secretion of saliva is controlled by the autonomic nervous system. Parasympathetic stimulation causes profuse secretion of watery saliva with a relatively low content of enzymes and other organic substances. Sympathetic stimulation results in secretion of small amounts of saliva rich in organic material, especially from the submandibular glands. Reflex secretion occurs when there is food in the mouth and the reflex becomes conditioned so that the sight, smell and even thought of food stimulate the flow of saliva.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="functions-of-saliva">Functions of saliva<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions-of-saliva" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="chemical-digestion-of-polysaccharides">Chemical digestion of polysaccharides<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chemical-digestion-of-polysaccharides" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Saliva contains the enzyme amylase, which begins the breakdown of complex sugars, including starches, reducing them to the disaccharide maltose. The optimum pH for the action of salivary amylase is 6.8 (slightly acid). Salivary pH ranges from 5.8 to 7.4 , depending on the rate of flow; the higher the flow rate, the higher the pH . Enzyme action continues during swallowing until terminated by the strongly acidic gastric juices, which degrade the amylase.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="lubrication-of-food">Lubrication of food<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lubrication-of-food" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The high water content means that dry food entering the mouth is moistened and lubricated by saliva before it can be made into a bolus ready for swallowing.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cleaning-and-lubrication-of-the-mouth">Cleaning and lubrication of the mouth<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cleaning-and-lubrication-of-the-mouth" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>An adequate flow of saliva is necessary to keep the mouth clean, moist and pliable. This also helps to prevent damage to the mucous membrane by rough or abrasive food.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="non-specific-defence">Non-specific defence<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#non-specific-defence" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Lysozyme and immunoglobulins (antibodies) present in saliva combat invading microbes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="taste">Taste<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#taste" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The taste buds are stimulated only by chemical substances in solution and therefore dry foods stimulate the sense of taste only after thorough mixing with saliva. The senses of taste and smell are closely linked and involved in the enjoyment, or otherwise, of food (see Figs 1.5 and 8.25).</p>
<ul>
<li>SPOT CHECK</li>
</ul>
<ol start="4">
<li>Outline the functions of the two enzymes in saliva.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="oesophagus">Oesophagus<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#oesophagus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="learning-outcomes">Learning outcomes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#learning-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pharynx">Pharynx<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pharynx" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe the location of the oesophagus</li>
<li>outline the structure of the oesophagus</li>
<li>explain the mechanisms involved in swallowing,
and the route taken by a bolus.
After studying this section, you should be able to: describe the structure of the pharynx.</li>
</ul>
<p>The oesophagus (Fig. 12.14) is about 25 cm long and about 2 cm in diameter; it lies in the median plane in the thorax in front of the vertebral column and behind the trachea and the heart. It is continuous with the pharynx above, and just</p>
<p>The pharynx is divided for descriptive purpose into three parts: the nasopharynx, oropharynx and laryngopharynx (p. 264). The nasopharynx is important in respiration. The
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo><mover><mo><mo>+</mo></mo><mn>1</mn></mover></mo><mo>+</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\stackrel{1}{+}+</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.4178em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mrel"><span class="mop op-limits"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3344em;"><span style="top: -3em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span><span class="mop">+</span></span></span><span style="top: -3.7833em; margin-left: 0em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">â€‹</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.0833em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">+</span></span></span></span></span>
S</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-3317b35c.jpeg" alt="img-32.jpeg"></p>
<p>Oesophagus
oropharynx and laryngopharynx are passages common <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>âˆ§</mo><mo>âˆ§</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi><mo>âˆ§</mo><mo mathvariant="normal" lspace="0em" rspace="0em">âŸ¦</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\wedge \wedge \mathrm{T} \wedge \llbracket</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5556em;"></span><span class="mord">âˆ§</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">âˆ§</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">T</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">âˆ§</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen"><span class="mopen">[</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: -0.1778em;"></span><span class="mopen">[</span></span></span></span></span></span>
to both the respiratory and the digestive systems. Food w
passes from the oral cavity into the pharynx and then to the ' Trachea
oesophagus below, with which it is continuous. The walls of the pharynx consist of three layers of tissue.</p>
<p>The lining membrane (mucosa) is stratified squamous epithelium, continuous with the lining of the mouth at one end and the oesophagus at the other. This provides a thick,
sturdy lining well suited to the wear and tear of swallowing bronchus__ - Left
ingested food. bronchus
The middle layer consists of connective tissue, which becomes thinner towards the lower end and contains blood and lymph vessels and nerves.
rT.1t <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>âˆ§</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\wedge</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5556em;"></span><span class="mord">âˆ§</span></span></span></span></span>-Thoracic</p>
<p>The outer layer consists of involuntary muscles that are
involved in swallowing. When food reaches the pharynx,</p>
<p>swallowing becomes reflexive, i.e. is no longer under
voluntary control.</p>
<p>T8</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="blood-supply">Blood supply<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blood-supply" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The blood supply to the pharynx is by several branches of the facial arteries.
Venous drainage is into the facial veins and the internal jugular veins.
Inferior vena cava</p>

<p>Diaphragm</p>

<li>SPOT CHECK</li>
</ul>
<ol start="5">
<li>Name the regions of the pharynx that form part of the digestive tract.</li>
</ol>
<p>Figure 12.14 The oesophagus and some related structures.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-01fb558f.jpeg" alt="img-33.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 12.15 The muscles used in chewing.
below the diaphragm it joins the stomach. It passes between muscle fibres of the diaphragm behind the central tendon at the level of the 10th thoracic vertebra. Immediately the oesophagus has passed through the diaphragm it curves upwards, before opening into the stomach. This sharp angle is believed to be one of the factors that prevents the regurgitation (backflow) of gastric contents into the oesophagus. The upper and lower ends of the oesophagus are closed by sphincters. The upper oesophageal sphincter prevents the passage of air into the oesophagus during inspiration, and the aspiration of oesophageal contents. The lower oesophageal (cardiac) sphincter (see Figs 12.14 and 12.18) prevents the reflux of acid gastric contents into the oesophagus. There is no thickening of the circular muscle in this area and this sphincter is therefore 'physiological', i.e. this region can act as a sphincter without the presence of the anatomical features. When intraabdominal pressure is raised, e.g. during inspiration and defaecation, the tone of the lower oesophageal sphincter increases. There is an added pinching effect by the contracting muscle fibres of the diaphragm. Q 12.1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="structure">Structure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#structure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>There are four layers of tissue, as shown in Fig. 12.2. As the oesophagus is almost entirely in the thorax, the outer covering, the adventitia, consists of elastic fibrous tissue that attaches the oesophagus to the surrounding structures. The proximal third is lined by stratified squamous epithelium for protection during swallowing, and the distal third by columnar epithelium. The middle third is lined by a mixture of the two.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="blood-supply-arterial-supply">Blood supply Arterial supply<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blood-supply-arterial-supply" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The thoracic region is supplied mainly by the paired oesophageal arteries, branches from the thoracic aorta. The abdominal region is supplied by branches from the inferior phrenic arteries and the left gastric branch of the coeliac artery.</p>
<p>Venous drainage
From the thoracic region venous drainage is into the azygos and hemiazygos veins. The abdominal part drains into the left gastric vein. There is a venous plexus at the</p>
<p>distal end that links the upward and downward venous drainage, i.e. the general and portal circulations.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="functions-of-the-mouth-pharynx-and-oesophagus">Functions of the mouth, pharynx and oesophagus<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions-of-the-mouth-pharynx-and-oesophagus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Formation of a bolus
When food is taken into the mouth, it is chewed (masticated) by the teeth and moved around the mouth by the tongue
and muscles of the cheeks (Fig. 12.15). It is mixed with saliva and formed into a soft mass, or bolus, ready for swallowing. The length of time that food remains in the mouth largely depends on the consistency of the food. Some foods need to be chewed longer than others before the individual feels that the bolus is ready for swallowing. 12.2</p>
<p>Swallowing (deglutition) <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">â–¡</mi><mn>12.3</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\square 12.3</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.675em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">â–¡</span><span class="mord">12.3</span></span></span></span></span>
Swallowing (Fig. 12.16) occurs in three stages after chewing is complete and the bolus has been formed. It is initiated voluntarily but completed by a reflex (involuntary) action.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-oral-stage">1. Oral stage<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-oral-stage" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>With the mouth closed, the voluntary muscles of the tongue and cheeks push the bolus backwards into the pharynx.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-pharyngeal-stage">2. Pharyngeal stage<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-pharyngeal-stage" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The muscles of the pharynx are stimulated by a reflex action initiated in the walls of the oropharynx and coordinated by the swallowing centre in the medulla. Involuntary contraction of these muscles propels the bolus down into the oesophagus. All other routes that the bolus could take are closed. The soft palate rises up and closes off the nasopharynx; the tongue and the pharyngeal folds block the way back into the mouth; and the larynx is lifted up and forwards so that its opening is occluded by the overhanging epiglottis, preventing entry into the airway (trachea).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-oesophageal-stage">3. Oesophageal stage<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-oesophageal-stage" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The presence of the bolus in the pharynx stimulates a wave of peristalsis that propels the bolus through the oesophagus to the stomach.</p>
<p>Peristaltic waves pass along the oesophagus only after swallowing begins (see Fig. 12.4). Otherwise the walls are</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-85975fd9.jpeg" alt="img-34.jpeg"></p>
<p>Soft palate blocks nasopharynx
Pharynx
Soft palate relaxes
Bolus in oesophagus
Nasal cavity
Bolus of food on tongue
Tongue
Larynx
Trachea
Oesophagus
Epiglottis occludes opening into larynx
Tongue blocks oral cavity
Bolus in oropharynx</p>
<p>Figure 12.16 The three stages of swallowing.
relaxed. Ahead of a peristaltic wave, the lower oesophageal sphincter guarding the entrance to the stomach relaxes to allow the descending bolus to pass into the stomach. Usually, constriction of the lower oesophageal sphincter prevents reflux of gastric acid into the oesophagus. Other factors preventing gastric reflux include:</p>
<ul>
<li>the attachment of the stomach to the diaphragm by the peritoneum</li>
<li>the acute angle formed by the position of the oesophagus as it enters the fundus of the stomach, i.e. an acute cardio-oesophageal angle (see Fig. 12.18)</li>
<li>increased tone of the cardiac sphincter when intra-abdominal pressure is increased, and the pinching effect of diaphragm muscle fibres.</li>
</ul>
<p>The walls of the oesophagus are lubricated by mucus, which assists the passage of the bolus during the peristaltic contraction of the muscular wall.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="i-spot-check">I # SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol start="6">
<li>List the stages of swallowing and indicate whether each is voluntary or involuntary.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="stomach">stomach<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#stomach" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe the location of the stomach with reference to surrounding structures</li>
<li>explain the physiological significance of the layers of the stomach wall</li>
<li>discuss the digestive functions of the stomach.</li>
</ul>
<p>The stomach (Fig. 12.17) is a J-shaped dilated portion of the alimentary tract situated in the epigastric, umbilical and left hypochondriac regions of the abdominal cavity.</p>
<p>Organs associated with the stomach
Anteriorly - left lobe of liver and anterior abdominal wall. Posteriorly - abdominal aorta, pancreas, spleen, left kidney and adrenal gland.</p>
<p>Superiorly - diaphragm, oesophagus and left lobe of liver. Inferiorly - transverse colon and small intestine.</p>
<p>To the left - diaphragm and spleen.
To the right - liver and duodenum.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="structure">Structure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#structure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The stomach is continuous with the oesophagus at the lower oesophageal sphincter and with the duodenum at the pyloric sphincter (Fig. 12.18). It has two curvatures. The lesser curvature is short, lies on the posterior surface of the stomach and is the downward continuation of the posterior wall of the oesophagus. Just before the pyloric sphincter it curves upwards to complete the J shape. Where the oesophagus joins the stomach the anterior region angles acutely upwards, curves downwards forming the greater curvature and then slightly upwards towards the pyloric sphincter.</p>
<p>The stomach is divided into three regions:</p>
<ul>
<li>the fundus</li>
<li>the body</li>
<li>the pylorus.</li>
</ul>
<p>At the distal end of the pylorus is the pyloric sphincter, guarding the opening between the stomach and the duodenum. When the stomach is inactive the pyloric sphincter is relaxed and open, and when the stomach contains food the sphincter is closed.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-71f36f6f.jpeg" alt="img-35.jpeg"></p>
<p>Liver
Inferior vena cava Right adrenal gland
Right kidney Head of pancreas</p>
<p>Duodenum
Diaphragm (cut edge)
Oesophagus
Spleen
Stomach
Left adrenal gland Abdominal aorta Transverse colon (cut) Left kidney
Descending colon Beginning of jejunum
Figure 12.17 The stomach and its associated structures.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-0ba35f1a.jpeg" alt="img-36.jpeg"></p>
<p>Duodenum Pylorus Rugae Greater curvature
Oesophagus
Lower oesophageal (cardiac) sphincter
Lesser cu
Fundus
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-46122db5.jpeg" alt="img-37.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 12.18 Longitudinal section of the stomach.
Figure 12.19 Muscle layers of the stomach wall.
Walls of the stomach
The four layers of tissue that comprise the basic structure of the alimentary canal (see Fig. 12.2) are found in the stomach but with some modifications.</p>
<p>Muscle layer
This consists of three layers of smooth muscle fibres (Fig. 12.19):</p>
<ul>
<li>an outer layer of longitudinal fibres</li>
<li>a middle layer of circular fibres</li>
<li>an inner layer of oblique fibres.</li>
</ul>
<p>In this respect the stomach is different from other regions of the alimentary tract, as it has three layers of muscle instead of two. This arrangement allows for the churning action characteristic of gastric activity, as well as peristaltic movement. Circular muscle is strongest between the pylorus and the pyloric sphincter.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-69bb5433.jpeg" alt="img-38.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 12.20 The entrance to a gastric gland. Coloured scanning electron micrograph of the mucous membrane lining the stomach. (Professors PM Motta, KR Porter and PM Andrews/Science Photo Library. Reproduced with permission.)</p>
<p>Mucosa
When the stomach is empty the mucous membrane lining is thrown into longitudinal folds or rugae, and when full the rugae are 'ironed out', giving the surface a smooth, velvety appearance. Numerous gastric glands are situated below the surface in the mucous membrane and open on to it (Fig. 12.20). They contain specialised cells, including chief cells and parietal cells which secrete constituents of gastric juice into the stomach as well as enteroendocrine cells (see next section).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="blood-supply">Blood supply<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blood-supply" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Arterial supply to the stomach is by the left gastric artery, a branch of the coeliac artery, the right gastric artery and the gastroepiploic arteries. Venous drainage is through veins of corresponding names into the portal vein. Figs 5.36 and 5.38 show these vessels.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="gastric-juice-and-functions-of-the-stomach">Gastric juice and functions of the stomach<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gastric-juice-and-functions-of-the-stomach" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Stomach size varies with the volume of food it contains, which may be 1.5 litres or more in an adult. After a meal food accumulates in the stomach in layers, the last part of the meal remaining in the fundus for some time. Mixing with the gastric juice takes place gradually and it may be some time before the food is sufficiently acidified to stop the action of salivary amylase.</p>
<p>The gastric muscle generates a churning action that breaks down the bolus and mixes it with gastric juice. Peristaltic waves in the stomach wall propel the contents towards the
pylorus. When the stomach is active the pyloric sphincter closes. Strong peristaltic contraction of the pylorus forces chyme, gastric contents after they are sufficiently liquefied, through the pyloric sphincter into the duodenum in small spurts.
Parasympathetic stimulation increases the motility of the stomach and secretion of gastric juice; sympathetic stimulation has the opposite effect. EÂ»12.4</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="gastric-juice">Gastric juice<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gastric-juice" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>About 2 litres of gastric juice are secreted daily by specialised secretory glands in the mucosa (Fig. 12.21). It consists of:</p>
<ul>
<li>water</li>
<li>mineral salts</li>
<li>mucus secreted by mucous neck cells in the glands and surface mucous cells on the stomach surface</li>
<li>hydrochloric acid secreted by parietal cells</li>
<li>intrinsic factor in the gastric glands</li>
<li>inactive enzyme precursors - pepsinogens secreted by chief cells in the glands.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="functions-of-gastric-juice">Functions of gastric juice<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions-of-gastric-juice" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Water further liquefies the food swallowed.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Hydrochloric acid:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>acidifies the food and stops the action of salivary amylase</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>kills ingested microbes</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>provides the acid environment needed for the action of pepsins.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Pepsinogens are activated to pepsins by hydrochloric acid and by pepsins already present in the stomach.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>These enzymes begin the digestion of proteins, breaking them into smaller molecules. Pepsins have evolved to act most effectively at a very low pH , between 1.5 and 3.5 .</p>
<ul>
<li>Intrinsic factor (a protein) is necessary for the absorption of vitamin B 12 from the ileum. (Deficiency leads to pernicious anaemia, p. 74.)</li>
<li>Mucus prevents mechanical injury to the stomach wall by lubricating the contents. It also prevents chemical injury by acting as a barrier between the stomach wall and the highly corrosive gastric juice; hydrochloric acid is present in potentially damaging concentrations and pepsins would digest the gastric tissues.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="secretion-of-gastric-juice">Secretion of gastric juice<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#secretion-of-gastric-juice" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>There is always a small quantity of gastric juice present in the stomach, even when it contains no food. This is known as fasting juice. Secretion reaches its maximum level about 1 hour after a meal, then declines to the fasting level after about 4 hours.</p>
<p>There are three phases of secretion of gastric juice (Fig. 12.22).
Gastric
glands
A</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-5b24ff57.jpeg" alt="img-39.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 12.21 Structure of the gastric mucosa showing gastric glands. (A) Diagram. (B) Stained section of the pyloric region of the stomach (magnified x 150). (B, Telser AG, Young JK, Baldwin KM 2007 Elsevier's integrated histology. Edinburgh: Mosby. Reproduced with permission.)</p>
<p>Food in stomach stimulates secretion of hormone</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="gastrin">GASTRIN<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gastrin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Bloodstream j</p>
<p>Gastric phase

<p>G
Intestinal phase
Figure 12.22 The three phases of secretion of gastric juice.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="1-cephalic-phase">1. Cephalic phase<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-cephalic-phase" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This flow of juice occurs before food reaches the stomach and is due to reflex stimulation of the vagus (parasympathetic) nerves, initiated by the sight, smell, taste or thought of food. Sympathetic stimulation, e.g. during emotional states, inhibits gastric activity.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-gastric-phase">2. Gastric phase<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-gastric-phase" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>When stimulated by the presence of food, the enteroendocrine cells in the pylorus (see Fig. 12.21) and duodenum secrete the hormone gastrin directly into the circulating blood. Gastrin, circulating in the blood that supplies the stomach, stimulates the gastric glands to produce more gastric juice. In this way, secretion of digestive juice is continued after completion of a meal and the end of the cephalic phase. Gastrin secretion is suppressed when the pH in the pylorus falls to about 1.5.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-intestinal-phase">3. Intestinal phase<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-intestinal-phase" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>When the partially digested contents of the stomach reach the small intestine, two hormones, secretin and cholecystokinin (CCK), are produced by endocrine cells in the intestinal mucosa. They slow down the secretion of gastric juice and reduce gastric motility. By slowing the emptying rate of the stomach, the chyme in the duodenum becomes more thoroughly mixed with bile and pancreatic juice. This phase of gastric secretion is most marked following a meal with a high fat content.</p>
<p>The rate at which the stomach empties depends largely on the type of food eaten. A carbohydrate meal leaves the stomach in 2-3 hours, a protein meal remains for longer and a fatty meal remains in the stomach for longest.</p>
<p>Functions of the stomach
These include:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Temporary storage - allows time for the digestive enzymes, pepsins, to act.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Chemical digestion - pepsins break proteins into polypeptides.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Mechanical breakdown - the three smooth muscle layers enable the stomach to act as a churn, gastric juice is added and the contents are liquefied to chyme. Gastric motility and secretion are increased by parasympathetic nerve stimulation.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Limited absorption - water, alcohol and some lipid-soluble drugs.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Non-specific defence against microbes - provided by hydrochloric acid in gastric juice. Vomiting (see Table 12.4) may occur in response to ingestion of gastric irritants, e.g. microbes or chemicals.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Preparation of iron for absorption - the acid environment of the stomach solubilises iron salts, essential for iron absorption in the small intestine.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Production and secretion of intrinsic factor - needed for absorption of vitamin B 12 in the terminal ileum.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Regulation of the passage of gastric contents into the duodenum - when the chyme is sufficiently acidified and liquefied, the pylorus forces small jets of gastric contents through the pyloric sphincter into the duodenum. The sphincter is normally closed, preventing backflow of chyme into the stomach.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Secretion of the hormone gastrin (see earlier).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="8fd23025">â– ãƒ»SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#8fd23025" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol start="7">
<li>Outline the functions of mucus secreted by mucous neck cells in the gastric glands.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="small-intestine">Small intestine<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#small-intestine" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe the location of the small intestine, with reference to surrounding structures</li>
<li>sketch a villus, labelling its component parts</li>
<li>discuss the digestive functions of the small intestine and its secretions</li>
<li>explain how nutrients are absorbed in the small intestine.</li>
</ul>
<p>The small intestine (Figs 12.23 and 12.24) is continuous with the stomach at the pyloric sphincter. The small intestine is about 2.5 cm in diameter and a little over 5 metres long; it leads into the large intestine at the ileocaecal valve. It lies in the</p>
<p>abdominal cavity, surrounded by the large intestine. In the small intestine the chemical digestion of food is completed and absorption of most nutrients takes place. The small intestine is comprised of three continuous parts.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="duodenum">Duodenum<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#duodenum" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is about 25 cm long and curves around the head of the pancreas. Secretions from the gall bladder and pancreas merge in a common structure - the hepatopancreatic ampulla - and enter the duodenum at the duodenal papilla. The duodenal papilla is guarded by a ring of smooth muscle, the hepatopancreatic sphincter (of Oddi) (see Fig. 12.38).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="jejunum">Jejunum<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#jejunum" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is the middle section of the small intestine and is about 2 metres long.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ileum">Ileum<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ileum" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This terminal section is about 3 metres long and ends at the ileocaecal valve (see Fig. 12.30), which controls the flow of
