material from the ileum to the caecum, the first part of the large intestine, and prevents backflow.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="structure">Structure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#structure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The walls of the small intestine are composed of the four layers of tissue shown in Fig. 12.2. Some modifications of the peritoneum and mucosa (mucous membrane lining) are described below.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="peritoneum">Peritoneum<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#peritoneum" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The mesentery, a double layer of peritoneum, attaches the jejunum and ileum to the posterior abdominal wall (see Fig. 12.3 A). The attachment is quite short in comparison with the length of the small intestine; it is therefore fan-shaped. The large blood vessels and nerves lie on the posterior abdominal wall and the branches to the small intestine pass between the two layers of the mesentery.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mucosa">Mucosa<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mucosa" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The surface area of the small intestine mucosa is greatly increased by permanent circular folds, villi and microvilli.</p>
<p>The permanent circular folds, unlike the rugae of the stomach, are not smoothed out when the small intestine is distended (Fig. 12.25). They promote mixing of chyme as it passes along.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-085ff0c3.jpeg" alt="img-45.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 12.26 Villi. (A) A highly magnified diagram of one oomplete villus in the small intestine. (B) Coloured scanning electron micrograph showing many villi. (B, Eye of Science/Science Photo Library. Reproduced with permission.)</p>
<p>The villi are tiny finger-like projections of the mucosal layer into the intestinal lumen, about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>0.5</mn><mo>âˆ’</mo><mn>1</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">0.5-1 \mathrm{~mm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">0.5</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">âˆ’</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span></span></span></span></span> long (Fig. 12.26). Their covering consists of columnar epithelial cells, or enterocytes, with tiny microvilli ( 1 pm long) on their free border. Goblet cells (see Fig. 12.5), which secrete mucus, are
interspersed between the enterocytes. The villi contain a network of blood capillaries and a central lymph capillary. Lymph capillaries are called lacteals because absorbed fat gives the lymph a milky appearance. Absorption and some final stages of digestion of nutrients take place in the enterocytes before entering the blood and lymph capillaries. a 12.5</p>
<p>The intestinal glands are simple tubular glands situated below the surface between the villi. The epithelial cells of these glands migrate upwards to form the walls of the villi, replacing those at the tips as they are rubbed off by the passage of intestinal contents. The entire epithelium is replaced every 3-5 days. During migration, epithelial cells produce digestive enzymes that lodge in the microvilli and, together with intestinal juice, complete the chemical digestion of carbohydrates, protein and fats.</p>
<p>Numerous lymph nodes are found in the mucosa at irregular intervals throughout the length of the small intestine. The smaller ones are known as solitary lymphatic follicles, and collections of about 20-30 larger nodes situated towards the distal end of the ileum are called aggregated lymphatic follicles (Peyer's patches, see Fig. 12.25). These lymphatic tissues, packed with defensive cells, are strategically located to neutralise ingested antigens (Ch. 15).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="blood-supply">Blood supply<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blood-supply" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The superior mesenteric artery supplies the whole of the small intestine. Venous drainage is by the superior mesenteric vein, which joins other veins to form the portal vein (see Figs 5.38 and 5.39). The portal vein contains a high concentration of absorbed nutrients; this blood passes through the liver before entering the hepatic veins and, ultimately, the inferior vena cava (see Fig. 12.36).</p>
<p>Intestinal juice
About 1500 mL of intestinal juice are secreted daily by the glands of the small intestine. It is slightly basic (alkaline) and consists of water, lubricating mucus and bicarbonate to neutralise gastric acid. Control of secretion of intestinal juice is poorly understood. Mechanical stimulation of the intestinal glands is believed to be the main stimulus, although hormones may also be involved. Unlike other parts of the digestive tract, enzymes are not secreted into intestinal juice but are found and act within the enterocytes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="functions">Functions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These are:</p>
<ul>
<li>onward movement of its contents by peristalsis, which is increased by parasympathetic stimulation</li>
<li>secretion of intestinal juice, also increased by parasympathetic stimulation</li>
<li>completion of chemical digestion of carbohydrates, protein and fats in the enterocytes of the villi
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-a2a112cd.jpeg" alt="img-46.jpeg"></li>
<li>protection against infection by microbes that have survived the antimicrobial action of the hydrochloric acid in the stomach, by both solitary and aggregated lymph follicles</li>
<li>secretion of the hormones CCK and secretin</li>
<li>absorption of nutrients.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="chemical-digestion-in-the-small-intestine">Chemical digestion in the small intestine<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chemical-digestion-in-the-small-intestine" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>When acid chyme passes into the small intestine it is mixed with pancreatic juice, bile and intestinal juice, and is in contact with the absorptive enterocytes of the villi. The digestion of all nutrients is completed:</p>
<ul>
<li>Carbohydrates are broken down to monosaccharides.</li>
<li>Proteins are broken down to amino acids.</li>
<li>Fats are broken down to fatty acids and glycerol.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pancreatic-juice">Pancreatic juice<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pancreatic-juice" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Pancreatic juice is secreted by the exocrine pancreas (p.336) and enters the duodenum at the duodenal papilla. It consists of:</p>
<ul>
<li>water</li>
<li>mineral salts</li>
<li>enzymes:</li>
<li>amylase</li>
<li>lipase</li>
<li>nucleases that digest the nucleic acids, DNA and RNA</li>
<li>inactive enzyme precursors including:</li>
<li>trypsinogen</li>
<li>chymotrypsinogen.</li>
</ul>
<p>Pancreatic juice is basic (alkaline, pH 8 ) because it contains significant quantities of bicarbonate ions, which are basic (alkaline) in solution. When acid stomach contents enter the duodenum they are mixed with pancreatic juice and bile, and the pH is raised to between 6 and 8 . This is the pH at which the pancreatic enzymes, amylase and lipase, act most effectively.</p>
<p>Functions Digestion of proteins
Trypsinogen and chymotrypsinogen are inactive enzyme precursors activated by enterokinase, an enzyme in the microvilli, which converts them into the active</p>
<p>proteolytic enzymes trypsin and chymotrypsin. These enzymes break polypeptides down into tripeptides, dipeptides and amino acids. It is important for them to be produced as inactive precursors and they are activated only on their arrival in the duodenum; otherwise they would digest the pancreas.</p>
<p>Digestion of carbohydrates
Pancreatic amylase converts all digestible polysaccharides (starches) not acted on by salivary amylase to disaccharides.</p>
<p>Digestion of fats
Lipase converts fats to fatty acids and glycerol. To aid the action of lipase, bile salts emulsify fats, i.e. reduce the size of the globules, increasing their surface area.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="control-of-secretion">Control of secretion<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#control-of-secretion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The secretion of pancreatic juice is stimulated by secretin and CCK, produced by endocrine cells in the walls of the duodenum. The presence in the duodenum of acid chyme from the stomach stimulates the production of these hormones (see Fig. 12.22).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bile">Bile<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bile" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Bile, secreted by the liver, is unable to enter the duodenum when the hepatopancreatic sphincter is closed; it therefore passes from the hepatic duct along the cystic duct to the gall bladder, where it is stored (see Fig. 12.38).</p>
<p>Bile has a pH of around 8 and between 500 and 1000 mL is secreted daily. It consists of:</p>
<ul>
<li>water</li>
<li>mineral salts</li>
<li>mucus</li>
<li>bile salts</li>
<li>bile pigments, mainly bilirubin</li>
<li>cholesterol.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="functions">Functions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The functions of bile are explained further on page 339. In summary, these are:</p>
<ul>
<li>emulsification of fats in the small intestine - bile salts</li>
<li>making cholesterol and fatty acids soluble, enabling their absorption along with the fat-soluble vitamins - bile salts</li>
<li>excretion of bilirubin (a waste product from the breakdown of red blood cells), most of which is in the form of stercobilin.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="release-from-the-gall-bladder">Release from the gall bladder<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#release-from-the-gall-bladder" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>After a meal, the duodenum secretes the hormones secretin and CCK during the intestinal phase of gastric secretion (p. 328). They stimulate contraction of the gall bladder and relaxation of the hepatopancreatic sphincter, expelling both bile and pancreatic juice through the duodenal papilla into the duodenum. Secretion is markedly increased when chyme entering the duodenum contains a high proportion of fat.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="chemical-digestion-in-enterocytes">Chemical digestion in enterocytes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chemical-digestion-in-enterocytes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Most of the digestive enzymes in the small intestine are contained in the enterocytes of the epithelium that covers the villi. Digestion of carbohydrate, protein and fat is completed
by direct contact between these nutrients and the microvilli and within the enterocytes.</p>
<p>Alkaline intestinal juice ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mn>7.8</mn><mo>âˆ’</mo><mn>8.0</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{pH} 7.8-8.0</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8778em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">pH</span></span><span class="mord">7.8</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">âˆ’</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">8.0</span></span></span></span></span> ) assists in raising the pH of the intestinal contents to between 6.5 and 7.5. The enzymes that complete chemical digestion of food at the surface of the enter ocytes are:</p>
<ul>
<li>peptidases</li>
<li>lipase</li>
<li>sucrase, maltase and lactase.</li>
</ul>
<p>Peptidases such as trypsin break down polypeptides into smaller peptides and amino acids. Peptidases are secreted in an inactive form from the pancreas (to prevent them from digesting it) and must be activated by enterokinase in the duodenum.</p>
<p>The final stage of breakdown of all peptides to amino acids takes place at the surface of the enterocytes.</p>
<p>Lipase completes the digestion of emulsified fats to fatty acids and glycerol in the intestine.</p>
<p>Sucrase, maltase and lactase complete the digestion of carbohydrates by splitting disaccharides such as sucrose, maltose and lactose into monosaccharides at the surface of the enterocytes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="control-of-secretion">Control of secretion<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#control-of-secretion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This process is poorly understood. Mechanical stimulation of the intestinal glands by chyme is believed to be the main stimulus for the secretion of intestinal juice, although hormones may also be involved.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="absorption-of-nutrients">Absorption of nutrients<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#absorption-of-nutrients" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Absorption of nutrients from the small intestine through the enterocytes occurs by several processes (Fig. 12.27), including diffusion, osmosis, facilitated diffusion and active transport. Water moves by osmosis; small fat-soluble substances, e.g. fatty acids and glycerol, are able to diffuse through cell membranes; and others are generally transported inside the villi by other mechanisms.</p>
<p>Monosaccharides and amino acids are actively cotransported with sodium ions into the blood capillaries in the villi. Fatty acids and glycerol diffuse into the lacteals and are transported along lymphatic vessels to the thoracic duct, where they enter the circulation (Ch. 6).</p>
<p>A small number of proteins and other large substances are absorbed unchanged, e.g. antibodies present in breast milk and oral vaccines, such as poliomyelitis vaccine.</p>
<p>Other nutrients, such as vitamins, mineral salts and water, are also absorbed from the small intestine into the blood capillaries. Fat-soluble vitamins are absorbed into the lacteals along with fatty acids and glycerol. Vitamin B 12 combines with intrinsic factor in the stomach and is actively absorbed in the terminal ileum.</p>
<p>Lumen of intestine
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-97bb19c1.jpeg" alt="img-47.jpeg"></p>
<p>Lymph from lacteal Blood in
containing fat capillaries
Figure 12.27 The absorption of nutrients into villi.</p>
<p>The surface area through which absorption takes place in the small intestine is greatly increased by the circular folds of mucous membrane and by the very large number of villi and microvilli present (see Fig. 12.26). It has been calculated that the surface area of the small intestine is about five times that of the whole body surface.</p>
<p>Large amounts of fluid enter the alimentary tract each day (Fig. 12.28). Of this, only about 1500 mL is not absorbed by the small intestine and passes into the large intestine.</p>
<ul>
<li>SPOT CHECK</li>
</ul>
<ol start="8">
<li>Name the valves found at each end of the small intestine.</li>
<li>Relate the structure of the villus to its functions.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="f50f5989"><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">F</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{N}_{2} \mathrm{~F}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">N</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">â€‹</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">F</span></span></span></span></span></span><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#f50f5989" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Saliva ( 1500 mL<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>
Water ( 1200 mL<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>
Gastric juice ( 2000 mL<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>
Bile
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>500</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(500 \mathrm{~mL})</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">500</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">mL</span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>
Pancreatic juice ( 1500 mL<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>
Intestinal juice ( 1500 mL<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>
Into GI tract</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-77af78bf.jpeg" alt="img-48.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 12.28 Average volumes of fluid ingested, secreted, absorbed and eliminated from the gastrointestinal <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">G</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(\mathrm{Gl})</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Gl</span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> tract daily.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="large-intestine-rectum-and-anal-canal">Large intestine, rectum and anal canal<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#large-intestine-rectum-and-anal-canal" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>identify the different sections of the large intestine</li>
<li>describe the structure and functions of the large intestine, the rectum and the anal canal.</li>
</ul>
<p>The large intestine is about 1.5 metres long, beginning at the caecum in the right iliac fossa and terminating at the rectum and anal canal. Its lumen is about 6.5 cm in diameter, larger than that of the small intestine. It forms an arch round the coiled-up small intestine (Fig. 12.29).</p>
<p>For descriptive purposes the large intestine is divided into the caecum, colon, rectum and anal canal.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="caecum">Caecum<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#caecum" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is the first part of the large intestine (Fig. 12.30). It is a dilated region that has a blind end interiorly and is continuous with the ascending colon superiorly. Just below the junction of the two, the ileocaecal valve opens from the ileum. The vermiform appendix (meaning 'worm-like', and often known simply as 'the appendix') is a fine tube, closed at one end, which leads from the caecum. It is about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>8</mn><mo>âˆ’</mo><mn>9</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">8-9 \mathrm{~cm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">8</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">âˆ’</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">9</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">cm</span></span></span></span></span></span> long and has the same structure as the walls of the large intestine but contains more lymphoid tissue. The appendix has no digestive function but can cause significant problems when it becomes inflamed (appendicitis, p. 354).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="colon">Colon<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#colon" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The colon has four parts, which have the same structure and functions:</p>
<ul>
<li>The ascending colon passes upwards from the caecum to the level of the liver, where it curves acutely to the left at the hepatic flexure to become the transverse colon.</li>
<li>The transverse colon extends across the abdominal cavity in front of the duodenum and the stomach to the area of the spleen, where it forms the splenic flexure and curves acutely downwards to become the descending colon.</li>
<li>The descending colon passes down the left side of the abdominal cavity, then curves towards the midline.</li>
</ul>
<p>At the level of the iliac crest it is known as the sigmoid colon.</p>
<ul>
<li>The sigmoid colon is an S-shaped curve in the pelvic cavity that continues downwards to become the rectum.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="rectum">Rectum<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rectum" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is a slightly dilated section of the large intestine and is about 13 cm long. It leads from the sigmoid colon and terminates in the anal canal.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="anal-canal">Anal canal<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#anal-canal" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is a short passage about 3.8 cm long in the adult and leads from the rectum to the exterior. Two muscular sphincters control the anus: the internal sphincter, consisting of smooth muscle, is under the control of the autonomic nervous system, and the external sphincter, formed by skeletal muscle, is under voluntary control (Fig. 12.31). <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">â–¡</mi><mn>12.6</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\square 12.6</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.675em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">â–¡</span><span class="mord">12.6</span></span></span></span></span></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="structure">Structure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#structure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The four layers of tissue described in the basic structure of the gastrointestinal tract (see Fig. 12.2) are present in the caecum, colon, rectum and anal canal. The arrangement of the longitudinal muscle fibres is modified in the caecum and colon. They do not form a continuous layer of tissue but are
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-f5e7dc1d.jpeg" alt="img-49.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>Splenic flexure of colon</li>
</ul>
<p>Transverse

Descending

Hepatic flexure of colon

Rectum</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-1aec1439.jpeg" alt="img-50.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 12.29 The large intestine. (A) Its position in the abdominal cavity. (B) Visualised with barium (false colour X-ray image). (B, Alain Pol, ISM/ Science Photo Library. Reproduced with permission.)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-521f27bf.jpeg" alt="img-51.jpeg"></p>

<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-784884bd.jpeg" alt="img-52.jpeg"></p>
<p>Longitudinal fibres forming a continuous sheet

Figure 12.30 Interior of the caecum.
instead collected into three strips, called taeniae coli, which run lengthways along the caecum and colon. They stop at the junction of the sigmoid colon and the rectum. As these longitudinal strips of muscle tissue are slightly shorter than the total length of the caecum and colon, they give it a puckered appearance (see Fig. 12.31).</p>
<p>Figure 12.31 Arrangement of muscle fibres in the large intestine, rectum and anus. Sections have been removed to show the layers.</p>
<p>In the rectum the longitudinal muscle fibres spread out as in the basic structure and this layer therefore completely surrounds the rectum and anal canal. The anal sphincters are formed by thickening of the circular muscle layer.</p>
<p>In the submucosal layer there is more lymphoid tissue than in any other part of the alimentary tract, protecting against infection, by either resident or invading bacteria.</p>
<p>In the mucosal lining of the colon and the upper rectum there are large numbers of mucus-secreting goblet cells (see Fig. 12.5) within simple tubular glands. They are not present beyond the junction between the rectum and the anal canal. The mucus produced here lubricates the passage of the solid faeces through the remainder of the tract.</p>
<p>The membrane lining the anal canal consists of stratified squamous epithelium that is continuous with the mucous membrane lining of the rectum above and merges with the skin beyond the external anal sphincter. In the upper section of the anal canal the mucous membrane is arranged in 6-10 vertical folds, the anal columns. Each column contains a terminal branch of the superior rectal artery and vein.</p>
<p>Blood supply Arterial supply
This is mainly by the superior and inferior mesenteric arteries (see Fig. 5.37). The superior mesenteric artery supplies the caecum, ascending colon and most of the transverse colon. The inferior mesenteric artery supplies the remainder of the colon and the proximal part of the rectum. The middle and inferior rectal arteries, branches of the internal iliac arteries, supply the distal section of the rectum and the anus.</p>
<p>Venous drainage
This is mainly by the superior and inferior mesenteric veins which drain blood from the parts supplied by arteries of the same names. These veins join the splenic and gastric veins to form the portal vein (see Fig. 5.39).</p>
<p>Veins draining the distal part of the rectum and the anus join the internal iliac veins, meaning that blood from this region returns directly to the inferior vena cava, bypassing the liver and portal circulation.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="functions">Functions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Absorption
The contents of the ileum that pass through the ileocaecal valve into the caecum are still fluid, even though a large amount of water has been absorbed in the small intestine. In the large intestine, absorption of water, by osmosis, continues until the familiar semisolid consistency of faeces is achieved. Mineral salts, vitamins and some drugs are also absorbed into blood capillaries from the large intestine.</p>
<p>Microbial activity
The large intestine is heavily colonised by certain types of bacteria, which synthesise vitamin K and folic acid. They include Escherichia coli, Enterobacter aerogenes, Streptococcus faecalis and Clostridium perfringens. These microbes are commensals, i.e. are normally harmless, in humans.</p>
<p>However, they may become pathogenic if transferred to another part of the body; for example, E. coli may cause cystitis (p. 389) if it gains access to the urinary bladder.</p>
<p>Gases in the bowel consist of some of the constituents of air, mainly nitrogen, swallowed with food and drink. Hydrogen, carbon dioxide and methane are produced by bacterial fermentation of unabsorbed nutrients, especially carbohydrate. Gases pass out of the bowel as flatus (wind).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mass-movement">Mass movement<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mass-movement" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The large intestine does not exhibit peristaltic movement as do other parts of the digestive tract. Only at fairly long intervals (4-6 times a day in adults) a wave of strong peristalsis sweeps along the transverse colon, forcing its contents into the descending and sigmoid colons. This is known as mass movement and it is often precipitated by the entry of food into the stomach. This combination of stimulus and response is called the gastrocolic reflex.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="defaecation">Defaecation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#defaecation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The rectum is usually empty, but when a mass movement forces the contents of the sigmoid colon into the rectum the nerve endings in its walls are stimulated by stretch. In infants, defaecation occurs by reflex (involuntary) action. However, during the second or third year of life, children develop voluntary control of bowel function. In practical terms, this acquired voluntary control means that the brain can inhibit the reflex until it is convenient to defaecate. The external anal sphincter is under conscious control through the pudendal nerve. Thus, defaecation involves involuntary contraction of the muscle of the rectum and relaxation of the internal anal sphincter. Contraction of the abdominal muscles and lowering of the diaphragm during a forced expiration (Valsalva's manoeuvre) increase the intra-</p>
<p>abdominal pressure and so assist defaecation. When the need to pass faeces is voluntarily postponed, it tends to fade until the next mass movement occurs and the reflex is initiated again. Repeated suppression of the reflex may lead to constipation (hard faeces) as more water is absorbed.</p>
<p>Constituents of faeces
The faeces consist of a semisolid brown mass. The brown colour is due to the presence of stercobilin (p. 339 and see Fig. 12.37).</p>
<p>Even though absorption of water takes place in the small and large intestines, water still makes up about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>60</mn><mo>âˆ’</mo><mn>70</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">60-70 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">60</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">âˆ’</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">70%</span></span></span></span></span> of the weight of the faeces. The remainder consists of:</p>
<ul>
<li>fibre (indigestible cellular plant and animal material)</li>
<li>dead and live microbes</li>
<li>epithelial cells shed from the walls of the tract</li>
<li>fatty acids</li>
<li>mucus secreted by the epithelial lining of the large intestine.</li>
</ul>
<p>Mucus helps to lubricate the faeces, and an adequate amount of dietary fibre, mainly non-starch polysaccharides (NSPs) and commonly known as 'roughage', ensures that the contents of the large intestine are sufficiently bulky to stimulate defaecation.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="5205029c">â–  SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5205029c" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol start="10">
<li>Name the parts of the large intestine.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pancreas">Pancreas<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pancreas" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Learning outcome
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>differentiate between the structures and functions of the exocrine and endocrine pancreas.</li>
</ul>
<p>The pancreas (Fig. 12.32) is a creamy pink gland weighing about 60 g . It is about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>12</mn><mo>âˆ’</mo><mn>15</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">12-15 \mathrm{~cm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">12</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">âˆ’</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">15</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">cm</span></span></span></span></span></span> long and is situated in the epigastric and left hypochondriac regions of the abdominal cavity (see Figs 1.25 and 1.26). It consists of a broad head, a body and a narrow tail. The head lies in the curve of the duodenum, the body behind the stomach, and the tail in front of the left kidney, just reaching the spleen. The abdominal aorta and the inferior vena cava lie behind the gland.</p>
<p>The pancreas is both an exocrine and an endocrine gland.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="exocrine-pancreas">Exocrine pancreas<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#exocrine-pancreas" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This consists of a large number of lobules made up of small acini, the walls of which are composed of secretory cells. Each lobule is drained by a tiny duct and these eventually unite to form the pancreatic duct, which extends along the whole length of the gland and opens into the duodenum. Just before entering the duodenum the pancreatic duct joins the common bile duct to form the hepatopancreatic ampulla. The duodenal opening of the ampulla is controlled by the hepatopancreatic sphincter (of Oddi) at the duodenal papilla.</p>
<p>The function of the exocrine pancreas is to produce pancreatic juice containing enzymes, some in the form of inactive precursors, which digest carbohydrates, proteins and fats. As in the alimentary tract, parasympathetic stimulation increases the secretion of pancreatic juice and sympathetic stimulation depresses it.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="endocrine-pancreas">Endocrine pancreas<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#endocrine-pancreas" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Distributed throughout the gland, in close proximity to the capillary networks, are groups of specialised cells called the pancreatic islets (of Langerhans). The islets have no ducts, so the hormones diffuse directly into the blood. The endocrine pancreas secretes the hormones insulin and glucagon, which are principally concerned with control of blood glucose levels (Ch. 9).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="blood-supply">Blood supply<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blood-supply" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The splenic and mesenteric arteries supply the pancreas, and venous drainage is by veins of the same names that join other veins to form the portal vein.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-37435769.jpeg" alt="img-53.jpeg"></p>
<p>Portal vein Hepatic artery Aorta

Figure 12.32 The pancreas in relation to the duodenunn and biliary tract. Part of the anterior wall of the duodenum has been removed.</p>
<p>I # SPOT CHECK
11. Describe how secretion of pancreatic juice is controlled.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="liver">Liver<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#liver" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe the location of the liver in the abdominal cavity</li>
<li>describe the structure of a liver lobule</li>
<li>outline the functions of the liver.</li>
</ul>
<p>The liver is the largest gland in the body; it is reddish brown in colour and weighs between 1 and 2.3 kg . Situated in the upper part of the abdominal cavity, it occupies the greater part of the right hypochondriac region and part of the epigastric region, and extends into the left hypochondriac
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-a64e28ce.jpeg" alt="img-54.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 12.33 The liver. Anterior view.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-bc8ac274.jpeg" alt="img-55.jpeg"></p>
<p>Duodenal impression Gall bladder Colic impression
Falciform ligament
Hepatic artery</p>
<p>Gastric impression
Right adrenal gland impression
Inferior vena cava
Portal vein
Common hepatic bile duct
Right renal impression
P
The liver is enclosed in a thin inelastic capsule and incompletely enclosed by a layer of peritoneum. Folds of peritoneum form supporting ligaments that attach the liver to the inferior surface of the diaphragm. It is held in position partly by these ligaments and partly by the pressure of the organs in the abdominal cavity.</p>
<p>The liver has four lobes. The two most obvious are the large right lobe and the smaller, wedge-shaped left lobe. The other two, the caudate and quadrate lobes, are areas on the posterior surface (Fig. 12.34).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="portal-fissure">Portal fissure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#portal-fissure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is the name given to the region on the posterior surface of the liver where various structures enter and leave the gland:</p>
<ul>
<li>The portal vein enters, carrying blood from the stomach, spleen, pancreas and small and large intestines. 12.7</li>
<li>The hepatic artery enters, carrying arterial blood. It is a branch from the coeliac artery, which branches from the abdominal aorta.</li>
<li>Nerve fibres, sympathetic and parasympathetic, enter here.</li>
<li>The right and left hepatic ducts leave, carrying bile from the liver to the gall bladder.</li>
<li>Lymph vessels leave the liver, draining lymph to abdominal and thoracic nodes.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="blood-supply">Blood supply<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blood-supply" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(See Figs 5.36 and 5.38.) The hepatic artery and the portal vein take blood to the liver (see Fig. 12.36). Venous return is by a variable number of hepatic veins that</p>
<p>leave the posterior surface and immediately enter the inferior vena cava just below the diaphragm.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="structure">Structure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#structure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Figure 12.34 The liver. Inferior view (turned up to show the posterior surface).
region. Its upper and anterior surfaces are smooth and
curved to fit the under-surface of the diaphragm (Fig. 12.33);
its posterior surface is irregular in outline (Fig. 12.34).
Organs associated with the liver
Superiorly and anteriorly - diaphragm and anterior abdominal wall.
Inferiorly - stomach, bile ducts, duodenum,
hepatic flexure of the colon, right kidney and adrenal gland.
Posteriorly - oesophagus, inferior vena cava,
aorta, gall bladder, vertebral column and diaphragm.
Laterally - lower ribs and diaphragm.
The lobes of the liver are made up of tiny functional units, called lobules, which are just visible to the naked eye (Fig. 12.35 A). Liver lobules are hexagonal in outline and are formed by cuboidal cells, the hepatocytes, arranged in pairs of columns radiating from a central vein. Between two pairs of columns of cells are sinusoids (blood vessels with incomplete walls, Ch. 5) containing a mixture of blood from the tiny branches of the portal vein and hepatic artery (Fig. 12.35B). This arrangement allows the arterial blood and portal venous blood (with a high concentration of nutrients) to mix and come into close contact with the liver cells. Among the cells lining the sinusoids are hepatic macrophages (Kupffer cells), whose function is to ingest and destroy worn-out blood cells and any foreign particles present in the blood flowing through the liver.</p>
<p>Blood drains from the sinusoids into central or centrilobular veins. These then merge with veins from other</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-e165e702.jpeg" alt="img-56.jpeg"></p>
<p>A Central vein Bile duct
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-f5276423.jpeg" alt="img-57.jpeg"></p>
<p>Central vein (branch of hepatic vein)
Hepatocytes
Hepatic macrophages (Kupffer cells)

Figure 12.35 The liver lobule. (A) A magnified transverse section of a liver lobule. (B) Direction of the flow of blood and bile in a liver lobule.

they become the hepatic veins, which leave the liver and
empty into the inferior vena cava. Fig. 12.36 shows the
system of blood flow through the liver. One of the functions</p>
<p>of the liver is to secrete bile. In Fig. 12.35B bile canaliculi (tiny

of liver cells. This means that each column of hepatocytes
has a blood sinusoid on one side and a bile canaliculus on
the other. The canaliculi join up to form larger bile canals 338

<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">âˆ’</mo></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{V}_{-}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8917em; vertical-align: -0.2083em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">V</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.2583em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0139em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">âˆ’</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">â€‹</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.2083em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>âˆ™</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\bullet \mathrm{c}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4445em;"></span><span class="mord">âˆ™</span><span class="mord mathrm">c</span></span></span></span></span>

Figure 12.36 Scheme of blood flow through the liver.</p>
<p>until eventually they form the right and left hepatic ducts, which drain bile from the liver. There is no mixing of the bile and the blood, and they are drained from the liver lobules separately.</p>
<p>Lymphoid tissue and a network of lymph vessels are also present in each lobule.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="functions">Functions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The liver is extremely active metabolically, with multiple interrelated functions, including metabolism of key nutrients, synthesis of many vital proteins, detoxification of unwanted chemicals and production of bile.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="carbohydrate-metabolism">Carbohydrate metabolism<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#carbohydrate-metabolism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The liver has an important role in maintaining plasma glucose levels. After a meal, when levels rise, glucose is converted to glycogen for storage under the influence of the hormone insulin. Later, when glucose levels fall, the hormone glucagon stimulates conversion of glycogen into glucose again, keeping levels within the normal range (see Fig. 12.39).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fat-metabolism">Fat metabolism<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fat-metabolism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Stored fat can be converted to a form in which it can be used by the tissues to provide energy (see Fig. 12.44).
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-cda30f7b.jpeg" alt="img-58.jpeg"></p>
<p>Protein metabolism Deamination of amino acids
This process:</p>
<ul>
<li>removes the nitrogenous portion from excess amino acids; urea is formed from this nitrogenous portion and is excreted in urine</li>
<li>breaks down nucleic acids (genetic material, e.g. DNA, p. 477) to form uric acid, which is excreted in the urine.</li>
</ul>
<p>Transamination</p>
<p>This process removes the nitrogenous portion of amino acids and attaches it to other carbohydrate molecules, forming new non-essential amino acids (see Fig. 12.42).</p>
<p>Synthesis of plasma proteins
The liver produces <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>90</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">90 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">90%</span></span></span></span></span> of the plasma proteins contained in the bloodstream, including albumins, globulins and blood clotting factors (Box. 4.1).</p>
<p>Breakdown of erythrocytes and defence against microbes
These processes are carried out by phagocytic hepatic macrophages (Kupffer cells) in the sinusoids, although breakdown of red blood cells also takes place in the spleen.</p>
<p>Detoxification of drugs and toxic substances
These include ethanol (alcohol), waste products and microbial toxins. Some drugs are extensively inactivated by the liver and are therefore not very effective when given by mouth (orally), e.g. glyceryl trinitrate. This is because, after absorption from the alimentary tract, they travel in the blood to the liver, where they are largely metabolised, so that levels in the blood leaving the liver and then entering the systemic circulation are inadequate to achieve therapeutic effects. This is known as 'first-pass metabolism'.</p>
<p>Inactivation of hormones
These include insulin, glucagon, cortisol, aldosterone, thyroid and sex hormones.
Production of heat
The liver uses a considerable amount of energy, has a high metabolic rate and consequently produces a great deal of heat. It is the main heat-producing organ of the body.</p>
<p>Secretion of bile
The hepatocytes synthesise the constituents of bile from the mixed arterial and venous blood in the sinusoids. These include bile salts, bile pigments and cholesterol (see later).
storage
Stored substances include:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>glycogen (Fig. 12.39)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>fat-soluble vitamins: A, D, E, K</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>iron, copper</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>some water-soluble vitamins, e.g. vitamin B 12 .</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Composition of bile
Between 500 and 1000 mL of bile is secreted by the liver daily. Bile consists of:</p>
<ul>
<li>water</li>
<li>mineral salts</li>
<li>mucus</li>
<li>bile pigments, mainly bilirubin</li>
<li>bile salts</li>
<li>cholesterol.</li>
</ul>
<p>Functions of bile
Fat digestion
The bile acids, cholic and chenodeoxycholic acid, are synthesised by hepatocytes from cholesterol, then secreted into bile as sodium or potassium salts. In the small intestine they emulsify fats by dispersing them into tiny droplets, thus aiding their digestion by lipases. Fatty acids are insoluble in water, which makes them very difficult to absorb through the intestinal wall. Bile salts make cholesterol and fatty acids more water-soluble, enabling both these and the fat-soluble vitamins (vitamins A, D, E and K) to be readily absorbed.</p>
<p>In the terminal ileum most of the bile salts are reabsorbed and return to the liver in the portal vein. This enterohepatic circulation recycles bile salts, ensuring that large amounts of bile salts enter the small intestine daily from a relatively small bile acid pool (Fig. 12.37).</p>
<p>Excretion of bilirubin
Bilirubin is one of the products of haemolysis of erythrocytes by macrophages (see earlier). Bilirubin is insoluble in water and is carried in the blood bound to the plasma protein albumin. It is conjugated (combined) with glucuronic acid by hepatocytes in the liver and becomes water-soluble enough to be excreted in bile. Microbes in the large intestine convert bilirubin into stercobilin, which is excreted in the faeces. Stercobilin colours and deodorises the faeces. A small amount is reabsorbed and excreted in urine as urobilinogen (Fig. 12.37). Jaundice is yellow</p>
<p>pigmentation of the tissues, seen in the skin and conjunctiva, caused by excess blood bilirubin (p. 365).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="5205029c">â–  SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5205029c" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol start="12">
<li>Which vessels enter and leave the liver at the portal fissure and what do they transport?</li>
</ol>
<p>Spleen
Haemoglobin from worn-out erythrocytes
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mspace width="2em"></mspace></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\qquad</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0em;"></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 2em;"></span></span></span></span></span>
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>âˆ§</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\wedge</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5556em;"></span><span class="mord">âˆ§</span></span></span></span></span> Haem <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>âˆ§</mo><mo>âˆ§</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\wedge \wedge</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5556em;"></span><span class="mord">âˆ§</span><span class="mord">âˆ§</span></span></span></span></span> Globin <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>âˆ§</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\wedge</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5556em;"></span><span class="mord">âˆ§</span></span></span></span></span>
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">r</mi><mo>âˆ§</mo><mspace width="1em"></mspace><mo>âˆ§</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{r} \wedge \quad \wedge</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5556em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">r</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">âˆ§</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 1em;"></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5556em;"></span><span class="mord">âˆ§</span></span></span></span></span> Amino acids <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>âˆ§</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\wedge</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5556em;"></span><span class="mord">âˆ§</span></span></span></span></span>
Bilirubin
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>âˆ§</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\wedge</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5556em;"></span><span class="mord">âˆ§</span></span></span></span></span> (unconjugated) <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>âˆ§</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\wedge</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5556em;"></span><span class="mord">âˆ§</span></span></span></span></span></p>
