<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="structure">structure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#structure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Figure 12.37 Fate of bilirubin from breakdovyn of yyorn-out erythrocytes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="biliary-tract">Biliary tract<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#biliary-tract" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe the route taken by bile from the liver to the gall bladder, and then to the duodenum</li>
<li>outline the structure and functions of the gall bladder.</li>
</ul>
<p>Bile ducts
The walls of the bile ducts have the same layers of tissue as those of the basic structure of the alimentary canal (see Fig. 12.2). In the cystic duct the mucous membrane lining is arranged in irregular circular folds, which have the effect of a spiral valve. Bile passes through the cystic duct twice: once on its way into the gall bladder, and again when it is expelled from the gall bladder into the common bile duct and then on to the duodenum.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="gall-bladder">Gall bladder<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gall-bladder" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The gall bladder is a pear-shaped sac attached to the posterior surface of the liver by connective tissue. It has a fundus or expanded end, a body or main part, and a neck, which is continuous with the cystic duct.
structure
The right and left hepatic ducts join to form the common hepatic duct just outside the portal fissure (Fig. 12.38). The hepatic duct passes downwards for about 3 cm and is then joined by the cystic duct from the gall bladder. The cystic and hepatic ducts merge, forming the common bile duct, which passes downwards behind the head of the pancreas. The common bile duct is joined by the main pancreatic duct at the hepatopancreatic ampulla. It opens into the duodenum at the duodenal papilla, which is controlled by the hepatopancreatic sphincter (of Oddi). The common bile duct is about 7.5 cm long and has a diameter of about 6 mm .</p>
<p>The wall of the gall bladder has the same layers of tissue as those of the basic structure of the alimentary canal, with some modifications.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="peritoneum">Peritoneum<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#peritoneum" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This covers only the inferior surface because the upper surface of the gall bladder is in direct contact with the liver and held in place by the visceral peritoneum that covers the liver.</p>
<p>Muscle layer
There is an additional layer of oblique muscle fibres.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="learning-outcomes">Learning outcomes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#learning-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Mucous membrane
This displays small rugae when the gall bladder is empty; these then disappear when it becomes distended with bile.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="blood-supply">Blood supply<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blood-supply" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The cystic artery, a branch of the hepatic artery, supplies the gall bladder. Blood is drained away by the cystic vein, which joins the portal vein.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="functions">Functions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These include:</p>
<ul>
<li>storage of bile</li>
<li>concentration of the bile by up to 10 - or 15 -fold, by absorption of water through the walls of the gall bladder</li>
<li>release of stored bile.</li>
</ul>
<p>When the muscle wall of the gall bladder contracts, bile is expelled into the bile ducts and then enters the duodenum. Contraction is stimulated by the hormone CCK, secreted by the duodenum, and by the presence of fat and acid chyme in the duodenum.</p>
<p>Relaxation of the hepatopancreatic sphincter (of Oddi) is caused by CCK and is a reflex response to contraction of the gall bladder.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="i-spot-check">I # SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol start="13">
<li>Outline the pathway taken by bile, from leaving the liver to entering the small intestine.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="summary-of-digestion-and-absorption-of-nutrients">Summary of digestion and absorption of nutrients<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#summary-of-digestion-and-absorption-of-nutrients" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>list the principal digestive enzymes, their sites of action, their substrates and their products</li>
<li>describe the sites of absorption of the main nutrient groups.</li>
</ul>
<p>Table 12.2 summarises the main digestive processes of the principal nutrient groups, the locations where these processes occur and the enzymes involved.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-spot-check">I # SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol start="14">
<li>Describe the functions of hydrochloric acid in the stomach.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="metabolism">Metabolism<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#metabolism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>discuss general principles of metabolism, including units of energy, metabolic rate, catabolism and anabolism</li>
<li>compare and contrast the metabolic rates of the body's main energy sources (carbohydrate, protein and fat)</li>
<li>describe in simple terms the central metabolic pathways - glycolysis, the citric acid cycle and oxidative phosphorylation.</li>
</ul>
<p>Metabolism constitutes all the chemical reactions that occur in the body to provide the chemical energy essential for all cellular activities. Units of energy, energy balance and metabolic rate are briefly outlined below before considering the metabolic pathways used to release energy from absorbed nutrients. Metabolism involves two types of processes:
large molecules cataboiisr <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">âˆ§</mo></msup><mo>âˆ§</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">{ }^{\wedge} \wedge</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7519em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7519em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">âˆ§</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord">âˆ§</span></span></span></span></span> molecules
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">âˆ§</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">{ }^{\wedge}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7519em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7519em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">âˆ§</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> anabolism</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="catabolism">Catabolism<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#catabolism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Catabolic processes break down large molecules into smaller ones, releasing chemical energy, which is stored as adenosine triphosphate (ATP), and heat. The heat generated maintains core body temperature at the optimum level for chemical activity <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo fence="true">(</mo><msup><mn>36.8</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">âˆ˜</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mo fence="true">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\left(36.8^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\right)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">(</span><span class="mord">36.</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">8</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">âˆ˜</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">)</span></span></span></span></span></span>. Excess heat is lost, mainly through the skin (Ch. 14).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="anabolism">Anabolism<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#anabolism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is building up, or synthesis, of large molecules from smaller ones and requires a source of energy, usually ATP.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="energy">Energy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#energy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>All body cells require energy to carry out their metabolic processes, including multiplication for replacement of worn-out cells, muscle contraction and synthesis of glandular secretions.</p>
<p>The energy produced in the body may be measured and expressed in units of work (joules) or units of heat (kilocalories).</p>
<p>A kilocalorie (kcal) is the amount of heat required to raise the temperature of 1 litre of water by 1 degree Celsius <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo fence="true">(</mo><msup><mn>1</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">âˆ˜</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mo fence="true">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\left(1^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\right)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">1</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">âˆ˜</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">)</span></span></span></span></span></span>. On a daily basis the body's collective metabolic processes generate a total of about 3 million kilocalories.
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>4184</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1 \mathrm{kcal}=4184</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">kcal</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">4184</span></span></span></span></span> joules <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">J</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>4.184</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(\mathrm{J})=4.184</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathrm">J</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">4.184</span></span></span></span></span> kilojoules <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">J</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(\mathrm{kJ})</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">kJ</span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span></p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;">Learning outcomes</th><th style="text-align: left;"></th><th style="text-align: left;"></th><th style="text-align: left;"></th><th style="text-align: left;"></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Learning outcomes</td><td style="text-align: left;"></td><td style="text-align: left;"></td><td style="text-align: left;"></td><td style="text-align: left;"></td></tr></tbody></table>

Summary of the sites of digestion and absorption of nutrients</p>
<p>Mouth Stomach Small intestine</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="digestion-absorption">Digestion Absorption<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#digestion-absorption" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<p>The nutritional value of carbohydrates, protein and fats eaten in the diet may be expressed in either kj per gram or kcal per gram.</p>
<p>1 g of carbohydrate provides <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>17</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">J</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>4</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">17 \mathrm{~kJ}(4 \mathrm{kcal})</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">17</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">kJ</span></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">4</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">kcal</span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> 1 g of protein provides <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>17</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">J</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>4</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">17 \mathrm{~kJ}(4 \mathrm{kcal})</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">17</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">kJ</span></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">4</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">kcal</span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> 1 g of fat provides <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>38</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">J</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>9</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">38 \mathrm{~kJ}(9 \mathrm{kcal})</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">38</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">kJ</span></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">9</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">kcal</span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> Energy balance is important, as it determines changes in body weight. Body weight remains constant when energy intake is equal to energy use. When intake exceeds requirement, body weight increases, which, when continual, will lead to obesity</p>
<p>(Ch. 11). Conversely, body weight decreases when nutrient intake does not meet energy requirements.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="metabolic-rate-u-12-8">Metabolic rate u 12.8<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#metabolic-rate-u-12-8" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The metabolic rate is the rate at which energy is released from the fuel molecules inside cells. As most of the processes involved require oxygen and produce carbon dioxide as waste, the metabolic rate can be estimated by measuring oxygen uptake or carbon dioxide excretion.</p>
<p>The basal metabolic rate (BMR) is the rate of metabolism when the individual is at rest in a warm environment and is in the postabsorptive state, i.e. has not had a meal for at least 12 hours. In this state the release of energy is sufficient to meet only the essential (basal) needs of vital organs, such as the heart, lungs, nervous system and kidneys. Some of
the many factors that affect metabolic rate are shown in Table 12.3.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="metabolic-pathways">Metabolic pathways<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#metabolic-pathways" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Anabolism and catabolism (see before) usually involve a series of chemical reactions, known as metabolic pathways. These are linked sequences of 'small steps' that permit controlled, efficient and gradual transfer of energy from ATP rather than large intracellular 'explosions'. Metabolic pathways (see later) are switched on and off by hormones, providing fine control of metabolism and meeting individual requirements.</p>
<p>Both catabolic and anabolic processes occur continually in all cells. Very active tissues, such as muscle and liver, need a large energy supply to support their metabolic requirements.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="central-metabolic-pathways">Central metabolic pathways<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#central-metabolic-pathways" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Much of the metabolic effort of cells is concerned with energy production to fuel cellular activities. Certain common pathways are central to this function. Fuel molecules enter these central energy-producing pathways and in a series of steps, during which a series of intermediate molecules are formed and energy is released, these fuel molecules are chemically broken down. The end results of these processes are production of energy, carbon dioxide and water (called</p>
<p>Table 12.3 Factors affecting metabolic rate</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Age</th><th>Gradually reduced with age</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Gender</td><td>Higher in men than women</td></tr><tr><td>Height, weight</td><td>Relatively higher in larger people</td></tr><tr><td>Pregnancy, menstruation, lactation</td><td>Increased</td></tr><tr><td>Ingestion of food</td><td>Increased</td></tr><tr><td>Muscular activity, physical exertion</td><td>Increased</td></tr><tr><td>Elevated body temperature (fever)</td><td>Increased</td></tr><tr><td>Excess thyroid hormones</td><td>Increased</td></tr><tr><td>Starvation</td><td>Decreased</td></tr><tr><td>Emotional states</td><td>Increased</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>metabolic water). Much of the energy is stored as ATP, although some is lost as heat. The carbon dioxide is excreted through the lungs and excess water excreted in urine.</p>
<p>The preferred fuel molecule is glucose but alternatives, should glucose be unavailable, include amino acids, fatty acids, glycerol and occasionally nucleic acids. Each of these may enter the central energy-producing pathways and be converted to energy, carbon dioxide and water. There are three central metabolic pathways (see Fig. 12.44):</p>
<ul>
<li>glycolysis</li>
<li>the citric acid (Krebs) cycle</li>
<li>oxidative phosphorylation.</li>
</ul>
<p>Products from glycolysis enter the citric acid cycle, and products from the citric acid cycle proceed to oxidative phosphorylation. The fates of the different fuel</p>
<p>molecules entering the central metabolic pathways are discussed in the following sections.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="carbohydrate-metabolism">Carbohydrate metabolism<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#carbohydrate-metabolism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Erythrocytes and neurones can use only glucose for fuel and therefore an adequate blood glucose level is needed to provide a constant energy source to these cells. Most other cells can also use other sources of fuel.</p>
<p>Digested carbohydrate, mainly glucose, is absorbed into the blood capillaries of the villi of the small intestine. It is transported by the portal circulation to the liver, where it is dealt with in several ways (Fig. 12.39):</p>
<ul>
<li>Glucose may be oxidised to provide the chemical energy, in the form of ATP, that is necessary for the considerable metabolic activity that takes place in the liver itself.</li>
<li>Some glucose may remain in the circulating blood to maintain normal blood glucose levels between 3.5 and 8 millimoles per litre (mmol/L) (63-144 mg/100 mL ).</li>
<li>Some glucose, if in excess of the above requirements, may be converted by the hormone insulin to the</li>
</ul>
<p>Glucose: used by liver or stored as glycogen
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-669cf02b.jpeg" alt="img-60.jpeg"></p>
<p>Glucagon
c</p>
<p>Glucose leaves in hepatic veins
Glucose in portal venous blood from intestine
To all body cells for fuel To maintain normal blood glucose level To muscles to be stored as glycogen To fat depots to be stored as fat</p>
<p>Figure 12.39 Summary of the source, distribution and use of glucose.
insoluble polysaccharide, glycogen, in the liver and the skeletal muscles. The formation of glycogen inside cells is a means of storing carbohydrate without upsetting the osmotic equilibrium. Before it can be used to maintain blood levels or</p>
<p>to provide ATP, it must be broken down again into its constituent glucose units. Liver glycogen constitutes a store of glucose used for liver activity and for maintenance of the blood glucose level. Muscle glycogen stores provide the glucose required for activity. Glucagon, adrenaline (epinephrine) and thyroxine are the main hormones associated with the breakdown of glycogen to glucose. These processes can be summarised:
, insulin . .
glycogen</p>
<ul>
<li>Carbohydrate in excess of that required to maintain the blood glucose level and glycogen stores in the tissues is converted to fat and stored in the fat depots.</li>
</ul>
<p>The oxidation of carbohydrate and fat provides most of the energy required by the body. When glycogen stores are low and more glucose is needed, the body can make glucose from non-carbohydrate sources, e.g. amino acids, glycerol. This is called gluconeogenesis (formation of new glucose).</p>
<p>Carbohydrate and energy release
This is shown in Fig. 12.40. Glucose is broken down in the body, releasing energy, carbon dioxide and metabolic water. Catabolism of glucose occurs in a series of steps, with a little energy being released at each stage. The total number of ATP molecules that may be generated from the complete breakdown of 1 molecule of glucose is 38 , but for this to be achieved the process must occur in the presence of oxygen</p>
<p>Glucose in portal venous blood from intestine</p>
<p>Glucose used by liver in stored as glycogen</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="c">C<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Glucose J
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">âˆ§</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">{ }^{\wedge}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7519em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7519em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">âˆ§</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> Glucose 1

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cytoplasm">CYTOPLASM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cytoplasm" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<p>ADP

<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>âˆ’</mo><mo>âˆ§</mo><mo>:</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">-\wedge:</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">âˆ’</span><span class="mord">âˆ§</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">:</span></span></span></span></span> T <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mrow><mo mathvariant="normal">â€²</mo><mo mathvariant="normal">â€²</mo></mrow></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{\prime \prime}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7519em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7519em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">â€²â€²</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></p>
<p>Figure 12.40 Oxidation of glucose./ADP, adenosine diphosphate; ATP, adenosine triphosphate.
(aerobically). In the absence of oxygen (anaerobically), this number is greatly reduced; the process is therefore much less efficient.</p>
<p>The remaining 34 molecules of ATP come from the third energy-generating process, oxidative phosphorylation (Fig. 12.40), which is dependent on hydrogen atoms released during earlier stages of glucose breakdown. Oxidative phosphorylation, like the citric acid cycle, can occur only in the presence of oxygen and takes place in the mitochondria.</p>
<p>Anaerobic catabolism
When oxygen levels in the cell are low, the molecule of glucose still undergoes glycolysis and is split into 2 molecules of pyruvic acid because glycolysis is an anaerobic process. However, the pyruvic acid does not enter the citric acid cycle or progress to oxidative phosphorylation; instead, it is converted anaerobically to lactic acid. Build-up of lactic acid causes the pain and cramps typical of over-</p>
<p>exercised muscles. When oxygen levels are restored, lactic acid is reconverted to pyruvic acid, which may then enter the citric acid cycle.</p>
<p>Fate of the end products of carbohydrate metabolism Lactic acid
Some of the lactic acid produced by anaerobic catabolism of glucose may be oxidised in the cells to carbon dioxide and water but first it must be changed back to pyruvic acid. If complete oxidation does not take place, lactic acid travels to the liver in the circulating blood, where it is converted to glucose and may then take any of the pathways open to glucose (see Fig. 12.39).</p>
<p>Aerobic respiration (cataboiism)
Aerobic catabolism of glucose can occur only when the oxygen supply is adequate, and is the process by which energy is released during prolonged, manageable exercise. When exercise levels become very intense, the energy requirements of muscles outstrip the oxygen supply, and anaerobic breakdown then occurs. Such high levels of activity can be sustained for only short periods because there is accumulation of wastes (mainly lactic acid) and reduced efficiency of the energy production process.</p>
<p>The first stage of glucose catabolism is glycolysis (Fig. 12.40). This is an anaerobic process that takes place in the cytoplasm of the cell. Through a number of intermediate steps, 1 glucose molecule is converted to 2 molecules of pyruvic acid, with the net production of 2 molecules of ATP.</p>
<p>The remainder of the considerable energy stores locked up within the original molecule of glucose is released only if there is enough oxygen to allow the pyruvic acid molecules to enter the biochemical roundabout called the citric acid cycle (Fig. 12.40). This takes place in the mitochondria of the cell and is oxygen-dependent. For every 2 molecules of pyruvic acid entering the citric acid cycle, a further 2 molecules of ATP are formed, but this is still far short of the maximum possible 38 ATP molecules. Q 12.9</p>
<p>Carbon dioxide
This is excreted from the body as a gas by the lungs.
Metabolic water
This is added to the considerable amount of water already present in the body. Excess is excreted in the urine by the kidneys.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="protein-metabolism">Protein metabolism<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#protein-metabolism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Dietary protein consists of a number of amino acids. About 20 amino acids have been named and 9 of these are described as essential because they cannot be synthesised in the body. The others are non-essential amino acids because they can be synthesised by many tissues. The enzymes involved in this process are called transaminases. Digestion breaks down dietary protein into its constituent amino acids in preparation for absorption into the blood capillaries of the villi in the small intestine. Amino acids are transported in the portal circulation to the liver and then into the general circulation, thus making them available to all body cells and tissues. From the amino acids available, different cells choose from the particular ones required for building or repairing their specific type of tissue and for</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: center;">Glutamylis acid</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Acetyl coenzyme A</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;"><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mtable rowspacing="0.16em" columnalign="left left" columnspacing="1em"><mtr><mtd><mstyle scriptlevel="0" displaystyle="false"><mtext>&nbsp;(In&nbsp;</mtext></mstyle></mtd><mtd><mstyle scriptlevel="0" displaystyle="false"><mtext>&nbsp;Pyruvic&nbsp;acid&nbsp;</mtext></mstyle></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mstyle scriptlevel="0" displaystyle="false"><mtext>&nbsp;)&nbsp;</mtext></mstyle></mtd></mtr></mtable><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\begin{array}{ll}\text { (In } &amp; \text { Pyruvic acid } \\ \text { ) }\end{array}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.4em; vertical-align: -0.95em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mtable"><span class="arraycolsep" style="width: 0.5em;"></span><span class="col-align-l"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.45em;"><span style="top: -3.61em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">&nbsp;(In&nbsp;</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -2.41em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">&nbsp;)&nbsp;</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">â€‹</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.95em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="arraycolsep" style="width: 0.5em;"></span><span class="arraycolsep" style="width: 0.5em;"></span><span class="col-align-l"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.45em;"><span style="top: -3.61em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">&nbsp;Pyruvic&nbsp;acid&nbsp;</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="arraycolsep" style="width: 0.5em;"></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></td></tr></tbody></table>

energy now or later
synthesising their secretions, e.g. antibodies, enzymes or hormones.
Amino acid pool
The body's capacity for storing amino acids is very limited and excess amino acids are deaminated in the liver. A small pool of amino acids (Fig. 12.41) is available to body cells to draw on when they need to synthesise their own materials, e.g. new cells or cell components, secretions such as enzymes, hormones and plasma proteins.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="sources-of-amino-acids-exogenous">Sources of amino acids Exogenous<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sources-of-amino-acids-exogenous" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="izihen">iziHen<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#izihen" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

Endogenous
These are obtained from the breakdown of existing body proteins. In adults, about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>80</mn><mo>âˆ’</mo><mn>100</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">80-100 \mathrm{~g}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">80</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">âˆ’</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8389em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">100</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">g</span></span></span></span></span></span> of protein are broken down and replaced each day.
