</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="loss-of-amino-acids-deamination">Loss of amino acids Deamination<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#loss-of-amino-acids-deamination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Amino acids not needed by the body are broken down, or deaminated, mainly in the liver. The nitrogenous part, the amino group (NH 2 ), is converted to ammonia (NH3) and then combined with carbon dioxide, forming urea, which is excreted in the urine. The remaining part is used to provide energy, as glucose by gluconeogenesis, or stored as fat, if in excess of immediate requirements.</p>
<p>Excretion</p>
<p>The faeces contain a considerable amount of protein within cells shed from the lining of the alimentary tract.</p>
<p>Endogenous and exogenous amino acids are mixed in the 'pool' and the body is said to be in nitrogen balance when the rate of removal from the pool is equal to the additions to it. Unlike carbohydrates, the body has no capacity for the storage of amino acids except for this relatively small pool. Fig. 12.42 shows what happens to amino acids in the body.</p>
<p>Amino acids and energy release
Amino acids are potential fuel molecules that are used by the body only when other energy sources are low, e.g. in starvation. To supply the amino acids for use as fuel, in extreme situations, the body breaks down muscle, its main protein source. Some amino acids can be converted directly to glucose, which enters glycolysis. Other amino acids are metabolised to intermediate compounds of the central metabolic pathways, e.g. acetyl coenzyme A or oxaloacetic acid, and therefore enter the system at a later stage (see Fig. 12.44).
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-376fac7a.jpeg" alt="img-62.jpeg"></p>
<p>DIET
Fatty acids and glycerol
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-56ccee57.jpeg" alt="img-63.jpeg"></p>
<p>FATE
Liver:
Fatty acids and glycerol-triglycerides
Adipose tissue:
Stores excess triglycerides, releases fatty acids and glycerol when required
Tissue cells:</p>
<p>Use fatty acids and glycerol as a source of energy to form ATP and heat
Figure 12.43 Sources, distribution and use of fats in the body. ATP, adenosine triphosphate.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="fat-metabolism">Fat metabolism<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fat-metabolism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is shown in Fig. 12.43. Fat is synthesised from excess dietary carbohydrates and proteins, and stored in the fat depots, i.e. under the skin, in the omentum or around the kidneys.</p>
<p>Fats that have been digested and absorbed as fatty acids and glycerol into the lacteals are transported via the cisterna chyli and the thoracic duct of the lymphatic system (Ch. 6) to the bloodstream and so, by a circuitous route, to the liver. Fatty acids and glycerol circulating in the blood are used by the cells to provide energy and to synthesise some of their secretions. In the liver, some fatty acids and glycerol are used to provide energy and heat, and some are recombined, forming triglycerides, the form in which fat is stored. A triglyceride consists of three fatty acids chemically combined with a glycerol molecule (see Fig. 2.9). When required, triglycerides are converted back to fatty acids and glycerol, and used to provide energy. The end products of fat metabolism are chemical energy, heat, carbon dioxide and metabolic water.</p>
<p>Fatty acids and energy release
When body tissues are deprived of glucose, as occurs in prolonged fasting, starvation, energy-restricted diets or strenuous exercise, the body uses alternative energy sources, mainly fat stores. Fatty acids may be converted to acetyl coenzyme A, and enter the energy production pathway in that form. One consequence of this is accumulation of ketone bodies, which are produced in the liver from acetyl coenzyme A when levels are too high for processing through the citric acid cycle (Fig. 12.44). Ketone bodies then enter the blood and can be used by other body tissues, including the brain (which is usually glucose-dependent).</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-92c99b33.jpeg" alt="img-64.jpeg">
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">âˆ—</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">\</mi><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>âˆ—</mo><mo>âˆ—</mo></mrow></msup><msup><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>âˆ’</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">f</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></mrow><mo>&gt;</mo><mo>&gt;</mo><mn>7</mn></mrow></msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">t</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></mrow><mo>&gt;</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{ADP}^{*} \backslash \mathrm{ADp}^{* *} \mathrm{~A}^{-\mathrm{fATP}&gt;&gt;7} \mathrm{tP}&gt;</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.1723em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">ADP</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7619em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">âˆ—</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord">\</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">ADp</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7619em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">âˆ—âˆ—</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">A</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.9223em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">âˆ’</span><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">fATP</span></span><span class="mrel mtight">&gt;&gt;</span><span class="mord mtight">7</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">tP</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span></span></span></span></span>
Figure 12.44 Summary of the fates of the three main energy sources in the central metabolic pathways. ADP, adenosine diphosphate; ATP, adenosine triphosphate.
as a source of fuel. However, at high concentrations, ketone bodies are toxic, particularly to the brain. Ketone bodies include acetone and some weak organic acids. Normally, levels are low because they are used as soon as they are produced. When production exceeds use, in the situations mentioned earlier, levels rise, causing ketosis. Ketosis is associated with acidosis, which can lead to coma or even death if severe. Excretion of excess ketone bodies is via:</p>
<ul>
<li>the urine (ketonuria)</li>
<li>the lungs, giving the breath a characteristic sweet smell
of acetone or 'pear drops'.
In ketosis, compensation is required to maintain acidbase balance. This is achieved by buffer systems that excrete excess acid (hydrogen ions) by the lungs, through hyperventilation, or kidneys. In health, ketosis is self-limiting and ketone body production stops when fasting or exercise ceases. Ketoacidosis is associated with uncontrolled type 1 diabetes mellitus (p. 255).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="glycerol-and-energy-release">Glycerol and energy release<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#glycerol-and-energy-release" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The body converts glycerol from the degradation of fats into one of the intermediary compounds produced during glycolysis, and in this form it enters the central metabolic pathways (Fig. 12.44).</p>
<ul>
<li>SPOT CHECK</li>
</ul>
<ol start="15">
<li>Define the terms 'anabolism' and 'catabolism'.</li>
<li>Name the three central metabolic pathways.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="effects-of-ageing-on-the-digestive-system">Effects of ageing on the digestive system<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#effects-of-ageing-on-the-digestive-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Learning outcome
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe the effects of ageing on the digestive system.</li>
</ul>
<p>Tooth loss, e.g. through periodontal disease, may cause difficulty chewing, which in turn restricts dietary choices. A reduction in the muscle mass of the tongue and lessened
salivation can exacerbate this. The sensitivity and number of taste buds decline with age.</p>
<p>Peristalsis within the alimentary canal reduces, which predisposes to constipation (Ch. 11). Other features of ageing, such as lessened mobility or poor cognitive function, also contribute to constipation unless dietary fibre is increased and an adequate fluid intake is maintained.</p>
<p>Liver mass decreases with age and this is accompanied by a variable decline in its reserve capacity, which can impair metabolism, including breakdown of drugs; this in turn may lead to toxicity.</p>
<p>In older adults there is a reduction in skeletal muscle mass and its responsiveness to hormones, including adrenaline (epinephrine), noradrenaline (norepinephrine) and thyroid hormones. Together, these lower BMR. Limited physical activity or inactivity also reduces BMR. A reduction in BMR that is not accompanied by a lower dietary intake predisposes to obesity and its consequences (Ch. 11).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="spot-check">- SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol start="17">
<li>Explain briefly why older adults are at increasing risk of drug toxicity.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="learning-outcome">Learning outcome<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#learning-outcome" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This section considers disorders of the digestive system. Table 12.4 and Fig. 12.45 list some common signs and symptoms of gastrointestinal disorders.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="diseases-of-the-mouth">Diseases of the mouth<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diseases-of-the-mouth" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>discuss the main inflammatory and infectious conditions of the mouth</li>
<li>outline the sites and effects of oral squamous cell carcinoma</li>
<li>distinguish between cleft lip and cleft palate, including describing the anatomical abnormalities involved.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="inflammatory-and-infectious-conditions">Inflammatory and infectious conditions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#inflammatory-and-infectious-conditions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Injury may be caused to tissues in and around the mouth by food and other ingested substances, if they are corrosive, abrasive or excessively hot or cold. The mouth contains a large number and variety of normally harmless commensal microorganisms. The antibacterial action of saliva helps to limit their growth, but the presence of dental plaque and residual foodstuffs, especially sugars, in the mouth can promote infection. Inflammation of the mouth is known as stomatitis, and inflammation of the gums as gingivitis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-bristol-stool-form-scale">The Bristol Stool Form Scale<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-bristol-stool-form-scale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Type 1 Separate hard lumps, like nuts (hard to pass)</p>
<p>Type 2 Sausage-shaped but lumpy</p>
<p>Type 3 Like a sausage but with oraoks on its surface</p>
<p>Type 4 Like a sausage or snake, smooth and soft</p>
<p>Type 5 Soft blobs with olear-cut edges (passed easily)</p>
<p>Type 6
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-330264f9.jpeg" alt="img-65.jpeg"></p>
<p>Table captionFluffy pieces with ragged edges, a mushy stool</p>
<p>Watery, no solid pieces ENTIRELY LIQUID</p>
<p>Figure 12.45 Bristol Stool Form Scale. (Distributed with the kind permission of Dr K. W. Heaton; formerly reader in Medioine at the University of Bristol. Reproduced as a service to the medical profession by Norgine Ltd. Â©2017 Norgine group of companies.)</p>
<p>Table 12.4
Common signs
and symptoms
of
gastrointestinal
disorders</p>
<p>Sign/symptom Definition and description</p>
<p>Abdominal Caused by stretching of smooth muscle or organ capsules. The pain location is described with reference to the regions of the abdomen (see Fig. 1.26)</p>
<p>Anorexia Loss of appetite that prevents or markedly reduces eating. When severe and ongoing, it is accompanied by weight loss</p>
<p>Constipation Passage of faeces less frequently than normal and/or passage of hard faeces (Fig. 12.45). Normal frequency varies greatly between individuals, ranging from 3 times daily to 3 times per week</p>
<p>Diarrhoea Unusually frequent passage of loose or watery faeces. Normally, most fluid in the gastrointestinal tract is reabsorbed (see</p>
<p>Fig. 12.28). Diarrhoea (Fig. 12.45) arises when water reabsorption from the intestines is reduced and/or intestinal motility is increased</p>
<p>Dysphagia Difficulty swallowing</p>
<p>Haematemesis Vomiting of blood, either fresh (red or purplish) or black when partly digested (described as 'coffee grounds')</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: center;">Melaena</th><th style="text-align: center;">Passing blood in the faeces which are black and tarry. Very small amounts are found only by testing for faecal occult (hidden) blood (FOB)</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Nausea</td><td style="text-align: center;">A feeling of sickness, which usually precedes vomiting. It may be accompanied by profuse salivation and tachycardia</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Vomiting</td><td style="text-align: center;">An (involuntary) reflex in which there is forceful ejection of stomach contents through the mouth. Vomiting follows stimulation of, for example, the pharynx, oesophagus, stomach or the vomiting centre in the medulla, e.g. by drugs. Coordinated by the medulla; the glottis closes, the diaphragm contracts, the upper oesophageal sphincter relaxes; strong waves of reverse peristalsis in the stomach then expel its contents upwards. If severe, consequences include disturbance of fluid, electrolyte and acid-base balance (metabolic alkalosis, as excessive <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">F</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">I</mi></mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{FI}+</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">FI</span></span><span class="mord">+</span></span></span></span></span> is lost)</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">The Bristol Stool Form Scale</td><td style="text-align: center;"></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Learning outcomes</td><td style="text-align: center;"></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Table 15.4 Common signs and symptoms of gastrointestinal disorders</td><td style="text-align: center;"></td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="thrush-oral-candidiasis">Thrush (oral candidiasis)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#thrush-oral-candidiasis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This acute fungal infection is caused by the yeast Candida albicans, which occurs when the commensal microbe grows in white patches on the tongue and oral mucosa. In adults it causes opportunistic infection, mainly in debilitated people and in those whose immunity is lowered, e.g. by steroids, antibiotics or cytotoxic drugs. In children it occurs most commonly in bottle-fed babies.</p>
<p>Chronic thrush may develop, affecting the roof of the mouth in people who wear dentures. The fungus survives in fine grooves on the upper surface of the denture and repeatedly reinfects the oral mucosa. The same fungus is also responsible for sexually transmitted infections (Ch. 18).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="gingivitis">Gingivitis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gingivitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is inflammation of the gums, which may be acute or, much more commonly, chronic. Chronic gingivitis is a common inflammatory condition that occurs in response to accumulation of bacterial plaque around the teeth. It causes bleeding gums and gradually destroys the tissues that support the teeth, which eventually loosen and may fall out.</p>
<p>Recurrent aphthous ulceration</p>
<p>This common condition affects up to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>25</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">25 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">25%</span></span></span></span></span> of the population. It features extremely painful ulcers that occur singly or in crops in any part of the mouth. The cause is unknown.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="viral-infections">Viral infections<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#viral-infections" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These are usually caused by one type of herpes simplex virus, HSV-1.
Acute herpetic gingivostomatitis
Inflammation of the mouth and gums is caused by HSV-land is the most common oral viral infection. It is characterised by extensive and very painful ulceration.</p>
<p>Secondary or recurrent herpes lesions (cold sores)
Lesions, caused by HSV-1, occur round the nose and on the lips. After an outbreak the viruses remain dormant within local nerves. Later outbreaks, usually at the same site, are precipitated by a variety of stimuli, including exposure to ultraviolet rays (strong sunlight) and impaired immunity.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="tumours-of-the-mouth">Tumours of the mouth<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tumours-of-the-mouth" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="squamous-cell-carcinoma">Squamous cell carcinoma<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#squamous-cell-carcinoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is the most common type of malignant tumour in the mouth; it mainly affects older adults. The usual sites are the floor of the mouth and the edge of the tongue. Ulceration occurs frequently and there is early spread to surrounding tissues and cervical lymph nodes, in which case the prognosis is poor.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="congenital-disorders">Congenital disorders<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#congenital-disorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cleft-palate-and-cleft-lip-harelip">Cleft palate and cleft lip (harelip)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cleft-palate-and-cleft-lip-harelip" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>During embryonic development, the roof of the mouth (hard palate) develops as two separate (right and left) halves; this occurs from the lips anteriorly to the uvula posteriorly. Before birth, these two halves normally fuse along the midline (Fig. 12.46 A). If fusion is incomplete, a cleft (division) remains, which may be very minor or may be substantial.</p>
<p>Cleft lip (Fig. 12.46B) ranges from a minor notch in the upper lip to a more extensive condition when the lip is completely split in one or two places and the nose is involved.</p>
<p>In cleft palate, there is a gap between the two halves of the palate, which creates a channel of communication between the mouth and the nasal cavity (Fig. 12.46C).</p>
<p>Contributing factors include genetic abnormalities, and certain drugs or poor nutrition between weeks 7 and 12 of pregnancy. Drinking, eating and development of speech do not take place normally until the defect has been surgically repaired.</p>
<p>Nostril
Upper lip
Roof of mouth -
Two halves of palate correctly fused
A
B
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-1083cddd.jpeg" alt="img-66.jpeg"></p>
<p>C
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-a9daa0b0.jpeg" alt="img-67.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 12.46 Cleft lip and cleft palate. (A) Normal hard palate. (B) Cleft lip. (C) Cleft palate.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="dental-caries">Dental caries<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#dental-caries" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Tooth decay starts with discoloration and then formation of cavities (caries). It arises when bacteria present in plaque on the teeth act on sugars, forming acid, which may eventually destroy the hard parts of the teeth. Caries can be prevented by good oral hygiene.</p>
<p>Without treatment, infection, inflammation of the soft tissues of the mouth and tooth loss can occur.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="i-spot-check">I # SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol start="18">
<li>Which organism causes oral thrush?</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="diseases-of-the-pharynx">Diseases of the pharynx<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diseases-of-the-pharynx" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>See tonsillitis and diphtheria (p. 284).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="diseases-of-salivary-glands">Diseases of salivary glands<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diseases-of-salivary-glands" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>outline the pathophysiology of mumps</li>
<li>describe the most common tumours of the salivary glands.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mumps-parotitis">Mumps (parotitis)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mumps-parotitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is an acute inflammatory condition of the salivary glands, especially the parotids. It is caused by the mumps virus, one of the parainfluenza group. The virus is spread by inhalation of infected droplets. Viruses multiply elsewhere in the body before spreading to the salivary glands. The virus is most infectious for 1-2 days before and 5 days after symptoms appear. Although most common between 5 and 15 years of age, mumps also affects adults and is often a more serious infection; about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>25</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">25 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">25%</span></span></span></span></span> of adult males suffer from testicular inflammation (orchitis), which can result in atrophy and occasionally sterility. Complications that affect the brain, including meningitis and meningoencephalitis (Ch. 7), may arise at any age.</p>
<p>In developed countries, children are usually vaccinated against mumps in their preschool years.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="tumours-of-the-salivary-glands">Tumours of the salivary glands<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tumours-of-the-salivary-glands" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="salivary-adenoma">Salivary adenoma<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#salivary-adenoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This benign tumour occurs mainly in the parotid gland and is the most common tumour of the salivary glands. A second tumour may develop in the same gland several years after the first has been removed and occasionally undergoes malignant change.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="carcinoma">Carcinoma<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#carcinoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Malignant tumours most commonly affect the parotid glands. Some forms may infiltrate nerves in the surrounding tissues, causing severe pain. Spread by lymph is to the cervical nodes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="spot-check">SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol start="19">
<li>Which infection of the salivary glands forms part of childhood immunisation programmes in many countries?</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="diseases-of-the-oesophagus">Diseases of the oesophagus<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diseases-of-the-oesophagus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>explain how oesophageal varices develop</li>
<li>discuss the main inflammatory conditions of the oesophagus</li>
<li>describe the main oesophageal tumours</li>
<li>define oesophageal atresia and tracheooesophageal fistula.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="oesophageal-varices-a-12-10">Oesophageal varices a 12.10<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#oesophageal-varices-a-12-10" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In conditions such as cirrhosis (p.363) or venous thrombosis, blood flow into the liver via the portal vein is impeded and blood pressure within the portal system rises (portal hypertension). This forces blood from the portal vein into anastomotic veins, which redirect (shunt) blood into the systemic venous circulation, bypassing the liver (Fig. 12.47). Fifty per cent or more of the portal blood may be shunted into anastomotic veins, leading to rising pressure in these veins too. One route taken by the shunted blood is into veins of the lower oesophagus, which then become distended and weakened by the abnormally high volume of blood. Varices (localised dilations of veins) develop when the weakest regions of the vessel wall bulge outwards into the lumen of the oesophagus; being thin-walled and fragile, they are easily eroded or traumatised by swallowed food. Bleeding may be minor but chronic, leading to iron deficiency anaemia (p. 74); however, sudden rupture can cause life-threatening haemorrhage.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="inflammatory-and-infectious-conditions">Inflammatory and infectious conditions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#inflammatory-and-infectious-conditions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="acute-oesophagitis">Acute oesophagitis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#acute-oesophagitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This arises if caustic materials are swallowed and also if immunocompromised people acquire severe fungal infections, typically candidiasis (p.319), or viral infections</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-04345b6f.jpeg" alt="img-68.jpeg"></p>
<p>Oesophageal
To superior vena cava
Oesophagus
Rising pressure causes varices in venous walls

<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-c2a16c9e.jpeg" alt="img-69.jpeg"></p>
<p>Portal vein
