Figure 12.47 Oesophageal varices.
such as herpes simplex. Dysphagia (difficulty in swallowing) is usually present. Following severe injury, healing often causes fibrosis, and there is a risk of oesophageal stricture developing later, as the fibrous tissue shrinks.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="gastro-oesophageal-reflux-disease">Gastro-oesophageal reflux disease<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gastro-oesophageal-reflux-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Gastro-oesophageal reflux disease (GORD), the most common cause of indigestion (or 'heartburn'), is caused by persistent regurgitation of acidic gastric juice into the oesophagus, causing irritation, inflammation and painful ulceration. Haemorrhage occurs when blood vessels are eroded. Persistent reflux leads to chronic inflammation, and if damage is extensive, secondary healing with fibrosis occurs. Shrinkage of mature fibrous tissue may cause stricture of the oesophagus. When</p>
<p>chronic, this condition can lead to Barrett's oesophagus (see next section). Reflux of gastric contents is associated with:</p>
<ul>
<li>an increase in the intra-abdominal pressure, e.g. in pregnancy, constipation and obesity</li>
<li>low levels of the hormone gastrin, that reduce the activity of the lower oesphageal sphincter</li>
<li>the presence of hiatus hernia (Fig. 12.52C).
those found in the stomach replace the squamous epithelium of the lower oesophagus.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="achalasia">Achalasia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#achalasia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>In this condition, peristalsis of the lower oesophagus is impaired and the lower oesophageal sphincter fails to relax during swallowing, causing accumulation of food and drink in the oesophagus, dysphagia, regurgitation of gastric contents and aspiration pneumonia. The oesophagus becomes dilated and the muscle layer hypertrophies. The autonomic nerve supply to the oesophageal muscle is abnormal but the cause is not known. Achalasia may occur at any age but is most common in middle life.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="tumours-of-the-oesophagus">Tumours of the oesophagus<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tumours-of-the-oesophagus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Benign tumours are rare, accounting for only <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>5</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">5 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">5%</span></span></span></span></span> of oesophageal tumours.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="malignant-tumours">Malignant tumours<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#malignant-tumours" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These occur more often in males than in females. They are most common in the lower oesophagus, often associated with Barrett's oesophagus, but can arise at any level. Both types of tumour described here tend to begin as an ulcer that spreads round the circumference, causing a stricture that results in dysphagia. By the time of diagnosis, local spread has usually occurred and the prognosis is therefore very poor.</p>
<p>The geographical incidence of squamous cell carcinoma varies greatly worldwide. It is associated with long-term high alcohol intake and cigarette smoking. Other predisposing factors are believed to include obesity, low fruit and vegetable consumption, and chewing betel nuts or tobacco.</p>
<p>Adenocarcinoma usually develops from Barrett's oesophagus (see earlier).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="congenital-disorders">Congenital disorders<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#congenital-disorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The most common congenital disorders of the oesophagus are:</p>
<ul>
<li>oesophageal atresia, in which the lumen is narrow or blocked</li>
<li>tracheo-oesophageal fistula, in which there is an opening (fistula) between the oesophagus and the trachea through which milk or regurgitated gastric contents are aspirated.</li>
</ul>
<p>One or both abnormalities may be present. The causes are unknown.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="barrett-s-oesophagus">Barrett's oesophagus<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#barrett-s-oesophagus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is a premalignant condition that is usually associated with long-standing GORD; it is sometimes accompanied by a hiatus hernia (Fig. 12.52C). Columnar cells resembling</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5205029c">â–  SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5205029c" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol start="20">
<li>Identify two congenital abnormalities of the oesophagus.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="diseases-of-the-stomach">Diseases of the stomach<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diseases-of-the-stomach" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>compare the main features of chronic and acute gastritis</li>
<li>discuss the pathophysiology of peptic ulcer disease</li>
<li>describe the main tumours of the stomach and their consequences</li>
<li>define the term 'congenital pyloric stenosis'.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="gastritis">Gastritis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gastritis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Inflammation of the stomach can be an acute or chronic condition.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="acute-gastritis">Acute gastritis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#acute-gastritis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is usually a response to irritant drugs or alcohol. The drugs most commonly implicated are non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), including aspirin, even at low doses, although many others may also be involved. Other causes include the initial response to Helicobacter pylori infection (see later) and severe physiological stress, e.g. extensive burns and multiple organ failure.</p>
<p>There are varying degrees of severity. Mild cases can be asymptomatic or may present with nausea and vomiting associated with inflammatory changes of the gastric mucosa. Erosions, which are characterised by tissue loss affecting the superficial layers of the gastric mucosa, may also occur. In more serious cases,</p>
<p>multiple erosions may result in life-threatening haemorrhage, causing haematemesis (see Table 12.4) and melaena (see Table 12.4), especially in older adults.</p>
<p>The outcome depends on the extent of the damage. In many cases, recovery is speedy and uneventful after the cause is removed. Where there has been extensive tissue damage, healing is by fibrosis, causing reduced elasticity and peristalsis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="chronic-gastritis">Chronic gastritis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chronic-gastritis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Chronic gastritis is a milder but longer-lasting condition. It is usually associated with H . pylori but is sometimes due to autoimmune disease or chemical injury. It is more common in later life.</p>
<p>Helicobacter-assoc'aXe6 gastritis
H. pylori is a bacterium that colonises the gastric mucosa and is commonly associated with gastric conditions, especially chronic gastritis and peptic ulcer disease.</p>
<p>Autoimmune chronic gastritis
This is a progressive disease. Destructive inflammatory changes that begin on the surface of the mucous membrane may extend to affect its whole thickness, including the gastric glands. When this stage is reached, secretion of hydrochloric acid and intrinsic factor is markedly reduced. The antigens are the gastric parietal cells and the intrinsic factor they secrete. When the parietal cells are destroyed as a result of this autoimmune condition, the inflammation subsides. The causes of the autoimmunity are not known but there is a familial predisposition and an association with autoimmune thyroid disorders. Secondary consequences include:</p>
<ul>
<li>pernicious anaemia due to lack of intrinsic factor (p. 74)</li>
<li>increased risk of cancer of the stomach.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="peptic-ulcer-disease">Peptic ulcer disease<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#peptic-ulcer-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Peptic ulcers involve the full thickness of the gastrointestinal mucosa and penetrate the muscle layer of the stomach or duodenum (Fig. 12.48). They are caused by disruption of the normal balance between the corrosive effect of gastric juice and the protective effect of mucus on the gastric epithelial cells. They may be viewed as an extension of the gastric erosions found in acute gastritis. The most common sites for ulcers are the stomach and the first few centimetres of the duodenum. More rarely, they occur in the oesophagus and round the anastomosis of the stomach and small intestine, following gastrectomy.
H. pylori infection is very common, affecting 50-60% of adults worldwide. Most people remain healthy and asymptomatic with only a minority developing symptoms; it is thought that infection is acquired in childhood. H. pylori is strongly</p>
<p>associated with peptic ulcer disease, being found in <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>90</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">90 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">90%</span></span></span></span></span> of people with duodenal ulcers and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>70</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">70 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">70%</span></span></span></span></span> of those with gastric ulcers. Most other gastric ulcers are attributed to the use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs).</p>
<p>H "1
â– 1 ' 1</p>
<p>Aãƒ».*V
V
. . <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mspace width="1em"></mspace></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\quad</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0em;"></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 1em;"></span></span></span></span></span>.f <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">\</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\backslash</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">\</span></span></span></span></span>
â– i- Tâ– t</p>
<p>MB % .</p>
<p>ãƒ»,1
.ir-pi . 'T
Â«
tki*
3 f', â– 'i,"',,"*</p>
<p>Figure 12.48 Peptic ulceration. A large duodenal ulcer. (CNRI/ Science Photo Library. Reproduced with permission.)</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-4d84f767.jpeg" alt="img-70.jpeg"></p>
<p>Smoking predisposes to peptic ulceration and delays healing. The incidence of peptic ulcers is greater in men than in women and increases with age.</p>
<p>If gastric mucosal protection is impaired, the epithelium can be exposed to gastric acid, causing the initial cell damage that leads to ulceration. The main protective mechanisms are a good blood supply, adequate mucus secretion and efficient epithelial cell replacement.</p>
<p>Blood supply. Reduced blood flow and ischaemia may be caused by cigarette smoking and severe stress, either physical or mental. In stressful situations the accompanying sympathetic activity causes constriction of the blood vessels supplying the alimentary tract.</p>
<p>Secretion of mucus. The composition and the amount of mucus may be altered, for example:</p>
<ul>
<li>by regular and prolonged use of aspirin and other anti-inflammatory drugs</li>
<li>by the reflux of bile acids and salts</li>
<li>in chronic gastritis.</li>
</ul>
<p>Epithelial cell replacement. There is normally a rapid turnover of gastric and intestinal epithelial cells. This may be reduced:</p>
<ul>
<li>by raised levels of steroid hormones, e.g. in response to stress or when they are used as drugs</li>
<li>in chronic gastritis</li>
<li>by radiotherapy and cytotoxic drugs.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="acute-peptic-ulcers">Acute peptic ulcers<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#acute-peptic-ulcers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These lesions may be single or multiple. They are found in many sites in the stomach and in the first few centimetres of the duodenum. Their development is often associated with acute gastritis, severe stress, e.g. severe illness, shock, burns, severe emotional disturbance and following major surgery. Healing without the</p>
<p>formation of fibrous tissue usually occurs when the stressor is removed, although haemorrhage, which may be life-threatening, can be a complication.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="chronic-peptic-ulcers">Chronic peptic ulcers<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chronic-peptic-ulcers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These ulcers are 2-3 times more common in the duodenum than in the stomach. They usually occur singly in the pylorus of the stomach or in the duodenum. Healing occurs with the formation of fibrous tissue. Its subsequent shrinkage may cause:</p>
<ul>
<li>stricture of the lumen of the stomach</li>
<li>gastric outflow obstruction or stenosis of the pyloric sphincter</li>
<li>adhesions to adjacent structures, e.g. pancreas, liver or transverse colon.</li>
</ul>
<p>Complications of peptic ulcers
Perforation. When an ulcer erodes through the full thickness of the wall of the stomach or duodenum, the contents of these structures enter the peritoneal cavity, causing acute peritonitis (p.354).</p>
<p>Infected inflammatory material may collect under the diaphragm, forming a subphrenic abscess (Fig. 12.49), and the infection may spread through the diaphragm to the pleural cavity.</p>
<p>Haemorrhage. When a major artery is eroded, a serious and possibly lifethreatening haemorrhage may occur, causing shock (p. 122), haematemesis and/or melaena.</p>
<p>Anaemia. Chronic, persistent, low-level bleeding from an ulcer may lead to development of iron deficiency anaemia (p. 73). Gastric outflow obstruction. Also known as pyloric stenosis, fibrous tissue formed as an ulcer in the pyloric region heals, causes narrowing of the pylorus that obstructs outflow from the stomach, and results in persistent vomiting.</p>
<p>Malignancy. See next section.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="tumours-of-the-stomach">Tumours of the stomach<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tumours-of-the-stomach" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Benign tumours of the stomach are rare.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="malignant-tumours">Malignant tumours<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#malignant-tumours" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is a common malignancy that occurs more frequently in men than in women; the incidence increases sharply after 50 years of age. The causes have not been established but there appears to be a link with H. pylori infection in <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>60</mn><mo>âˆ’</mo><mn>70</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">60-70 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">60</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">âˆ’</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">70%</span></span></span></span></span> of</p>
<p>cases. Smoking, alcohol and diets high in salted, smoked and pickled food have also been implicated.</p>
<p>Local growth of the tumour gradually destroys the normal tissue so that achlorhydria (reduced hydrochloric acid secretion) and pernicious anaemia are frequently secondary features. As the tumour grows, the surface may ulcerate and become infected, especially when achlorhydria develops.</p>
<p>This condition carries a poor prognosis because spread has often already occurred prior to diagnosis. Local spread is to adjacent organs, e.g. the oesophagus, duodenum and pancreas, and also to the peritoneal cavity when the outermost layer, the serosa, is affected. Spread via the blood is by the hepatic portal vein to the liver, where tumour cells may lodge, causing metastases. Lymphatic spread is also common, initially to nearby nodes and later to more distant ones.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="congenital-pyloric-stenosis">Congenital pyloric stenosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#congenital-pyloric-stenosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>In this condition there is spasmodic constriction of the pyloric sphincter, characteristic projectile vomiting and failure to put on weight. In an attempt to overcome the spasms, hypertrophy of the muscle of the pylorus develops, causing pyloric obstruction 2-3 weeks after birth. The cause is not known but there is a familial tendency and the condition is more common in boys.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5205029c">â–  SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5205029c" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol start="21">
<li>Name the two most common causes of peptic ulceration.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="diseases-of-the-intestines">Diseases of the intestines<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diseases-of-the-intestines" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe appendicitis and its consequences</li>
<li>discuss the principal infectious disease of the intestines</li>
<li>compare and contrast the features of Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis</li>
<li>distinguish between diverticulitis and diverticulosis</li>
<li>describe the main tumours of the intestines</li>
<li>describe the abnormalities present in hernia, volvulus and intussusception</li>
<li>list the main causes of intestinal obstruction</li>
<li>compare the causes and outcomes of primary and secondary malabsorption.</li>
</ul>
<p>Diseases of the small and large intestines are described together because they have certain characteristics in common and some conditions affect both.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="appendicitis">Appendicitis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#appendicitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The lumen of the appendix is very narrow and there is little room for swelling when it becomes inflamed. The initial cause of inflammation is not always clear. Microbial infection is commonly superimposed on obstruction by, for example, hard faecal matter (faecoliths), kinking or a foreign body. Inflammatory exudate, with fibrin and phagocytes, causes swelling and ulceration of the mucous membrane lining. In the initial stages the pain of appendicitis is usually located in the central area of the abdomen. After a few hours the pain typically shifts and becomes localised to the region above the appendix (the right iliac fossa). In mild cases the inflammation subsides and healing takes place. In more severe cases, microbial growth progresses, leading to suppuration, abscess formation and further congestion. The rising pressure inside the appendix occludes local veins first and then the arteries, causing ischaemia, which may be followed by gangrene and perforation.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="complications-of-appendicitis-peritonitis">Complications of appendicitis Peritonitis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#complications-of-appendicitis-peritonitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The peritoneum becomes acutely inflamed, the blood vessels dilate and excess serous fluid is secreted. Peritonitis occurs as a complication of appendicitis when:</p>
<ul>
<li>microbes spread through the wall of the appendix and infect the peritoneum</li>
<li>an appendix abscess (Fig. 12.49) perforates and pus enters the peritoneal cavity
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-5b7466b5.jpeg" alt="img-71.jpeg"></li>
</ul>
<p>Figure 12.49 Abscess fornnation. This is a compiication of
appendicitis.</p>
<ul>
<li>the appendix becomes gangrenous and perforates, discharging its contents into the peritoneal cavity.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="abscess-formation">Abscess formation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#abscess-formation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The most common types are:</p>
<ul>
<li>subphrenic abscess, between the liver and diaphragm, from which infection may spread upwards to the pleura, pericardium and mediastinal structures</li>
<li>pelvic abscess, from which infection may spread to adjacent structures (Fig. 12.49).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="adhesions">Adhesions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#adhesions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>When healing takes place, bands of fibrous scar tissue
(adhesions) form and later shrinkage may cause:</p>
<ul>
<li>stricture or obstruction of the bowel</li>
<li>limitation of the movement of a loop of bowel, which may twist around the adhesion, causing a type of bowel obstruction called a volvulus (p.359).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="gastrointestinal-infections">Gastrointestinal infections<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gastrointestinal-infections" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The incidence of these diseases varies considerably but they represent a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. Public health measures, including clean, safe drinking water and effective sewage disposal, and safe food hygiene practices greatly reduce their spread; many are highly contagious. As most of these infections are spread by the faecal-oral route, meticulous handwashing after defaecation and after contact of the hands with any potentially contaminated material is essential, especially in healthcare facilities. Contaminated drinking water results in</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="learning-outcomes">Learning outcomes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#learning-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>diarrhoeal diseases that are a major cause of illness in all age groups and of infant death in developing countries.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="typhoid-and-paratyphoid-enteric-fever">Typhoid and paratyphoid (enteric) fever<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#typhoid-and-paratyphoid-enteric-fever" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Typhoid and paratyphoid fevers are caused by Salmonella typhi and S. paratyphi A or B, respectively. Both are common in some tropical countries and both are spread by the faecaloral route from food, water or any items contaminated by individuals who either are suffering from the illness or are carriers (see later).</p>
<p>The incubation period is about 10-14 days, during which time bacteria invade the lymphoid tissue of the small intestine, especially the aggregated lymph follicles (Peyer's patches). Thereafter, the microbes spread via the blood to the liver, spleen and gall bladder. A bacteraemic period (febrile illness) follows, accompanied by malaise, headache, drowsiness and aching limbs. The intestinal lymphoid tissue becomes acutely inflamed and ulcerated, although healing usually follows. The spleen becomes enlarged (splenomegaly) and red spots are typically seen on the skin, especially that of the chest and back.</p>
<p>Typhoid fever is serious and often fatal without treatment. Complications due to spread of microbes during the bacteraemic phase include pneumonia, meningitis and typhoid cholecystitis, in which microbes multiply in the gall bladder and are secreted in the bile, reinfecting the intestine (Fig. 12.50). Bacterial toxins can cause disorders of the heart (myocarditis, Ch. 5) and kidneys (nephritis, Ch. 13). In the bowel, ulcers may perforate a blood vessel wall, resulting in haemorrhage, or erode the intestinal wall, causing acute peritonitis.</p>
<p>A few individuals (up to 5%) may become carriers if there is asymptomatic but chronic infection of the gall bladder.</p>
<p>Continued release of microbes into the bile for months or years after recovery leads to infection of the faeces; much less often the urinary system is also involved and</p>
<p>microbes are released into the urine. Carriers may transmit the infection to others through contact with their infected faeces or urine.</p>
<p>Paratyphoid fever follows a similar course but is usually milder and of shorter duration, although the onset can be more sudden; complications are less frequent. Some people may become carriers but fewer than in typhoid fever.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="other-salmonella-infections">Other Salmonella infections<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#other-salmonella-infections" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Salmonella typhimurium and S. enteritidis are the most common bacteria in this group. Generally, the effects are confined to the gastrointestinal tract, unlike the Salmonella infections already described. In addition to humans, their hosts are domestic animals and birds. The microbes may be present in meat, poultry, eggs and milk, causing infection if cooking does not achieve sterilisation. Mice and rats also carry the organisms and may contaminate food before or after cooking.</p>
<p>The incubation period is 12-72 hours; enteritis is usually short-lived and accompanied by acute abdominal pain, diarrhoea and sometimes vomiting, which may cause dehydration and electrolyte imbalance. In children and debilitated older adults the infection may be severe or even fatal.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="escherichia-coli-food-poisoning">Escherichia coli food poisoning<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#escherichia-coli-food-poisoning" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Common sources of these bacteria include under-cooked meat and unpasteurised milk; adequate cooking and pasteurisation kill E. coli. The severity of the disease depends on the type of E. coli responsible; some types are more virulent than others. Outbreaks of E. coli food poisoning can cause fatalities, particularly in young children and older adults.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-c15ddf27.jpeg" alt="img-72.jpeg"></p>
<p>Infected bile <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">âˆ§</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">{ }^{\wedge}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7519em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7519em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">âˆ§</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> ^ Infected urine j ^ Infected faeces j
Figure 12.50 The routes of excretion of microbes in typhoid and paratyphoid (enteric) fever.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="staphylococcal-food-poisoning">Staphylococcal food poisoning<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#staphylococcal-food-poisoning" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>After contaminated food is eaten, ingested Staphylococcus aureus releases toxins that cause acute gastroenteritis (rather than the bacteria that cause the condition). Although cooking kills the bacteria, the toxins are heat-resistant.</p>
<p>There is usually short-term acute inflammation with violent vomiting occurring 2-4 hours after ingestion, which may cause dehydration and electrolyte imbalance. Diarrhoea may not be significant. In most cases, complete recovery occurs within 24 hours.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="clostridium-perfringens-food-poisoning">Clostridium perfringens food poisoning<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clostridium-perfringens-food-poisoning" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These commensal anaerobic, spore-forming bacteria are normally present in the intestines of humans and animals, but can cause food poisoning when ingested in large numbers. Bacterial spores may become a source of food poisoning; large outbreaks are generally associated with industrial catering, e.g. in schools and hospitals. When meat or poultry is cooled slowly and/or stored in unrefrigerated conditions and/or prepared in advance
and kept warm for several hours before serving, dormant microbial spores germinate into viable bacteria, which then multiply very rapidly. When the ingested bacteria reach the intestines, they release powerful toxins that cause watery diarrhoea and severe abdominal pain. The illness is usually self-limiting.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="antibiotic-associated-diarrhoea">Antibiotic-associated diarrhoea<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#antibiotic-associated-diarrhoea" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The bacterium Clostridium difficile is already present in the large intestine, but after antibiotic therapy many other commensal intestinal bacteria die. This allows C. difficile to proliferate, releasing toxins that damage the mucosa of the large intestine and causing profound diarrhoea. Hospitalised older adults are most commonly affected and they are highly susceptible to inflammation of the large intestine (colitis), which is often fatal.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="campylobacter-food-poisoning">Campylobacter food poisoning<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#campylobacter-food-poisoning" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These Gram-negative bacilli are a common cause of gastroenteritis, which affects mainly young adults and children under 5 years. The bacteria are present in the intestines of birds and animals, and are transmitted in under-cooked poultry and meat. They may also be spread in contaminated water and milk. There is an association with Guillain-Barre syndrome (Ch. 7).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cholera">Cholera<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cholera" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Cholera is caused by Vibrio cholerae, which is spread by contaminated drinking water, faeces, vomit, food, hands and fomites. The only known hosts are humans. In some infected people, known as subclinical cases, no symptoms occur, although these people can transmit the condition to others while their infection remains. A</p>
<p>very powerful toxin is released by the bacteria, which stimulates the intestinal glands to secrete large quantities of water, bicarbonate and chloride. This leads to persistent watery diarrhoea, severe dehydration and electrolyte imbalance, and may cause death due to hypovolaemic shock.</p>
<p>Dysentery Bacillary dysentery
This infection of the large intestine is caused by bacteria of the Shigella group, which are closely related to E. coli. The severity of the condition depends on the organisms involved. In the UK it is usually a relatively mild condition caused by Shigella sonnei. S. dysenteriae causes the most severe infection and it occurs mainly in the tropics. Children and older debilitated adults are particularly susceptible. The only host is humans and the organisms are spread by faecal contamination of food, drink, hands and any items handled by infected individuals (fomites).</p>
<p>The intestinal mucosa becomes inflamed, ulcerated and oedematous with excessive mucus secretion. In severe
infections, the acute diarrhoea, which contains blood and excessive mucus, causes dehydration, electrolyte imbalance and anaemia. When healing occurs, the mucous membrane is fully restored.</p>
<p>Amoebiasis (amoebic dysentery)
This disease is caused by the protozoan Entamoeba histolytica. The only known hosts are humans and infection is spread by faecal contamination of food, water, hands and fomites. Although many infected people do not develop symptoms, they may become asymptomatic carriers.</p>
<p>The amoebae grow, divide and invade the mucosal cells, causing inflammation within the colon (colitis). Without treatment the condition frequently becomes chronic with mild, intermittent diarrhoea and abdominal pain. This may progress with ulceration of the colon, accompanied by persistent and debilitating diarrhoea that contains mucus and blood. Complications are unusual but include severe haemorrhage from ulcers and liver abscesses.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="viral-gastroenteritis">Viral gastroenteritis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#viral-gastroenteritis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Several viruses, including rotavirus and norovirus, are known to cause vomiting and/or diarrhoea.</p>
<p>Rotavirus
This is a major cause of diarrhoea in young children worldwide. It is easily spread in childcare facilities.</p>
<p>Norovirus</p>
<p>Also known as the 'winter vomiting virus', this is responsible for outbreaks of acute but self-limiting enteritis with vomiting as the main symptom. Most common in the winter months, it spreads easily in families and in closed communities, e.g. childcare and healthcare facilities. Spread is generally by the faecal-oral route but airborne transmission by inhalation may also occur.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="inflammatory-bowel-disease">Inflammatory bowel disease<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#inflammatory-bowel-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The term inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) includes two chronic conditions: Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis. A comparison of the main features is shown in Table 12.5; however, it is not always possible to distinguish them in practice. Their aetiology is unknown but is thought to involve environmental and immune factors in genetically susceptible individuals. Both conditions typically have a pattern of relapse and remission.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="crohn-s-disease">Crohn's disease<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#crohn-s-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This chronic inflammatory condition of the alimentary tract usually occurs in young adults. The terminal ileum and the rectum are most commonly affected but the disease may affect any part of the tract. There is chronic patchy inflammation with oedema of the full thickness of the</p>
<p>Table 12.5
Comparison of the main features of Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis</p>
<p>Crohn's disease Ulcerative colitis</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: center;">Incidence</th><th style="text-align: center;">Usually between 20 and 40 years of age (mean 26 years); both sexes affected equally; smokers at higher risk</th><th style="text-align: center;">Usually between 20 and 40 years of age (mean 34 years); both sexes affected equally; smoking not a risk factor</th></tr></thead></table>
<p>Main sites of lesions Anywhere in digestive tract Rectum always involved, from mouth to anus; with variable spread along common in terminal ileum colon</p>
<p>Tissue involved Entire thickness of wall Only mucosa involved affected; ulcers and fistulae common</p>
<p>Nature of lesions 'Skip' lesions, i.e. diseased Continuous lesion that areas interspersed with spreads proximally from</p>
<table><thead><tr><th></th><th>regions of normal tissue; ulcers and fistulae common</th><th>rectum; mucosa is red and inflamed</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Prognosis</td><td>In severe cases, surgery may improve condition but relapse rate very high; slightly increased risk of cancer</td><td>Surgical removal of entire colon cures condition; significantly increased risk of cancer</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>intestinal wall, causing partial obstruction of the lumen, sometimes described as skip lesions. There are periods of remission of varying duration. The main symptoms are diarrhoea, abdominal pain and weight loss. Complications include:</p>
<ul>
<li>secondary infections, occurring when inflamed areas ulcerate</li>
<li>fibrous adhesions and subsequent intestinal obstruction, caused by the healing process</li>
<li>fistulae between intestinal lesions and adjacent structures, e.g. loops of bowel, surface of the skin (p. 401)</li>
<li>perianal fistulae, fissures and skin tags</li>
<li>cancer of the small or large intestine.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="ulcerative-colitis">Ulcerative colitis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ulcerative-colitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is a chronic inflammatory disease of the mucosa of the colon and rectum, which may ulcerate and become infected. It usually occurs in young adults and begins in the rectum. From there, it may spread proximally to involve a variable proportion of the colon and, sometimes, the entire colon. The main symptom is bloody diarrhoea. There are periods of remission lasting weeks, months or years. Individuals may develop other systemic problems affecting, for example, the joints (ankylosing spondylitis, p. 470), skin and liver. In long-standing cases, cancer sometimes develops.</p>
<p>Toxic megacolon is an acute complication in which the colon loses its muscle tone and dilates. There is a high risk of electrolyte imbalance, perforation and hypovolaemic shock, which may be fatal if untreated.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="a832b156">Diverticular disease <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">â–¡</mi><mn>12.11</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\square 12.11</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.675em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">â–¡</span><span class="mord">12.11</span></span></span></span></span><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a832b156" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-d63192cc.jpeg" alt="img-73.jpeg"></p>
<p>Mucosa</p>
<p>Submucosa
Smooth muscle (circular fibres)
Diverticuli
Taenia coli
Figure 12.51 Diverticular disease. Cross-section of bowel showing diverticuli.
The causes of diverticulosis (presence of diverticula) are not known but it is associated with deficiency of dietary fibre. In Western countries, diverticulosis is fairly common after middle age but is usually asymptomatic.</p>
<p>Diverticulitis arises as a consequence of diverticulosis when faeces become trapped in the diverticula. The walls become inflamed and oedematous as secondary infection develops. This reduces the blood supply, causing ischaemic abdominal pain. Occasionally, perforation occurs, resulting in peritonitis (p.354).</p>
<p>Diverticula are small pouches of mucosa that protrude (herniate) into the peritoneal cavity through the circular muscle fibres of the colon between the taeniae coli (Fig. 12.51). The walls consist of mucous membrane with a covering of visceral peritoneum. They occur at the weakest points of the intestinal wall, i.e. where the blood vessels enter, most commonly in the sigmoid colon.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="tumours-of-the-small-and-large-intestines">Tumours of the small and large intestines<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tumours-of-the-small-and-large-intestines" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Benign and malignant tumours of the small intestine are rare, especially in comparison with the stomach, large intestine and rectum.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="table-12-5-comparison-of-the-main-features-of-crohn-s-disease-and-ulcerative-colitis">Table 12.5 Comparison of the main features of Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#table-12-5-comparison-of-the-main-features-of-crohn-s-disease-and-ulcerative-colitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="benign-tumours">Benign tumours<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#benign-tumours" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Benign neoplasms may form a broad-based mass or polyp, i.e. develop a pedicle. Occasionally, polyps twist on themselves, causing ischaemia, necrosis and sometimes gangrene.</p>
<p>Malignant changes may occur in adenomas, which are mostly found in the large intestine. The incidence is high in developed countries.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="colorectal-cancer">Colorectal cancer<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#colorectal-cancer" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is the most common malignancy of the alimentary tract in developed countries and in the UK is second only to lung cancer as a cause of cancer-related death.</p>
<p>The most important predisposing factor for colorectal cancer is thought to be diet. In cultures eating a high-fibre, low-fat diet the disease is virtually unknown, whereas in countries where large quantities of red meat and saturated animal fat and insufficient fibre are eaten, the disease is much more common. Slow movement of bowel contents may result in conversion of unknown substances present into carcinogenic agents. Genetic factors are also implicated. Predisposing diseases include ulcerative colitis and some benign tumours (usually adenomas).</p>
<p>The tumours are adenocarcinomas with about half arising in the rectum, one-third in the sigmoid colon and the remainder elsewhere in the colon. The tumour may be:</p>
<ul>
<li>a soft polypoid mass, projecting into the lumen of the colon or rectum with a tendency to ulceration, infection and bleeding</li>
<li>a hard fibrous mass encircling the colon, causing narrowing of the lumen and, eventually, obstruction.</li>
</ul>
<p>Local spread occurs early but may not be evident until there is severe ulceration and haemorrhage or intestinal obstruction. Spread can be outwards through the wall into the peritoneal cavity and adjacent structures.</p>
<p>Lymph-spread metastases occur in mesenteric lymph nodes, the peritoneum and other abdominal and pelvic organs. Pressure caused by enlarged lymph nodes may cause obstruction or damage other structures.</p>
<p>Blood-spread metastases are most common in the liver, brain and bones.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="hernias">Hernias<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hernias" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A hernia is a protrusion of an organ or part of an organ through a weak point or aperture in the surrounding structures. In hernias affecting the digestive system, a piece of bowel protrudes through a weak point in either the musculature of the anterior abdominal wall or an existing opening (Fig. 12.52 A). It occurs when there are intermittent increases in intra-abdominal pressure, most commonly in men who lift heavy loads at work. Outcomes include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Spontaneous reduction, when the loop of bowel slips back to its correct place once the intra-abdominal pressure returns to normal.</li>
<li>Manual reduction, when gentle pressure is applied over the abdominal swelling.</li>
<li>Strangulation (Fig. 12.52B), when reduction is not possible and the venous drainage from the herniated loop of bowel is impaired, causing congestion, ischaemia and gangrene. In addition, there is intestinal obstruction (p.359).</li>
</ul>
<p>Lower \oesophageal t (cardiac) *sphincter
Incisional (any site)
Femoral
(bowel)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-05ff3c3e.jpeg" alt="img-74.jpeg"></p>
<p>Diaphragm
Stomach

(bowel)
