(bowel)</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-4697cbc1.jpeg" alt="img-75.jpeg"></p>
<p>Skin</p>
<p>Peritoneum
Loop of bowel pushed through B weak point in abdominal wall
Oesophagus
Diaphragm
Stomach
Muscle layers of Rolling abdominal wall
Figure 12.52 Hernias. (A) Common sites of herniation. (B) Strangulated hernia. (C) Hiatus hernia.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="sites-of-hernias">Sites of hernias<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sites-of-hernias" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These are shown in Fig. 12.52A.
Inguinal hernia
The weak point is the inguinal canal, which contains the spermatic cord in the male and the round ligament in the female. It occurs more commonly in males than in females.</p>
<p>Femoral hernia
The weak point is the femoral canal, through which the femoral artery, vein and lymph vessels pass from the pelvis to the thigh.</p>
<p>Umbilical hernia</p>
<p>The weak point is the umbilicus, where the umbilical blood vessels from the placenta entered the fetus before birth.</p>
<p>Incisional hernia
This is caused by repeated stretching of fibrous (scar) tissue formed after previous abdominal surgery.</p>
<p>Hiatus hernia
This is the protrusion of a part of the fundus of the stomach through the oesophageal opening in the diaphragm (Fig. 12.52C). Although often asymptomatic, irritation of the oesophagus occurs, but only when there is reflux of acid gastric juice, especially when the individual lies flat or bends down. The longterm effects may be oesophagitis and fibrosis and narrowing of the oesophagus, causing dysphagia. Strangulation does not occur.</p>
<p>Rolling hiatus hernia. An abnormally large opening in the diaphragm allows a pouch of stomach to 'roll' upwards into the thorax beside the oesophagus. This is associated with obesity and increased intra-abdominal pressure.</p>
<p>Sliding hiatus hernia. Part of the stomach is pulled upwards into the thorax. The abnormality may be caused by shrinkage of fibrous tissue formed during healing of a previous oesophageal injury. The sliding movement of the stomach in the oesophageal opening is due to shortening of the oesophagus by muscular contraction during swallowing.</p>
<p>Peritoneal hernia
A loop of bowel may herniate through the epiploic foramen (of Winslow, see Fig. 12.3A), the opening in the lesser omentum that separates the greater and lesser peritoneal sacs.</p>
<p>Congenital diaphragmatic hernia
Incomplete formation of the diaphragm, usually on the left side, allows abdominal organs such as the stomach and loops of intestine into the thoracic cavity, preventing normal development of the fetal lungs.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="volvulus">Volvulus<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#volvulus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This occurs when a loop of bowel twists, occluding its lumen and resulting in intestinal obstruction. It is usually
accompanied by strangulation, where there is interruption of the blood supply, causing gangrene (Fig. 12.52B). It occurs in parts of the intestine that are attached to the posterior abdominal wall by the mesentery (a long double fold of visceral peritoneum). The most common site in adults is the sigmoid colon and in children it is the small intestine.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="intussusception">Intussusception<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#intussusception" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>In this condition a length of intestine is invaginated into itself, causing intestinal obstruction (Fig. 12.53). It occurs most commonly in children when a piece of terminal ileum is pushed through the ileocaecal valve. The overlying mucosa bulges into the lumen, creating a partial obstruction and a rise in pressure inside the intestine proximal to the swelling. Strong peristaltic waves develop in an attempt to overcome the partial obstruction. These push the swollen piece of bowel into the lumen of the section immediately distal to it, creating the intussusception. The pressure on the veins in the invaginated portion is increased, causing congestion, further swelling, ischaemia and, in severe cases, gangrene. Complete intestinal obstruction may occur. In adults, tumours that bulge into the lumen, e.g. polyps, together with strong peristaltic waves, may be the cause.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="intestinal-obstruction">Intestinal obstruction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#intestinal-obstruction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is not a disease in itself but arises as a consequence of many other conditions. The summary here outlines the effects and main causes of obstruction.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mechanical-causes">Mechanical causes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mechanical-causes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Constriction or blockage of the intestine by, for example, a strangulated hernia, intussusception, volvulus or
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-59dabfa6.jpeg" alt="img-76.jpeg"></li>
</ul>
<p>Appendix
Large intestine (colon)
Small intestine</p>
<p>Caecum</p>
<p>Figure 12.53 Intussusception.
peritoneal adhesions; there is partial obstruction (narrowing of the lumen) that suddenly becomes complete.</p>
<ul>
<li>Stenosis and thickening of the intestinal wall, e.g. in diverticulosis, Crohn's disease and malignant tumours; there is usually a gradual progression from partial to complete obstruction.</li>
<li>Physical causes, where the obstruction is by, for example, a large gallstone or a tumour growing into the lumen.</li>
<li>Pressure on the intestine from outside, e.g. from a large tumour in any pelvic or abdominal organ, such as a uterine fibroid; this is most likely to occur inside the confined space of the pelvic cavity.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="neurological-causes">Neurological causes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#neurological-causes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Partial or complete loss of peristaltic activity produces the effects of obstruction. Paralytic ileus is the most common form. The mechanisms are not clear but there are well-recognised predisposing conditions, including major surgery requiring considerable handling of the intestines, and peritonitis.</p>
<p>Secretion of water and electrolytes continues, although intestinal mobility is lost and absorption impaired. This causes distension and electrolyte imbalance, leading to hypovolaemic shock.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vascular-causes">Vascular causes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vascular-causes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>When the blood supply to a segment of bowel is cut off, ischaemia is followed by infarction and gangrene. The damaged bowel becomes unable to function. The causes of impaired intestinal blood supply include:</p>
<ul>
<li>atheromatous changes in the blood vessel walls, with thrombosis (p. 124)</li>
<li>embolism (p. 124)</li>
<li>secondary mechanical obstruction of the bowel, e.g. strangulated hernia (Fig. 12.52B).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="effects">Effects<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#effects" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Symptoms include abdominal pain, vomiting and constipation. When the upper gastrointestinal tract is affected, vomiting may be profuse, although it may be absent in lower bowel obstruction. There are neither bowel sounds nor passing of flatus (wind) present, as peristalsis ceases. Without treatment, irrespective of the cause, this condition is fatal.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="malabsorption">Malabsorption<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#malabsorption" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Impaired absorption of nutrients and water from the intestines is not a disease in itself, but the result of abnormal changes in one or more of the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>villi in the small intestine, e.g. coeliac disease, tropical sprue (see later)</li>
<li>digestion of food</li>
<li>absorption or transport of nutrients from the small intestine.</li>
</ul>
<p>Intestinal conditions that impair normal digestion and/ or absorption and transport of nutrients include:</p>
<ul>
<li>extensive resection of the small intestine</li>
<li>'blind loop syndrome', where there is microbial overgrowth in a blind end of intestine following surgery</li>
<li>lymphatic obstruction by diseased or absent (following surgical excision) lymph nodes.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="coeliac-disease">Coeliac disease<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#coeliac-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This disease is the main cause of malabsorption in developed countries. It is due to an abnormal, genetically determined autoimmune reaction to the protein gluten, present in wheat, barley and rye. When it is removed from the diet, there is complete remission of symptoms. There is marked villous atrophy, especially in the jejunum, and malabsorption characterised by the passage of loose, pale-coloured, fatty stools (steatorrhoea).</p>
<p>T-cell function may be disordered, causing abnormal immune reactions to other antigens as well. Atrophy of the spleen is common and malignancy of the small intestine is a rarer consequence. Sometimes other autoimmune conditions are also present. It often presents in infants after weaning or in adults during the third or fourth decades, more commonly in women.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="tropical-sprue">Tropical sprue<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tropical-sprue" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This disease is endemic in subtropical and tropical countries except those in Africa. The disease may become chronic and progressive in indigenous populations. After returning from an endemic area most travellers suffering from sprue recover, but others may not develop symptoms until months or even years later.</p>
<p>There is partial villous atrophy with malabsorption, chronic diarrhoea, a variable degree of weight loss and pernicious anaemia due to deficient absorption of vitamin</p>
<p>Bi 2 and folic acid. The cause is unknown but microbial infection may be a factor, as occasional epidemics occur.</p>
<ul>
<li>SPOT CHECK</li>
</ul>
<ol start="22">
<li>Gastrointestinal infections are often highly contagious. Describe how their transmission can be minimised.</li>
<li>What is a hernia?</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="diseases-of-the-pancreas">Diseases of the pancreas<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diseases-of-the-pancreas" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>compare and contrast the causes and effects of acute and chronic pancreatitis</li>
<li>outline the main pancreatic tumours and their consequences.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pancreatitis">Pancreatitis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pancreatitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Proteolytic enzymes produced by the pancreas are secreted in inactive forms, which are not activated until they reach the intestine; this protects the pancreas from digestion by its own enzymes. If these precursor enzymes are activated while still in the pancreas, pancreatitis results.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="acute-pancreatitis">Acute pancreatitis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#acute-pancreatitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The severity of the disease is directly related to the amount of pancreatic tissue involved. Mild forms are more common and damage only those cells near the ducts; recovery is usually complete.</p>
<p>Severe forms cause widespread damage with necrosis and haemorrhage. Common complications include infection, suppuration and local venous thrombosis. Pancreatic enzymes, especially amylase, enter and circulate in the blood, causing similar damage to other structures. In severe cases there is a high mortality rate.</p>
<p>The causes of acute pancreatitis are not clear but known predisposing factors are gallstones and excessive alcohol intake. Less common causes include:</p>
<ul>
<li>pancreatic cancer (see later)</li>
<li>viral infections, notably mumps</li>
<li>kidney and liver transplantation</li>
<li>hypercalcaemia</li>
<li>severe hypothermia</li>
<li>drugs, e.g. corticosteroids, some cytotoxic agents.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="chronic-pancreatitis">Chronic pancreatitis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chronic-pancreatitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This either is due to repeated attacks of acute pancreatitis or may arise gradually without evidence of pancreatic disease. Chronic pancreatitis is associated with irreversible structural changes. It is more common in men and is frequently associated with fibrosis and distortion of the main pancreatic duct. There is intestinal malabsorption when pancreatic secretions are reduced, and diabetes mellitus (p. 255) occurs when damage affects the p-islet cells.</p>
<p>Protein material secreted by the acinar cells blocks the tiny acinar ducts. This eventually leads to the formation of</p>
<p>encapsulated cysts, which are a feature of acute and chronic pancreatitis.
The most common cause in developed countries is excessive alcohol consumption. In developing countries, dietary factors and malnutrition have been implicated. Chronic pancreatitis is also associated with cystic fibrosis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cystic-fibrosis">Cystic fibrosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cystic-fibrosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>See page 288 .</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="tumours-of-the-pancreas">Tumours of the pancreas<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tumours-of-the-pancreas" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Benign tumours are very rare.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="malignant-tumours">Malignant tumours<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#malignant-tumours" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These are relatively common and affect more men than women. There is an association with cigarette smoking, excessive alcohol intake, use of aspirin and coexisting conditions, e.g. diabetes mellitus and chronic pancreatitis.</p>
<p>Tumours usually affect the exocrine tissue in the head of the pancreas, where they typically obstruct the flow of bile and pancreatic juice into the duodenum. Jaundice, sometimes accompanied by itching, develops. Weight loss is the result of impaired digestion and absorption of fat, although anorexia and metabolic effects of the tumour may also play a role. Tumours in the body and tail of the gland rarely cause symptoms until the disease is advanced.</p>
<p>Irrespective of the site, metastases are often recognised before the primary tumour and therefore the prognosis is generally very poor.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="8fd23025">â– ãƒ»SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#8fd23025" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol start="24">
<li>Where do most pancreatic tumours originate and what are the common local consequences?</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="diseases-of-the-liver">Diseases of the liver<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diseases-of-the-liver" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>compare and contrast the causes, forms and effects of chronic and acute hepatitis</li>
<li>describe the main non-viral inflammatory conditions of the liver</li>
<li>discuss the causes and consequences of liver failure</li>
<li>describe the main liver tumours.</li>
</ul>
<p>Learning outcomes
Learning outcomes</p>
<p>Liver tissue has a remarkable capacity for regeneration and therefore damage is usually extensive before it is evident. The effects of disease or toxic agents are seen when:</p>
<ul>
<li>regeneration of hepatocytes (liver cells) does not keep pace with damage, leading to hepatocellular failure</li>
<li>there is gradual replacement of damaged cells by fibrous tissue, leading to portal hypertension.</li>
</ul>
<p>In most liver disease both conditions are present.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="acute-hepatitis">Acute hepatitis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#acute-hepatitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Areas of necrosis develop as groups of hepatocytes die and the eventual outcome depends on the size and number of these areas. Causes of the damage may be a variety of conditions, including:</p>
<ul>
<li>viral infections</li>
<li>toxic substances</li>
<li>circulatory disturbances.</li>
</ul>
<p>Viral hepatitis
Viral infections are the most common cause of acute liver dysfunction and different types are recognised. The types are distinguished serologically, i.e. by the antibodies produced to combat the infection. The severity of the ensuing disease caused by the different virus types varies considerably but the effect on the liver is similar. The viruses enter the liver cells, causing degenerative changes. An inflammatory reaction ensues, accompanied by production of an exudate containing lymphocytes, plasma cells and granulocytes. There is reactive hyperplasia of the hepatic macrophages (Kupffer cells) in the walls of the sinusoids.</p>
<p>As groups of cells die, necrotic areas of varying sizes develop, phagocytes remove the necrotic material and the lobules collapse. The basic lobule framework (see Fig. 12.35) becomes distorted and blood vessels develop kinks. These changes interfere with the circulation of blood to the remaining hepatocytes and the resultant hypoxia causes further damage locally. Fibrous tissue develops in the damaged area and adjacent hepatocytes proliferate. The effect of these changes on the overall functioning of the liver depends on the size of the necrotic areas, the amount of fibrous tissue formed and the extent to which the blood and bile channels are distorted.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hepatitis-a">Hepatitis A<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hepatitis-a" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Previously known as 'infectious hepatitis', this type often occurs as epidemics in all parts of the world. It affects mainly children and young adults but is often asymptomatic (subclinical disease). In both situations, antibodies develop, conferring lifelong immunity; up to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>30</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">30 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">30%</span></span></span></span></span> of adults have antibodies to this virus without any history of the disease. There is no carrier state. Infection is spread by the faecal-oral route, e.g. via contaminated hands, food, water and fomites.</p>
<p>Viruses are excreted in the faeces for around 2 weeks before clinical symptoms appear and for about 7 days after.</p>
<p>This is usually a mild and self-limiting illness. Symptoms include general malaise, followed by a period of jaundice (p. 365), which is accompanied by the passing of dark urine and pale faeces. Complications are rare.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="hepatitis-b">Hepatitis B<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hepatitis-b" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Previously known as 'serum hepatitis', infection occurs at any age but mostly in adults. The incubation period is between 50 and 180 days. The virus enters the blood and is spread by contaminated blood and blood products. People at greatest risk of infection are those who come in contact with blood and blood products in the course of their work, e.g. healthcare workers. The virus is also spread by body fluids, i.e. saliva, semen and vaginal secretions, and by transmission from mother to fetus (vertical transmission). Others at risk include those in contact with potentially contaminated needles, e.g. intravenous drug users, tattooists and acupuncturists, and men who have sex with men. Antibodies are formed and immunity persists after recovery.</p>
<p>Infection usually leads to severe illness lasting from 2 to 6 weeks, often followed by a protracted convalescence. Carriers may or may not have had clinical disease. Hepatitis B virus may cause massive liver necrosis and death. In less severe cases, recovery may be complete. In others, chronic hepatitis may develop; live viruses continue to circulate in the blood and other body fluids. The condition also predisposes to cirrhosis (see later) and liver cancer.</p>
<p>Hepatitis D. This virus contains no RNA and can replicate only in the presence of hepatitis B virus. It most often infects intravenous drug users who already have hepatitis B but also affects others with hepatitis B.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hepatitis-c">Hepatitis C<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hepatitis-c" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This virus is spread by blood and blood products, which accounted for the infection of many people with haemophilia. In countries where blood products are routinely screened for the virus, including the UK, this route of transmission is now rare, although hepatitis C remains prevalent in intravenous drug users ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>50</mn><mo>âˆ’</mo><mn>60</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">50-60 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">50</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">âˆ’</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">60%</span></span></span></span></span> ). The infection is very frequently asymptomatic, although a carrier state occurs. Infection is usually diagnosed later in life when cirrhosis or chronic liver failure becomes evident.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hepatitis-e">Hepatitis E<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hepatitis-e" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is clinically similar to hepatitis A and is spread by the faecal-oral route, usually by contaminated water. Unlike hepatitis A, if it is contracted during pregnancy, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>20</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">20 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">20%</span></span></span></span></span> of cases develop acute liver failure that is often fatal.</p>
<p>Toxic substances</p>
<p>Many drugs undergo chemical change in the liver before excretion in bile or by other organs. Both the parent drug
as well as drug metabolites may be capable of damaging liver cells. Some substances always cause liver damage in a dose-dependent manner (they are predictably toxic), e.g. paracetamol, while others only do so in certain individuals and even at small doses (they are unpredictably toxic), e.g. indometacin.</p>
<p>Circulatory disturbances
The intensely active hepatocytes are particularly vulnerable to damage by hypoxia, which is usually due to impaired blood supply caused by:</p>
<ul>
<li>fibrosis in the liver following inflammation</li>
<li>compression of the portal vein, hepatic artery or vein by a tumour</li>
<li>acute general circulatory failure and shock</li>
<li>venous congestion caused by acute or chronic right-sided heart failure (Ch. 5).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="chronic-hepatitis">Chronic hepatitis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chronic-hepatitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is defined as any form of hepatitis that persists for more than 6 months. It may be caused by viruses, alcohol or drugs but sometimes the cause is unknown.</p>
<p>Mild, persistent inflammation may follow acute viral hepatitis. There is usually little or no fibrosis.</p>
<p>There may be continuing progressive inflammation with cell necrosis and formation of fibrous tissue that may lead to cirrhosis of the liver. Distortion of the liver blood vessels causes localised hypoxia, leading to further hepatocyte damage. This condition is commonly associated with hepatitis B and C, some forms of autoimmune disease and unpredictable (idiosyncratic) drug reactions.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cirrhosis-of-the-liver">Cirrhosis of the liver<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cirrhosis-of-the-liver" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is the result of long-term injury caused by a variety of agents. The most common causes are:</p>
<ul>
<li>hepatitis B and C infections</li>
<li>excessive alcohol consumption</li>
<li>recurrent obstruction of the biliary tract.</li>
</ul>
<p>Chronic liver damage results in inflammation and necrosis; in time, affected tissue is replaced with fibrous tissue. Hyperplasia of hepatocytes occurs in areas adjacent to the damaged tissue in an attempt to compensate for destroyed cells, which leads to formation of nodules. The normal structure of the liver lobules becomes increasingly abnormal, usually over several years, which interferes with blood flow resulting in portal hypertension and its consequences (p.350), and impairment of liver cell function.</p>
<p>Liver failure may occur when cell regeneration is unable to keep pace with cell destruction, and the risk of liver cancer developing is increased.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="liver-failure">Liver failure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#liver-failure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This occurs when liver function is markedly impaired. It can be acute or chronic, and may be the outcome of a wide variety of disorders, such as:</p>
<ul>
<li>acute viral hepatitis</li>
<li>extensive necrosis due to poisoning, e.g. some drug overdoses, hepatotoxic chemicals, adverse drug reactions</li>
<li>cirrhosis of the liver.</li>
</ul>
<p>Liver failure has serious effects on other parts of the body.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hepatic-encephalopathy">Hepatic encephalopathy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hepatic-encephalopathy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This condition is characterised by apathy, disorientation, confusion and muscular rigidity, progressing to coma. The cells affected are the astrocytes in the brain, and several factors may be involved, such as:</p>
<ul>
<li>nitrogenous bacterial metabolites absorbed from the colon, which are normally detoxified in the liver, reaching the brain via the bloodstream</li>
<li>other metabolites, normally present only in trace amounts, e.g. ammonia, which may reach toxic concentrations and change the permeability of the cerebral blood vessels and the effectiveness of the blood-brain barrier</li>
<li>hypoxia and electrolyte imbalance.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="blood-coagulation-defects">Blood coagulation defects<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blood-coagulation-defects" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The liver fails to synthesise adequate supplies of blood clotting factors, i.e. prothrombin, fibrinogen and factors II, V, VII, IX and X. Purpura, bruising and bleeding may occur.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="oliguria-and-renal-failure">Oliguria and renal failure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#oliguria-and-renal-failure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Portal hypertension may cause oesophageal varices (p. 350). If these rupture, severe haemorrhage may lead to a fall in blood pressure sufficient to reduce the renal blood flow, causing progressive oliguria and renal failure (Ch. 13).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="oedema-and-ascites">Oedema and ascites<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#oedema-and-ascites" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These may arise from one or both of the following factors:</p>
<ul>
<li>Portal hypertension raises the capillary hydrostatic pressure in the organs drained by the tributaries of the portal vein (see Fig. 5.38).</li>
<li>Diminished production of serum albumin and clotting factors reduces the plasma osmotic pressure.</li>
</ul>
<p>Together, these changes cause the movement of excess fluid into the interstitial spaces, where it causes oedema (p. 129) as the fluid cannot leave the tissue.
Eventually, free fluid accumulates in the peritoneal cavity and the resultant ascites may be severe.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="jaundice">Jaundice<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#jaundice" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The following factors may cause jaundice as liver failure
develops:</p>
<ul>
<li>inability of the hepatocytes to conjugate and excrete bilirubin</li>
<li>obstruction to the movement of bile through the bile channels by fibrous tissue that has distorted the structural framework of liver lobules.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="tumours-of-the-liver">Tumours of the liver<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tumours-of-the-liver" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Benign tumours are rare.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="malignant-tumours">Malignant tumours<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#malignant-tumours" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Cancer of the liver is frequently associated with cirrhosis but the relationship between them is not clear. It may be that both cirrhosis and cancer are caused by the same agents or that the carcinogenic action of an agent is promoted by cirrhotic changes. Malignancy sometimes develops following hepatitis B and C. The most common sites of metastases are the abdominal lymph nodes, the peritoneum and the lungs.</p>
<p>Secondary malignant tumours (metastases) in the liver are more common than primary liver tumours. They usually spread there from primary tumours in the gastrointestinal tract (via the tributaries of the portal vein), the lungs and the breast. These tumours tend to grow rapidly and are often the cause of death.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-spot-check">I # SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol start="25">
<li>Compare and contrast the routes of transmission of hepatitis A and B infection.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="diseases-of-the-gall-bladder-and-bile-ducts">Diseases of the gall bladder and bile ducts<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diseases-of-the-gall-bladder-and-bile-ducts" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe the causes and consequences of gallstones</li>
<li>compare and contrast cholecystitis and cholangitis</li>
<li>briefly outline the common sites and consequences of biliary tract tumours</li>
<li>discuss the main causes and effects of jaundice.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="gallstones-cholelithiasis">Gallstones (cholelithiasis)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gallstones-cholelithiasis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Gallstones consist of deposits of the constituents of bile, most commonly cholesterol. Many small stones or one or
more large stones may form but, in many cases, they do not produce symptoms. Predisposing factors include:</p>
<ul>
<li>changes in the composition of bile that affect the solubility of its constituents</li>
<li>high blood cholesterol levels</li>
<li>female gender</li>
<li>obesity</li>
<li>several pregnancies in young women, especially when accompanied by obesity</li>
<li>diabetes mellitus.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cholecystitis">Cholecystitis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cholecystitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Inflammation of the gall bladder is usually associated with the presence of gallstones.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="acute-cholecystitis">Acute cholecystitis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#acute-cholecystitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Acute inflammation occurs when a gallstone becomes impacted (stuck) in the cystic duct (Fig. 12.54), often after a fatty meal. Strong peristaltic contractions of the smooth muscle in the wall of the cystic duct, which occur in an attempt to move the stone onwards, result in biliary colic, severe acute pain in the epigastrium or right hypochondrium. This does not cause jaundice because bile from the liver can still pass directly into the duodenum. However, bile is unable to
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-42ddb8bb.jpeg" alt="img-77.jpeg">
sphincter
Common hepatic duct
Duodenum
Gallstones in gall bladder (asymptomatic)
Impacted in cystic duct causes acute cholecystitis (no jaundice)
Impacted in common bile duct causes acute cholecystitis (jaundice)
Pancreatic duct
Figure 12.54 Effects of gallstones in different locations.</p>
<p>leave the gall bladder and an inflammatory reaction follows. Nausea and vomiting may accompany severe attacks.</p>
<p>This is occasionally complicated by bacterial infection and distension of the gall bladder, which carries the risk of perforation and peritonitis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cholangitis">Cholangitis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cholangitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is inflammation of bile ducts caused by bacterial infection and is typically accompanied by abdominal pain, fever and jaundice (because the flow of bile into the duodenum is blocked). It accompanies existing gall bladder disease, e.g. stones in the common bile duct, biliary stricture or tumour. Infection can spread upwards in the biliary tree to the liver (ascending cholangitis), causing liver abscesses.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="tumours-of-the-biliary-tract">Tumours of the biliary tract<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tumours-of-the-biliary-tract" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Benign tumours are rare.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="malignant-tumours">Malignant tumours<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#malignant-tumours" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These are relatively rare and gallstones are nearly always present. Local spread to the liver, the pancreas and other adjacent organs is common. Lymph and blood spread leads to widespread metastases. The tumour has often spread by the time of diagnosis and the prognosis is therefore poor.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="jaundice">Jaundice<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#jaundice" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is not a disease in itself, but yellowing of the skin and mucous membrane is a sign of abnormal bilirubin metabolism and excretion. Bilirubin, produced from the breakdown of haemoglobin, is normally conjugated in the liver and excreted in the bile (see Fig. 12.37). Conjugation makes bilirubin water-soluble and greatly enhances its removal from the blood, an essential step in excretion.</p>
<p>Unconjugated bilirubin, which is fat-soluble, has a toxic effect on brain cells. It is unable to cross the blood-brain barrier until the plasma level rises above 340 <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">o</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{pmol} / \mathrm{L}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">pmol</span></span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord mathrm">L</span></span></span></span></span>, but when it does, it may cause neurological damage, seizures (fits) and cognitive impairment. Serum bilirubin may rise to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>40</mn><mo>âˆ’</mo><mn>50</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">j</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">o</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">40-50 \mathrm{jiimol} / \mathrm{L}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">40</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">âˆ’</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">50</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">jiimol</span></span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord mathrm">L</span></span></span></span></span> before the yellow coloration of jaundice is evident in the skin and conjunctiva (normal 3-13 pmol/L). Jaundice is often accompanied by pruritus (itching), caused by the irritating effects of bile salts on the skin.</p>
<p>Jaundice develops when there is an abnormality of bilirubin processing and the different types are considered here.</p>
<p>Types of jaundice
Whatever stage in bilirubin processing is affected, the end result is rising blood bilirubin levels.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="prehepatic-jaundice">Prehepatic jaundice<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#prehepatic-jaundice" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is due to increased haemolysis of red blood cells (see Fig. 12.37), which results in production of excess bilirubin. Because the excess bilirubin is unconjugated it cannot be excreted in the urine, which therefore remains normal in colour.</p>
<p>Neonatal haemolytic jaundice
This occurs in many babies, especially in those born prematurely, when the normally high rate of haemolysis is coupled with a shortage of conjugating enzymes in the hepatocytes of the still immature liver.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="intrahepatic-jaundice">Intrahepatic jaundice<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#intrahepatic-jaundice" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is the result of damage to the liver itself by, for example:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>viral hepatitis (p. 362)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>toxic substances, such as drugs</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>amoebiasis (amoebic dysentery, p. 356)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>cirrhosis (p. 363).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Excess bilirubin accumulates in the liver. Because it is mainly in the conjugated form, it is water-soluble and excreted in the urine, making it dark in colour.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="posthepatic-jaundice">Posthepatic jaundice<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#posthepatic-jaundice" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>There is obstruction to the flow of bile in the biliary tract. Causes include:</p>
<ul>
<li>gallstones in the common bile duct (Fig. 12.54)</li>
<li>tumour of the head of the pancreas</li>
<li>fibrosis of the bile ducts, following cholangitis or injury by the passage of gallstones.</li>
</ul>
<p>In this situation, excess bilirubin is also conjugated and is therefore excreted in the urine. The effects of raised serum bilirubin include:</p>
<ul>
<li>pruritus (itching)</li>
<li>pale faeces due to the absence of stercobilin</li>
<li>dark urine due to the presence of increased amounts of bilirubin.</li>
</ul>
<p>I # SPOT CHECK
26. Gallstones lodged in which passageway may lead to jaundice?</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="section-3-intake-of-raw-materials-and-elimination-of-waste">SECTION 3 Intake of raw materials and elimination of waste<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#section-3-intake-of-raw-materials-and-elimination-of-waste" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="review-and-revise">Review and revise<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#review-and-revise" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Complete each of the following statements:</p>
<ol>
<li>Secretions released into the gastrointestinal
tract include _ from the parotid glands,
_from the chief cells in the gastric
glands and_from the liver.</li>
<li>The shape and position of teeth depend on their function. The cutting teeth used for biting are the
<em>and</em>, while those involved in
chewing are the_and_.</li>
<li>The tiny functional units of the liver are known as
_. They are formed from cuboidal cells
called _. These are situated next to
_, which are capillaries with incomplete
walls that contain a mixture of blood, some from
branches of the_vein and some from
the_artery.</li>
<li>The three central metabolic pathways that generate
most of the body's energy are
the_and_.</li>
<li>Peptic ulcer disease is strongly associated with the
bacterium_, which more commonly
affects the_gender; ulcers most commonly
affect the_and_.</li>
</ol>
<p>Choose one answer to complete each of the following statements:
6. In parts of the digestive tract subject to considerable
wear and tear, the mucosa is formed from: <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mspace width="2em"></mspace></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\qquad</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0em;"></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 2em;"></span></span></span></span></span>
a. Stratified squamous epithelium
b. Simple squamous epithelium
c. Columnar epithelium
d. Smooth muscle.
7. In parts of the digestive tract responsible for secretion
and absorption, the mucosa is formed from: <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mspace width="2em"></mspace></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\qquad</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0em;"></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 2em;"></span></span></span></span></span>
a. Stratified squamous epithelium
b. Simple squamous epithelium
c. Cuboidal epithelium
d. Columnar epithelium.
8. The function of the stomach is most accurately
described as: <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mspace width="2em"></mspace></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\qquad</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0em;"></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 2em;"></span></span></span></span></span>
a. Two layers of smooth muscle enable the stomach to act as a churn that breaks food down
b. Peristaltic waves propel the contents of the stomach towards the pylorus
c. Salivary amylase is inactivated by chyme in the stomach
d. Sympathetic stimulation increases peristalsis and secretion of gastric juice.
9. After bile is released from the liver, its route to the
duodenum is: <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mspace width="2em"></mspace></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\qquad</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0em;"></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 2em;"></span></span></span></span></span>
a. Hepatic duct, common bile duct, duodenum
b. Hepatic duct, cystic duct, gall bladder, common bile duct, duodenum
c. Hepatic duct, cystic duct, gall bladder, cystic duct, common bile duct, duodenum</p>
<p>d. Hepatic duct, common bile duct, gall bladder, common bile duct, cystic duct, duodenum.
10. Gastro-oesophageal reflux disease (GORD) is best described as: <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mspace width="2em"></mspace></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\qquad</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0em;"></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 2em;"></span></span></span></span></span>
a. A common tumour of the gastrointestinal tract
b. A congenital abnormality of the gastrointestinal tract
c. A gastrointestinal infection
d. The most common cause of indigestion or 'heartburn'.</p>
<p>Indicate whether each of the following statements is true or false:
11. The accessory organs of digestion are three pairs of salivary glands, the pancreas, the liver and the biliary tract. <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mspace width="2em"></mspace></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\qquad</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0em;"></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 2em;"></span></span></span></span></span>
12. The visceral peritoneum is attached to the abdominal wall. <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mspace width="2em"></mspace></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\qquad</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0em;"></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 2em;"></span></span></span></span></span>
13. The submucosal layer of the alimentary tract propels the contents along it by peristalsis. <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mspace width="2em"></mspace></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\qquad</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0em;"></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 2em;"></span></span></span></span></span>
14. Saliva contains antimicrobial substances. <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mspace width="2em"></mspace></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\qquad</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0em;"></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 2em;"></span></span></span></span></span>
15. Intrinsic factor is essential for absorption of vitamin</p>
<p>Bi 2 in the terminal ileum. <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mspace width="2em"></mspace></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\qquad</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0em;"></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 2em;"></span></span></span></span></span>
16. Match each letter in List A to the appropriate number in List B:</p>
<p>List A
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mspace width="2em"></mspace></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\qquad</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0em;"></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 2em;"></span></span></span></span></span>
(a) Bilirubin
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mspace width="2em"></mspace></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\qquad</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0em;"></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 2em;"></span></span></span></span></span>
(b) Glycogen
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mspace width="2em"></mspace></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\qquad</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0em;"></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 2em;"></span></span></span></span></span>
(c) Uric acid
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mspace width="2em"></mspace></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\qquad</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0em;"></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 2em;"></span></span></span></span></span>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="list-b">List B<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#list-b" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<li>The first part of the large intestine</li>

<li>Tiny projections on the tongue that contain the taste buds</li>
<li>The largest serous membrane</li>
<li>Strips of smooth muscle in the large intestine that give it its puckered appearance</li>
<li>The middle section of the small intestine</li>
</ol>
<p>For a range of further self-assessment exercises on the topics in this chapter, visit Evolve online resources: <a href="https://evolve.elsevier.comA/1/augh/anatomy/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">https://evolve.elsevier.comA/1/augh/anatomy/</a></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3">(3)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<p>This page intentionally left blank</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-urinary-system">The urinary system<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-urinary-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="13">13<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#13" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

Q Animations
13.1 The urinary system 369
13.2 Structure of the nephron 371
13.3 Processes invoived in urine formation 373
13.4 Secretion 375
13.5 Aidosterone reguiation mechanism 377
13.6 Ureters 378
13.7 Biadder 379
13.8 Urethra 379</p>
<p>The urinary system is the main excretory system and consists of the following structures:</p>
<ul>
<li>two kidneys, which secrete urine</li>
<li>two ureters that convey the urine from the kidneys to the urinary bladder</li>
<li>the urinary bladder, which collects and stores urine</li>
<li>the urethra, through which urine leaves the body Q 13.1.</li>
</ul>
<p>Fig. 13.1 shows an overview of the urinary system. The</p>
<p>urinary system plays a vital part in maintaining homeostasis of water and electrolytes within the body. The kidneys produce urine, which contains metabolic waste products, including the nitrogenous compounds urea and uric acid, excess ions and, sometimes, excreted drugs. The main functions of the kidneys are:
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">âˆ§</mo></msup><mn>369</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">{ }^{\wedge} 369</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7519em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7519em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">âˆ§</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord">369</span></span></span></span></span></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="chapter">CHAPTER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chapter" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-df84070c.jpeg" alt="img-78.jpeg"></p>
<p>Inferior vena cava
Diaphragm

<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-2a89b13a.jpeg" alt="img-79.jpeg"></p>
