<p>0 Nerve innpulses to spinal cord
: 2 " Nerve innpulses stimulate
contraction of detrusor muscle
(i) Nerve impulses stimulate relaxation of internal urethral sphincter</p>
<p>Conscious contraction of external urethral sphincter overrides reflex micturition
Figure 13.21 Control of micturition after bladder control is established.
When bladder control is established, the micturition reflex is still stimulated but sensory impulses also pass upwards to the brain and there is awareness of the need to pass urine as the bladder fills (around <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>300</mn><mo>âˆ’</mo><mn>400</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">300-400 \mathrm{~mL}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">300</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">âˆ’</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">400</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">mL</span></span></span></span></span></span> in adults). By learned and conscious effort, contraction of the external urethral sphincter and muscles of the pelvic floor can inhibit micturition until it is convenient to pass urine (Fig. 13.21).</p>
<p>Urination can be assisted by increasing the pressure within the pelvic cavity, achieved by lowering the diaphragm and contracting the abdominal muscles. Overdistension of the bladder is extremely painful, and when this occurs there is a tendency for involuntary relaxation of the external sphincter to occur, allowing a small amount of urine to escape, provided there is no mechanical obstruction. Incontinence is the involuntary loss of urine after bladder control has been established.
where a spinal reflex (p. 175) is initiated. This stimulates involuntary contraction of the detrusor muscle and relaxation of the internal urethral sphincter (Fig. 13.20), and expels urine from the bladder: this is known as micturition, urination or voiding of urine.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="5205029c">â–  SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5205029c" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol start="6">
<li>Briefly explain the changes needed during childhood to establish bladder control and urinary continence.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="effects-of-ageing-on-the-urinary-system">Effects of ageing on the urinary system<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#effects-of-ageing-on-the-urinary-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Learning outcome
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe the effects of ageing on the urinary system.</li>
</ul>
<p>The kidneys have a substantial functional reserve; the loss of one kidney does not cause problems in an otherwise healthy individual. The number of nephrons declines with age, glomerular filtration rate falls and the renal tubules function less efficiently; the kidneys become less able to concentrate urine.</p>
<p>These changes mean that older adults become more sensitive to alterations in fluid balance, and problems associated with fluid overload or dehydration are more
prevalent. Elimination of drugs also becomes less efficient with declining kidney function, which may lead to accumulation and toxicity.</p>
<p>The ability to inhibit contraction of the detrusor muscle declines and may result in the urgent need to pass urine and urinary frequency. Nocturia becomes increasingly common in older adults. Incontinence (p.389) is more prevalent in older adults, affecting <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>15</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">15 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">15%</span></span></span></span></span> of women and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>10</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">10%</span></span></span></span></span> of men over 65 , figures that double by 85 years of age. Enlargement of the prostate gland is common in older men and may cause retention of urine and problems with micturition (Ch. 18).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="spot-check">- SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol start="7">
<li>Identify a common cause of urinary retention in older men.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="diseases-of-the-kidneys">Diseases of the kidneys<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diseases-of-the-kidneys" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="learning-outcomes">Learning outcomes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#learning-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>outline the principal effects of glomerulonephritis and nephrotic syndrome</li>
<li>describe the effects of diabetes mellitus and hypertension on kidney function</li>
<li>discuss the sources and consequences of kidney infections</li>
<li>explain the causes and implications of acute kidney injury and chronic kidney disease</li>
<li>describe the pathogenesis of kidney stones</li>
<li>list common congenital abnormalities of the kidneys</li>
<li>outline the development and spread of common kidney tumours.</li>
</ul>
<p>As the kidneys have considerable functional reserve, impairment of renal function does not become evident until the equivalent of more than one kidney is lost. This is why it is possible for a person with healthy kidneys to donate one for transplantation. Table 13.1 lists common signs and symptoms of renal disorders.</p>
<p>Table 13.1
Common signs and
symptoms of
disorders of the
urinary system</p>
<p>Sign/symptom Definition and description</p>
<p>Oliguria
Urine output of less than 400 mL per day</p>
<p>Haematuria Presence of blood in the urine. Leaky glomeruli allow red blood cells to escape from the glomerular capillaries and they cannot be reabsorbed from the filtrate, as they are too large. Bleeding in the urinary tract also causes haematuria</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Proteinuria</th><th>Presence of protein in the urine. This is abnormal and occurs when leaky glomeruli allow plasma proteins to escape into the filtrate but they are too large to be reabsorbed</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Anuria</td><td>Absence of urine</td></tr><tr><td>Dysuria</td><td>Pain on passing urine, often described as a burning sensation</td></tr><tr><td>Glycosuria</td><td>Presence of sugar glucose in the urine. This is abnormal and occurs in diabetes mellitus (p. 255)</td></tr><tr><td>Ketonuria</td><td>Presence of ketones in the urine. This is abnormal and occurs in, for example, starvation, diabetes mellitus</td></tr><tr><td>Nocturia</td><td>Passing urine during the night</td></tr><tr><td>Polyuria</td><td>Passing unusually large amounts of urine</td></tr><tr><td>Frequency of micturition</td><td>Need to pass urine frequently, often in small amounts</td></tr><tr><td>Incontinence</td><td>Involuntary loss of urine (p. 389)</td></tr><tr><td>Effects of glomerulonephritis</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>These depend on the type.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="glomerulonephritis">Glomerulonephritis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#glomerulonephritis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This term suggests inflammatory conditions of the glomerulus, but there are several types of glomerulonephritis (GN) and inflammatory changes are not always present. In many cases, GN has an autoimmune component, which leads to production of immune complexes that may lodge in the glomerular capillaries, causing inflammation and impairment of glomerular filtration. Other immune mechanisms are also implicated in GN.</p>
<p>Classification of GN is based on a number of features: the cause, immunological characteristics and findings on microscopy. Microscopic distinction is based on:</p>
<ul>
<li>extent of damage:</li>
<li>diffuse: affecting all glomeruli</li>
<li>focal: affecting some glomeruli</li>
<li>appearance:</li>
<li>proliferative: increased number of cells in the glomeruli</li>
<li>membranous: thickening of the basement membrane of the glomerular epithelium.</li>
</ul>
<p>Examples of different types of GN, with their causes, features and prognoses, are shown in Table 13.2.</p>
<p>Haematuria
This is usually painless and not accompanied by other symptoms. When microscopic, it may be found on routine urinalysis when red blood cells have passed through damaged glomeruli into the filtrate.</p>
<p>Overt haematuria occurs when there is considerable escape of red blood cells into the renal tubules, while smaller amounts give urine a smoky appearance.</p>
<p>Asymptomatic proteinuria
Damaged glomeruli may allow protein to escape from the blood into the filtrate, which may be asymptomatic and found only during routine urinalysis. There are also other causes of asymptomatic proteinuria, including urinary tract infection. Significant proteinuria is associated with nephrotic syndrome (see next section).</p>
<p>Acute nephritis
This is characterised by the presence of:</p>
<ul>
<li>oliguria (less than 400 mL urine/ day in adults)</li>
<li>hypertension</li>
<li>haematuria</li>
<li>uraemia (p. 386).</li>
</ul>
<p>Loin pain, headache and malaise are also common.</p>
<p>Table 13.1 Common signs and symptoms of disorders of the animal systems</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Learning outcomes</th><th></th><th></th><th></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Table 13.2 Glomerulonephritis: features and prognosis of different types 1</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>1 Type Cause</th><th>Presenting features</th><th>Prognosis</th><th></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Diffuse</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>proliferative</td><td>Usually follows a transient infection, especially phaemolytic streptococcus but also other microbes</td><td>Acute nephritis</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Haematuria</td><td>Good in children; less good in adults, up to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>40</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">40 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">40%</span></span></span></span></span> develop hypertension or chronic kidney disease</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Focal proliferative</td><td>Associated with other systemic conditions, e.g. systemic lupus erythematosus (p. 472), infective endocarditis (p. 133)</td><td>Acute nephritis</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Haematuria</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Proteinuria</td><td>Variable</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">â–¡</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\square</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.675em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">â–¡</span></span></span></span></span></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Membranous Only sometimes has an identified Nephrotic Variable, but cause such as infection, e.g. syndrome most cases syphilis, malaria, hepatitis B; Haematuria progress to chronic kidney</p>
<p>some drugs, e.g. penicillamine, gold, diamorphine; tumours</p>
<p>Minimal-change Unknown
Nephrotic Good in syndrome children but
Haematuria recurrences are common in
Proteinuria adults</p>
<p>Nephrotic syndrome
See next section.
Chronic kidney disease
Chronic kidney disease (CKD) occurs when nephrons are progressively and irreversibly damaged after the renal reserve is lost.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="nephrotic-syndrome">Nephrotic syndrome<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nephrotic-syndrome" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is not a disease in itself but is an important feature of several kidney diseases. The main characteristics are:</p>
<ul>
<li>marked proteinuria</li>
<li>hypoalbuminaemia</li>
<li>generalised oedema</li>
<li>hyperlipidaemia.</li>
</ul>
<p>When glomeruli are damaged, the permeability of the basement membrane of the glomerular epithelium increases and plasma proteins pass through into the filtrate. Albumin is the main protein lost because it is the most common and smallest of the plasma proteins. When the daily loss exceeds the rate of production by the liver, there is a significant fall in the total plasma protein level. The consequent low plasma osmotic pressure leads to widespread oedema and reduced plasma volume (see Fig. 5.55). This reduces the renal blood flow and stimulates the reninangiotensinaldosterone system (see Fig. 13.14), causing increased reabsorption of water and sodium from the renal tubules. The reabsorbed water further reduces the blood osmotic pressure and increases the oedema. The key factor is the loss of albumin across the glomerular membrane, and as long as this continues, the vicious circle is perpetuated (Fig. 13.22). Levels of nitrogenous waste products, i.e. uric acid, urea and creatinine, usually remain normal. Hyperlipidaemia,</p>
<p>C
C
C
Glomerular damage
Plasma proteins and fats in filtrate
Reduced plasma osmotic pressure</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id=""><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>:</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">:</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mrel">:</span></span></span></span></span> )<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"></span></h1></div>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo><mo>=</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;=</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;=</span></span></span></span></span>
f Reabsorption of water and salt
L
r Renin secretion 'll
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">f</mi><msup><mo>âˆ’</mo><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">âˆ§</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{f}-^{\wedge}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8352em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.07778em;">f</span><span class="mord"><span class="mbin">âˆ’</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7519em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">âˆ§</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></p>
<p>Oedema
r Reduced renal
blood flow J</p>
<p>Figure 13.22 Stages of development of nephrotic syndrome.
especially hypercholesterolaemia, also occurs but the cause is unknown.
Nephrotic syndrome occurs in a number of diseases. In children the most common cause is minimal-change glomerulonephritis. In adults it may complicate:</p>
<ul>
<li>most forms of glomerulonephritis</li>
<li>diabetic nephropathy (see next section)</li>
<li>systemic lupus erythematosus (p. 472)</li>
<li>infections, e.g. malaria, syphilis, hepatitis B</li>
<li>drug treatment, e.g. penicillamine, gold, captopril, phenytoin.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="diabetic-nephropathy">Diabetic nephropathy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diabetic-nephropathy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Renal failure is the most common cause of death in young people with diabetes mellitus (p. 255), especially if</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="table-13-8-glomerulonephritis-features-and-prognosis-of-different-types">Table 13.8 Glomerulonephritis: features and prognosis of different types<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#table-13-8-glomerulonephritis-features-and-prognosis-of-different-types" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Plaema proteins and fats in filtrate
hypertension and severe, long-standing hyperglycaemia are present. Diabetes damages large and small blood vessels throughout the body, although the effects vary considerably between individuals. In the kidney, these are known collectively as diabetic nephropathy or diabetic kidney and include:</p>
<ul>
<li>progressive damage of glomeruli, proteinuria and nephrotic syndrome</li>
<li>ascending infection, leading to acute pyelonephritis (see later)</li>
<li>arteriosclerosis (Ch. 5) of the renal arteries and their branches, leading to renal ischaemia and hypertension</li>
<li>chronic kidney disease (p. 386).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hypertension-and-the-kidneys">Hypertension and the kidneys<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hypertension-and-the-kidneys" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Hypertension can be the cause or the result of renal disease. Hypertension of any aetiology (p. 136) disrupts renal function if renal blood vessel damage causes ischaemia. The reduced blood flow stimulates the renin-angiotensinaldosterone system (see Fig. 13.14), raising the blood pressure still further.</p>
<p>Rising blood pressure is common in older adults and can cause gradual and progressive damage to the glomeruli, which may lead to chronic kidney disease after the renal reserve has been lost, or to malignant hypertension.</p>
<p>Malignant hypertension
Damage to arterioles spreads to the glomeruli with subsequent destruction of nephrons that leads to a further rise in blood pressure and a variable degree of renal impairment. Sometimes there are more serious effects; increased permeability of the glomeruli allows escape of plasma proteins and red blood cells into the filtrate, causing proteinuria and haematuria, which may progress to renal failure.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="acute-pyelonephritis">Acute pyelonephritis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#acute-pyelonephritis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is acute bacterial infection of the renal pelvis and calyces, which spreads to the kidney substance, causing small abscesses. Bacteria usually reach the kidney by travelling up the urinary tract from the perineum but are sometimes blood-borne. This condition is accompanied by fever, malaise and loin pain.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="ascending-infection">Ascending infection<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ascending-infection" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>upward spread of bacteria from the bladder (see cystitis, p. 389) is the most common cause of this condition. Reflux of infected urine into the ureters when the bladder contracts during micturition predisposes to upward spread of infection to the renal pelves and the kidneys themselves. Normally, the relative positions of the ureters and bladder
(see Fig. 13.15) prevents reflux that permits ascending access of bacteria to the kidneys.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="blood-borne-infection">Blood-borne infection<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blood-borne-infection" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The kidneys are susceptible to blood-borne infection due to their large blood supply ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>20</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">20 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">20%</span></span></span></span></span> of cardiac output). Bacteria may reach the kidney directly in sepsis, or septicaemia, or travel there from distant sites, e.g. a respiratory tract infection, infected wound or an abscess.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathophysiology">Pathophysiology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathophysiology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Bacterial infection of the kidney tissues causes suppuration and destruction of nephrons. The prognosis depends on the amount of healthy kidney tissue remaining after the infection subsides. Necrotic tissue is eventually replaced by fibrous tissue but there may be some hypertrophy of healthy nephrons. The outcomes are healing, recurrence - especially if there is a structural abnormality of the urinary tract - and reflux nephropathy.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="reflux-nephropathy">Reflux nephropathy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reflux-nephropathy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Previously known as chronic pyelonephritis, this is almost always associated with reflux of urine from the bladder to the ureter, allowing spread of infection upwards towards the kidneys. A congenital abnormality of the angle of insertion of the ureter into the bladder predisposes to this, but it is sometimes caused by an obstruction that develops later in life. Progressive damage to the renal papillae and collecting ducts may lead to chronic kidney disease and concurrent hypertension is common.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="acute-kidney-injury">Acute kidney injury<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#acute-kidney-injury" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This occurs as a complication of conditions not necessarily associated with the kidneys. The causes of acute kidney injury (AKI), previously known as acute renal failure, are classified as:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>prerenal: the result of reduced renal blood flow, e.g. in severe and prolonged shock</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>renal: due to damage to the kidney itself, e.g. acute tubular necrosis, glomerulonephritis</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>postrenal: arises from obstruction to the outflow of urine, e.g. disease of the prostate gland, tumour of the bladder, uterus or cervix, large calculus (stone) in the renal pelvis.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>There is a sudden and severe reduction in the glomerular filtration rate and kidney function that is often reversible over days or weeks if treated. Oliguria or anuria is accompanied by metabolic acidosis due to retention of ff, electrolyte imbalance and accumulation of mainly nitrogenous waste products.</p>
<p>Box 13.2 Some causes of acute tubular necrosis
Ischaemia - severe shock, dehydration, haemorrhage, trauma; extensive burns; myocardial infarction; prolonged and complex surgery, especially in older people</p>
<p>Drugs - e.g. aminoglycoside antibiotics, non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors, lithium compounds, paracetamol overdose</p>
<p>Haemoglohinaemia - accumulation of haemoglobin, released by haemolysis of red blood cells, e.g. incompatible blood transfusion, malaria</p>
<p>Myoglohinaemia - accumulation of myoglobin released from damaged muscle that raises blood levels, e.g. following crush injury</p>
<p>Acute tubular necrosis
Acute tubular necrosis (ATN) is the most common cause of acute renal failure. There is severe damage to the tubular epithelial cells, caused by ischaemia or, less often, by nephrotoxic substances (Box 13.2).</p>
<p>Oliguria, severe oliguria (less than 100 mL of urine per day in adults) or anuria (see Table 13.1) may last for a few weeks, followed by profound diuresis. There is a reduction in glomerular filtration, selective reabsorption and secretion by the tubules, leading to:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>heart failure due to fluid overload</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>generalised and pulmonary oedema</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>accumulation of urea and other metabolic wastes</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>electrolyte imbalance, which may be exacerbated by the retention of potassium (hyperkalaemia) released from damaged cells anywhere in the body</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>acidosis due to retention of hydrogen ions.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Profound diuresis (the diuretic phase) occurs during the healing process, when the epithelial cells of the tubules have regenerated but are still incapable of selective reabsorption and secretion. Diuresis may lead to acute dehydration, complicating the existing high plasma urea, acidosis and electrolyte imbalance. If the patient survives the initial acute phase, a considerable degree of renal function is usually restored over several weeks (the recovery phase).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="chronic-kidney-disease">Chronic kidney disease<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chronic-kidney-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Previously known as chronic renal failure, chronic kidney disease (CKD) is present when GFR has fallen to around <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>20</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">20 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">20%</span></span></span></span></span> of normal. Onset is usually slow and asymptomatic, progressing irreversibly over several years. The main causes are diabetes mellitus, glomerulonephritis and hypertension.</p>
<p>The effects on GFR, selective reabsorption and tubular secretion are significant. GFR and filtrate volumes are greatly</p>
<p>Table 13.3 Polyuria in chronic kidney disease</p>
<p>1 Normal kidney <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>âˆ£</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mid</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mrel">âˆ£</span></span></span></span></span></p>

vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">99%</span></span></span></span></span></td><td style="text-align: left;">Approx. 30%</td></tr></tbody></table>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;">Less than <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1 \mathrm{~mL} / \mathrm{min}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">mL</span></span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">min</span></span></span></span></span></span> or</th><th style="text-align: left;">Approx. <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>7</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">7 \mathrm{~mL} / \mathrm{min}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">7</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">mL</span></span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">min</span></span></span></span></span></span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;"><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1.5</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1.5 \mathrm{~L} /</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">1.5</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">L</span></span><span class="mord">/</span></span></span></span></span> day</td><td style="text-align: left;">or</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;"></td><td style="text-align: left;"><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>10</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10 \mathrm{~L} /</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">10</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">L</span></span><span class="mord">/</span></span></span></span></span> day</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>reduced and reabsorption of water is seriously impaired. This results in production of up to 10 litres of urine per day (Table 13.3). Reduced glomerular filtration leads to accumulation of waste substances in the blood, notably urea and creatinine. When renal failure becomes evident, blood urea levels are raised and this is referred to as uraemia. Some of the signs and symptoms that may accompany this</p>
<p>condition include nausea, vomiting, gastrointestinal bleeding and pruritus (itching). Others are explained here.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="polyuria">Polyuria<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#polyuria" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Large volumes of dilute urine (with a low specific gravity) are passed because water reabsorption is impaired. Nocturia is a common presenting symptom.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="acidosis">Acidosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#acidosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>As the kidney buffer system that normally controls the pH of body fluids fails, hydrogen ions accumulate.</p>
<p>Electrolyte imbalance
This is also the result of impaired tubular reabsorption and secretion.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="anaemia">Anaemia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#anaemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Deficiency of erythropoietin (p. 66) occurs after a
few months, causing anaemia that is exacerbated by haemodialysis, which damages red blood cells. If untreated, anaemia results in fatigue and may also lead to dyspnoea and cardiac failure (p. 131). Tiredness and breathlessness are sometimes the initial symptoms of chronic kidney disease.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hypertension">Hypertension<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hypertension" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is often a consequence, if not a cause, of chronic kidney disease.
End-stage renal disease
When death is likely without renal replacement therapy, such as haemodialysis, peritoneal dialysis or a kidney transplant, the condition is referred to as end-stage renal disease (ESRD). The excretory functions of the kidneys are lost, acid-base balance cannot be maintained and endocrine functions of the kidney are disrupted.</p>
<p>Table 13.2 Polyuria in chronic kidney disease</p>
<p>Box 13.2 Some causes of acute tubular necrosis
Ischaemia - severe shock, dehydration, haemorrhage, trauma, extensive burns; myocardial infarction; prolonged and complex surgery, especially in older people
Drugs - e.g. aminoglycoside antibiotics, non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors, lithium compounds, paracetamol overdose
Haemoglobinemia - accumulation of haemoglobin, released by haemolysis of red blood cells, e.g. incompatible blood transfusion, malaria
Myoglobinemia - accumulation of myoglobin released from damaged muscle that raises blood levels, e.g. following crush injury</p>
<p>Towards the end of life, anorexia, nausea and very deep (Kussmaul's) respirations occur as uraemia progresses. In the final stages there may be hiccoughs, itching, vomiting, muscle twitching, seizures, drowsiness and coma.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="renal-calculi">Renal calculi<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#renal-calculi" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Calculi (stones) form in the kidneys and bladder when urinary constituents normally in solution, usually oxalate and phosphate salts, are precipitated. They are often recurrent, and are more common in males and after 30 years of age. Most originate in the collecting tubules or renal papillae. They then pass into the renal pelvis, where they may increase in size. Some become too large to pass through the ureter and may obstruct the outflow of urine, causing kidney damage. Others pass to the bladder and either are excreted or increase in size and obstruct the urethra (Fig. 13.23). In developing countries and often in children, stones</p>
<p>Staghorn calculus Tumour of renal pelvis
Stricture at pelvic ureteric junction
Tumour of ureter
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-5e6424b2.jpeg" alt="img-102.jpeg"></p>
<p>Tumour of the bladder
Urethral stricture
Retroperitoneal fibrosis or tumourÂ»
Damage to nerves involved in micturition</p>
<p>Uterus in women: Pregnancy Carcinoma of the cervix
Endometriosis
Prostate in men: Prostatic hypertrophy
Blood clot
Ureteric calculus
Figure 13.23 Summary of obstructions of the urinary tract.
sometimes originate in the bladder. Predisposing factors
include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Dehydration: this leads to increased reabsorption of water from the tubules but does not change solute reabsorption, resulting in a low volume of highly concentrated filtrate in the collecting tubules.</li>
<li>Raised pH of urine: when the normally acid filtrate becomes alkaline, some substances may be precipitated, e.g. phosphates. This occurs when the kidney buffering system is impaired and in some infections.</li>
<li>Infection: necrotic material and pus provide foci on which solutes in the filtrate may be deposited and the products of infection may alter the pH of the urine. Infection sometimes leads to alkaline urine (see previous point).</li>
<li>Metabolic conditions: these include hyperparathyroidism (p. 252) and gout (p. 471).</li>
</ul>
<p>Small calculi
These may pass through or become impacted in a ureter and damage the epithelium, leading to haematuria and, after healing, fibrosis and stricture. In ureteric obstruction, which is usually unilateral, there is spasmodic contraction of the ureter, causing acute intermittent ischaemic pain (renal colic) as the smooth muscle of the ureter contracts over the stone in an attempt to move it. Stones reaching the bladder may be passed in urine, or increase in size and eventually obstruct the urethra. Consequences include retention of urine and bilateral hydronephrosis (p. 388), infection proximal to the blockage, pyelonephritis and severe kidney damage.</p>
<p>Large calculi (staghorn calculus)
One large stone may form, usually over many years, filling the renal pelvis and the calyces (Fig. 13.23). It causes stagnation of urine, predisposing to infection,</p>
<p>hydronephrosis (p. 388) and occasionally kidney tumours. It may cause chronic kidney disease.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="congenital-abnormalities-of-the-kidneys">Congenital abnormalities of the kidneys<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#congenital-abnormalities-of-the-kidneys" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Misplaced (ectopic) kidney
One or both kidneys may develop in abnormally low positions. Misplaced kidneys function normally if the blood vessels are long enough to provide an adequate blood supply, but a kidney in the pelvic cavity may cause problems during pregnancy as the expanding uterus compresses renal blood vessels or the ureters. If the ureters become kinked, there is increased risk of infection, as there is a tendency for reflux and backflow to the kidney. There may also be difficulties during childbirth.</p>
<p>Polycystic disease
Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD)
Also known as infantile polycystic kidney disease, this is a rare inherited childhood condition in which there is abnormal development of the kidneys and liver, which are prone to failure.</p>
<p>Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD)
This is inherited as an autosomal dominant condition (Ch. 17) that may become apparent any time between childhood and late adult life. Both kidneys are affected. Dilations (cysts) form at the junction of the distal convoluted tubules and collecting ducts. The cysts slowly enlarge and pressure causes ischaemia and destruction of nephrons. The disease is progressive and secondary hypertension is common; chronic kidney disease affects about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>50</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">50 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">50%</span></span></span></span></span> of patients. Death may be caused by chronic kidney disease, cardiac failure or subarachnoid haemorrhage due to increased incidence of berry aneurysms of the circulus arteriosus. Cysts may also develop in the liver, spleen and pancreas but are not associated with dysfunction of these organs.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="tumours-of-the-kidney">Tumours of the kidney<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tumours-of-the-kidney" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Benign tumours are relatively uncommon.
Malignant tumours
These are most common in the bladder or kidney.
Renal adenocarcinoma
This tumour of tubular epithelium is more common after 50 years of age and in males. Clinical features include haematuria, back or loin pain, anaemia, weight loss and fever. Local spread involves the renal vein and leads to early blood spread of</p>
<p>tumour fragments, most commonly to the lungs and bones. The causes are unknown, although there is an increased incidence in cigarette smokers.</p>
<p>Nephroblastoma (Wilms' tumour)
This is one of the most common malignant tumours in children under 10 years, usually occurring in the first 4 years. Clinical features include haematuria, hypertension, abdominal pain and, sometimes, intestinal obstruction. It is usually unilateral but rapidly becomes very large and invades the renal blood vessels, causing early blood spread to the lungs.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="5205029c">â–  SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5205029c" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol start="8">
<li>Define the terms 'oliguria', 'anuria' and 'dysuria'.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="diseases-of-the-renal-pelvis-ureters-bladder-and-urethra">Diseases of the renal pelvis, ureters, bladder and urethra<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diseases-of-the-renal-pelvis-ureters-bladder-and-urethra" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe the causes and implications of urinary obstruction</li>
<li>explain the pathological features of urinary tract infections</li>
<li>outline the characteristics of the main bladder tumours</li>
<li>discuss the principal causes of urinary incontinence.</li>
</ul>
<p>These structures are considered together because their combined functions are to collect and store urine prior to excretion. Obstruction and infection are the main problems (Fig. 13.23).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="obstruction-to-the-outflow-of-urine">Obstruction to the outflow of urine<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#obstruction-to-the-outflow-of-urine" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Hydronephrosis
This is dilation of the renal pelvis and calyces, caused by accumulation of urine above an obstruction in the urinary tract (Fig. 13.23). It leads to destruction of the nephrons and fibrosis and atrophy of the kidney. One or both kidneys may be involved, depending on the cause and site. When there is an abnormality of the bladder or urethra, both kidneys are affected, whereas an obstruction above the bladder is more common and affects only one kidney. Urinary stasis predisposes to infection.</p>
<p>Complete sustained obstruction
In this condition, hydronephrosis develops quickly, pressure in the nephrons rises and urine production stops. The most common causes are a large calculus or</p>
<p>tumour. The outcome depends on whether one or both kidneys are involved (adequate renal function can be maintained by one kidney).</p>
<p>Partial or intermittent obstruction
This may progress undetected for many years. It leads to progressive hydronephrosis and is caused by, for example:</p>
<ul>
<li>a succession of renal calculi in a ureter, eventually moved onwards by peristalsis</li>
<li>constriction of a ureter or the urethra by fibrous tissue, following epithelial inflammation caused by the passage of a stone or by infection</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="learning-outcomes">Learning outcomes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#learning-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>a tumour in the urinary tract or in the abdominal or pelvic cavity</li>
<li>an enlarged prostate gland in the male.</li>
</ul>
<p>Spinal lesions
When the nerve supply to the bladder is interrupted, e.g. in transverse spinal cord lesions, micturition does not occur. When the bladder fills, the rise in pressure causes overflow incontinence (p.390), back pressure into the ureters and hydronephrosis. Reflex micturition is usually re-established after a time but loss of voluntary control may be irreversible. Pressure on the spinal cord and other abnormalities, e.g. spina bifida, can also impair micturition.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="urinary-tract-infections">Urinary tract infections<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#urinary-tract-infections" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Infection of any part of the urinary tract (a UTI) may spread upwards, causing acute pyelonephritis (p.385) and kidney damage.</p>
<p>Ureteritis
Inflammation of a ureter is usually due to the upward spread of infection in cystitis.
Cystitis
This is inflammation of the bladder and may be due to:</p>
<ul>
<li>upward spread of commensal bacteria of the bowel (Escherichia coli and Streptococcus faecalis) from the perineum via the urethra, especially in women</li>
<li>trauma, with or without infection, following healthcare interventions, e.g. radiotherapy, insertion of a urinary catheter or instrument into the bladder.</li>
</ul>
<p>The effects of inflammation include oedema and small haemorrhages of the mucosa, which may be accompanied by haematuria. The sensory nerve endings in</p>
<p>the bladder wall become hypersensitive and are stimulated even when the bladder contains only small volumes of urine, leading to frequency of micturition and dysuria. The urine may appear cloudy and have an unpleasant smell. Lower abdominal pain often accompanies cystitis. If untreated, upward spread may cause acute pyelonephritis (p. 385) or sepsis (septicaemia).</p>
<p>Cystitis is uncomplicated when it occurs in otherwise healthy individuals with a normal urinary tract. When it affects people with structural or functional abnormalities of the urinary tract or those with pre-existing conditions, e.g. diabetes mellitus or urinary outflow obstruction, it is described as complicated. Complicated UTIs sometimes cause permanent renal damage, whereas this is very rare in uncomplicated infections. Recurrence is fairly common, especially in women, either when the original infection is not eradicated or when reinfection occurs.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="predisposing-factors">Predisposing factors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#predisposing-factors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These include stasis of urine in the bladder and/ or the shorter female urethra, which is close to the anus (see Fig. 13.18A); the moist perineal conditions there may harbour commensal microbes. Sexual intercourse may cause trauma to the urethra and transfer of microbes from the perineum, especially in the female. Hormones associated with pregnancy relax perineal muscle and cause relaxation and kinking of the ureters. Towards the end of pregnancy, pressure caused by the fetus may obstruct the outflow of urine. In the male, prostatitis provides a focus of local infection, or an enlarged prostate gland may cause progressive urethral obstruction.</p>
<p>Urethritis
This is inflammation of the urethra and is described in Chapter 18.
It is not always clear whether bladder tumours are benign or malignant. Tumours are often multiple and recurrence is common. Predisposing factors include cigarette smoking, prolonged use of certain analgesics and occupational exposure to some chemicals, e.g. aniline dyes used in the textile and printing industries.</p>
<p>Transitional cell carcinomas
These tumours, also known as papillomas, arise from transitional epithelium and are often benign. They consist of a stalk with fine-branching fronds, which tend to break off, causing painless bleeding and haematuria. Papillomas commonly recur, even when benign. Sometimes the tumour cells are well differentiated and noninvasive but in other cases they behave as carcinomas and invade surrounding blood and lymph vessels.</p>
<p>These are all malignant to some degree. At an early stage the more malignant and solid tumours rapidly invade the bladder wall and spread in lymph and blood to other parts of the body. If the surface ulcerates, there may be haemorrhage and necrosis.</p>
<p>In this condition, normal micturition is affected and there is involuntary loss of urine. Several types are recognised and described here. In addition to the mechanisms described, neurological abnormalities can also impair voluntary control of micturition, e.g. spinal cord injury, multiple sclerosis (p. 199).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="tumours-of-the-bladder">Tumours of the bladder<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tumours-of-the-bladder" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Solid tumours</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="urinary-incontinence">Urinary incontinence<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#urinary-incontinence" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>SECTION 3 Intake of raw materials and elimination of waste</p>
<p>Stress incontinence
This is leakage of urine when intra-abdominal pressure is raised, e.g. on coughing, laughing, sneezing or lifting. It usually affects women when there is weakness of the pelvic floor muscles or pelvic ligaments, e.g. after childbirth or as part of the ageing process. It occurs physiologically in young children before bladder control is established.</p>
<p>Urge incontinence
Leakage of urine follows a sudden and intense urge to void and there is inability to delay passing urine. This may be due to a urinary tract infection, calculus, tumour or hypersensitivity of the detrusor muscle.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="overflow-incontinence">Overflow incontinence<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#overflow-incontinence" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This occurs when there is chronic overfilling of the bladder and may be caused by retention of urine due to incomplete voiding when there is obstruction of urinary outflow, e.g. enlarged prostate gland or urethral stricture and/ or impaired contraction of the detrusor muscle during micturition. It may also arise as a complication of pelvic nerve damage caused by, for example, surgery or trauma, or when the cauda equina is compressed by a tumour or prolapsed intervertebral disc.</p>
<p>The bladder becomes distended, and when the pressure inside overcomes the resistance of the external urethral sphincter, urine dribbles from the urethra. There may be difficulty initiating and/or maintaining micturition. Larger than normal residual volumes of urine in the bladder (over <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>50</mn><mo>âˆ’</mo><mn>100</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">50-100 \mathrm{~mL}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">50</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">âˆ’</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">100</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">mL</span></span></span></span></span></span> ) predispose to infection.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="spot-check">- SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol start="9">
<li>List three factors that predispose to renal calculi.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="review-and-revise">Review and revise<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#review-and-revise" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Complete each of the following statements:</p>
<ol>
<li>Several hormones influence selective reabsorption in the kidneys by increasing the permeability of parts of
the nephron to water. These include_, secreted
by the posterior pituitary; <em>, secreted by the
adrenal cortex; and</em>, secreted by the atria of the
heart.</li>
<li>There are different types of urinary incontinence.
incontinence occurs when intra-abdominal pressure
is raised, e.g. during coughing._incontinence
follows a sudden and intense desire to void.
incontinence is associated with overfilling of the bladder.
Choose one answer to complete each of the following statements:</li>
<li>The proportion of glomerular filtrate that is normally
reabsorbed is around: <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mspace width="2em"></mspace></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\qquad</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0em;"></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 2em;"></span></span></span></span></span>
a. <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">1%</span></span></span></span></span>
b. <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>10</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">10%</span></span></span></span></span>
c. <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>50</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">50 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">50%</span></span></span></span></span>
d. <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>99</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">99 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">99%</span></span></span></span></span>.</li>
<li>The ureters are lined with: <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mspace width="2em"></mspace></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\qquad</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0em;"></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 2em;"></span></span></span></span></span>
a. Transitional epithelium
b. Stratified epithelium
c. Adipose tissue
d. Connective tissue.</li>
</ol>
<p>Indicate whether each of the following statements is true or false:</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>The urethra carries urine from the kidneys to the
bladder. <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mspace width="2em"></mspace></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\qquad</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0em;"></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 2em;"></span></span></span></span></span></li>
<li>Proteinuria can be normal. <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mspace width="2em"></mspace></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\qquad</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0em;"></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 2em;"></span></span></span></span></span></li>
<li>Match each letter in List A to the appropriate number in List B:</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="list-a">List A<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#list-a" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mspace width="2em"></mspace></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\qquad</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0em;"></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 2em;"></span></span></span></span></span> (a) Erythropoietin
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mspace width="2em"></mspace></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\qquad</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0em;"></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 2em;"></span></span></span></span></span> (b) Parathyroid hormone
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mspace width="2em"></mspace></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\qquad</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0em;"></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 2em;"></span></span></span></span></span> (c) Renin
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mspace width="2em"></mspace></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\qquad</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0em;"></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 2em;"></span></span></span></span></span> (d) Urea
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mspace width="2em"></mspace></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\qquad</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0em;"></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 2em;"></span></span></span></span></span> (e) Angiotensinogen
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mspace width="2em"></mspace></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\qquad</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0em;"></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 2em;"></span></span></span></span></span> (f) Bicarbonate
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mspace width="2em"></mspace></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\qquad</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0em;"></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 2em;"></span></span></span></span></span> (g) Urobilin</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="list-b">List B<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#list-b" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<li>Malignant kidney tumour more common after middle age</li>
