<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="section-4">SECTION 4<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#section-4" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="z">Z<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#z" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Structure and functions of the skin 393
Structure 393
Functions 397
Wound healing 399
Effects of ageing on the skin 402
Disorders of the skin 403
Infections 403
Non-infective inflammatory conditions 403</p>
<p>Pressure ulcers 404</p>
<p>Burns 404</p>
<p>Malignant tumours 405</p>
<p>Review and revise 405</p>
<p>Q Animation
14.1 Burns 404
structure and functions of the skin
Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe the structure of the skin</li>
<li>explain the principal functions of the skin</li>
</ul>
<p>The first parts of this chapter explore the structure and functions of the skin (the integumentary system) and describe the process of wound healing. The effects of ageing on the skin are discussed in the following section. The chapter concludes with a review of common skin conditions.</p>
<p>The skin completely covers the body and is continuous with the membranes lining the body orifices. It:</p>
<ul>
<li>protects the underlying structures from injury and from invasion by microbes</li>
<li>contains sensory nerve endings that enable discrimination of pain, temperature and touch</li>
<li>is involved in the regulation of body temperature.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="structure">Structure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#structure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The skin is the largest organ in the body and has a surface area of about 1.5-2 square metres in adults. In many parts of the body, it contains accessory structures: glands, hair and nails. It varies in thickness, being thickest on the palms of the hands and soles of the feet. There are two main layers: the superficial layer is called the epidermis, and the layer below is the dermis.</p>
<p>Between the dermis and underlying structures is a subcutaneous layer composed of areolar tissue and adipose (fat) tissue.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="epidermis">Epidermis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#epidermis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is composed of stratified keratinised squamous epithelium (see Fig. 3.14). There are no blood vessels or nerve endings in the epidermis, but its deeper layers are bathed in interstitial fluid from the dermis, which provides oxygen and nutrients, and drains away as lymph.</p>
<p>There are several layers (strata) of cells in the epidermis, which extend from the deepest basal layer to the most superficial stratum corneum (a thick horny layer) (Fig. 14.1).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="chapter">CHAPTER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chapter" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-2c944b5a.jpeg" alt="img-103.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 14.1 The skin. Coloured scanning electron micrograph showing the superficial stratum corneum (pale brown), above the lower layers of the epidermis (pink) and the dermis (grey-brown). (Steve G Schmeissner/Science Photo Library. Reproduced with permission.)</p>
<p>The cells of the epidermis originate in the basal layer, which is made up of cuboidal, nucleated, highly active epithelial cells that are constantly dividing. As new cells are formed, they are pushed upwards, away from the basal layer and further from their blood and nutrient supply. As they progress towards the skin surface, their shape and structure gradually change. By the time they reach the skin surface, they are flat, thin, non-nucleated, dead cells, or squames, in which the cytoplasm has been replaced by the fibrous protein keratin. The surface cells are constantly rubbed off and replaced by those beneath. Complete replacement of the epidermis takes about a month.</p>
<p>Hairs, secretions from sebaceous glands and ducts of sweat glands pass through the epidermis to reach the skin surface.</p>
<p>Upward projections of the dermal layer, the dermal papillae (Fig. 14.2), anchor the dermis securely to the epidermis and allow passage and exchange of nutrients and wastes to the lower part of the epidermis. This arrangement stabilises the two layers, preventing damage due to shearing forces. Blisters develop when trauma separates the dermis</p>
<p>Hair shaft Stratum corneum Germinative layer</p>
<p>Dermal papilla Meissner's corpuscle
Sebaceous gland
Arrector pili muscle Hair root Hair follicle Hair papilla (bulb) Cutaneous nerve
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-989ff501.jpeg" alt="img-104.jpeg"></p>
<p>Opening of sweat ducts Epidermis
Dermis
Subcutaneous
tissue
Pacinian corpuscle Sweat gland
Figure 14.2 The skin showing its main structures.
and epidermis, and serous fluid collects between the two layers.
Where the skin is subject to greater wear and tear, e.g. the palms and fingers of the hands and soles of the feet, the epidermis is thicker and hairs are absent. In these areas the dermal papillae are arranged in parallel lines, giving the skin surface a ridged appearance. The pattern of ridges on the fingertips is unique to every individual and the impression made by them is the 'fingerprint'.</p>
<p>Skin colour is affected by various factors.</p>
<ul>
<li>Melanin, a dark pigment derived from the amino acid tyrosine and secreted by melanocytes in the deep germinative layer, is absorbed by surrounding epithelial</li>
</ul>
<p>cells. The amount is genetically determined and varies between different parts of the body, between people
of the same ethnic origin and between ethnic groups.
The number of melanocytes is fairly constant, so the differences in colour depend on the amount of melanin secreted. It protects the skin from the harmful effects of ultraviolet rays in sunlight. Exposure to sunlight promotes synthesis of melanin.</p>
<ul>
<li>Normal saturation of haemoglobin and the amount of blood circulating in the dermis give white skin its pink colour. When oxygen saturation is very low, the skin in white people may appear bluish (cyanosis).</li>
<li>Excessive levels of bile pigments in blood and carotenes in subcutaneous fat give the skin a yellowish colour.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="dermis">Dermis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#dermis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The dermis (Fig. 14.2) is tough and elastic. It is formed from connective tissue, and the matrix contains collagen fibres (see Fig. 3.17) interlaced with elastic fibres. Rupture of elastic fibres occurs when the skin is overstretched, resulting in permanent striae, or stretch marks, which are typically found in pregnancy and obesity. Collagen fibres bind water and give the skin its tensile strength, but as this ability declines with age, wrinkles develop. Fibroblasts (see Fig. 3.8), macrophages and mast cells (see Fig. 3.18) are the main cells found in the dermis. The subcutaneous layer, containing areolar tissue and varying amounts of adipose (fat) tissue, lies under the dermis. Structures found in the dermis are:</p>
<ul>
<li>small blood and lymph vessels</li>
<li>sensory nerve endings</li>
<li>sweat glands and their ducts</li>
<li>hairs, arrector pili muscles and sebaceous glands.</li>
</ul>
<p>Blood and lymph vessels
Arterioles form a fine network with capillary branches supplying sweat glands, sebaceous glands, hair follicles and the dermis. Lymph vessels also form a network throughout the dermis.</p>
<p>Table 14.1 Sensory receptors in the skin</p>
<p>Meissner's corpuscle Light pressure</p>
<p>Pacinian corpuscle Deep pressure</p>
<p>Free nerve ending Pain
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-33b0b5f4.jpeg" alt="img-105.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 14.3 Pacinian corpuscle. (Anatomical Travelogue/Science Photo Library. Reproduced with permission.)</p>
<p>Sensory nerve endings
Sensory receptors (specialised nerve endings) sensitive to touch, temperature, pressure and pain are widely distributed in the dermis. Incoming stimuli activate different types of sensory receptors (Fig. 14.2 and Table 14.1); for example, the Pacinian corpuscle is sensitive to deep pressure (Fig.
14.3). The skin is an important sensory organ through which individuals receive information about their environment.</p>
<p>Nerve impulses, generated in the sensory receptors in the dermis, are transmitted to the spinal cord by sensory nerves (Fig. 14.4). From there, impulses are conducted to the sensory area of the cerebrum, where the sensations are perceived (see Fig. 7.22B).</p>
<p>Sweat glands
These are widely distributed throughout the skin and are most numerous in the palms of the hands, soles of the feet, axillae and groins. They are formed from epithelial cells. The bodies of the glands lie coiled in the subcutaneous tissue.</p>
<p>There are two types of sweat gland.</p>
<p>Eccrine sweat glands are the more common type and open on to the skin surface through tiny pores. The sweat produced here is a clear, watery fluid important in regulating body temperature.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-48c9f2d0.jpeg" alt="img-106.jpeg"></p>
<p>Sensory nerve endings
Sensory nerve
(conducts sensory impulses to spinal cord and brain)
Epidermis
Dermis
Figure 14.4 Sensory nerves in the dermis.
Apocrine sweat glands open into hair follicles and become active at puberty. They may play a role in sexual arousal. These glands are found, for example, in the axilla and genital area. Bacterial decomposition of their secretions causes an unpleasant odour. A specialised example of this type of gland is the ceruminous gland of the outer ear, which secretes earwax (Ch. 8).</p>
<p>The most important function of sweat is in the regulation of body temperature (p. 398). Excessive sweating may lead to dehydration and serious depletion of sodium chloride unless intake of water and salt is appropriately increased. After 7-10 days'</p>
<p>exposure to high environmental temperatures the amount of salt lost is substantially reduced, although water loss remains high.</p>
<p>Hairs
These grow outwards from hair follicles, downgrowths of epidermal cells into the dermis or subcutaneous tissue. At the base of the follicle is a cluster of cells called the hair papilla or bulb. A hair is formed by multiplication of cells of the bulb and as the hairs are pushed upwards, away from their source of nutrition, the cells die and become keratinised. The part of the hair above the skin is the shaft, and the remainder the root (see Fig. 14.2). Fig. 14.5 shows hair growing through the skin and also desquamation, which roughens the skin surface; the roughened surface may harbour microbial growth, although many microbes are removed by the constant rubbing off of the topmost layers.</p>
<p>Hair colour is genetically determined and depends on the amount and type of melanin present. Hair turns white when melanin production by the follicle stops.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-bc6a3646.jpeg" alt="img-107.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 14.5 Coloured scanning electron micrograph of hair shafts growing through the skin. (Steve G Schmeissner/Science Photo Library. Reproduced with permission.)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="arrector-pili">Arrector pili<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#arrector-pili" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Arrector pili (see Fig. 14.2) are little bundles of smooth muscle fibres attached to the hair follicles. Contraction of the muscle fibres makes the hair stand erect and raises the skin around the hair, causing 'gooseflesh'. This is stimulated by sympathetic nerve fibres in response to fear and cold. Erect hairs trap air, which acts as an insulating layer, providing an efficient warming mechanism, especially when accompanied by shivering, i.e. involuntary contraction of skeletal muscles.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="sebaceous-glands">Sebaceous glands<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sebaceous-glands" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Sebaceous glands (see Fig. 14.2) consist of secretory epithelial cells derived from the same tissue as the hair follicles. They secrete an oily antimicrobial substance, sebum, into the hair follicles and are present in the skin of all parts of the body except the palms of the hands and the soles of the feet. They are most numerous in the scalp, face, axillae and groins. In regions of transition from one type of superficial epithelium to another, such as lips, eyelids, nipple, labia minora and</p>
<p>glans penis, there are sebaceous glands that are independent of hair follicles, secreting sebum directly on to the surface.</p>
<p>Sebum keeps the hair soft and pliable, and gives it a shiny appearance. It waterproofs the skin and acts as a bactericidal and fungicidal agent, preventing infection. It also prevents drying and cracking of skin, especially on exposure to heat and sunlight. The activity of these glands increases at puberty and is less at the extremes of age, rendering the skin of infants and older adults prone to the effects of excessive moisture (maceration).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="nails">Nails<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nails" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Human nails (Fig. 14.6) are equivalent to the claws, horns and hooves of animals. Derived from the same cells as
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-d9e20908.jpeg" alt="img-108.jpeg"></p>
<p>Lunula Nail plate
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-8e72f2af.jpeg" alt="img-109.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 14.6 The nail and related structures.
epidermis and hair, these are hard, horny keratin plates that protect the tips of the fingers and toes.</p>
<p>The root of the nail is embedded in the skin and covered by the cuticle, which forms the hemispherical pale area called the lunula. The nail plate is the exposed part that has grown out from the nail bed, the basal layer of the epidermis.</p>
<p>Finger nails grow more quickly than toe nails and growth is faster when the environmental temperature is high.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="functions">Functions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>environment, e.g. by reflex action (withdrawal) to unpleasant or painful stimuli, protecting it from further injury.</p>
<p>The pigment melanin protects against harmful ultraviolet rays in sunlight.
Regulation of body temperature
Core body temperature remains fairly constant at around <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>36.8</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">âˆ˜</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">36.8^{\circ} \mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">36.</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">8</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">âˆ˜</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span> across a wide range of environmental temperatures, ensuring that the optimal range for enzyme activity required for metabolism is maintained. In health, variations are usually limited to between 0.5 and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>0.75</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">âˆ˜</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">0.75^{\circ} \mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">0.7</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">5</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">âˆ˜</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span>, although temperature rises slightly in the evening, during exercise and in women just after ovulation. To maintain this constant temperature, a negative feedback system regulates the balance between heat produced in the body and heat lost to the environment.</p>
<p>Heat production
When metabolic rate increases, body temperature rises; when it decreases, body temperature falls. Some of the energy released during metabolic activity is in the form of heat; the most active organs produce most heat. The principal organs involved are:</p>
<ul>
<li>Skeletal muscle contraction, which produces a large amount of heat; the more strenuous the muscular exercise, the greater the heat produced. Shivering, a rapid repetitive cycle of skeletal muscle contraction and relaxation, increases heat production when there is a risk of body temperature falling below normal.</li>
<li>The liver is very active metabolically, and so generates considerable heat as a byproduct. Metabolic rate and heat production are increased after eating.</li>
<li>The digestive organs generate heat during peristalsis and the chemical reactions involved in digestion.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="protection">Protection<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#protection" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The skin forms a relatively waterproof layer, provided mainly by its keratinised epithelium, which protects the deeper, more delicate structures. As an important non-specific defence mechanism it acts as a barrier against:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>invasion by microorganisms</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>chemicals</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>physical agents, e.g. mild trauma, ultraviolet light</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>dehydration.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>The epidermis contains specialised immune cells called dendritic (Langerhans) cells, which are a type of fixed macrophage (see Fig. 4.13). They phagocytose intruding antigens and present antigen to T-lymphocytes, thus stimulating an immune response (Ch. 15).</p>
<p>Abundant sensory nerve endings in the dermis enable perception, discrimination and location of internal and external stimuli. This allows responses to changes in the</p>
<p>Heat loss
Most heat loss from the body occurs through the skin. Small amounts are lost in expired air, urine and faeces. Only heat loss through the skin can be regulated; heat lost by the other routes cannot be controlled.</p>
<p>Heat loss through the skin is affected by the difference between body and environmental temperatures, the amount of the body surface exposed and the type of clothes worn. Air insulates against heat loss when trapped in layers of clothing and between the skin and clothing. For this reason, several layers of lightweight clothes provide more effective insulation against low environmental temperatures than one heavy garment.</p>
<p>Mechanisms of heat loss
There are four mechanisms of heat loss (Fig. 14.7):</p>
<ul>
<li>Radiation, the main mechanism, when exposed parts of the body radiate heat away from the body.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-8ad87f5a.jpeg" alt="img-110.jpeg"></li>
</ul>
<p>causing sweating; this continues until body temperature falls into the normal range again, when the negative feedback mechanism is switched off.</p>
<p>Activity of the sweat glands
When body temperature is increased by <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>0.25</mn><mo>âˆ’</mo><msup><mn>0.5</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">âˆ˜</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">0.25-0.5^{\circ} \mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">0.25</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">âˆ’</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">0.</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">5</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">âˆ˜</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span> the sweat glands secrete sweat on to the skin surface. Evaporation of sweat cools the body, but is slower in humid conditions.</p>
<p>Loss of heat from the body by evaporation of water through the skin and expired air still occurs even when the environmental temperature is low. This is called insensible water loss (around 500 mL per day) and is accompanied by insensible heat loss.</p>
<p>Regulation of blood flow through the skin
The amount of heat lost from the skin depends largely on blood flow through dermal capillaries. As body temperature rises, the arterioles dilate and more blood enters the capillary network in the skin. The skin is warm and pink in colour. In addition to increasing the amount of sweat produced, the temperature of the skin rises and more heat is lost by radiation, conduction and convection.</p>
<p>If the environmental temperature is low or if heat production is decreased, the arterioles in the dermis are constricted. This reduces blood flow to the body surface, conserving heat. The skin appears paler and feels cool.</p>
<p>Figure 14.7 Mechanisms of heat loss.</p>
<ul>
<li>Evaporation, when the body is cooled as body heat converts the water in sweat to water vapour.</li>
<li>Conduction, when clothes and other objects in direct contact with the skin take up heat.</li>
<li>Convection, when air passing over exposed parts of the body is heated and rises, and cool air replaces it, setting up convection currents. Convection also cools the body when clothes are worn, except when they are windproof.</li>
</ul>
<p>Control of body temperature
The temperature regulating centre in the hypothalamus is sensitive to the temperature of circulating blood. This centre responds to decreasing temperature by sending nerve impulses to:</p>
<ul>
<li>arterioles in the dermis, which constrict, decreasing blood flow to the skin</li>
<li>skeletal muscles, stimulating shivering.</li>
</ul>
<p>As heat is conserved, body temperature rises; when it returns to the normal range, the negative feedback mechanism is switched off (see Fig. 2.13).</p>
<p>Conversely, when body temperature rises, heat loss is increased by dilation of arterioles in the dermis, increasing blood flow to the skin, and stimulation of the sweat glands.</p>
<p>Fever
This is often the result of infection and is caused by release of chemicals (called pyrogens) from inflammatory cells and invading bacteria. Pyrogens, e.g. interleukin 1 (p. 411), act on the hypothalamus, which releases prostaglandins that reset the hypothalamic thermostat to a higher temperature. The body responds by activating heat-promoting mechanisms, e.g. shivering and vasoconstriction, until the new higher temperature is reached. When the thermostat is reset to the normal level, heat-loss mechanisms are activated. There is profuse sweating and vasodilation, accompanied by warm, pink (flushed) skin, until body temperature falls to the normal range again. This shivering (sometimes referred to as a 'chill'), followed by profuse sweating, is known as a rigor.</p>
<p>Hypothermia
This is defined as a core (e.g. rectal) temperature below <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>35</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">âˆ˜</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">35^{\circ} \mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">3</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">5</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">âˆ˜</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span>. At a core temperature below <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>32</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">âˆ˜</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">32^{\circ} \mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">3</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">2</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">âˆ˜</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span>, compensatory mechanisms that normally restore body temperature fail, e.g. shivering is replaced by muscle rigidity and cramps, vasoconstriction fails and blood pressure, pulse and respiration rates fall. There is confusion and disorientation. Death usually occurs when the temperature falls below <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>25</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">âˆ˜</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">2</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">5</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">âˆ˜</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
<p>Individuals at the extremes of age are prone to hypothermia, as temperature regulation is less effective in babies, young people and older adults.</p>
<p>Formation of vitamin D
A lipid-based substance present in the skin, called 7-dehydrocholesterol, is converted to vitamin D by sunlight. This vitamin is used with calcium and phosphate in the formation and maintenance of bone.</p>
<p>Cutaneous sensation
Sensory receptors in the dermis can be sensitive to touch, pressure, temperature or pain (see Table 14.1). Stimulation generates impulses in sensory nerves, which are transmitted to the cerebral cortex (see Fig. 7.22). Some areas have more abundant sensory receptors than others, causing them to be especially sensitive, e.g. the lips and fingertips.</p>
<p>Absorption</p>
<p>This property is limited but substances that can be absorbed include:</p>
<ul>
<li>some drugs when applied as transdermal patches, e.g. hormone replacement therapy during the menopause, nicotine as an aid to smoking cessation</li>
<li>some toxic chemicals, e.g. mercury.</li>
</ul>
<p>Excretion
The skin is a minor excretory organ for some substances, including:</p>
<ul>
<li>sodium chloride in sweat; excess sweating may lead to low blood sodium levels (hyponatraemia)</li>
<li>urea, especially when kidney function is impaired</li>
<li>aromatic substances, e.g. garlic and other spices.</li>
<li>SPOT CHECK</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Outline four ways in which the skin protects the structures underneath it.</li>
<li>Define hypothermia.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="wound-healing">Wound healing<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#wound-healing" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Learning outcome
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>compare and contrast the processes of primary and secondary wound healing.</li>
</ul>
<p>Conditions required for wound healing
Systemic factors
These include good nutritional status and general health. Infection, impaired immunity, poor blood supply and
systemic conditions, e.g. diabetes mellitus and cancer, all reduce the rate of wound healing.</p>
<p>Local factors
Local factors that facilitate wound healing include a good blood supply to provide oxygen and nutrients and remove waste products, and freedom from contamination by, for example, microbes, foreign bodies or toxic chemicals.</p>
<p>Primary healing (healing by first intention)
This type of healing follows minimal destruction of tissue when the damaged edges of a wound are in close apposition, e.g. a surgical incision (Fig. 14.8). There are several overlapping stages in the repair process.</p>
<p>Inflammation
In the first few hours the cut surfaces become inflamed, and blood clot (mainly fibrin, see Fig. 4.15) and cell debris fill the gap between them. Phagocytes, including macrophages, and fibroblasts migrate into the blood clot:</p>
<ul>
<li>Phagocytes begin to remove the clot and cell debris, stimulating fibroblast activity.</li>
<li>Fibroblasts secrete collagen fibres, which begin to bind the wound margins together.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="proliferation">Proliferation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#proliferation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Epithelial cells proliferate across the wound, through the clot. The epidermis meets and grows upwards until full thickness is restored. The clot above the new tissue becomes the scab, which separates after 3-10 days.</p>
<p>Granulation tissue, consisting of new capillary buds, phagocytes and fibroblasts, develops, invading the clot and restoring blood supply to the wound. Fibroblasts continue to secrete collagen fibres as the clot and any bacteria are removed by phagocytosis.</p>
<p>Maturation
The granulation tissue is gradually replaced by fibrous scar tissue. Rearrangement of collagen fibres occurs and the strength of the wound increases. In time the scar becomes less vascular, appearing after a few months as a fine line.</p>
<p>The channels left when stitches are removed heal by the same process.
Secondary healing (healing by second intention)
This type of healing occurs when there is extensive tissue destruction or when the edges of a wound cannot be brought into apposition, e.g. varicose ulcers and pressure ulcers. The stages of secondary healing (Fig. 14.9) are the same as those in primary healing (just described). Healing time depends on effective removal of the cause and on the size of the wound.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-1d2866e6.jpeg" alt="img-111.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="inflammation">Inflammation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#inflammation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Fibroblast # Phagocyte Figure 14.8 Stages in primary wound healing.
Proliferation
Maturation
Inflammation
This develops on the surface of the healthy tissue and separation of necrotic tissue (slough) begins, due mainly to the action of phagocytes in the inflammatory exudate. The inflammatory process is described on page 409.</p>
<p>Proliferation
This begins as granulation tissue, consisting of capillary buds, phagocytes and fibroblasts, develops at the base of the cavity. Granulation tissue grows towards the surface, probably stimulated by macrophages and a range of locally released chemicals. Phagocytes in the plentiful blood supply reduce or prevent infection of the wound by ingesting bacteria after separation of the slough. Some fibroblasts in</p>
<p>the wound, called myofibroblasts, develop a limited ability to contract, reducing the size of the wound and healing time. When granulation tissue reaches the level of the dermis, epithelial cells at the edges proliferate and grow towards the centre.</p>
<p>Maturation
This occurs by fibrosis (see next section), in which scar tissue replaces granulation tissue, usually over several months, until the full thickness of the skin is restored. Scar tissue is shiny and does not contain sweat glands, hair follicles or sebaceous glands.</p>
<p>Fibrosis (scar formation)
Fibrous tissue is formed during healing by secondary intention, e.g. following chronic inflammation, persistent ischaemia, suppuration or extensive trauma. The process begins with formation of granulation tissue; then, over time, the inflammatory material is removed, leaving only
the collagen fibres secreted by the fibroblasts. Fibrous tissue may have long-lasting damaging effects.</p>
<p>Adhesions
These consist of fibrous tissue, which causes adjacent structures to stick together and may limit movement, e.g. between the layers of pleura, preventing inflation of the lungs, or between loops of bowel, interfering with peristalsis.</p>
<p>Fibrosis of infarcts
Blockage of a blood vessel by a thrombus or an embolus causes an infarction (p. 124). Fibrosis of one large infarct or of numerous small infarcts may follow, leading to varying degrees of organ dysfunction, e.g. in heart, brain, kidneys or liver.</p>
<p>Tissue shrinkage
This occurs as fibrous tissue ages. The effects depend on the site and extent of the fibrosis, e.g.:</p>
<ul>
<li>Small tubular structures, such as blood vessels, air passages, ureters, the urethra and ducts of glands may become narrow or obstructed and lose their elasticity.</li>
<li>Contractures (bands of shrunken fibrous tissue) may extend across joints, e.g. in a limb or digit, and limit movement.</li>
</ul>
<p>Complications of wound healing</p>
<p>In addition to the effects of adhesions, fibrosis of infarcts and tissue shrinkage just described, other complications are outlined here.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-f849ef87.jpeg" alt="img-112.jpeg"></p>
<p>Proliferation
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-7c5754df.jpeg" alt="img-113.jpeg"></p>
<p>Loss of tissue
Granulation
tissue
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-2016b368.jpeg" alt="img-114.jpeg"></p>
<p>Maturation
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-94035d91.jpeg" alt="img-115.jpeg"></p>
<p>Early fibrous scar
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-daf656c9.jpeg" alt="img-116.jpeg"></p>
<p>New layer of epidermal cells grows</p>
<p>Scar
contraction
Full skin thickness restored
Figure 14.9 Stages in secondary wound healing.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-7cbafa8f.jpeg" alt="img-117.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 14.10 Sinus between an abscess and the body surface.
Infection
This arises from microbial contamination, usually by bacteria, and results in formation of pus (suppuration).</p>
<p>Pus consists of dead phagocytes, other dead cells, cell debris, fibrin, inflammatory exudate and living and dead microbes. The most common pyogenic (pus-forming) pathogens are Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococcus pyogenes. Small amounts of pus form boils and larger collections form abscesses. S. aureus produces the enzyme coagulase, which converts fibrinogen to fibrin, localising the pus. S. pyogenes produces toxins that break down tissue, spreading the infection. Healing following pus formation is by secondary intention (see above).</p>
<p>Superficial abscesses tend to rupture and discharge pus through the skin. Healing is usually complete unless tissue damage is extensive.</p>
<p>Deep abscesses have a variety of outcomes, which include:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>early rupture with complete discharge of pus on to the surface, followed by healing</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>rupture and limited discharge of pus on to the surface, followed by the development of a chronic abscess with an infected open channel or sinus (Fig. 14.10)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>rupture and discharge of pus into an adjacent organ or cavity, forming an infected channel open at both ends, a fistula (Fig. 14.11)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>eventual removal of pus by phagocytes, followed by healing</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>enclosure of pus by fibrous tissue that may become calcified, harbouring live organisms that may become a source of future infection, e.g. tuberculosis</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>formation of adhesions (see earlier) between adjacent membranes, e.g. pleura, peritoneum
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-c750ca7a.jpeg" alt="img-118.jpeg"></p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Figure 14.11 Fistula between the stomach and the colon.</p>
<ul>
<li>shrinkage of fibrous tissue as it ages, which may reduce the lumen or obstruct a tube, e.g. oesophagus, bowel, blood vessel.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="i-spot-check">I # SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol start="3">
<li>List the stages of wound healing.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="effects-of-ageing-on-the-skin">Effects of ageing on the skin<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#effects-of-ageing-on-the-skin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Learning outcome
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe the effects of ageing on the structure and function of the skin.</li>
</ul>
<p>From the third decade, there are gradual changes in the structure and functioning of the skin, which become much more prominent in old age. As the basal layer becomes less active, the epidermis thins. The dermis also thins and there are fewer elastic and collagen fibres, which causes wrinkling and sagging. These changes may be accelerated by chronic and/or repeated exposure to strong sunlight, which is also associated with the development of malignant changes.</p>
<p>Sweat gland activity and temperature regulation become less efficient, putting older adults at greater risk in extreme temperatures because they are more prone to heatstroke and hypothermia. Less sebum is secreted, making the skin dry and susceptible to continual exposure to moisture (maceration).</p>
<p>Production of vitamin D decreases, predisposing older adults to deficiency and reduction in bone strength, especially when exposure to sunlight is limited.</p>
<p>Melanocytes become less active, causing older adults to be more sensitive to sunlight and more prone to sunburn. In hair, when the pigment melanin is replaced by air bubbles, greying occurs. There are fewer active hair follicles and therefore hair thins, although in some areas this is not the case: notably, the eyebrows, nose and ears in males, and the face and upper lip in females.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-spot-check">I # SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol start="4">
<li>Why are older adults prone to macerated skin?</li>
</ol>
<p>Learning outcome</p>
<p>Disorders of the skin</p>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>list the causes of the diseases described here</li>
<li>explain the pathological features and effects of common skin conditions.</li>
</ul>
<p>Viral infections
Human papilloma virus
Human papilloma virus (HPV) causes warts or verrucas, which are spread by direct contact, e.g. from another lesion or another infected individual. The epidermis proliferates and a small, firm growth develops, which is nearly always benign. Common sites are the hands, the face and the soles of the feet.</p>
<p>Herpes viruses
Rashes seen in chickenpox and shingles (p. 198) are caused by the herpes zoster virus. Other herpes viruses cause cold sores (herpes simplex virus 1, p. 349) and genital herpes (herpes simplex virus 2, p. 506).</p>
<p>Bacterial infections
Impetigo
This is a highly infectious condition commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus. Superficial pustules develop, usually round the nose and mouth. It is spread by direct contact and affects mainly children and immunosuppressed individuals. When caused by Streptococcus pyogenes (a group A P-haemolytic streptococcus) the infection may be complicated by an immune reaction, causing glomerulonephritis (p.383) a few weeks later.</p>
<p>Cellulitis
This is a spreading infection caused by some anaerobic bacteria, including Streptococcus pyogenes and Clostridium perfringens, which enter through a break in the skin. Their spread is facilitated by the formation of enzymes, which break down the connective tissue that normally isolates an area of inflammation. If the infection is untreated, the bacteria may enter the blood, causing septicaemia (sepsis).</p>
<p>In severe cases, necrotising fasciitis may occur. There is rapid and progressive necrosis of subcutaneous tissue that usually includes the fascia in the affected area. Multiple organ failure is common and mortality is high.</p>
<p>Fungal infections (mycoses)
Fungal infections are more likely in warm, moist areas of skin, such as skin folds and between the toes, and also in immunocompromised individuals.</p>
<p>Ringworm and tinea pedis</p>
<p>These are superficial skin infections. In ringworm there is an outward spreading ring of inflammation with a dear patch of apparently normal skin in the centre. It most commonly affects the scalp, feet and groin and is easily spread to others.</p>
<p>Tinea pedis (athlete's foot) affects the skin between the toes.
Both infections are spread by direct contact.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="non-infective-inflammatory-conditions">Non-infective inflammatory conditions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#non-infective-inflammatory-conditions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="dermatitis-eczema">Dermatitis (eczema)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#dermatitis-eczema" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Dermatitis is a common inflammatory skin condition that may be either acute or chronic. In acute dermatitis there is redness, swelling and exudation of serous fluid, usually accompanied by pruritus (itching). This is often followed by crusting and scaling. If the condition becomes chronic, the skin thickens and may become leathery due to long-term scratching, which may cause infection.</p>
<p>Atopic dermatitis
This is associated with allergy and commonly affects atopic individuals, i.e. those prone to hypersensitivity disorders (p. 405). Children, who may also suffer from hay fever or asthma (pp. 285 and 286), are often affected.</p>
<p>Contact dermatitis
This may be caused by direct contact with irritants, e.g. cosmetics, soap, detergent, strong acids or alkalis, industrial chemicals or a hypersensitivity reaction (see Fig. 15.9) to latex, nickel, dyes and other chemicals, for example.</p>
<p>Psoriasis
Genetic and environmental factors are implicated in the development of this common condition, which is characterised by exacerbations and periods of remission of varying duration. Trigger factors that worsen the condition include trauma, infection, sunburn and some drugs. It is thought that anxiety and stress may also contribute in some individuals. Psoriasis is sometimes associated with rheumatoid arthritis (p. 470).</p>
<p>Cell division in the basal layer of the epidermis increases, so that new cells are pushed more quickly towards the surface layers. Transit time (from basal to superficial layer) may be as little as 5 days (instead of the normal 28 days), so that cells arriving at the surface have not had time to mature into keratinised squames.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-98837f3e.jpeg" alt="img-119.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 14.12 Psoriasis. (Biophoto Associates/Science Photo Library. Reproduced with permission.)</p>
<p>Psoriasis is characterised by red, scaly plaques with a silvery surface (Fig. 14.12). Bleeding may occur when scales are scratched or rubbed off. The elbows, knees and scalp are common sites but other parts can also be affected.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="acne-vulgaris">Acne vulgaris<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#acne-vulgaris" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This most frequently affects adolescent males and is thought to be caused by increased levels of testosterone after puberty. Sebaceous glands (in hair follicles) become blocked and then infected, leading to inflammation and pustule formation. In severe cases permanent scarring may result. The most common sites are the face, chest and upper back.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pressure-ulcers">Pressure ulcers<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pressure-ulcers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Also known as decubitus ulcers or bedsores, these occur over 'pressure points', areas where the skin may be compressed for long periods between a bony prominence and a hard surface, e.g. a bed or chair. When this occurs, blood flow to the affected area is impaired and ischaemia develops. Initially, the skin reddens and later, as ischaemia and necrosis occur, the skin sloughs and an ulcer forms, which may then enlarge into a cavity. If infection occurs, this can result in sepsis. Healing takes place by secondary intention (p.399).</p>
<p>Predisposing factors may be:</p>
<ul>
<li>extrinsic, e.g. pressure, shearing forces, trauma, immobility, moisture, infection</li>
<li>intrinsic, e.g. poor nutritional status, emaciation, incontinence, infection, concurrent illness, sensory impairment, poor circulation.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="burns">Burns<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#burns" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Burns may be caused by many types of trauma, including heat, cold, electricity, ionising radiation and corrosive chemicals, such as strong acids or alkalis (bases). Local damage occurs, disrupting the structure and functions of the skin.</p>
<p>Burns are classified according to their depth:
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-3ae08034.jpeg" alt="img-120.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 14.13 The 'rule of nines' for estinnating the extent of burns in adults.</p>
<ul>
<li>Superficial (epidermal), when only the epidermis is involved. The surface is moist and there are signs of inflammation, including redness, swelling and pain. There are no blisters and tissue damage is minimal.</li>
<li>Partial thickness, when the epidermis and upper dermis are affected. In addition to the signs and symptoms just listed, blistering is present.</li>
<li>Full thickness, when the epidermis and dermis are destroyed. These burns are usually relatively painless, as the sensory nerve endings in the dermis are destroyed. After a few days the destroyed tissue coagulates and forms an eschar, or thick scab, which sloughs off after 2-3 weeks.</li>
</ul>
<p>In circumferential burns, which encircle any area of the body, complications may arise from constriction of the part by eschar, e.g. respiratory impairment may follow circumferential burns of the chest, or the circulation to the distal part of an affected limb may be seriously impaired. Skin grafting is required except for small injuries. Healing, which is prolonged, occurs by secondary intention (p. 399) and there is no regeneration of sweat glands, hair follicles or sebaceous glands. Resultant scar tissue often limits movement of affected joints. 14.1</p>
<p>The extent of burns in adults is roughly estimated using the 'rule of nines' (Fig. 14.13). In adults, hypovolaemic shock usually develops when <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>15</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">15 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">15%</span></span></span></span></span> of the surface</p>
<p>area is affected. Fatality is likely in adults with full-thickness burns if the surface area affected is added to the patient's age and the total is greater than 80 .
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-d007f1d3.jpeg" alt="img-121.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="complications-of-bums">Complications of bums<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#complications-of-bums" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Although burns affect the skin, their systemic consequences can also be lifethreatening or fatal when they are extensive.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="dehydration-and-hypovolaemia">Dehydration and hypovolaemia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#dehydration-and-hypovolaemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These may occur in extensive burns when there is excessive leakage of water and plasma proteins from the damaged skin surface.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="shock">Shock<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#shock" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This may accompany severe hypovolaemia.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hypothermia">Hypothermia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hypothermia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This develops when excessive heat is lost in leakage from burns.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="infection">Infection<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#infection" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>When subcutaneous tissue is exposed to the environment, microbes can readily infect the wound, which may result in sepsis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="kidney-faiiure">Kidney faiiure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#kidney-faiiure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Acute tubular necrosis (p. 386) occurs in severe burns when the kidney tubules are damaged by the large amounts of waste from haemolysed erythrocytes, and inflamed and degenerating burn tissue.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="contractures">Contractures<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#contractures" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These may develop later as fibrous scar tissue contracts, distorting joints such as the hands and restricting their range of motion.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="malignant-tumours">Malignant tumours<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#malignant-tumours" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="basal-cell-carcinoma">Basal cell carcinoma<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#basal-cell-carcinoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is the least malignant and most common type of skin cancer. It is associated with long-term exposure to sunlight and is therefore most likely to occur in older adults on sun-exposed sites, usually the head or neck. It appears as a shiny nodule and later this breaks down, becoming an ulcer with irregular edges, commonly called a rodent ulcer. Although this is locally invasive, it seldom metastasises.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="malignant-melanoma">Malignant melanoma<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#malignant-melanoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is malignant proliferation of melanocytes, usually originating in a mole that enlarges and may have an irregular outline (Fig. 14.14). It may ulcerate and bleed, and most commonly affects young and middle-aged adults. Predisposing factors are a fair skin and recurrent episodes of intensive exposure to sunlight, including repeated episodes of sunburn, especially in childhood. Sites for this tumour show a gender bias, with the lower leg being the most common site in females and the upper back in males.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-2180d1d7.jpeg" alt="img-122.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 14.14 Malignant melanoma. (James Stevenson/Science Photo Library. Reproduced with permission.)</p>
<p>Metastases usually develop early and are associated with a poor prognosis. Initial spread is usually to nearby lymph nodes and is followed by blood-spread metastases in the liver, brain, lungs, bowel and bone marrow.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="kaposi-s-sarcoma">Kaposi's sarcoma<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#kaposi-s-sarcoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This malignant tumour arises from the walls of blood and lymphatic vessels. It is associated with a human herpes virus and is usually AIDS-related. A small red-blue patch or nodule develops, usually on the lower limbs but the mouth, oesophagus, stomach and intestines can also be affected. Without treatment, skin lesions enlarge and become more numerous.</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>Which skin cancer usually starts as a dark, enlarging mole with an irregular outline?</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="review-and-revise">Review and revise<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#review-and-revise" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Complete each of the following statements:</p>
<ol>
<li>When the body needs to cool down, the blood vessels
called_dilate to divert more blood to the skin. Use
of a fan generates currents and heat is lost by.
This also assists in conversion of sweat into water vapour, a process known as</li>
<li>A burn that involves only the epidermis is defined as
<em>. If it also involves the upper dermis and there is
blistering of the skin, it is described as</em>. Deeper
burns are called_burns.
Choose one answer to complete each of the following statements:</li>
<li>The healthy epidermis is formed from: <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mspace width="2em"></mspace></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\qquad</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0em;"></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 2em;"></span></span></span></span></span>
a. One layer of columnar epithelium
b. Several layers of connective tissue
c. Division of epithelial cells in the basal layer, which are pushed upwards
d. Blood vessels, nerve endings, sebaceous glands and sweat glands.</li>
<li>The skin condition that is characterised by red, scaly
skin that often affects the elbows, knees and scalp is called: <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mspace width="2em"></mspace></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\qquad</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0em;"></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 2em;"></span></span></span></span></span>

b. Contact dermatitis
c. Impetigo
d. Psoriasis.</li>
<li>Match each letter in List A to the appropriate number in List B:</li>
</ol>
<p>List A</p>
<p>(a) Melanin

(c) Fibroblast
(d) Sebum
(e) Arrector pili
(f) Macrophage
(g) Interleukin 1
(h) Keratin</p>
