</ol>
<p>For a range of further self-assessment exercises on the topics in this chapter, visit Evolve online resources: <a href="https://evolve.elsevier.comA/Vaugh/anatomy/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">https://evolve.elsevier.comA/Vaugh/anatomy/</a></p>
<p>Non-specific defence mechanisms 407
Epithelial barriers 408
Phagocytosis 408
Natural antimicrobial substances 408
The inflammatory response 409
Immunological surveillance 411
Immunity 411
Lymphocytes 412
Cell-mediated immunity 412
Antibody-mediated (humoral) immunity 413
Acquired immunity 414
Summary of the immune response to a bacterial infection 416
Ageing and immunity 416
From the months spent in the womb to the end of life, every individual is under constant attack from an enormous range of potentially harmful invaders. These threats include such diverse entities as bacteria, viruses, cancer cells, parasites and foreign (non-self) cells, e.g. in tissue transplant. The body has therefore developed a wide selection of protective measures, which can be divided into two categories.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="non-specific-innate-defence-mechanisms">Non-specific (innate) defence mechanisms<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#non-specific-innate-defence-mechanisms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These protect against any of an enormous range of possible dangers and are present at birth: hence the term 'innate'.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="specific-adaptive-defence-mechanisms">Specific (adaptive) defence mechanisms<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#specific-adaptive-defence-mechanisms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These are grouped together under the term 'immunity'. Resistance is directed against only one specific invader. This type of immunity is sometimes called adaptive immunity because it adapts, refines and strengthens its response to multiple exposures to the same antigen. This ability to 'learn' is responsible for the development of immunological</p>
<p>Abnormal immune function ..... 417
Hypersensitivity (allergy) ..... 417
Autoimmune disease ..... 417
Immunodeficiency ..... 418
Review and revise ..... 419
Q Animations
15.1 Phagocytosis ..... 408
15.2 Complement ..... 409
15.3 T-cells ..... 412
15.4 B-cells ..... 413
15.5 Antibodies and antigens ..... 414
15.6 Antibodies ..... 414
15.7 Allergic response ..... 417
memory, giving long-term immunity to specific infections. An antigen is anything that stimulates an immune response.
The later sections of the chapter describe the effects of ageing on the immune system and consider some disorders of immune function.
Non-specific defence mechanisms</p>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>identify the body's main non-specific defence cells</li>
<li>describe the functions and features of the inflammatory response</li>
<li>explain the process of phagocytosis</li>
<li>list the main antimicrobial substances in the body.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="chapter">CHAPTER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chapter" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-faf102ca.jpeg" alt="img-123.jpeg"></p>
<p>These are the first lines of general defence; they prevent entry and minimise further passage of microbes and other foreign material into the body. They offer a rapid response system, permanently mobilised and providing constant protection. There are five main non-specific defence mechanisms:</p>
<ul>
<li>epithelial barriers</li>
<li>phagocytosis</li>
<li>natural antimicrobial substances</li>
<li>the inflammatory response</li>
<li>immunological surveillance.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="epithelial-barriers">Epithelial barriers<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#epithelial-barriers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Healthy, intact skin and mucous membranes provide an efficient physical barrier protecting the body's exposed surfaces. The skin carries a rich population of bacteria, called commensals, that do not normally cause infections. Few pathogens can establish themselves on healthy skin. Sebum and sweat secreted on to the skin surface contain antibacterial and antifungal substances.</p>
<p>Epithelial membranes lining body cavities and passageways exposed to the external environment (e.g. the respiratory, genitourinary and digestive tracts) are more delicate but are also well defended. Epithelia produce antibacterial secretions, often acidic, containing antibodies and enzymes, as well as sticky mucus for trapping passing microbes.</p>
<p>Hairs in the nose act as a coarse filter, and the sweeping action of cilia in the respiratory tract (see Fig. 10.12) moves mucus and inhaled foreign materials towards the throat. Then it is coughed up or swallowed.</p>
<p>The one-way flow of urine from the bladder minimises the risk of infection ascending through the urethra into the bladder. In the female the acidity of vaginal secretions discourages microbial growth.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="phagocytosis-15-1">Phagocytosis 15.1<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#phagocytosis-15-1" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The process of phagocytosis ('cell eating') is shown in Fig.
4.11. Phagocytic defence cells, such as neutrophils and
macrophages, are the body's first line of cellular defence.
Phagocytes actively migrate (chemotaxis, p. 410) to sites of
inflammation and infection because neutrophils themselves
and invading microbes release chemicals that attract them
(chemoattractants). Phagocytes attack and engulf their
targets (Fig. 15.1). They indiscriminately digest and destroy
foreign cells, antigenic material and damaged body cells and
debris. They may also release chemicals toxic to invading
microbes into the interstitial fluid. Some of these chemicals
alert the adaptive immune response to the presence of a
threat. Neutrophils are very short-lived once activated,
and destroy themselves as well as their targets with their
own toxic products. Macrophages are much longer-lived
phagocytes, and also have an important role as a link
between the non-specific and specific defence mechanisms. <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>408</mn><mrow><mo>âˆ§</mo><mo>âˆ§</mo></mrow></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">408^{\wedge \wedge}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7519em;"></span><span class="mord">40</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">8</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7519em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">âˆ§âˆ§</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-8f9149ce.jpeg" alt="img-124.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 15.1 Phagocytosis. A white blood cell (blue) phagocytosing a yeast cell (yellow). (Biology Media/Science Photo Library. Reproduced with permission.)</p>
<p>After ingestion and digestion of an antigen, they act as antigen-presenting cells, displaying their antigen on their own cell surface to stimulate T-lymphocytes and activate the adaptive immune response (p. 411).</p>
<p>The body's population of fixed and roaming macrophages (the mononuclear phagocyte system) is also discussed in Chapter 4. Other important populations of phagocytes include glial cells in the nervous system (p. 160) and osteoclasts in bone tissue (p. 423).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="natural-antimicrobial-substances">Natural antimicrobial substances<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#natural-antimicrobial-substances" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hydrochloric-acid">Hydrochloric acid<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hydrochloric-acid" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is present in high concentrations in gastric juice and kills the majority of ingested microbes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="lysozyme">Lysozyme<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lysozyme" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This antibacterial enzyme is present in granulocytes, tears and other body secretions but not in sweat, urine or cerebrospinal fluid. It destroys bacterial cell walls but does not affect viruses or other pathogens.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="antibodies">Antibodies<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#antibodies" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These protective proteins inactivate bacteria and are found coating membranes exposed to the external environment, e.g. those of the genitourinary, respiratory and gastrointestinal tracts, and in body fluids (p. 414).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="saliva">Saliva<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#saliva" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is secreted into the mouth and washes away food debris that may otherwise encourage bacterial growth. It contains antibodies, lysozyme and buffers to neutralise bacterial acids that promote dental decay.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="interferons">Interferons<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#interferons" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These chemicals are produced by T-lymphocytes, macrophages and body cells that have been invaded by
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-13a97055.jpeg" alt="img-125.jpeg">
viruses. They activate immune cells, including killer T-cells, prevent viral replication within infected cells, and reduce the spread of viruses to healthy cells.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="complement-qi5-2">Complement Qi5.2<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#complement-qi5-2" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Complement is a system of about 20 proteins found in the blood and tissues. It is activated by the presence of immune complexes (an antigen and antibody bound together) and by foreign sugars on bacterial cell walls. Complement:</p>
<ul>
<li>binds to, and damages, bacterial cell walls, destroying the microbe</li>
<li>binds to bacterial cell walls, stimulating phagocytosis by neutrophils and macrophages</li>
<li>attracts phagocytic cells such as neutrophils into an area of infection, i.e. stimulates chemotaxis.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-inflammatory-response">The inflammatory response<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-inflammatory-response" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is the physiological response to tissue damage and is accompanied by a characteristic series of local changes (Fig. 15.2). Its purpose is protective: to isolate, inactivate and remove both the causative agent and damaged tissue, so that healing can take place. The cardinal signs of inflammation are</p>
<ul>
<li>redness</li>
<li>heat</li>
<li>swelling</li>
<li>pain.</li>
</ul>
<p>Inflammatory conditions are recognised by their Latin suffix '-itis'; for example, appendicitis is inflammation of the appendix and laryngitis is inflammation of the larynx.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="causes-of-inflammation">Causes of inflammation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#causes-of-inflammation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Any form of tissue damage stimulates the inflammatory response, even in the absence of infection. The wide range of triggers includes extremes of temperature, the presence of foreign bodies, trauma, corrosive chemicals including extremes of pH , abrasion, immune reactions including autoimmunity, and infection.</p>
<p>Acute inflammation
Acute inflammation is typically of short duration, e.g. days to a few weeks, and may range from mild to very severe, depending on the extent of tissue damage. Most aspects of the inflammatory response are hugely beneficial, promoting removal of the harmful agent and optimising conditions for healing to follow.</p>
<p>The acute inflammatory response is described here as a collection of separate events: increased blood flow, accumulation of tissue fluid, migration of leukocytes, increased core temperature, pain and suppuration. In reality, these events significantly overlap and develop together. Even when inflammation is localised, the release
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-0b7d8365.jpeg" alt="img-126.jpeg"></p>
<p>Inflammatory mediators: Prostaglandins (C) Histamine Bradykinin Figure 15.2 The inflammatory response.
of inflammatory mediators into the blood leads to systemic effects. This is called the acute phase response, and systemic changes such as fever and elevated white blood cell count are important indicators of inflammation, with or without infection, somewhere in the body.</p>
<p>Some of the most important substances released in inflammation are summarised in Table 15.1.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="increased-blood-flow">Increased blood flow<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#increased-blood-flow" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Following injury, the arterioles supplying the damaged area dilate and the local capillaries expand, increasing blood flow to the site.</p>
<p>This is caused mainly by the local release of a number of chemical mediators from damaged cells, including histamine and serotonin. Increased blood flow to the area of tissue damage provides more oxygen and nutrients for the increased cellular activity that accompanies inflammation.</p>
<p>Table 15.1
Summary of the
principal
substances released
in inflammation</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;">Substance</th><th style="text-align: left;">Made by</th><th style="text-align: left;">Trigger for &lt;br&gt; release</th><th style="text-align: left;">Main pro-inflammatory &lt;br&gt; actions</th></tr></thead></table>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;">Histamine</th><th style="text-align: left;">Mast cells (in &lt;br&gt; most tissues), &lt;br&gt; basophils &lt;br&gt; (blood); stored &lt;br&gt; in cytoplasmic &lt;br&gt; granules</th><th style="text-align: left;">Binding of &lt;br&gt; antibody to mast &lt;br&gt; cells and &lt;br&gt; basophils</th><th style="text-align: left;">Vasodilation, itching, &lt;br&gt; increased vascular &lt;br&gt; permeability, &lt;br&gt; degranulation, smooth &lt;br&gt; muscle contraction (e.g. &lt;br&gt; bronchoconstriction)</th></tr></thead></table>
<p>Serotonin Platelets Platelet Vasoconstriction, increased
(5- <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mspace width="1em"></mspace></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\quad</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0em;"></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 1em;"></span></span></span></span></span> Mast cells and mast
hydroxytryptamine, basophils (stored cell/basophil
5-HT) in granules) degranulation

nervous system
(acts as
neurotransmitter)</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;">Prostaglandins &lt;br&gt; (PGs)</th><th style="text-align: left;">Nearly all cells; &lt;br&gt; not stored, but &lt;br&gt; made from cell &lt;br&gt; membranes as &lt;br&gt; required</th><th style="text-align: left;">Many different &lt;br&gt; stimuli, e.g. &lt;br&gt; drugs, toxins, &lt;br&gt; other &lt;br&gt; inflammatory &lt;br&gt; mediators, &lt;br&gt; hormones, &lt;br&gt; trauma</th><th style="text-align: left;">Diverse, sometimes &lt;br&gt; opposing, e.g. fever, pain, &lt;br&gt; vasodilation or &lt;br&gt; vasoconstriction, increased &lt;br&gt; vascular permeability</th></tr></thead></table>
<p>Increased blood flow causes the increased temperature and reddening of an inflamed area, and contributes to the swelling (oedema) associated with inflammation.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="increased-tissue-fluid-formation">Increased tissue fluid formation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#increased-tissue-fluid-formation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>One of the cardinal signs of inflammation is swelling of the tissues involved, which is caused by fluid leaving local blood vessels and entering the interstitial spaces (oedema).</p>
<p>This is partly due to increased capillary permeability caused by inflammatory mediators such as histamine, serotonin and prostaglandins, and partly due to elevated pressure inside the vessels because of increased blood flow. Most of the excess tissue fluid drains away in the lymphatic vessels, taking damaged tissue, dead and dying cells, and toxins with it.</p>
<p>Plasma proteins, normally retained within the bloodstream, also escape into the tissues through the leaky capillary walls; this increases the osmotic pressure of the tissue fluid and draws more fluid out of the blood. These proteins include antibodies, which combat infection, and fibrinogen, a clotting protein. Fibrinogen in the tissues is converted by thromboplastin to fibrin, which forms an insoluble mesh within the interstitial space, walling off the inflamed area and helping to limit the spread of any infection. Some pathogens, e.g. Streptococcus pyogenes, which</p>
<p>causes throat and skin infections, release toxins that break down this fibrin network and promote spread of infection into adjacent, healthy tissue.</p>
<p>Sometimes tissue oedema can be harmful. For instance, swelling around respiratory passages can obstruct breathing, and significant swelling often causes pain. On the other hand, the swelling around a painful, inflamed joint cushions it and limits movement, which encourages healing.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="migration-of-leukocytes">Migration of leukocytes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#migration-of-leukocytes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Loss of fluid from the blood thickens it, slowing flow and allowing the normally fast-flowing white blood cells to make contact with, and adhere to, the vessel wall. In the acute stages, the most important leukocyte is the neutrophil, which adheres to the blood vessel lining, squeezes between the endothelial cells and enters the tissues (diapedesis, see Fig. 4.10), where its main function is in phagocytosis of antigens. Phagocyte activity is promoted by the raised temperatures (local and systemic) associated with inflammation.</p>
<p>After about 24 hours, macrophages become the predominant cell type at the inflamed site, and they persist in the tissues if the situation is not resolved, leading to chronic inflammation. They phagocytose dead/ dying tissue, microbes and other antigenic material, and dead/dying neutrophils. Some microbes resist digestion and provide a possible source of future infection, e.g. Mycobacterium tuberculosis (p. 291).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="chemotaxis">Chemotaxis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chemotaxis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is the chemical attraction of leukocytes, including neutrophils and macrophages, to an area of inflammation.</p>
<p>It may be that chemoattractants act to retain passing leukocytes in the inflamed area, rather than actively attracting them from distant areas of the body. Chemoattractants include microbial toxins, chemicals released from leukocytes, prostaglandins from damaged cells and complement proteins.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="increased-temperature">Increased temperature<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#increased-temperature" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The increased temperature of inflamed tissues has the twin benefits of inhibiting the growth and division of microbes while promoting the activity of phagocytes.</p>
<p>The inflammatory response may be accompanied by a rise in body temperature (fever, or pyrexia), especially if there is bacterial infection. Body temperature rises when an endogenous pyrogen (interleukin 1) is released from macrophages and granulocytes in response to microbial toxins or immune complexes. Interleukin 1 is a chemical mediator that resets the temperature thermostat in the hypothalamus at a higher level, causing pyrexia and other symptoms that may also accompany systemic inflammation, e.g. fatigue and loss of appetite. Pyrexia increases the</p>
<p>metabolic rate of cells in the inflamed area and, consequently, there is an increased need for oxygen and nutrients.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pain">Pain<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pain" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Pain occurs when local swelling compresses sensory nerve endings. It is exacerbated by chemical mediators of the inflammatory process, e.g. bradykinin and prostaglandins, which potentiate the sensitivity of the sensory nerve endings to painful stimuli. Although pain is an unpleasant experience, it may indirectly promote healing because it encourages protection of the damaged site.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="suppuration-pus-formation">Suppuration (pus formation)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#suppuration-pus-formation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Pus consists of dead phagocytes, dead cells, fibrin, inflammatory exudate, and living and dead microbes. A localised collection of pus in the tissues is called an abscess (see Fig. 14.10). The most common pyogenic (pus-forming) bacteria are Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococcus pyogenes.
laying down of collagen, and to fibrosis. If the body defences are unable to clear the infection, they may try to wall it off instead, forming nodules called granulomas, within which are collections of defensive cells. Tuberculosis is an example of an infection that frequently becomes chronic, leading to granuloma formation. The causative bacterium, Mycobacterium tuberculosis, is resistant to body defences and so pockets of organisms (Ghon foci, p. 291) are sealed up in granulomas within the lungs.</p>
<p>Chronic inflammation may either be a complication of acute inflammation (see earlier) or follow chronic exposure to an irritant. It is also seen in hypersensitivity disorders (p. 417), where inappropriate immune activation leads to extended and harmful periods of inflammation (e.g. asthma, p. 286). Fibrosis (scar formation) is discussed in Chapter 14.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="immunological-surveillance">Immunological surveillance<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#immunological-surveillance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A population of lymphocytes, called natural killer (NK) cells, constantly patrol the body searching for abnormal host cells. Cells that have been infected with a virus, or mutated cells that might become malignant, frequently display unusual markers on their cell membranes, which are recognised by NK cells. Having detected an abnormal cell, the NK cell immediately kills it. NK cells are therefore particularly effective in clearing pre-cancerous body cells and in certain viral infections, including herpes virus. Although NK cells are lymphocytes, they are much less selective about their targets than the other two types discussed later in this chapter (T- and B-cells).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="outcomes-of-acute-inflammation-resolution">Outcomes of acute inflammation Resolution<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#outcomes-of-acute-inflammation-resolution" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This occurs when the cause has been successfully overcome. Damaged cells and residual fibrin are removed, being replaced with new healthy tissue, with or without scar formation.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="development-of-chronic-inflammation">Development of chronic inflammation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#development-of-chronic-inflammation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Acute inflammation may become chronic if resolution is not complete because the area infected is not readily accessible to body defences, as in some deep-seated abscesses, wound infections and bone infections.</p>
<p>In addition, some organisms are more resistant to body defences than others, and so survive in the tissues. For example, members of the Mycobacteria family live inside host cells rather than in the extracellular fluids, and so are protected against host defences (see next section).</p>
<p>Chronic inflammation
The processes involved are very similar to those of acute inflammation but, because the processes are of longer duration, considerably more tissue damage is likely. The inflammatory cells are mainly lymphocytes instead of neutrophils, and fibroblasts are activated, leading to the</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="spot-check">- SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Explain the relationship between chemotaxis and phagocytosis.</li>
<li>In what ways is increased temperature beneficial to the inflammatory response?</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="immunity">Immunity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#immunity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>discuss the roles of the different types of T-lymphocyte in providing cellmediated immunity</li>
<li>describe the process of antibody-mediated immunity</li>
<li>distinguish between artificially and naturally acquired immunity, giving examples of each</li>
<li>distinguish between active and passive immunity, giving examples of each.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="learning-outcomes">Learning outcomes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#learning-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The body's first line of defence is its collection of non-specific innate defences, including phagocytes such as macrophages. If these are overwhelmed, activation of</p>
<p>the powerful immune system follows. Immunity possesses three key attributes not seen with non-specific defences: specificity, memory and tolerance.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="specificity">Specificity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#specificity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Unlike mechanisms such as the inflammatory response and the phagocytic action of macrophages, which are triggered by a wide range of threats, an immune response is directed against one antigen and no others.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="memory">Memory<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#memory" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Again, unlike general defence mechanisms, an immune response against a particular antigen will usually generate immunological memory of that antigen. This means that the immune response on subsequent exposures to the same antigen is generally faster and more powerful.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="tolerance">Tolerance<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tolerance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The cells of the immune system are aggressive and potentially extremely destructive. Control of their activity is essential to protect healthy body tissues. As immune cells travel around the body, they check the marker proteins that cells show on their cell membranes. Healthy body cells display the expected 'self markers and are ignored by the patrolling immune cells. However, non-self cells, such as cancer cells, foreign (transplanted) cells or pathogens possess different patterns of markers, which immediately activate the immune cell and usually lead to the destruction of the non-self cell.</p>
<p>Failure of immune cells to distinguish self-proteins accurately can lead to an inappropriate immune response against host cells. This is called autoimmunity (p. 417) and can lead to significant tissue destruction over a period of time.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="lymphocytes">Lymphocytes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lymphocytes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Lymphocytes make up 20-30% of circulating white blood cells but at any one time most of them are found in lymphatic and other tissues rather than in the bloodstream. They include natural killer cells (p. 411), involved in immunological surveillance, T-cells (the majority) and B-cells. T- and B-cells are responsible for immunity (specific defence) and are produced in the bone marrow and some lymphatic tissues, although T-cells migrate to the thymus gland for final maturation.</p>
<p>Each individual T- and B-cell carries antigen recognition
molecules, allowing it to respond to only one specific
antigen. The range of antigen recognition molecules is</p>
<p>genetically determined, i.e. inherited from the parents. A
healthy immune system has the capacity to recognise and
respond to millions of different antigens; i.e. it can produce
millions of different populations of T- and B-cells.
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>412</mn><mo>âˆ§</mo><mo>âˆ§</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">412 \wedge \wedge</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">412</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">âˆ§</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5556em;"></span><span class="mord">âˆ§</span></span></span></span></span></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="t-cells">T-cells<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#t-cells" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The hormone thymosin, produced by the thymus gland, promotes T-cell maturation, which leads to the formation of fully specialised (differentiated), mature, functional T-cells. It is important to recognise that a mature T-cell has been programmed to recognise only one type of antigen, and during its subsequent travels through the body will react to no other antigen, however dangerous it might be. Thus, a T-cell manufactured to recognise the chickenpox virus will not react to a measles virus, a cancer cell or a tuberculosis bacterium.</p>
<p>T-cells provide cell-mediated immunity, discussed later.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="b-cells">B-cells<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-cells" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>B-cells are both produced and matured in the bone marrow. They produce antibodies (immunoglobulins), proteins designed to bind to, and destroy, an antigen. As with T-cells, each B-cell targets one specific antigen; the antibody released reacts with one type of antigen and no other. B-cells provide antibodymediated immunity, discussed later.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="6929eae3">Cell-mediated immunity <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">â–¡</mi><mn>15.3</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\square 15.3</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.675em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">â–¡</span><span class="mord">15.3</span></span></span></span></span><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6929eae3" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>T-cells that have matured in the thymus gland are released into the circulation. When they encounter their antigen for the first time, they become sensitised to it. T-cells cannot detect free antigen in body fluids. To recognise and be activated by antigen, the T-cell must be 'presented' with it on the membrane of another cell. These cells are called antigen-presenting cells (APCs). Many different cell types present antigen to T-cells, and so are important in activating the adaptive immune system when antigen is present. Dendritic cells in the skin, for example, defend the body surface; they phagocytose invading organisms and present their antigens to Tcells. Macrophages are very important APCs. They are part of the non-specific defences because they engulf and digest antigens indiscriminately, but they are a crucial 'link' cell between initial non-specific innate defences and the adaptive immune system. After digesting the antigen, they transport the most antigenic fragment to their own cell membrane and display it on their surface (Fig. 15.3). They display (present) this antigen to the T-cell that recognises that particular antigen, activating the T-cell. In addition, abnormal body cells, e.g. those infected</p>
<p>with a virus or with a mutation in their DNA, express abnormal proteins, which the cell displays on its cell membrane. In this way, the abnormal cell is also acting as an APC and marking itself for destruction.</p>
<p>T-cell activation triggers it to divide and proliferate (clonal expansion) (Fig. 15.3). Four main types of specialised T-cell are produced, each of which is still directed against the original antigen but will tackle it in different ways.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cytotoxic-t-cells">Cytotoxic T-cells<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cytotoxic-t-cells" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These directly inactivate any cells carrying antigens. They attach themselves to the target cell and release powerful toxins, which are very effective because the two cells are
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-82ca5aea.jpeg" alt="img-127.jpeg">
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">âˆ§</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">{ }^{\wedge}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7519em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7519em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">âˆ§</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> Proliferation of T-cells and differentiation into 4 main types J</p>
<p>Regulatory T-cells</p>
<p>Turn off the immune response once the threat has been dealt with</p>
<p>Helper T-cells</p>
<p>Release cytokines to support cytotoxic Tlymphocytes and B-lymphocytes</p>
<p>Memory T-cells</p>
<p>Long-lived and provide immunity to the antigen
! Cytotoxic T-cells</p>
<p>Bind to antigen and destroy it</p>
<p>Figure 15.3 Clonal expansion of T-cells.
so close together. The main role of cytotoxic T-cells is in destruction of abnormal body cells, e.g. infected cells and cancer cells.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="helper-t-cells">Helper T-cells<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#helper-t-cells" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These are essential not only for cell-mediated immunity but also for antibodymediated immunity. Their central role in immunity is emphasised in situations where they are destroyed, as by the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV). When helper T-cell numbers fall significantly, the whole immune system is compromised. T-helpers are the most common of the T-cells and their main functions include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Production of chemicals called cytokines, e.g. interleukins and interferons, which support and promote cytotoxic T-cells and macrophages.</li>
<li>Cooperation with B-cells to produce antibodies; although B-cells are responsible for antibody manufacture, they need to be stimulated by a helper T-cell first.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="regulatory-t-cells">Regulatory T-cells<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#regulatory-t-cells" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These cells act as 'brakes', turning off activated T- and B-cells. This limits the powerful and potentially damaging effects of the immune response. Regulatory Tcells are involved in immunological tolerance; they help prevent the development of autoimmunity (p. 417) and protect the fetus in pregnancy.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="memory-t-cells">Memory T-cells<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#memory-t-cells" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These long-lived cells survive after the threat has been neutralised, and provide cell-mediated immunity by responding rapidly to another encounter with the same antigen.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="99876b8f">Antibody-mediated (humorai) immunity <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">â–¡</mi><mn>15.4</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\square 15.4</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.675em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">â–¡</span><span class="mord">15.4</span></span></span></span></span><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#99876b8f" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>B-cells are much less mobile than T-cells and spend much of their time in lymphoid tissue, e.g. the spleen and lymph nodes. Unlike T-cells, B-cells recognise and bind antigen particles directly, without having to be presented with them by an</p>
<p>antigen-presenting cell. B-cells make antibodies. Some of these antibodies are released into the bloodstream for distribution around the body but each B-cell also displays the antibody that it makes on its cell membrane. These bound antibodies act as antigen receptors. Once its antigen has been detected and bound, and with the help of an activated helper T-cell, the B-cell enlarges and begins to divide (clonal expansion. Fig. 15.4). It produces two functionally distinct types of cell, plasma cells and memory B-cells.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="plasma-cells">Plasma cells<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#plasma-cells" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Plasma cells secrete massive quantities of antibodies (immunoglobulins, Igs) into the blood. Antibodies distribute
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-17402c7e.jpeg" alt="img-128.jpeg"></p>
<p>Sensitised T- and B-cell B-cell in
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-a14df766.jpeg" alt="img-129.jpeg"></p>
<p>Memory B-cells</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1">(1)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Long-lived and provide immunity to the antigen</p>
<p>1
Plasma cells *]</p>
<p>Antibodies <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mspace width="2em"></mspace></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\qquad</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0em;"></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 2em;"></span></span></span></span></span> Produce and release antibodies</p>
<p>Table captionFigure 15.4 Clonal expansion of B-cells.
throughout the tissues and into body fluids. They comprise about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>20</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">20 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">20%</span></span></span></span></span> of plasma proteins. Plasma cells live no longer than a day and produce millions of molecules of only one type of antibody, which targets the specific antigen that originally activated the B-cell.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="antibodies">Antibodies<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#antibodies" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Antibodies:</p>
<ul>
<li>bind to antigens, labelling them as targets for other defence cells such as cytotoxic T-cells and macrophages</li>
<li>bind to bacterial toxins, neutralising them</li>
<li>activate complement (p. 409). U15.5</li>
</ul>
<p>There are five main types of antibody, summarised in Table 15.2. QIS-G</p>
