<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="memory-b-cells">Memory B-cells<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#memory-b-cells" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Like memory T-cells, these cells remain in the body long after the initial episode has been dealt with, and rapidly</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="acquired-immunity">Acquired immunity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#acquired-immunity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The immune response to an antigen following the first exposure (primary immunisation) is called the primary
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-2b6c7f8a.jpeg" alt="img-132.jpeg">
exposure exposure
Figure 15.6 The primary and secondary immune responses. Ig, immunoglobulin.
response. Second and subsequent exposures give rise to a secondary response (Fig. 15.6).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-primary-response">The primary response<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-primary-response" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Exposure of the immune system to an antigen for the first time leads to a slow and delayed rise in antibody levels, peaking 1-2 weeks after infection. The antibody produced is mainly IgM. This delayed response reflects the time required to activate the T-cell system, which then stimulates B-cell division. Antibody levels start to fall once the infection is cleared, but if the immune system has responded well, it will have generated a population of long-lived memory B-cells, making the individual immune to future infection.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-secondary-response">The secondary response<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-secondary-response" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>On subsequent exposures to the same antigen, the immune response is much faster and 10-15 times more powerful because the memory B-cells generated after the first infection rapidly divide and antibody production begins almost immediately. Antibody produced is mainly IgG, which is more effective than IgM, and is characteristic of a secondary rather than a primary immune response.</p>
<p>Immunity may be acquired naturally or artificially and both forms may be active or passive (Fig. 15.7). Active immunity means that the individual has responded to an antigen and produced their own antibodies, lymphocytes are activated and the memory cells formed provide long-lasting resistance. In passive immunity the</p>
<p>individual is given antibodies produced by someone else. The antibodies break down with time, so passive immunity is relatively brief.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="active-naturally-acquired-immunity">Active naturally acquired immunity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#active-naturally-acquired-immunity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The body may be stimulated to produce its own antibodies by either having the disease or having a subclinical infection.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="having-the-disease">Having the disease<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#having-the-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>During the course of the illness, B-cells develop into plasma cells, which produce antibodies in sufficient quantities to
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>âˆ§</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\wedge</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5556em;"></span><span class="mord">âˆ§</span></span></span></span></span> Acquired immunity" "^
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-0ba07c61.jpeg" alt="img-133.jpeg"></p>
<p>Natural
TTT^
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">â–¡</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\square</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.675em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">â–¡</span></span></span></span></span>
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>âˆ§</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\wedge</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5556em;"></span><span class="mord">âˆ§</span></span></span></span></span> Natural <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>âˆ§</mo><mo>âˆ§</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\wedge \wedge</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5556em;"></span><span class="mord">âˆ§</span><span class="mord">âˆ§</span></span></span></span></span> Artificial</p>
<p>Clinical disease, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">\</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\backslash</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">\</span></span></span></span></span> accine,
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>âˆ§</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\wedge</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5556em;"></span><span class="mord">âˆ§</span></span></span></span></span> From 1 r Immunoglobulins mother <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">âˆ¥</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\|</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">âˆ¥</span></span></span></span></span> (serum with antibodies)
, subclinical infection , toxoid <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>âˆ§</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\wedge</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5556em;"></span><span class="mord">âˆ§</span></span></span></span></span></p>
<p>Figure 15.7 Summary of the types of acquired immunity.</p>
<p>Box 15.1 Diseases preventable by vaccination</p>
<p>Anthrax</p>
<p>Cholera</p>
<p>Diphtheria</p>
<p>Hepatitis B</p>
<p>Measles</p>
<p>Mumps</p>
<p>Poliomyelitis</p>
<p>Rubella</p>
<p>Smallpox</p>
<p>Tetanus</p>
<p>Tuberculosis</p>
<p>Typhoid</p>
<p>Whooping cough</p>
<p>overcome the infection. After recovery, the memory B-cells produced confer immunity to future infection by the same antigen.</p>
<p>Having a subciinicai infection</p>
<p>Sometimes the infection is not sufficiently severe to cause clinical disease but stimulates sufficient memory B-cells to establish immunity, e.g. to hepatitis A (p. 362). In other cases, subclinical infection may be too mild to stimulate an adequate response and for immunity to develop.</p>
<p>Active artificially acquired immunity</p>
<p>This type of immunity develops in response to the administration of dead or live artificially weakened pathogens (vaccines) or deactivated toxins (toxoids). The vaccines and toxoids retain the antigenic properties that stimulate the development</p>
<p>of immunity but they cannot cause the disease. Many infectious diseases can be prevented by artificial immunisation. Examples are shown in Box 15.1.</p>
<p>Active immunisation against some infectious disorders gives lifelong immunity, e.g. diphtheria, whooping
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-16943c65.jpeg" alt="img-134.jpeg">
cough or mumps. In other infections the immunity may last for a number of years or for only a few weeks before revaccination is necessary. Apparent loss of immunity may be due to infection with a different strain of the same pathogen, which has different antigenic properties but causes the same clinical illness, e.g. viruses that cause the common cold and influenza. In older or poorly nourished individuals, production of lymphocytes, especially B-cells, is reduced and the primary and secondary response may be inadequate.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="passive-naturally-acquired-immunity">Passive naturally acquired immunity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#passive-naturally-acquired-immunity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This type of immunity is acquired before birth by the passage of maternal antibodies across the placenta to the fetus, and to the baby in breast milk. The range of antibodies provided depends on the mother's active immunity, i.e. the mother will produce antibodies to infections that she has been exposed to, which in turn protect her baby as well. The baby's lymphocytes are not stimulated and this form of immunity is short-lived.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="passive-artificially-acquired-immunity">Passive artificially acquired immunity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#passive-artificially-acquired-immunity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In this type of immunity, ready-made antibodies, in human or animal serum, are injected into the recipient. The source of the antibodies may be an individual who has recovered from the infection or an animal, commonly a horse, that has been artificially actively immunised. A specific immunoglobulin (antiserum) may be administered prophylactically to prevent the development of disease in people who have been exposed to the infection, e.g. rabies, or therapeutically after the disease has developed.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="summary-of-the-immune-response-to-a-bacterial-infection">Summary of the immune response to a bacterial infection<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#summary-of-the-immune-response-to-a-bacterial-infection" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Fig. 15.8 shows the main events that make up the body's integrated response to infection. Initially, non-specific defence cells (neutrophils, natural killer cells and macrophages) accumulate at the site of infection and attempt to limit bacterial expansion. If the threat is strong enough and many macrophages are involved, arriving T-cells are activated, producing populations of cytotoxic and helper Tcells, which in turn activate B-cells. As B-cells
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-42a4e921.jpeg" alt="img-135.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 15.8 Summary of the defensive response to bacterial infection.
proliferate and differentiate into plasma cells, antibody levels progressively rise.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="i-spot-check">I # SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol start="3">
<li>What is meant by the term 'immunological specificity'?</li>
<li>Outline the role of regulatory and cytotoxic T-cells in immunity.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ageing-and-immunity">Ageing and immunity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ageing-and-immunity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Learning outcome
After studying this section, you should be able to: <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>â‹…</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\cdot</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4445em;"></span><span class="mord">â‹…</span></span></span></span></span> describe the effects of ageing on immunity.</p>
<p>Immunity declines with advancing age, increasing the risk of infection in older adults and lengthening recovery times. The thymus gland progressively shrinks from its maximum size at puberty and may be only a quarter of that by age 50 . This is linked to decreased T-cell responsiveness, and as the B-cell response is dependent on T-cell function, antibody levels also fall with age. Levels of autoantibodies and incidence of autoimmunity increase in later life, and reduced function of natural killer cells is associated with increasing incidence of most types of cancer.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="learning-outcome">Learning outcome<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#learning-outcome" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="abnormal-immune-function">Abnormal immune function<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#abnormal-immune-function" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Learning outcomes</p>
<p>After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe, with examples, the four types of allergic response</li>
<li>outline the basis of autoimmune disease</li>
<li>discuss specific examples of autoimmune disease</li>
<li>list the cause and effects of acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="a0d50d60">Hypersensitivity (allergy) <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">â–¡</mi><mn>15.7</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\square 15.7</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.675em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">â–¡</span><span class="mord">15.7</span></span></span></span></span><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a0d50d60" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Allergy is an inappropriate, powerful immune response to an antigen (allergen) that is usually harmless. Examples include house dust, animal dander and grass pollen. It is therefore usually the immune response that causes the damage to the body, not the allergen itself. On initial exposure to the allergen the individual becomes sensitised to it, and on second and subsequent exposures the immune system mounts a response entirely out of proportion to the perceived threat. It is important to note that these responses are exaggerated versions of normal immune function (secondary response, see Fig. 15.6). Sometimes symptoms are mild, although annoying, e.g. the running nose and streaming eyes of hay fever. Occasionally, the reaction can be extreme, overwhelming body systems and causing death, e.g. anaphylactic shock, described later.</p>
<p>There are four mechanisms of hypersensitivity, which are classified according to the parts of the immune system that are involved. They are summarised in Fig. 15.9 .</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="type-i-anaphylactic-hypersensitivity">Type I, anaphylactic hypersensitivity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#type-i-anaphylactic-hypersensitivity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Type I is usually called allergy, and happens very quickly when a sensitised individual is exposed to an allergen, such as house dust, animal fur, pollen, bee stings and so on. There is a strong hereditable factor in allergy, and a tendency to have higher than normal levels of IgE (atopy). The allergen binds to mast cells and basophils, which degranulate and release large amounts of histamine. Histamine contracts some smooth muscle, e.g. airway smooth muscle, causes vasodilation and increases vascular permeability (leading to movement of fluid and proteins into the tissues from the bloodstream). Examples of type I reactions include the serious situation of anaphylaxis. There is profound bronchoconstriction and shock (p. 122) due to extensive vasodilation. The condition can lead to death.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="type-ii-antibody-mediated-hypersensitivity">Type II, antibody-mediated hypersensitivity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#type-ii-antibody-mediated-hypersensitivity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>When an antibody reacts with an antigen on a cell surface, that cell is marked for destruction by the body's defence</p>
<p>cells. This is the usual procedure in the elimination of, for example, bacteria, but if the antibodies are directed against self-antigens the result is destruction of the body's own tissues (autoimmune disease). Type II mechanisms cause other conditions, e.g. haemolytic disease of the newborn (p. 75) and transfusion reactions (p. 76).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="type-iii-immune-complex-mediated-hypersensitivity">Type III, immune complex-mediated hypersensitivity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#type-iii-immune-complex-mediated-hypersensitivity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Antibody-antigen complexes (immune complexes) are usually cleared efficiently from the blood by phagocytosis. If they are not, e.g. when there is phagocyte failure or an excessive production of immune complexes (as in chronic infections), they can be deposited in tissues such as the kidneys, skin, joints and eye, where they set up an inflammatory reaction. The kidney is a common site of deposition because it receives a large proportion of the cardiac output and filters the blood. Immune complexes collecting here lodge in and block the glomerular capillaries, impairing kidney function (glomerulonephritis). Penicillin allergy is also a type III reaction: antibodies bind to penicillin (the antigen), and the symptoms are the result of deposition of immune complexes in tissues - rashes, joint pains and sometimes haematuria.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="type-iv-delayed-type-cell-mediated-hypersensitivity">Type IV, delayed type (cell-mediated) hypersensitivity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#type-iv-delayed-type-cell-mediated-hypersensitivity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Unlike types I-III, type IV hypersensitivity does not involve antibodies but is an over-reaction of T-cells to an antigen. When an antigen is detected by memory Tcells, it provokes clonal expansion of the T-cell (see Fig. 15.3), and large numbers of cytotoxic T-cells are released to eliminate the antigen. Usually, this system is controlled and the T-cell response is appropriate. If not, the actively aggressive cytotoxic T-cells trigger chronic and prolonged inflammation, which damages normal tissues.</p>
<p>An example of this is contact dermatitis (p. 403). Graft and transplant rejection is also caused by T-cells; an incompatible skin graft, for instance, will become necrotic and slough off in the days following application of the graft.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="autoimmune-disease">Autoimmune disease<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#autoimmune-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Normally, an immune response is mounted only against foreign (non-self) antigens, but occasionally the body fails to recognise its own tissues and attacks itself. Autoimmune diseases have a strong genetic component and tend to be chronic and progressive in nature. They can involve self-directed antibodies (type II) or misdirected T-cells (type IV), and some disorders, e.g. diabetes mellitus (p. 255), may have both components. The resulting autoimmune disorders include a number of relatively common conditions (Table 15.3).</p>
<p>f Type 3C Characteristics ^</p>
<p>I
Anaphylactic
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-7f2ed8a8.jpeg" alt="img-136.jpeg"></p>
<p>Basophils
Mast cells
Binding of antigen
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-e3a838e0.jpeg" alt="img-137.jpeg"></p>
<p>Degranulation, leading to large amounts of inflamnnatory mediators, e.g. histamine, being released</p>
<p>Onset immediate
Examples include hay fever, eczema, anaphylaxis and food allergy, e.g. to peanuts
II
Antibody
mediated</p>
<p>Binding of antibody</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-22f02a57.jpeg" alt="img-138.jpeg"></p>
<p>Cell expressing Antibodies foreign antigen
Cell expressing foreign antigen is now a target for phagocytes
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-ae486707.jpeg" alt="img-139.jpeg"></p>
<p>Onset immediate
Examples include autoimmunity (e.g. rheumatoid arthritis), haemolytic disease of the newborn and transfusion reactions</p>
<p>III
Immune
complex
mediated
L
^^ntibody 'V. Deposition of excess immune complexes in e.g. kidneys, joints and skin
J. <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>â‹…</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\cdot</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4445em;"></span><span class="mord">â‹…</span></span></span></span></span> . 1
H
1 r</p>
<p>Antigen Formation of immune complexes</p>
<p>Onset in 4-8 hours</p>
<p>Examples include most cases of glomerulonephritis and penicillin allergy
IV
Delayed
(cell-mediated)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-530777d9.jpeg" alt="img-140.jpeg"></p>
<p>Onset in 24-48 hours
Examples include autoimmunity, graft rejection and contact dermatitis, e.g. nickel allergy</p>
<p>Figure 15.9 The four types of hypersensitivity.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="immunodeficiency">Immunodeficiency<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#immunodeficiency" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>When the immune system is compromised, there is a tendency to recurrent infections, often by microbes not normally pathogenic in humans (opportunistic infections). Immunodeficiency is classified as primary, usually arising in infancy and genetically mediated, or secondary, acquired in later life as the result of another disease, e.g. cancers and
cancer treatments, protein deficiency, acute infection, chronic renal failure, bone marrow diseases and acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS), or following splenectomy.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="acquired-immune-deficiency-syndrome">Acquired immune deficiency syndrome<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#acquired-immune-deficiency-syndrome" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This condition is caused by the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), an RNA retrovirus that produces the enzyme reverse transcriptase inside the cells of the infected person</p>
<p>Table 15.3 Important autoimmune disorders</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Condition</th><th>Autoantibodies/autoreactive T-cells made against</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Rheumatoid arthritis (p. 470)</td><td>Synovial membrane of joints</td></tr><tr><td>Autoimmune thyroiditis (Hashimotoâ€™s disease) (p. 251)</td><td>Thyroglobulin</td></tr><tr><td>Gravesâ€™ disease (p. 250)</td><td>Thyroid stimulating hormone receptors on thyroid cells</td></tr><tr><td>Myasthenia gravis (p. 472)</td><td>Acetylcholine receptors of skeletal muscle</td></tr><tr><td>Glomerulonephritis (p. 383)</td><td>Glomerular membrane</td></tr><tr><td>Type 1 diabetes (p. 256)</td><td>(3-cells of the pancreas</td></tr><tr><td>(host cells). This enzyme transforms viral RNA to DNA and this new DNA, called the provirus, is incorporated into the host cell DNA. The host cell then produces new copies of the virus that infect other host cells. When infected host cells divide, copies of the provirus are integrated into the DNA of daughter cells, spreading the disease within the body. HIV infection particularly affects the immune and nervous systems, reflected in the clinical signs and symptoms. The virus has an affinity for cells that have a protein receptor called CD 4 in their membrane, including T-cells, monocytes, macrophages, some B-cells and, possibly, cells in the gastrointestinal tract and neuroglial cells in the brain. CD4 helper T-cells (see Fig. 15.3) are the main cells involved. HIV establishes itself within the body's CD4 cell populations and gradually destroys them, while at the same time it is protected from other body defence mechanisms. CD4 cells are central to the body's immune system, and so both antibody-mediated immunity and cell-mediated immunity are progressively impaired, with the consequent development of widespread opportunistic infections, often by microbes of relatively low pathogenicity, and cancers. HIV has been isolated from semen, cervical secretions, lymphocytes, plasma, cerebrospinal fluid, tears, saliva, urine and breast milk. The secretions known to be especially infectious are semen, cervical secretions, blood and blood products.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Infection is spread by:</p>
<ul>
<li>sexual intercourse, vaginal and anal</li>
<li>contaminated needles:</li>
<li>during treatment of patients</li>
<li>when drug users share needles</li>
<li>an infected mother to her child:</li>
<li>across the placenta before birth (vertical transmission)</li>
<li>during childbirth</li>
<li>in breast milk.</li>
</ul>
<p>Stages of HIV infection
A few weeks after initial infection there may be an acute influenza-like illness with no specific features, followed by a period of 2 or more years without symptoms.</p>
<p>Chronic HIV infection may cause persistent generalised lymphadenopathy (Ch. 6). Some patients may then develop AIDS-related complex and experience chronic low-grade fever, diarrhoea, weight loss, anaemia and leukopenia (Ch.4).</p>
<p>AIDS is the most advanced stage of HIV infection, associated with a low CD4 count and the presence of one or more characteristic infections, tumours or presentations:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>pneumonia, commonly caused by Pneumocystis jirovecii although many other microbes may be involved</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>persistent nausea, diarrhoea and weight loss due to recurrent infections of the alimentary tract by a wide variety of microbes</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>meningitis, encephalitis and brain abscesses, which may be recurrent and are caused either by opportunistic microbes or possibly by HIV</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>deteriorating neurological function, characterised by forgetfulness, loss of concentration, confusion, apathy, dementia, limb weakness, ataxia and incontinence</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>skin conditions, often extensive, e.g. eczema, psoriasis, cellulitis, impetigo, warts, shingles and cold sores (Ch. 14)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>generalised lymphadenopathy (see Table 6.1)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>development of malignant tumours, which is not uncommon because of the progressive failure of immunological surveillance as the virus destroys the T-cell population. Typical cancers include:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>lymphoma (p. 150)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Kaposi's sarcoma, manifesting as tumours under the skin and in internal organs (p. 405).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>SPOT CHECK</p>
</li>
</ul>
<ol start="5">
<li>What are the main differences between type I and type IV hypersensitivity?</li>
<li>Why are those with HIV prone to opportunistic infections?</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="review-and-revise">Review and revise<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#review-and-revise" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
