<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="chapter">CHAPTER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chapter" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-musculoskeletal-system">The musculoskeletal system<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-musculoskeletal-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bone">Bone<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bone" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>state the functions of bones</li>
<li>list five types of bone and give an example of each</li>
<li>outline the general structure of a long bone</li>
<li>describe the structure of compact and spongy bone tissue</li>
<li>describe the development of bone</li>
<li>explain the process of bone healing and the factors that complicate it</li>
<li>outline the factors that determine bone growth.</li>
</ul>
<p>Although bones are often thought to be static or permanent, they are highly vascular living structures that are continuously being remodelled.</p>
<p>Functions of bones
The functions of bones include:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>providing the body framework</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>giving attachment to muscles and tendons</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>allowing movement of the body as a whole and of parts of the body, by forming joints that are moved by muscles</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>forming the boundaries of the cranium, thorax and pelvis, and protecting the organs they contain</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>haemopoiesis, the production of blood cells in red bone marrow (see Fig. 4.3)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>mineral storage, especially calcium phosphate the mineral reservoir within bone is essential for maintenance of blood calcium levels, which must be tightly controlled.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="types-of-bone">Types of bone<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-bone" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Bones are classified by shape as long, short, irregular, flat and sesamoid (Fig. 16.1).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="long-bones">Long bones<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#long-bones" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These consist of a shaft and two extremities. As the name suggests, these bones are longer than they are wide. Most long bones are found in the limbs; examples include the femur, tibia and fibula.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="short-irregular-flat-and-sesamoid-bones">Short, irregular, flat and sesamoid bones<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#short-irregular-flat-and-sesamoid-bones" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These have no shafts or extremities and are diverse in shape
and size. Examples include:
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>422</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">âˆ§</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">422^{\wedge}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7519em;"></span><span class="mord">42</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">2</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7519em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">âˆ§</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-547517f8.jpeg" alt="img-141.jpeg"></p>
<p>Sesamoid: patella
Irregular: vertebrae</p>
<p>Flat: sternum
Fig. 16.1 Types of bone.</p>
<ul>
<li>short bones - carpals (wrist), metacarpals (ankle)</li>
<li>irregular bones - vertebrae and some skull bones</li>
<li>flat bones - sternum, ribs and most skull bones</li>
<li>sesamoid (shaped like a sesame seed) bones - patella (knee cap).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="bone-structure">Bone structure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bone-structure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="long-bones">Long bones<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#long-bones" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These have a diaphysis (shaft) and two epiphyses (extremities) (Fig. 16.2). The diaphysis is composed mainly of compact bone, with a central medullary canal containing fatty yellow bone marrow. The epiphyses consist of an outer covering of compact bone with spongy (cancellous) bone inside. The diaphysis and epiphyses are separated by epiphyseal cartilages, which ossify when growth is complete.</p>
<p>Long bones are almost completely covered by a vascular membrane, the periosteum, which has two layers. The outer layer is tough and fibrous, and protects the bone underneath. The inner layer contains osteoblasts and osteoclasts, the cells responsible for bone production and breakdown (see later), and is important in repair and remodelling of the bone. The periosteum covers the whole bone except within joint cavities, allows attachments of tendons and is continuous with the joint capsule. Hyaline cartilage replaces periosteum on bone surfaces that form joints.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-cc73c130.jpeg" alt="img-142.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 16.2 A mature long bone, partially sectioned.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-b8592385.jpeg" alt="img-143.jpeg"></p>
<p>Flat bone, Irregular bone,
e.g. skull e.g. vertebral bone</p>
<p>Fig. 16.3 Sections of flat and irregular bones.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="microscopic-structure-of-bone">Microscopic structure of bone<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#microscopic-structure-of-bone" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Bone is a strong and durable type of connective tissue. Its major constituent (65%) is a mixture of calcium salts, mainly calcium phosphate. This inorganic matrix gives bone great hardness but on its own would be brittle and prone to shattering. The remaining third is organic material, called osteoid, which is composed mainly of collagen fibres. Collagen is very strong and gives bone slight flexibility. It is used as the framework for building the calcium-rich inorganic matrix. The cellular component of bone contributes less than <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">2%</span></span></span></span></span> of bone mass.</p>
<p>Bone cells</p>
<p>There are three types of bone cell:</p>
<ul>
<li>osteoblasts, bone-building cells</li>
<li>osteocytes, mature bone cells</li>
<li>osteoclasts, bone-reabsorbing cells.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="osteoblasts">Osteoblasts<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#osteoblasts" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These bone-forming cells deposit both inorganic salts and osteoid in bone tissue. They are therefore present at sites where bone is growing, repairing or remodelling, e.g.:</p>
<ul>
<li>in the deeper layers of periosteum</li>
<li>in the centres of ossification of immature bone</li>
<li>at the ends of the diaphysis, adjacent to the epiphyseal cartilages of long bones</li>
<li>at the site of a fracture.</li>
</ul>
<p>As they deposit new bone tissue around themselves, they eventually become trapped in tiny pockets called lacunae (Fig. 16.4) in the growing bone, and differentiate into osteocytes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="osteocytes">Osteocytes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#osteocytes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These mature bone cells do not divide. They monitor and maintain bone tissue, and are nourished by tissue fluid in the canaliculi that radiate from the central canals (Fig. 16.5).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="blood-and-nerve-supply">Blood and nerve supply<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blood-and-nerve-supply" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>One or more nutrient arteries supply the bone shaft; the epiphyses have their own blood supply, although in the mature bone the capillary networks arising from the two are heavily interconnected. The sensory nerve supply usually enters the bone at the same site as the nutrient artery, and branches extensively throughout the bone. Bone injury is, therefore, usually very painful.</p>
<p>Short, irregular, flat and sesamoid bones
These have a relatively thin outer layer of compact bone, with spongy bone inside containing red bone marrow (Fig. 16.3). They are enclosed by periosteum except for the inner layer of the cranial bones, where it is replaced by dura mater.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="osteoclasts">Osteoclasts<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#osteoclasts" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These cells break down bone, releasing calcium and phosphate. They are giant cells with up to 50 nuclei, which have formed from the fusion of many monocytes (p. 69). The continuous remodelling of healthy bone tissue is the result of balanced activity of the bone's osteoblast and osteoclast populations. Like osteoblasts, osteoclasts are found in areas of the bone where there is active growth, repair or remodelling, e.g.:</p>
<ul>
<li>under the periosteum, maintaining bone shape during growth and removing excess callus formed during healing of fractures (Fig. 16.9)</li>
<li>round the walls of the medullary canal during growth and canalising callus during healing.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-56317b3f.jpeg" alt="img-144.jpeg"></p>
<p>Lamella
Central (Haversian) canal containing blood vessels and nerve
Osteon
(Haversian system)
Perforating canal
Lacuna containing osteocyte
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span></span></span></span></span> Canaliculi
Fig. 16.4 Microscopic structure of compact bone.
Compact (cortical) bone
Compact bone makes up about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>80</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">80 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">80%</span></span></span></span></span> of the body bone mass. It is made up of a large number of parallel tube-shaped units called osteons (Haversian systems), each of which is made up of a central canal surrounded by a series of expanding rings, similar to the growth rings of a tree (see Fig. 16.4). Osteons tend to be aligned the same way that force is applied to the bone; for example, in the femur (thigh bone), they run from one epiphysis to the other. This gives the bone great strength.</p>
<p>The central canal contains nerves, lymphatics and blood vessels, and each central canal is linked with neighbouring canals by tunnels running at right angles between them, called perforating canals. The series of cylindrical plates of bone arranged around each central canal are called lamellae. Between the adjacent lamellae of the</p>
<p>osteon are strings of little cavities called lacunae, in each of which sits an osteocyte. Lacunae communicate with each other through a
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-b55b571f.jpeg" alt="img-145.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 16.5 Light micrograph of osteocytes. The multiple fine processes are shown that extend through bone oanaliouli and allow eaoh oell to oommunicate directly with its neighbours. (Jean-Claude Revy, ISM/Science Photo Library. Reproduced with permission.)
network of tiny channels called canaliculi, which allows the circulation of interstitial fluid through the bone, and direct contact between the osteocytes, which extend fine processes into them (Fig. 16.5).</p>
<p>Between the osteons are interstitial lamellae, the remnants of older systems partially broken down during remodelling or growth of bone.</p>
<p>Spongy (cancellous, trabecular) bone
About <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>20</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">20 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">20%</span></span></span></span></span> of skeletal bone mass is spongy bone. To the naked eye, spongy bone looks like a honeycomb (Fig. 16.6A). This honeycomb arrangement has two main functions. The spaces contain red bone marrow, which produces blood cells; this means that spongy bone is much lighter than compact bone, reducing the weight of the skeleton. Microscopic examination reveals a bony framework formed from trabeculae (meaning Tittle beams') (Fig. 16.6B). Like compact bone, the bone tissue is organised into osteons, with osteocytes living in lacunae and communicating with each other via canaliculi. The bone tissue here is not dense like compact bone, and so individual osteocytes are never very far away from an internal bone surface; the osteocytes are nourished by diffusion through the canaliculi and there is no need for a central canal in the middle of the osteon. The branching framework of pillars and plates in spongy bone is not arranged randomly. Rather, the bony honeycomb develops maximum strength along the directions from which maximum stress comes, so that even though it is not solid bone, it can absorb its share of applied force.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="development-of-bone-tissue-d-16-1">Development of bone tissue D 16.1<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#development-of-bone-tissue-d-16-1" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Also called osteogenesis or ossification, this begins before birth and is not complete until about the 21 st year of life.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-f7cb25ff.jpeg" alt="img-146.jpeg"></p>
<p>Trabeculae
Red bone marrow
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-f3cfce20.jpeg" alt="img-147.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 16.6 Spongy bone. (A) Electron micrograph of spongy bone showing bone marrow (orange) filling the spaces between trabeculae (grey/blue). (B) Microscopic structure of spongy bone. (A, Prof. P Motta/Dept of Anatomy, University 'La Sapienza', Rome/Science Photo Library. Reproduced with permission.)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-2f1025b9.jpeg" alt="img-148.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-0739bf17.jpeg" alt="img-149.jpeg"></p>
<p>Birth
Epiphyseal
Periosteum
Epiphyseal
line</p>
<p>Childhood and adolescence
Secondary centres of ossification in epiphyses
Compact bone
Medullary
canal
Medullary canal
Adult
Long, short and irregular bones develop in the fetus from rods of cartilage, called cartilage models. Flat bones develop from membrane models and sesamoid bones from tendon models.</p>
<p>During ossification, osteoblasts secrete osteoid, which gradually replaces the initial cartilage model; then the osteoblasts lay down calcium and phosphate salts through the osteoid, progressively calcifying it and converting it to the hard, rigid structure of mature bone. As the bone grows, the osteoblasts become trapped in the matrix of their own making and become osteocytes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="development-of-long-bones">Development of long bones<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#development-of-long-bones" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>In long bones the focal points from which ossification begins are small areas of osteogenic cells, or centres of</p>
<p>Fig. 16.7 The stages of development of a long bone.
ossification in the cartilage model (Fig. 16.7). Ossification is accompanied by development of a bone collar at about 8 weeks of gestation. Later the blood supply develops and bone tissue replaces cartilage as osteoblasts secrete osteoid in the shaft. The bone lengthens as ossification continues and spreads to the epiphyses. Around birth, secondary centres of ossification develop in the epiphyses, and the medullary canal forms when osteoclasts break down the central bone tissue in the middle of the shaft. During childhood, long bones continue to lengthen because the epiphyseal plate at each end of the bone, which is made of cartilage, continues to produce new cartilage on its diaphyseal surface (the surface facing the shaft of the bone. Fig. 16.8). This cartilage</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-411c251f.jpeg" alt="img-150.jpeg"></p>
<p>Area of new Spongy Bone end with
bone deposition bone hyaline cartilage
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-ba4432e5.jpeg" alt="img-151.jpeg"></p>
<p>Growing epiphyseal plate <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">âˆ§</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">{ }^{\wedge}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7519em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7519em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">âˆ§</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> Direction of
bone growth
Fig. 16.8 Light micrograph of the end of a growing bone, showing the epiphyseal plate. (Innerspace Imaging/Science Photo Library. Reproduced with permission.)
is then turned to bone. As long as cartilage production matches the rate of ossification, the bone continues to lengthen. At puberty, under the influence of sex hormones, the epiphyseal plate growth slows down and is overtaken by bone deposition. Once the whole epiphyseal plate is turned to bone, no further lengthening of the bone is possible.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="hormonal-regulation-of-bone-growth">Hormonal regulation of bone growth<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hormonal-regulation-of-bone-growth" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Some of the hormones (Ch. 9) that regulate the growth, size and shape of bones are described here.</p>
<p>Growth hormone and the thyroid hormones thyroxine and tri-iodothyronine are especially important during infancy and childhood; deficient or excessive secretion of these results in abnormal development of the skeleton (pp. 249 and 251).</p>
<p>Testosterone and oestrogens influence the physical changes that occur at puberty and help maintain bone structure throughout life. Rising levels of these hormones are responsible for the growth spurt of puberty but later stimulate closure of the epiphyseal plates (Fig. 16.8), so that bone growth lengthways stops (although bones can grow in thickness throughout life). Average adult male height is usually greater</p>
<p>than female because male puberty tends to occur at a later age than female puberty, giving a male child's bones longer to keep growing. Oestrogens are responsible for the wider female pelvis that develops during puberty, and for maintaining bone mass in the adult female. A fall in oestrogen levels after menopause puts postmenopausal women at higher risk of osteoporosis (p. 468) and bone fracture.</p>
<p>Calcitonin and parathyroid hormone (p. 242) control blood levels of calcium by regulating its uptake into and
release from bone. Calcitonin increases calcium uptake into bone (reducing blood calcium), and parathyroid hormone decreases it (increasing blood calcium).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="exercise-and-bone">Exercise and bone<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#exercise-and-bone" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Although bone growth lengthways ceases permanently once the epiphyseal plates have ossified, thickening of bone is possible throughout life. This involves the laying down of new osteons at the periphery of the bone through the action of osteoblasts in the inner layer of the periosteum. Weight-bearing exercise stimulates thickening of bone, strengthening it and making it less liable to fracture. Lack of exercise reverses these changes, leading to lighter, weaker bones.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="diet-and-bone">Diet and bone<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diet-and-bone" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Healthy bone tissue requires adequate dietary calcium and vitamins A, C and D. Calcium, and smaller amounts of other minerals such as phosphate, iron and manganese, are essential for adequate mineralisation of bone. Vitamin A is needed for osteoblast activity. Vitamin C is used in collagen synthesis, and vitamin D is required for calcium and phosphate absorption from the intestinal tract.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bone-remodelling">Bone remodelling<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bone-remodelling" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Bone is subject to constant mechanical stresses that damage, crack and weaken it over time. To combat this, there is a constant turnover of bone tissue, mediated by osteoblast and osteoclast activity. On average, about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>10</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">10%</span></span></span></span></span> of bone is replaced each year, but the rate at which individual bones are remodelled varies. Bones subject to high stress are remodelled faster than others. The distal part of the femur, for example, is generally renewed every 3-6 months. The process is not a simple replacement but reflects adjustment of bone to the stresses to which it is exposed. For example, remodelling of lower limb bones in regular runners strengthens the bones along the lines of regularly applied stress.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bone-markings">Bone markings<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bone-markings" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Most bones have rough surfaces, raised protuberances and ridges that give attachment to muscle tendons and ligaments. These are not included in the descriptions of individual bones in later sections, unless they are of particular note,</p>
<p>but many are marked on illustrations. Bone markings and related terminology are defined in Table 16.1.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="40264e1a">Healing of bone <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">â–¡</mi><mn>16.2</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\square 16.2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.675em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">â–¡</span><span class="mord">16.2</span></span></span></span></span><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#40264e1a" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>There are a number of terms used to classify bone fractures, including:</p>
<ul>
<li>simple - the bone ends do not protrude through the skin</li>
<li>compound - the bone ends protrude through the skin</li>
<li>pathological - fracture of a bone weakened by disease.</li>
</ul>
<p>Table 16.1
Anatomical
terminology
related to bones</p>
<p>Term Meaning</p>
<p>Articulating The part of the bone that enters into the formation of a joint surface</p>
<p>Articulation A joint between two or more bones</p>
<p>Bony sinus A hollow cavity within a bone</p>
<p>Border A ridge of bone separating two surfaces</p>
<p>Condyle A smooth, rounded projection of bone that forms part of a joint</p>
<p>Facet A small, generally rather flat, articulating surface</p>
<p>Fissure or cleft A narrow slit</p>
<p>Foramen (plural: A hole in a structure
foramina)</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Fossa (plural:</th><th>A hollow or depression</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>fossae)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Meatus</td><td>A tube-shaped cavity within a bone</td></tr><tr><td>Septum</td><td>A partition separating two cavities</td></tr><tr><td>Spine, spinous</td><td>A sharp ridge of bone</td></tr><tr><td>process or crest</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Styloid process</td><td>A sharp downward projection of bone that gives attachment to muscles and ligaments</td></tr><tr><td>Suture</td><td>An immovable joint, e.g. between the bones of the skull</td></tr><tr><td>Trochanter,</td><td>Roughened bony projections, usually for attachment of muscles or ligaments. The different names are used according to the size of the projection. Trochanters are the largest and tubercles the smallest</td></tr><tr><td>tuberosity or</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>tubercle</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Following a fracture, the broken ends of bone are joined by the deposition of new bone. This occurs in several stages (Fig. 16.9): 1. A haematoma (collection of clotted blood) forms rapidly between the ends of bone and in surrounding soft tissues. The acute inflammatory response causes swelling and attracts inflammatory cells, including macrophages. This stage may be very painful, as the periosteum contains many sensory nerve endings. 2. The repair process begins as the haematoma is stabilised with large amounts of fibrin and becomes the framework for the formation of granulation tissue (p. 400). Fibroblasts migrate to the site to lay down collagen fibres and other repair materials. Osteoblasts begin laying down new osteoid and the bone ends are joined with these soft tissues. Macrophages phagocytose dead bone and other tissues, to clear the way for new bone, and new capillaries begin to grow into the granulation tissue, restoring blood supply.</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>After about 2 weeks, bony callus forms as osteoblasts begin to calcify the osteoid. Callus is laid down as spongy bone and unites, supports and splints the fracture.</li>
<li>A period of remodelling converts the external callus to compact bone and recanalises the bone. Assuming
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-b80e1a63.jpeg" alt="img-152.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Haematoma formation
Periosteum Compact bone Haematoma
Fragments of dead bone
Local inflammation
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-95f2b82b.jpeg" alt="img-153.jpeg"></p>
<p>Callus formation begins
Osteoblasts and fibroblasts lay down granulation tissue and osteoid
Dead bone and tissue fragments removed by macrophages
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-14301c23.jpeg" alt="img-154.jpeg"></p>
<p>Recanalisation and remodelling
Recanalisation of medullary cavity by osteoclasts
Replacement of spongy bone with new compact bone
Fig. 16.9 Stages in bone healing.
healing has proceeded normally, bone structure is back to normal, and the bone at the site of the original callus may even be slightly thicker than before. The whole process can take months, depending on the degree of damage.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="factors-that-delay-fracture-healing-tissue-fragments-between-bone-ends">Factors that delay fracture healing Tissue fragments between bone ends<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#factors-that-delay-fracture-healing-tissue-fragments-between-bone-ends" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Splinters of dead bone (sequestrae) and soft tissue fragments not removed by phagocytosis delay healing.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="deficient-blood-supply">Deficient blood supply<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#deficient-blood-supply" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Poor blood supply provides inadequate oxygen and other nutrients needed for healing. This impairs the activity of repair cells, including osteoblasts, which means that the cartilage laid down in the early stages of repair might not be converted to bone fast enough. This can ultimately lead to the healed tissue at the fracture site being too rich in inadequately calcified cartilage, resulting in a weaker repair called a cartilaginous union of the fracture. The most vulnerable sites, because of their normally poor blood supply, are the neck of femur, the scaphoid and the shaft of tibia.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="axial-skeleton">Axial skeleton<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#axial-skeleton" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>identify the bones of the skull (face and cranium)</li>
<li>list the functions of the sinuses and fontanelles of the skull</li>
<li>outline the characteristics of a typical vertebra</li>
<li>describe the structure of the vertebral column</li>
<li>explain the movements and functions of the vertebral column</li>
<li>identify the bones forming the thoracic cage.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="poor-alignment-of-bone-ends">Poor alignment of bone ends<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#poor-alignment-of-bone-ends" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The bone ends need to be very closely aligned for good healing to take place. If they are displaced, it may result in the formation of a large and irregular callus that heals slowly and often results in permanent deformity or disability.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="continued-mobility-of-bone-ends">Continued mobility of bone ends<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#continued-mobility-of-bone-ends" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Continuous movement disrupts normal granulation tissue formation and results in fibrosis of the granulation tissue, followed by fibrous union of the fracture.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="miscellaneous">Miscellaneous<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#miscellaneous" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These include infection (see next section), systemic illness, malnutrition, drugs such as corticosteroids and ageing.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="complications-of-fractures-infection">Complications of fractures Infection<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#complications-of-fractures-infection" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Pathogens enter through broken skin, although they may occasionally be bloodborne. Healing will not occur until the infection (osteomyelitis, p. 469) resolves.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fat-embolism">Fat embolism<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fat-embolism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Emboli consisting of fat from the bone marrow in the medullary canal may enter the circulation through torn veins. They are most likely to lodge in the lungs and block blood flow through the pulmonary capillaries.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-spot-check">I # SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Compare the living environment and functions of osteocytes and osteoblasts. :</li>
<li>In terms of closure of epiphyseal plates, why are I
males generally taller than females?
The bones of the skeleton are divided into two groups: the axial skeleton and the appendicular skeleton (Fig. 16.10).</li>
</ol>
<p>The axial skeleton consists of the skull, vertebral column, ribs and sternum. Together the bones forming these structures constitute the central bony core of the body, the axis. The appendicular skeleton consists of the shoulder and pelvic girdles and the limb bones.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="skull">Skull<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#skull" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The skull (Figs 16.11 and 16.12) rests on the upper end of the vertebral column and its bony structure is divided into two parts: the cranium and the face.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="sinuses">Sinuses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sinuses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Sinuses containing air are present in the sphenoid, ethmoid, maxillary and frontal bones. They all communicate with the nasal cavity and are lined with ciliated mucous membrane. They give resonance to the voice and reduce the weight of the skull, making it easier to carry.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cranium">Cranium<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cranium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The cranium is formed by a number of flat and irregular bones that protect the brain. It has a base on which the brain rests and a vault that surrounds and covers it. The periosteum lining the inner surface of the skull bones forms the outer layer of dura mater (p. 162). In the mature skull the joints (sutures) between the bones are immovable. The bones have numerous perforations (e.g. foramina, fissures) through which nerves, blood and lymph vessels pass. The bones of the cranium are:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-frontal-bone">1 frontal bone<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-frontal-bone" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>2 parietal bones 2 temporal bones 1 occipital bone 1 sphenoid bone 1 ethmoid bone.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-3eec9832.jpeg" alt="img-155.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-59d8d831.jpeg" alt="img-156.jpeg"></p>
<p>Cranium</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cranium">Cranium<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cranium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="frontal-bone">Frontal bone<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#frontal-bone" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is the bone of the forehead. It forms part of the orbital cavities (eye sockets) and the prominent ridges above the eyes, the supraorbital margins. Just above the supraorbital margins, within the bone, are two air-filled cavities or sinuses lined with ciliated mucous membrane, which open into the nasal cavity.</p>
<p>The coronal suture joins the frontal and parietal bones, and other sutures are formed with the sphenoid, zygomatic, lacrimal, nasal and ethmoid bones. The frontal bone originates in two parts, joined in the midline by the frontal suture (see Fig. 16.19C).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="parietal-bones">Parietal bones<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#parietal-bones" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These bones form the sides and roof of the skull. They articulate with each other at the sagittal suture (see Fig. 16.11B), with the frontal bone at the coronal suture, with the occipital bone at the lambdoidal suture and with the temporal bones at the squamous sutures. The inner surface is concave and is grooved to accommodate the brain and blood vessels.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="temporal-bones">Temporal bones<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#temporal-bones" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The temporal bones (Fig. 16.13) lie one on each side of the head and form sutures with the parietal, occipital, sphenoid and zygomatic bones. The squamous part is the thin fan-shaped area that articulates with the parietal bone. The zygomatic process articulates with the zygomatic bone to form the zygomatic arch (cheekbone).
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-e214c038.jpeg" alt="img-159.jpeg"></p>
<p>Squamous part
Zygomatic process
Site of temporomandibular joint
External acoustic (auditory) meatus
Mastoid part
Mastoid process
Styloid process
Fig. 16.13 The right temporal bone. Lateral view.
The mastoid part contains the mastoid process, a thickened region easily felt behind the ear. It contains a large number of very small air sinuses that communicate with the middle ear and are lined with squamous epithelium.</p>
<p>The petrous portion forms part of the base of the skull and contains the organs of hearing (the spiral organ) and balance (the semicircular canals).</p>
<p>The temporal bone articulates with the mandible at the temporomandibular joint, the only movable joint of the skull. Immediately behind this articulating surface is the external acoustic meatus (auditory canal), which passes inwards towards the petrous portion of the bone.</p>
<p>The styloid process projects from the lower process of the temporal bone, and supports the hyoid bone and muscles associated with the tongue and pharynx.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="occipital-bone">Occipital bone<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#occipital-bone" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The occipital bone (Fig. 16.14) forms the back of the head and part of the base of the skull. It forms sutures with the parietal, temporal and sphenoid bones. Its inner surface is deeply concave to accommodate the occipital lobes of the cerebrum and the cerebellum. The occiput (the lower back part of the skull) has two articular condyles that form condyloid joints (p. 447) with the first bone of the vertebral column, the atlas. This joint permits nodding movements of the head. Between the condyles is the foramen magnum (meaning Targe hole'), through which the spinal cord passes into the cranial cavity.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="sphenoid-bone">Sphenoid bone<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sphenoid-bone" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The sphenoid bone (Fig. 16.15) occupies the middle portion of the base of the skull and articulates with the occipital.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-99dcca87.jpeg" alt="img-160.jpeg"></p>

<p>Greater wing</p>
