Articulates /
with temporal bone / ,
/ Hypophyseal
Articulates fossa with occipital bone
Fig. 16.15 The sphenoid bone. Viewed from above.
temporal, parietal and frontal bones (see Fig. 16.12). It links the cranial and facial bones, and cross-braces the skull. On the superior surface in the middle of the bone is a little saddle-shaped depression, the hypophyseal fossa (sella turcica), in which the pituitary gland rests. The body of the
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-139ff95f.jpeg" alt="img-162.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 16.16 Lateral view of the right nasal cavity. Viewed from the left.
bone contains some fairly large air sinuses lined with ciliated mucous membrane with openings into the nasal cavity. The optic nerves pass through the optic foramina on their way to the brain.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="ethmoid-bone">Ethmoid bone<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ethmoid-bone" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The ethmoid bone (Fig. 16.16) occupies the anterior part of the base of the skull and helps to form the orbital cavity, the nasal septum and the lateral walls of the nasal cavity. On each side there are two projections into the nasal cavity: the superior and middle conchae or turbinated processes. The ethmoid is a very delicate bone containing many air sinuses lined with ciliated epithelium and with openings into the nasal cavity. The horizontal flattened part, the cribriform plate, forms the roof of the nasal cavity and has numerous small foramina, through which nerve fibres of the olfactory nerve (sense of smell) pass upwards from the nasal cavity to</p>
<p>the brain. There is also a very fine perpendicular plate of bone that forms the upper part of the nasal septum.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="face">Face<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#face" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The skeleton of the face is formed by 13 bones in addition to the frontal bone already described. They fit together like an intricate, three-dimensional jigsaw puzzle, forming the internal cavities of the face (e.g. the nasal and orbital cavities) and articulating with the bones of the cranium.</p>
<p>Fig. 16.17 shows the relationships between the bones:</p>
<ul>
<li>2 zygomatic (cheek) bones</li>
<li>1 maxilla</li>
<li>2 nasal bones</li>
<li>2 lacrimal bones</li>
<li>1 vomer</li>
<li>2 palatine bones</li>
<li>2 inferior conchae</li>
<li>1 mandible.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="zygomatic-cheek-bones">Zygomatic (cheek) bones<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#zygomatic-cheek-bones" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Each zygomatic bone originates as two bones that fuse before birth. It forms the prominences of the cheeks and part of the floor and lateral walls of the orbital cavities.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="maxilla-upper-jaw-bone">Maxilla (upper jaw bone)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#maxilla-upper-jaw-bone" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This originates as two bones that fuse before birth. The maxilla forms the upper jaw, the anterior part of the roof of the mouth, the lateral walls of the nasal cavity and part of the floor of the orbital cavities. The alveolar ridge, or process, projects downwards and carries the upper teeth. On each side is a large air sinus, the maxillary sinus. This is the largest sinus; it is lined with ciliated mucous membrane and has openings into the nasal cavity.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="nasal-bones">Nasal bones<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nasal-bones" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These two small flat bones form the greater part of the lateral and superior surfaces of the bridge of the nose.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="lacrimal-bones">Lacrimal bones<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lacrimal-bones" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These two small bones are posterior and lateral to the nasal bones and form part of the medial walls of the orbital cavities. Each is pierced by a foramen for the passage of the nasolacrimal duct, which carries the tears from the medial canthus of the eye to the nasal cavity.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vomer">Vomer<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vomer" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The vomer is a thin, flat bone that extends upwards from the middle of the hard palate to form most of the inferior part of the nasal septum. Superiorly, it articulates with the perpendicular plate of the ethmoid bone.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="palatine-bones">Palatine bones<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#palatine-bones" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These are two small, L-shaped bones. The horizontal parts unite to form the posterior part of the hard palate and the perpendicular parts project upwards to form part of the lateral walls of the nasal cavity. At their upper extremities they form part of the orbital cavities.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="inferior-conchae">Inferior conchae<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#inferior-conchae" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Each concha is a scroll-shaped bone, which forms part of the lateral wall of the nasal cavity and projects into it below the middle concha. The superior and middle conchae are parts
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-f80dce46.jpeg" alt="img-163.jpeg"></p>
<p>Parietal bone
I</p>
<p>Temporal bone "Nasal bone</p>
<p>Zygomatic bone
Inferior nasal concha
Vomer
Maxilla
Frontal bone Supra-orbital margin
Sphenoid bone Lacrimal bone
Ethmoid bone
Mandible
Fig. 16.17 The bones of the face. Anterior view.
of the ethmoid bone. The conchae collectively increase the surface area in the nasal cavity, allowing inspired air to be warmed and humidified more effectively.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="mandible-lower-jaw-bone">Mandible (lower jaw bone)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mandible-lower-jaw-bone" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is the lower jaw (Fig. 16.18), the only movable bone of the skull. It originates as two parts that unite at the midline. Each half consists of two main parts: a curved body with the alveolar ridge containing the lower teeth, and a ramus, which projects upwards almost at right angles to the posterior end of the body.</p>
<p>At the upper end the ramus divides into the condylar process, which articulates with the temporal bone to form the temporomandibular joint (see Fig. 16.13), and the coronoid process, which gives attachment to muscles and ligaments that close the jaw. The point where the ramus joins the body is the angle of the jaw.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hyoid-bone">Hyoid bone<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hyoid-bone" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is an isolated horseshoe-shaped bone lying in the soft tissues of the neck just above the larynx and below the mandible (see Fig. 10.4). It does not articulate with any other bone but is attached to the styloid process of the temporal bone by ligaments. It supports the larynx and gives attachment to the base of the tongue.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-3194563f.jpeg" alt="img-164.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 16.18 The left mandible. Lateral view.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="fontanelles-of-the-skull">Fontanelles of the skull<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fontanelles-of-the-skull" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>At birth, ossification of the cranial sutures is incomplete. The skull bones do not fuse earlier to allow for moulding of the baby's head during childbirth. Where three or more bones
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-37a9c9de.jpeg" alt="img-165.jpeg"></p>
<p>B Posterior fontanelle C
Fig. 16.19 The skull showing the fontanelles and sutures. (A) Fontanelles viewed from the side. (B) Fontanelles viewed from above. (C) Main sutures viewed from above when ossification is complete.</p>
<p>meet there are distinct membranous areas, or fontanelles (Fig. 16.19). The two largest are the anterior fontanelle, not fully ossified until the child is between 12 and 18 months old, and the posterior fontanelle, usually ossified 2-3 months after birth.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="functions-of-the-skull">Functions of the skull<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions-of-the-skull" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The various parts of the skull have specific and different functions:</p>
<ul>
<li>The cranium protects the brain.</li>
<li>The bony eye sockets protect the eyes and give attachment to the muscles that move them.</li>
<li>The temporal bone protects the delicate structures of the inner ear.</li>
<li>The sinuses in some face and skull bones give resonance to the voice.</li>
<li>The bones of the face form the walls of the posterior part of the nasal cavities and form the upper part of the air passages.</li>
<li>The maxilla and the mandible provide alveolar ridges in which the teeth are embedded.</li>
<li>The mandible, controlled by muscles of the lower face, allows chewing.</li>
</ul>
<p>There are 26 bones in the vertebral column (Fig. 16.20). Twenty-four separate vertebrae extend downwards from the occipital bone of the skull; then there is the sacrum, formed from five fused vertebrae, and lastly the coccyx, or tail, which is formed from between three and five small fused vertebrae. The vertebral column is divided into different regions. The first 7 vertebrae, in the neck, form the cervical spine; the next 12 vertebrae are the thoracic spine, and the next 5 the lumbar spine, the lowest vertebra of which articulates with</p>
<p>Sphenoidal
fontanelle
Cervical vertebrae (7)
Thoracic vertebrae (12)
Lumbar vertebrae (5)
Sacrum
Coccyx</p>
<p>Mastoid fontanelle
Cl (atlas)
Intervertebral
Intervertebral
Fig. 16.20 The vertebral column. Lateral view.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="vertebral-column">Vertebral column<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vertebral-column" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Anterior fontanelle
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-281161eb.jpeg" alt="img-166.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 16.21 A lumbar vertebra showing the features of a typical vertebra. Viewed from above.
the sacrum. Each vertebra is identified by the first letter of its region in the spine, followed by a number indicating its position. For example, the topmost vertebra is Cl and the third lumbar vertebra is L3.</p>
<p>The movable vertebrae have many characteristics in common but some groups have distinguishing features.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="characteristics-of-a-typical-vertebra">Characteristics of a typical vertebra<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#characteristics-of-a-typical-vertebra" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These are shown in Fig. 16.21.
Body
This is the broad, flattened, largest part of the vertebra. When the vertebrae are stacked together in the vertebral column, the flattened surfaces of the body of each vertebra articulate with the corresponding surfaces of the vertebrae above and below. However, there is no direct bone-to-bone contact since between each pair of bones is a tough pad of fibrocartilage called the intervertebral disc. The bodies of the vertebrae lie to the front of the vertebral column, increasing greatly in size towards the base of the spine, as the lower spine has to support much more weight than the upper regions.</p>
<p>Vertebral (neural) arch
This encloses a large vertebral foramen. It lies behind the body and forms the posterior and lateral walls of the vertebral foramen. The lateral walls are formed from plates of bone called pedicles, and the posterior walls are formed from laminae. Projecting from the regions where the pedicle meets the lamina is a lateral prominence, the transverse process, and where the two laminae meet at the back is a process called the spinous process. These bony prominences can be felt through</p>
<p>the skin along the length of the spine. The vertebral arch has four articular surfaces: two articulate with the vertebra above and two with the one below. The
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-32cc4d94.jpeg" alt="img-167.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 16.22 A cervical vertebra, showing typical features. Viewed from above.
vertebral foramina form the vertebral (neural) canal that contains the spinal cord.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="region-specific-vertebral-characteristics">Region-specific vertebral characteristics<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#region-specific-vertebral-characteristics" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cervical-vertebrae">Cervical vertebrae<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cervical-vertebrae" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These are the smallest vertebrae (Fig. 16.22) because they only have to support the head. The transverse processes have a foramen through which a vertebral artery passes upwards to the brain. The first two cervical vertebrae, the atlas and the axis, are atypical.</p>
<p>The first cervical vertebra <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(\mathrm{Cl})</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Cl</span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>, the atlas, is the bone on which the skull rests. Below the atlas is the axis, the second cervical vertebra (C2).</p>
<p>The atlas (Fig. 16.23A) is essentially a ring of bone, with no distinct body or spinous process, although it has two short transverse processes. It has two flattened facets that articulate with the occipital bone; these are condyloid joints (p. 447) and they permit nodding of the head.</p>
<p>The axis (Fig. 16.23B and C) sits below the atlas, and has a small body with a small superior projection called the odontoid process (or dens, meaning tooth). This occupies part of the posterior foramen of the atlas above and is held securely within it by the transverse ligament (Fig. 16.23D). The head pivots (i.e. turns from side to side) on this joint.</p>
<p>The 7th cervical vertebra, C7, is also known as the vertebra prominens. It has a long spinous prominence terminating in a swollen tubercle, which is easily felt at the base of the neck.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="thoracic-vertebrae">Thoracic vertebrae<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#thoracic-vertebrae" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The 12 thoracic vertebrae (Fig. 16.24) are larger than the cervical vertebrae because this section of the vertebral column has to support more body weight. The bodies and transverse processes have facets for articulation with the ribs.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="lumbar-vertebrae">Lumbar vertebrae<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lumbar-vertebrae" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These are the largest of the vertebrae (see Fig. 16.21) because they have to support the weight of the entire upper body.</p>
<p>Superior articular facet for occipital condyle
Facet for articulation with dens (odontoid process) of axis
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-e5f0d501.jpeg" alt="img-168.jpeg"></p>
<p>Transverse process
Posterior tubercle
A</p>
<p>Transverse foramen for vertebral artery
Dens (odontoid process)
Transverse process
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-8f0520cb.jpeg" alt="img-169.jpeg"></p>
<p>Superior articular facet for atlas
Vertebral foramen
Lamina
Spinous process</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-b7fdeac2.jpeg" alt="img-170.jpeg"></p>
<p>4*
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-65d25805.jpeg" alt="img-171.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 16.23 The upper cervical vertebrae. (A) The atlas viewed from above. (B) The axis viewed from above. (C) The axis, lateral view. (D) The atlas and axis in position, showing the transverse ligament.</p>
<p>They have substantial spinous processes for attachment of the muscles of the lower back.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="sacrum">Sacrum<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sacrum" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This consists of five rudimentary vertebrae fused to form a triangular or wedgeshaped bone with a concave anterior
surface (Fig. 16.25). The upper part, or base, articulates with the 5th lumbar vertebra. On each side it articulates with the ilium to form a sacroiliac joint, and at its inferior tip it articulates with the coccyx. The anterior edge of the base, the promontory, protrudes into the pelvic cavity. The vertebral foramina are present, and on each side of the bone there is a series of foramina for the passage of sacral spinal nerves.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="coccyx">Coccyx<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#coccyx" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This consists of the four terminal vertebrae, fused to form a very small triangular bone (Fig. 16.25), the broad base of which articulates with the tip of the sacrum.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="features-of-the-vertebral-column">Features of the vertebral column<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#features-of-the-vertebral-column" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="intervertebral-discs">Intervertebral discs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#intervertebral-discs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The bodies of adjacent vertebrae are separated by intervertebral discs, consisting of an outer rim of fibrocartilage (annulus fibrosus) and a central core of soft gelatinous material (nucleus pulposus) (Fig. 16.26). They are thinnest in the</p>
<p>cervical region and become progressively thicker towards the lumbar region, as spinal loading increases. The posterior longitudinal ligament in the vertebral canal helps to keep them in place. They act as shock absorbers, and the cartilaginous joints they form contribute to the flexibility of the vertebral column as a whole.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="intervertebral-foramina">Intervertebral foramina<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#intervertebral-foramina" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>When two adjacent vertebrae are viewed from the side, a foramen formed by a gap between adjacent vertebral pedicles can be seen.</p>
<p>Throughout the length of the vertebral column there is an intervertebral foramen on each side between every pair of vertebrae, through which the spinal nerves, blood vessels and lymph vessels pass (Fig. 16.27).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ligaments-of-the-vertebral-column">Ligaments of the vertebral column<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ligaments-of-the-vertebral-column" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These ligaments (see Fig. 16.26) hold the vertebrae together and keep the intervertebral discs in position.</p>
<p>The transverse ligament holds the odontoid process of the axis in the correct position in relation to the atlas (see Fig. 16.23C).</p>
<p>The anterior longitudinal ligament extends for the whole length of the column and lies in front of the vertebral bodies.</p>
<p>The posterior longitudinal ligament lies inside the vertebral canal and extends for the whole length of the vertebral column in close contact with the posterior surface of the bodies of the bones.</p>
<p>The ligamenta flava connect the laminae of adjacent vertebrae.
The ligamentum nuchae (see Fig. 16.61) and the supraspinous ligament connect the spinous processes, extending from the occiput to the sacrum.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-43d1934e.jpeg" alt="img-172.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-b1a5bc25.jpeg" alt="img-173.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="vertebral-foramen">Vertebral foramen<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vertebral-foramen" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="transverse-process">Transverse process<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#transverse-process" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="spinous-process">Spinous process<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spinous-process" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Superior articular process with facet for articulation with adjacent vertebra
Transverse process
Inferior articular process
Superior articular process with facet <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">âˆ§</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">{ }^{\wedge}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7519em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7519em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">âˆ§</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> or articulation with adjacent vertebra

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="curves-of-the-vertebral-column">Curves of the vertebral column<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#curves-of-the-vertebral-column" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>When viewed from the side, the vertebral column presents four curves: two primary and two secondary (Fig. 16.28).</p>
<p>The fetus in the uterus lies curled up so that the head and the knees are more or less touching. This position shows the primary curvature. The secondary cervical curve develops when the child can hold up their head (after about 3 months) and the secondary lumbar curve develops when the child is able to stand (after 12-15 months). The primary thoracic and sacral curves are retained.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="movement-of-the-vertebral-column">Movement of the vertebral column<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#movement-of-the-vertebral-column" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Movement between the individual bones of the vertebral column is very limited. However, the movements of the column as a whole are quite extensive and include flexion
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-0962def2.jpeg" alt="img-175.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 16.26 Section of the vertebral column showing the ligaments, intervertebral discs and intervertebral foramina.
(bending forwards), extension (bending backwards), lateral flexion (bending to the side) and rotation. There is more movement in the cervical and lumbar regions than elsewhere.</p>
<p>Functions of the vertebral column
These include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Collectively, the vertebral foramina form the vertebral canal, which provides strong bony protection for the delicate spinal cord lying within it.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-b1ec629e.jpeg" alt="img-176.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 16.27 Lower cervical vertebrae showing the spinal cord and spinal nerves emerging through the intervertebral foramina. Lateral view.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-ecbbf1da.jpeg" alt="img-177.jpeg"></p>
<p>Clavicle</p>
<p>Manubrium of sternum</p>
<p>Ribs</p>
<p>Body of sternum</p>
<p>Xiphoid process of sternum</p>
<p>Costal cartilages</p>
<p>Rib 11 Rib 12</p>
<p>Primary curve in fetus</p>
<p>1st secondary curve (cervical)
3 months <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span></span></span></span></span>

<p>Sacral/coccygeal curvature
(primary curvature)
Fig. 16.28 Development of the spinal curves.</p>
<ul>
<li>The pedicles of adjacent vertebrae form intervertebral foramina, one on each side, providing access to the spinal cord for spinal nerves, blood vessels and lymph vessels.</li>
<li>The numerous individual vertebrae with their intervertebral discs allow movement of the whole column.</li>
<li>Support is provided for the skull.</li>
<li>The intervertebral discs act as shock absorbers,
protecting the brain.
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>438</mn><mrow><mo>âˆ§</mo><mo>âˆ§</mo></mrow></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">438^{\wedge \wedge}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7519em;"></span><span class="mord">43</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">8</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7519em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">âˆ§âˆ§</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></li>
</ul>
<p>Fig. 16.29 The thoracic cage. Anterior view.</p>
<ul>
<li>The axis of the trunk is formed, giving attachment to the ribs, shoulder girdle and upper limbs, and the pelvic girdle and lower limbs.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="thoracic-cage">Thoracic cage<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#thoracic-cage" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The thorax (thoracic cage. Fig. 16.29) is made up of the sternum anteriorly, 12 pairs of ribs forming the lateral bony cages, and the 12 thoracic vertebrae.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="sternum-breast-bone">Sternum (breast bone)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sternum-breast-bone" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This flat bone (Fig. 16.30) can be felt just under the skin in the middle of the front of the chest.</p>
<p>The manubrium is the uppermost section and articulates with the clavicles at the sternoclavicular joints and with the first two pairs of ribs.</p>
<p>The body or middle portion gives attachment to the ribs. The xiphoid process is the inferior tip of the bone. It gives attachment to the diaphragm, muscles of the anterior abdominal wall and the linea alba (literally 'white line'; see Fig. 16.64).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ribs">Ribs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ribs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The 12 pairs of ribs form the lateral walls of the thoracic cage (see Fig. 16.29). They are elongated, curved bones (Fig. 16.31) that articulate posteriorly with the vertebral column. Anteriorly, the first seven pairs of ribs articulate directly with the sternum and are known as the true ribs. The next three pairs articulate only indirectly. In both cases, costal cartilages attach the ribs to the sternum. The lowest</p>
<p>Jugular (suprasternal) notch
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-d52ecaf7.jpeg" alt="img-178.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 16.30 The sternum and its attachments. Anterior view.
S Head</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-5feceaf5.jpeg" alt="img-179.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 16.31 A typical rib. Viewed from below.
two pairs of ribs, referred to as floating ribs, do not join the sternum at all, their anterior tips being free.</p>
<p>Each rib forms up to three joints with the vertebral column. Two of these joints are formed between facets on the head of the rib and facets on the bodies of two vertebrae, the one above the rib and the one below. Ten of the ribs also form joints between the tubercle of the rib and the transverse process of (usually) the lower vertebra.</p>
<p>The inferior surface of the rib is deeply grooved, providing a channel along which intercostal nerves and blood vessels run. Between each rib and the one below are the intercostal muscles, which move the ribcage during breathing.</p>
<p>Due to the arrangement of the ribs and the quantity of cartilage present in the ribcage, it is a flexible structure that can change its shape and size during breathing. The first rib is firmly fixed to the sternum and to the 1st thoracic vertebra, and does not move during inspiration. It is a fixed point, so when the intercostal muscles contract, they pull the entire ribcage upwards towards the first rib. The mechanism of breathing is described on page 275 .</p>
<p>The upper limb forms a joint with the trunk via the shoulder (pectoral) girdle.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="shoulder-girdle">Shoulder girdle<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#shoulder-girdle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The shoulder girdle consists of two clavicles and two scapulae.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="clavicle-collar-bone">Clavicle (collar bone)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clavicle-collar-bone" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The clavicle (Fig. 16.32) is an S-shaped long bone. It
articulates with the manubrium of the sternum at the
sternoclavicular joint and forms the acromioclavicular</p>
<ul>
<li>SPOT CHECK</li>
</ul>
<ol start="3">
<li>Which sutures are formed at the edges of the parietal bone?</li>
<li>Describe the position and structure of the vertebra prominens.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="appendicular-skeleton">Appendicular skeleton<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#appendicular-skeleton" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>identify the bones forming the appendicular skeleton</li>
<li>state the characteristics of the bones forming the appendicular skeleton</li>
<li>outline the differences in structure between the male and female pelves.</li>
</ul>
<p>The appendicular skeleton (see Fig. 16.10) consists of the:</p>
<ul>
<li>shoulder girdle with the upper limbs</li>
<li>pelvic girdle with the lower limbs.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="shoulder-girdle-and-upper-limb">Shoulder girdle and upper limb<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#shoulder-girdle-and-upper-limb" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="learning-outcomes">Learning outcomes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#learning-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>P Facet for articulation
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-ce50b44c.jpeg" alt="img-180.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 16.32 The right clavicle. Viewed from above.
Facet for articulation with clavicle Superior Superior Coracoid Acromion
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-e92f69f9.jpeg" alt="img-181.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 16.33 The right scapula. Posterior view.
joint with the acromion process of the scapula. The clavicle provides the only bony link between the upper limb and the axial skeleton.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="scapula-shoulder-blade">Scapula (shoulder blade)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#scapula-shoulder-blade" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The scapula (Fig. 16.33) is a flat, triangular-shaped bone, lying on the posterior chest wall superficial to the ribs and separated from them by muscles.</p>
<p>At the lateral angle there is a shallow articular surface, the glenoid cavity, which, with the head of the humerus, forms the shoulder joint.</p>
<p>On the posterior surface runs a rough ridge called the spine, which extends beyond the lateral border of the scapula and overhangs the glenoid cavity. The prominent overhang, which can be felt through the skin as the highest point of the</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-27f40da0.jpeg" alt="img-182.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 16.34 The right humerus. Anterior view.
shoulder, is called the acromion process and forms a joint with the clavicle; this is the acromioclavicular joint, a slightly movable synovial joint that contributes to the mobility of the shoulder girdle. The coracoid process, a projection from the upper border of the bone, gives attachment to muscles that move the shoulder joint.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-upper-limb">The upper limb<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-upper-limb" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="humerus">Humerus<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#humerus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The humerus (Fig. 16.34) is the bone of the upper arm. The head sits within the glenoid cavity of the scapula, forming the shoulder joint. Distal to the head are two roughened projections of bone, the greater and lesser tubercles, and between them there is a deep groove, the bicipital groove or intertubercular sulcus, occupied by one of the tendons of the biceps muscle.</p>
<p>The distal end of the bone has two surfaces that articulate with the radius and ulna to form the elbow joint.</p>
<p>Proximal radioulnar joint Olecranon Facet for articulation</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-dcb34adf.jpeg" alt="img-183.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 16.35 The right radius and ulna with the interosseous membrane. Anterior view.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="ulna-and-radius">Ulna and radius<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ulna-and-radius" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These are the two bones of the forearm (Fig. 16.35). The ulna is longer than and medial to the radius, and when the arm is in the anatomical position, i.e. with the palm of the hand facing forwards, the two bones are parallel. They articulate with the humerus at the elbow joint, with the carpal bones at the wrist joint, and with each other at the proximal and distal radioulnar joints. In addition, an interosseous membrane, a fibrous joint, connects the bones along their shafts, stabilising their association and maintaining their relative positions despite forces applied from the elbow or wrist.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="carpal-wrist-bones">Carpal (wrist) bones<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#carpal-wrist-bones" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There are eight carpal bones arranged in two rows of four (Fig. 16.36). From outside inwards, they are:</p>
<p>Scaphoid <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">âˆ§</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">{ }^{\wedge}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7519em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7519em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">âˆ§</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> Lunate</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-0e58a41b.jpeg" alt="img-184.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 16.36 The bones of the right hand, wrist and fingers. Anterior view.</p>
<ul>
<li>proximal row: scaphoid, lunate, triquetrum, pisiform</li>
<li>distal row: trapezium, trapezoid, capitate, hamate.</li>
</ul>
<p>These bones fit closely together and are held in position by ligaments that allow a limited amount of movement between them. The bones of the proximal row are associated with the wrist joint and those of the distal row form joints with the metacarpal bones. Tendons of muscles lying in the forearm cross the wrist and are held close to the bones by strong fibrous bands, called retinacula (see Fig. 16.52).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="metacarpal-bones-bones-of-the-hand">Metacarpal bones (bones of the hand)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#metacarpal-bones-bones-of-the-hand" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These five bones form the palm of the hand. They are numbered from the thumb side inwards. The proximal ends articulate with the carpal bones and the distal ends with the phalanges.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="phalanges-finger-bones">Phalanges (finger bones)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#phalanges-finger-bones" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There are 14 phalanges, 3 in each finger and 2 in the thumb. They articulate with the metacarpal bones and with each other, by hinge joints.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pelvic-girdle-and-lower-limb">Pelvic girdle and lower limb<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pelvic-girdle-and-lower-limb" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The lower limb forms a joint with the trunk at the pelvic girdle.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pelvic-girdle">Pelvic girdle<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pelvic-girdle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The pelvic girdle is formed from two innominate (hip) bones. The 'pelvis' is the term given to the basin-shaped structure formed by the pelvic girdle and its associated sacrum.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="innominate-hip-bones">Innominate (hip) bones<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#innominate-hip-bones" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Each hip bone (Fig. 16.37) consists of three fused bones: the ilium, ischium and pubis. On its lateral surface there is a deep depression, the acetabulum, which forms the hip joint with the almost-spherical head of femur.</p>
<p>The ilium is the upper flattened part of the bone and it presents the iliac crest, the anterior curve of which is called the anterior superior iliac spine. The ilium forms a synovial joint with the sacrum; this is the sacroiliac joint, a strong joint capable of absorbing the stresses of weight bearing and which tends to become fibrosed in later life.</p>
<p>The pubis is the anterior part of the bone and it articulates with the pubis of the other hip bone at a cartilaginous joint, the symphysis pubis.</p>
<p>The ischium is the inferior and posterior part. The rough inferior projections of the ischia, the ischial tuberosities, bear the weight of the body when the individual is seated. These are the so-called 'sitting bones'.</p>
<p>The union of the three parts takes place in the acetabulum.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-pelvis">The pelvis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-pelvis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The pelvis (Fig. 16.38) is formed by the hip bones, the sacrum and the coccyx. It is divided into upper and lower parts by the brim of the pelvis, consisting of the promontory of the sacrum and the iliopectineal lines of the innominate bones.</p>
<p>The greater or false pelvis is above the brim and the lesser or true pelvis is below.
Differences between male and female pelves
The shape of the female pelvis allows for the passage of the baby during childbirth. In comparison with the male pelvis.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-54bde1ee.jpeg" alt="img-185.jpeg"></p>
<p>Posterior inferior iliac spine

superior iliac spine

Obturator foramen
Fig. 16.37 The right hip bone. Lateral view.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-cafaf931.jpeg" alt="img-186.jpeg"></p>
<p>Iliac crest</p>
<p>Iliac fossa</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="ilium">Ilium<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ilium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Pelvic inlet</p>
<p>Iliopectineal line Acetabulum
