Fig. 16.38 The bones of the pelvis and the upper part of the left femur.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-60237c64.jpeg" alt="img-187.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 16.40 The left femur. Posterior view.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-7a56732c.jpeg" alt="img-188.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 16.39 The difference in shape of the male and female pelves.
the female pelvis has lighter bones, is shallower and more rounded, and is generally roomier (Fig. 16.39).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="lower-limb">Lower limb<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lower-limb" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="femur-thigh-bone">Femur (thigh bone)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#femur-thigh-bone" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The femur (Fig. 16.40) is the longest and heaviest bone of the body. The head is almost spherical and fits into the acetabulum of the hip bone to form the hip joint. The neck extends outwards and slightly downwards from the head to the shaft and most of it is within the capsule of the hip joint.</p>
<p>The posterior surface of the lower third forms a flat triangular area called the popliteal surface. The distal extremity has two articular condyles, which, with the tibia and patella, form the knee joint. The femur transmits the weight of the body through the bones below the knee to the foot.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="tibia-shin-bone">Tibia (shin bone)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tibia-shin-bone" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The tibia (Fig. 16.41) is the medial of the two bones of the lower leg. The proximal extremity is broad and flat, and has two condyles for articulation with the femur at the knee joint. The head of the fibula articulates with the inferior aspect of the lateral condyle, forming the proximal tibiofibular joint.</p>
<p>The distal extremity of the tibia forms the ankle joint with the talus and the fibula. The medial malleolus is a downward projection of bone medial to the ankle joint. It is easily felt through the skin on the inner aspect of the ankle.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fibula">Fibula<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fibula" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The fibula (Fig. 16.41) is the long, slender lateral bone in the leg. The head or upper extremity articulates with the lateral condyle of the tibia, forming the proximal tibiofibular joint, and the lower extremity articulates with the tibia, and projects beyond it to form the lateral malleolus. This helps to stabilise the ankle joint. It is easily felt through the skin on the outer aspect of the ankle.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="patella-knee-cap">Patella (knee cap)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#patella-knee-cap" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is a roughly triangular-shaped sesamoid bone forming part of the anterior wall of the knee joint. Its posterior surface
articulates with the patellar surface of the femur in the knee joint and its anterior surface is in the patellar tendon, i.e. the tendon of the quadriceps femoris muscle.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="tarsal-ankle-bones">Tarsal (ankle) bones<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tarsal-ankle-bones" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The seven tarsal bones (Fig. 16.42A) forming the posterior part of the foot (ankle) are the talus, calcaneus, navicular, cuboid and three cuneiform bones. The talus articulates with the tibia and fibula at the ankle joint. The calcaneus forms the heel of the foot. The other bones articulate with each other and with the metatarsal bones.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="metatarsals-bones-of-the-foot">Metatarsals (bones of the foot)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#metatarsals-bones-of-the-foot" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These are five bones (Fig. 16.42A), numbered from inside out, which form the greater part of the dorsum (sole) of the</p>
<p>Facet for articulation with Intercondylar Facet for articulation with
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-25f65687.jpeg" alt="img-189.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 16.41 The left tibia and fibula with the interosseous membrane. Anterior view.
foot. At their proximal ends they articulate with the tarsal bones, and at their distal ends with the phalanges. The enlarged distal head of the 1st metatarsal bone forms the 'balT of the foot.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="phalanges-toe-bones">Phalanges (toe bones)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#phalanges-toe-bones" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There are 14 phalanges (Fig. 16.42 A), arranged in a similar manner to those in the fingers, i.e. two in the great toe (the hallux) and three in each of the other toes.</p>
<p>Arches of the foot
The arrangement of bones in the foot, supported by associated ligaments and the action of associated muscles, gives the sole of the foot an arched or curved shape (Figs</p>
<p>A
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-436ff897.jpeg" alt="img-190.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 16.42 The bones of the left foot. (A) Viewed from above. (B) Lateral view.
16.42B and 16.43). The curve running from heel to toe is called the longitudinal arch, and the curve running across the foot is called the transverse arch.</p>
<p>In the normal longitudinal arch, only the calcaneus and the distal ends of the metatarsals touch the ground, the bones in between being lifted clear. This gives the conventional footprint shape. If, however, the concavity of the sole is lost because of sagging ligaments or tendons, the arch sinks and much more of the sole of the foot is in contact with the ground: this is called flat foot. The arched design is an effective shock absorber and allows the foot to lever the body forwards in walking and running. Since the arches of the foot are also important in distributing the weight of the body evenly while upright, whether stationary or moving, the flat foot loses the springiness of normal foot structure</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-6d1e2293.jpeg" alt="img-191.jpeg"></p>
<p>Posterior tibialis muscle
Tibia
Talus</p>
<p>Navicular</p>
<p>Medial cuneiform 1st metatarsal</p>
<p>Calcaneus</p>
<p>Long plantar ligament
Short plantar ligament
Spring ligament
Tendon of posterior tibialis muscle
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-154904b6.jpeg" alt="img-192.jpeg"></p>
<p>Sutural liaament
Tooth</p>
<p>Tibia</p>
<p>Interosseous</p>
<p>membrane
Fibula
Periodontal
ligament
Bone
Fig. 16.43 The tendons and ligaments supporting the arches of the left foot. Medial view.</p>
<p>Fig. 16.44 Fibrous joints. (A) Suture of the skull. (B) The periodontal ligament. (C) The interosseous membrane linking the tibia and fibula.
and leads to sore feet when standing, walking or running for long periods. As there are movable joints between all the bones of the foot, very strong muscles and ligaments are necessary to maintain the strength, resilience and stability of the foot during walking, running and jumping.</p>
<p>Posterior tibialis muscle. This is the most important muscular support of the longitudinal arch (Fig. 16.43). It lies on the posterior aspect of the lower leg and originates from the middle third of the tibia and fibula; its tendon passes behind the medial malleolus to be inserted into the navicular, cuneiform, cuboid and metatarsal bones. It acts as a sling or 'suspension apparatus' for the arch.</p>
<p>Short muSClOS of the foot. This group of muscles is mainly concerned with the maintenance of the longitudinal and transverse arches. They make up the fleshy part of the sole of the foot.</p>
<p>Plantar calcaneonavicular ligament ('spring' ligament). This is a very strong thick ligament stretching from the calcaneus to the navicular bone (Fig. 16.43). It plays an important part in supporting the medial longitudinal arch.</p>
<p>Plantar ligaments and interosseous membranes. These structures support the lateral longitudinal and transverse arches.</p>
<ul>
<li>SPOT CHECK</li>
</ul>
<ol start="5">
<li>On which bone would you find the acromion process and how would you locate this on the body?</li>
<li>What is meant by the arches of the foot and why are they important to its function?</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="joints">Joints<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#joints" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>state the characteristics of fibrous and cartilaginous joints</li>
<li>list the different types of synovial joint</li>
<li>outline the movements possible at six types of synovial joint</li>
<li>describe the structure and functions of a typical synovial joint</li>
<li>describe the structure and movements of the following synovial joints: shoulder, elbow, wrist, hip, knee and ankle.</li>
</ul>
<p>A joint is the site at which any two or more bones articulate or come together, meaning the ends or edges of the bones are held together by connective tissues. Joints may allow flexibility and movement of the skeleton. In some joints, however, the participating bones are fastened together so firmly that no movement between them is possible.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="fibrous-joints">Fibrous joints<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fibrous-joints" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The bones forming these joints are linked with tough, fibrous material. Such an arrangement often permits no movement. For example, the joints between the skull bones, the sutures, are completely immovable (Fig. 16.44A), and the healthy
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-58007503.jpeg" alt="img-193.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 16.45 Cartilaginous joints. (A) The epiphyseal plate.
(B) Intervertebral discs and the symphysis pubis.
tooth is cemented into the mandible by the periodontal ligament (Fig. 16.44B). The tibia and fibula in the leg are held together along their shafts by a sheet of fibrous tissue called the interosseous membrane (Fig. 16.44C). This fibrous joint allows a limited amount of movement and stabilises the alignment of the bones.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cartilaginous-joints">Cartilaginous joints<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cartilaginous-joints" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These joints are formed by a pad of tough fibrocartilage between the bones that acts as a shock absorber. The joint may be immovable, as in the cartilaginous epiphyseal plates (Fig. 16.45A), which in the growing child link the diaphysis of a long bone to the epiphysis. Some cartilaginous joints permit limited movement, as between the vertebrae, which are separated by the intervertebral discs (Fig. 16.45B), or at the symphysis pubis (Fig. 16.45B), which is softened by circulating hormones during pregnancy to allow for expansion during childbirth.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="synovial-joints">Synovial joints<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#synovial-joints" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Synovial joints are characterised by the presence of a space or capsule between the articulating bones (Fig. 16.46). The ends of the bones are held close together by a sleeve of fibrous tissue and lubricated with a small amount of fluid. Synovial joints are the most movable of the body.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="characteristics-of-a-synovial-joint">Characteristics of a synovial joint<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#characteristics-of-a-synovial-joint" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>All synovial joints have certain characteristics in common (Fig. 16.46).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="articular-or-hyaline-cartilage">Articular or hyaline cartilage<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#articular-or-hyaline-cartilage" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The parts of the bones in contact with each other are coated with hyaline cartilage (see Fig. 3.23). This provides a smooth articular surface, reduces friction, distributes weight and
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-6018bbc6.jpeg" alt="img-194.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 16.46 The basic structure of a synovial joint.
prevents damaging bone-to-bone contact. The cartilage lining, which is up to 7 mm thick in young people, becomes thinner and less compressible with age. This leads to increasing stress on other structures in the joint. Cartilage has no blood supply and receives its nourishment from synovial fluid.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="capsule-or-capsular-ligament">Capsule or capsular ligament<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#capsule-or-capsular-ligament" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The joint is wrapped in a sleeve of fibrous tissue that holds the bones together. It is sufficiently loose to allow freedom of movement but strong enough to protect it from injury. The capsule is formed by an extension of the periosteum covering the participating bones.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="synovial-membrane">Synovial membrane<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#synovial-membrane" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This delicate epithelial layer lines the capsule and covers all non-weight-bearing surfaces inside the joint. It secretes synovial fluid.</p>
<p>Synovial fluid
This is a thick, sticky fluid of egg-white consistency, which fills the synovial cavity. It:</p>
<ul>
<li>nourishes the structures within the joint cavity</li>
<li>contains phagocytes, which remove microbes and cellular debris</li>
<li>coats and lubricates the moving parts of the joint</li>
<li>maintains joint stability</li>
<li>prevents the ends of the bones from being separated, as does a little water between two glass surfaces.</li>
</ul>
<p>Little sacs of synovial fluid (bursae) are present in some joints, e.g. the knee. They act as cushions to prevent friction between a bone and a ligament or tendon, or skin where a bone in a joint is near the surface.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="other-intracapsular-structures">other intracapsular structures<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#other-intracapsular-structures" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Some joints have structures within the capsule to pad and stabilise the joint, e.g. fat pads and menisci in the knee joint. If these structures do not bear weight, they are covered by synovial membrane.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="extracapsular-structures">Extracapsular structures<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#extracapsular-structures" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Ligaments that blend with the capsule stabilise the joint.</li>
<li>Muscles or their tendons also provide stability and stretch across the joints they move. When the muscle contracts, it shortens, pulling one bone towards the other.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="nerve-and-blood-supply">Nerve and blood supply<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nerve-and-blood-supply" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Nerves and blood vessels crossing a joint usually supply the capsule and the muscles that move it.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="4e5afba5">Movements at synovial joints <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">â–¡</mi><mn>16.3</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\square 16.3</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.675em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">â–¡</span><span class="mord">16.3</span></span></span></span></span><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4e5afba5" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Movement at any given joint depends on various factors, such as the tightness of the ligaments holding the joint together, how well the bones fit and the presence or absence of intracapsular structures. Generally, the more stable the joint, the less</p>
<p>mobile it is. The main movements possible are summarised in Table 16.2 and Fig. 16.47.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="types-of-synovial-joint">Types of synovial joint<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-synovial-joint" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Synovial joints are classified according to the range of movement possible (Table 16.2) or the shape of the articulating parts of the bones involved (Fig. 16.48).</p>
<p>Table 16.2 Movements possible at
synovial joints</p>
<p>Movement</p>
<p>Flexion</p>
<p>Extension</p>
<p>Abduction</p>
<p>Adduction</p>
<p>Circumduction</p>
<p>Rotation</p>
<p>Pronation</p>
<p>Supination</p>
<p>Inversion</p>
<p>Eversion</p>
<p>Definition</p>
<p>Bending, usually forwards but occasionally backwards, e.g. knee joint</p>
<p>Straightening or bending backwards</p>
<p>Movement away from the midline of the body</p>
<p>Movement towards the midline of the body</p>
<p>Movement of a limb or digit so that it describes the shape of a cone</p>
<p>Movement round the long axis of a bone</p>
<p>Turning the palm of the hand down</p>
<p>Turning the palm of the hand up</p>
<p>Turning the sole of the foot inwards</p>
<p>Turning the sole of the foot outwards</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="ball-and-socket-joints">Ball and socket joints<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ball-and-socket-joints" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The head of one bone is ball-shaped and articulates with a cup-shaped socket of another. These joints allow a wide range of movement, including flexion, extension, adduction, abduction, rotation and circumduction. Examples include the shoulder and hip.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hinge-joints">Hinge joints<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hinge-joints" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The articulating ends of the bones fit together like a hinge on a door, and movement is therefore restricted to flexion and extension. The elbow joint is one example, permitting only flexion and extension of the forearm. Other hinge joints include the knee, ankle and the joints between the phalanges of the fingers and toes (interphalangeal joints).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="gliding-joints">Gliding joints<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gliding-joints" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The articular surfaces are flat or very slightly curved and glide over one another but the amount of movement possible is very restricted; this group of joints is the least movable of all the synovial joints. Examples include the joints between the carpal bones in the wrist, the tarsal bones in the foot, and the processes of the spinal vertebrae (note that the joints between the vertebral bodies are the cartilaginous discs).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pivot-joints">Pivot joints<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pivot-joints" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These joints allow a bone or a limb to rotate. One bone fits into a hoop-shaped ligament that holds it close to another bone and allows it to rotate in the ring thus formed. For example, the head rotates on the pivot joint formed by the dens of the axis held within the ring formed by the transverse ligament and the dens (odontoid process) of the atlas (see Fig. 16.23D).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="condyloid-joints">Condyloid joints<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#condyloid-joints" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A condyle is a smooth, rounded projection on a bone and in a condyloid joint it sits within a cup-shaped depression on the other bone. Examples include the joint between the condylar process of the mandible and the temporal bone, those between the metacarpal and phalangeal bones of the hand, and those between the metatarsal and phalangeal bones of the foot. These joints permit flexion, extension, abduction, adduction and circumduction.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="saddle-joints">Saddle joints<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#saddle-joints" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The articulating bones fit together like a person sitting on a saddle. The most important saddle joint is at the base of the thumb, between the trapezium of the wrist and the first metacarpal bone (see Fig. 16.36). The range of movement is similar to that at a condyloid joint but with additional flexibility; opposition of the</p>
<p>thumb, the ability to touch each of the finger tips on the same hand, is due to the nature of the thumb joint.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-6f73db33.jpeg" alt="img-195.jpeg"></p>
<p>Circumduction
Supination (palm up)
Pronation (palm down)
Fig. 16.47 The main movements possible at synovial joints.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="53766a70">Principal synovial joints of the limbs <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">â–¡</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\square</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.675em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">â–¡</span></span></span></span></span> 16.4<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#53766a70" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>All synovial joints have the characteristics described above, so only their distinctive features are included in this section.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="shoulder-joint">Shoulder joint<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#shoulder-joint" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This ball and socket joint (Fig. 16.49) is the most mobile in the body and, consequently, is the least stable and prone to dislocation, especially in children. It is formed by the glenoid cavity of the scapula and the head of the humerus, and is well padded with protective bursae. The capsular ligament is very loose interiorly to allow for the free movement normally possible at this joint. The glenoid cavity is very shallow but is deepened by a rim of fibrocartilage, the glenoidal labrum, which provides additional stability without limiting movement. The tendon of the long head of the biceps muscle is held in the intertubercular (bicipital)
groove of the humerus by the transverse humeral ligament. It extends through the joint cavity and attaches to the upper rim of the glenoid cavity.</p>
<p>Synovial membrane forms a sleeve round the part of the tendon of the long head of the biceps muscles within the capsular ligament and covers the glenoidal labrum.</p>
<p>The joint is stabilised partly by a number of ligaments (the glenohumeral, coracohumeral and transverse humeral) but mainly by the muscles (and their tendons) present in the shoulder. Some of these muscles are collectively called the rotator cuff, and rotator cuff injury is a common cause of shoulder pain. Repeated dislocations can stretch the tendons and ligaments supporting the shoulder joint, making it less stable.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="muscles-and-movements">Muscles and movements<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#muscles-and-movements" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The muscles that move the arm (see Fig. 16.66) are described in more detail on page 463 , and Table 16.3 summarises the muscles and movements possible at the shoulder joint.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-2c3d3609.jpeg" alt="img-196.jpeg"></p>
<p>Ball and socket joint
Condyloid joint
Hinge joint
Gliding joint
Saddle joint
Pivot joint
Fig. 16.48. Types of synovial joint with examples of their locations in the skeleton.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="elbow-joint">Elbow joint<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#elbow-joint" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The elbow joint (Fig. 16.50) involves three bones: the humerus of the upper arm, and the radius and ulna of the forearm. The humerus has surfaces that articulate with both the radius and the ulna, meaning that the elbow joint actually contains two articulations. The capitulum of the humerus is a rounded projection that fits against the head of the radius, forming the radiohumeral joint. The trochlea is a grooved projection on the humerus and it fits very closely into the trochlear notch of the ulna, forming the humeroulnar joint. As the bones fit together very closely and the whole joint is wrapped in strong medial, anterior, lateral and posterior ligaments, the elbow joint is very stable.</p>
<p>The ulnar nerve runs superficially at the back of the elbow joint, along a shallow groove on the medial epicondyle. This
area is referred to colloquially as the Tunny bone' and if it is bumped or struck, it produces a tingling sensation in the forearm.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="muscles-and-movements">Muscles and movements<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#muscles-and-movements" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The structure of the elbow joint only allows the two movements of flexion and extension. The biceps is the main flexor of the forearm, aided by the brachialis; the triceps extends it (see Fig. 16.66).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="proximal-and-distal-radioulnar-joints">Proximal and distal radioulnar joints<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#proximal-and-distal-radioulnar-joints" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The proximal radioulnar joint is a pivot joint formed by the rim of the head of the radius rotating in the radial notch of the ulna, and is in the same capsule as the elbow joint. The
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-30b4b64f.jpeg" alt="img-197.jpeg"></p>
<p>Bursa
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-e612ed01.jpeg" alt="img-198.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-74a6f63e.jpeg" alt="img-199.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 16.49 The right shoulder joint. (A) Section viewed from the front. (B) The position of the glenoidal labrum with the humerus removed, viewed from the side. (C) The supporting ligaments viewed from the front.</p>

<table><thead><tr><th>Medial rotation</th><th>Latissimus dorsi, pectoralis major, teres major and anterior part of deltoid</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Circumduction</td><td>Combination of actions of above muscles</td></tr><tr><td>annular ligament is a strong extracapsular ligament that encircles the head of the radius and keeps it in contact with the radial notch of the ulna (Fig. 16.50B).</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>The distal radioulnar joint is a pivot joint between the distal end of the radius and the head of the ulna (Fig. 16.51). They also allow the radius to rotate relative to the ulna. In forearm supination, i.e. palm up and thumb lying laterally, the radius and ulna are parallel, but when the hand is turned through 180 degrees so that the thumb is lying medially, the radius crosses over the ulna, rotating in the ring formed by the annular ligament.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Note, in addition, the presence of a fibrous membrane linking the radius and ulna along their shafts; this interosseous membrane (see Fig. 16.35) is a type of fibrous joint that prevents separation of the bones when force is applied at either end, i.e. at the wrist or elbow.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Muscles and movements</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Forearm pronation is caused by the action of pronator teres (p. 465) and supination by the supinator and biceps muscles (p. 465 and see Fig. 16.66).</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Wrist joint</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>This is a condyloid joint between the distal end of the radius and the proximal ends of the scaphoid, lunate and triquetrum (Fig. 16.51). A disc of white fibrocartilage separates the ulna from the joint cavity and articulates with the carpal bones. It also separates the inferior radioulnar joint from the wrist joint.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Extracapsular structures consist of medial and lateral ligaments and anterior and posterior radiocarpal ligaments.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Muscles and movements</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>The wrist can be flexed, extended, abducted and adducted. <div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="joints-of-the-hands-and-fingers">Joints of the hands and fingers<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#joints-of-the-hands-and-fingers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The carpal bones are held firmly together by several ligaments. There are synovial joints between the carpal bones, between the carpal and metacarpal bones, between the metacarpal bones and proximal phalanges, and between the phalanges. Movement at the hand and finger joints is controlled by muscles in the forearm and smaller muscles within the hand. There are no muscles in the fingers; finger movements are produced by tendons extending from muscles in the forearm and the hand.</p>
<p>The joint at the base of the thumb is a saddle joint, unlike the corresponding joints of the other fingers, which are condyloid. This means that the thumb is more mobile than the fingers and the thumb can be flexed, extended, circumducted, abducted and adducted. In addition the thumb can be moved across the palm to touch the tips of each of the fingers on the same hand (opposition), giving great
manual dexterity and allowing, for example, the holding of a pen and the fine manipulation of objects held in the hand.</p>
<p>The joints between the metacarpals and finger bones allow movement of the fingers. The fingers may be flexed, extended, adducted, abducted and</p>
<p>circumducted, with the first finger more flexible than the others. The finger joints are hinge joints and allow only flexion and extension.</p>
<p>The flexor retinaculum is a strong fibrous band that stretches across the front of the carpal bones, forming the carpal tunnel. The tendons of flexor muscles of the wrist joint and the fingers and the median nerve pass through the carpal tunnel, the retinaculum holding them close to the bones. Synovial membrane forms sleeves around these tendons in the carpal tunnel and extends some way into the palm of the hand. Synovial sheaths also enclose the tendons on the flexor surfaces of the fingers. Their synovial fluid prevents friction that might damage the tendons as they move over the bones (Fig. 16.52).</p>
<p>The extensor retinaculum is a strong fibrous band that extends across the back of the wrist. Tendons of muscles that extend the wrist and finger joints are encased in synovial membrane under the retinaculum. The synovial fluid secreted prevents friction.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="hip-joint">Hip joint<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hip-joint" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This strong ball and socket joint is formed by the cup-shaped acetabulum of the innominate (hip) bone and the almost spherical head of the femur (Fig. 16.53). The capsular ligament encloses the head and most of the neck of the femur. The cavity is deepened by the acetabular labrum, a ring of fibrocartilage attached around the rim of the acetabulum, which stabilises the joint without limiting its range of movement. The hip joint needs to be sturdy and powerful, since it bears all the body weight when an individual is standing. It is stabilised by its surrounding musculature but its ligaments are also important. The three main external ligaments are the iliofemoral, pubofemoral and ischiofemoral ligaments (Fig. 16.53B). Within the joint the ligament of the head of the femur (ligamentum teres) attaches the femoral head to the acetabulum (Fig. 16.53A and C).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="muscles-and-movements">Muscles and movements<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#muscles-and-movements" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The lower limb can be extended, flexed, abducted, adducted, rotated and circumducted at the hip joint (Table 16.5 and see Fig. 16.67).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="knee-joint">Knee joint<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#knee-joint" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is the body's largest and most complex joint (Fig. 16.54). It is a very stable hinge joint formed by the condyles of the femur, the condyles of the tibia and the posterior surface of the patella. The anterior part of the capsule is formed by the tendon of the quadriceps femoris muscle, which also</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-4dcf7373.jpeg" alt="img-202.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 16.52 The carpal tunnel and synovial sheaths in the wrist and hand (pink), with tendons (white). (A) Palmar view, left hand. (B) Transverse section.</p>
