<p>Fig. 16.53 The left hip joint: anterior view. (A) Section. (B) Supporting ligaments. (C) Head of femur and acetabulum separated to show acetabular labrum and ligament of head of femur.</p>
<p>Fig. 16.54 The left knee joint. (A) Section viewed from the front. (B) Section viewed from the side. (C) The superior surface of the tibia, showing the semilunar cartilages and the cruciate ligaments.
supports the patella. Intracapsular structures include two cruciate ligaments that cross each other, extending from the intercondylar notch of the femur to the intercondylar eminence of the tibia. They help to stabilise the joint.</p>
<p>Semilunar cartilages or menisci are incomplete discs of white fibrocartilage lying on top of the articular condyles of the tibia. They are wedge-shaped, being thicker at their outer edges, and provide stability. They prevent lateral displacement of the bones, and cushion the moving joint by shifting within the joint space according to the relative positions of the articulating bones.</p>
<p>The joint is associated with numerous bursae and pads of fat. They prevent friction between a bone and a ligament or tendon, and between the skin and the patella. Synovial membrane covers the cruciate ligaments and the pads of fat. The menisci are not covered with synovial membrane because they are weight-bearing. External ligaments provide further support, making it a hard joint to dislocate. The main ligaments are the patellar ligament, an extension of the quadriceps tendon, the popliteal ligaments at the back of the knee and the collateral ligaments to each side.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="muscles-and-movements">Muscles and movements<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#muscles-and-movements" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The knee joint flexes and extends, and also permits a small amount of rotation, which locks the joint when fully extended. This makes it possible to stand upright for long periods of time without tiring the knee extensors. The main muscles extending the knee are the quadriceps femoris, and the principal flexors are the gastrocnemius and hamstrings (see Fig. 16.67).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="ankle-joint">Ankle joint<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ankle-joint" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This hinge joint is formed between the distal end of the tibia and its malleolus (medial malleolus), the distal end of the fibula (lateral malleolus) and the talus (Fig. 16.55). Several important ligaments strengthen this joint: the deltoid and the anterior, posterior, medial and lateral ligaments.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="muscles-and-movements">Muscles and movements<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#muscles-and-movements" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Ankle joint movements and the related muscles are shown in Table 16.6 and Fig. 16.67. The movements of inversion and eversion occur between the tarsal bones and not at the ankle joint.</p>
<p>Table 16.6 Muscles and movements at the ankle joint</p>
<p>Movement</p>
<p>Dorsiflexion (lifting toes towards
calf)</p>
<p>Plantar flexion (rising on tiptoe)</p>
<p>Muscles involved</p>
<p>Anterior tibialis and toe extensors</p>
<p>Gastrocnemius, soleus and toe
flexors</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="joints-of-the-feet-and-toes">Joints of the feet and toes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#joints-of-the-feet-and-toes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>There are a number of synovial joints between the tarsal bones, between the tarsal and metatarsal bones, between the metatarsals and proximal phalanges, and between the phalanges. Movements are produced by muscles in the leg with long tendons that cross the ankle joint, and by muscles of the foot. The tendons crossing the ankle joint are wrapped in synovial sheaths and held close to the bones by strong transverse ligaments. They move smoothly within their sheaths as the joints move. In addition to moving the joints of the foot, these muscles support the arches of the foot and help to maintain balance.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-343b366f.jpeg" alt="img-205.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 16.55 The left ankle joint. (A) Section viewed from the front. (B) Supporting ligaments: medial view.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="spot-check">- SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol start="7">
<li>What is the difference between rotation and circumduction?</li>
<li>The glenoid cavity of the scapula is actually very shallow. How is the head of the humerus held firmly in such a shallow cup?</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="skeletal-muscle">Skeletal muscle<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#skeletal-muscle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="learning-outcomes">Learning outcomes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#learning-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>identify the main characteristics of skeletal muscle</li>
<li>relate the structure of skeletal muscle fibres to their contractile activity</li>
<li>describe the nature of muscle tone and fatigue</li>
<li>discuss the factors that affect the performance of skeletal muscle</li>
<li>name the main muscles of the body regions described in this section</li>
<li>outline the functions of the main muscles described in this section.</li>
</ul>
<p>Muscle cells are specialised contractile cells, also called fibres. The three types of muscle tissue - smooth, cardiac and skeletal - each differ in structure, location and physiological function. Smooth muscle and cardiac muscle are not under voluntary control and are discussed elsewhere (p. 54). Skeletal muscles, which are under voluntary control, are attached to bones via their tendons (Fig. 16.56A) and move the skeleton. Like cardiac (but not smooth) muscle, skeletal muscle is striated (striped), and the stripes are seen in a characteristic banded pattern when the cells are viewed under the microscope (Fig. 16.56B and Fig. 16.57).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="organisation-of-skeietai-muscle">Organisation of skeietai muscle<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#organisation-of-skeietai-muscle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-78970dc6.jpeg" alt="img-206.jpeg"></p>
<p>Muscle belly
Epimysium
Tendon</p>
<p>Blood vessels</p>
<p>Fascicles</p>
<p>Fascicle</p>
<p>Perimysium</p>
<p>Endomysium</p>
<p>Muscle fibres</p>
<p>Sarcolemma</p>
<p>Sarcoplasm Dark band
B Muscle fibre (cell) Mitochondria
Sarcomere Thin filament - Actin</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-302f3e4c.jpeg" alt="img-207.jpeg"></p>
<p>Thick filament-Myosin M line Zline Myofibril relaxed
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-9193c1ab.jpeg" alt="img-208.jpeg">
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>âˆ’</mo><mo separator="true">;</mo><mi>n</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1-; n</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8389em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord">âˆ’</span><span class="mpunct">;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">n</span></span></span></span></span></p>
<p>C Dark band Light band Myofibril contracted
Fig. 16.56 Organisation within a skeletal muscle. (A) A skeletal muscle and its connective tissue. (B) A muscle fibre (cell). (C) A myofibril, relaxed and contracted.</p>
<p>A skeletal muscle can contain hundreds of thousands of muscle fibres as well as blood vessels and nerves (Fig. 16.56). Throughout the muscle, providing internal structure and scaffolding, is an extensive network of connective tissue. The entire muscle is covered in a connective tissue sheath called the epimysium. Within the muscle the cells are collected into separate bundles called fascicles, and each fascicle is covered in its own connective tissue sheath called the perimysium. Within the fascicles the individual muscle cells are each wrapped in a fine connective tissue layer called the endomysium. Each of these connective tissue layers runs
the length of the muscle. They bind the fibres into a highly organised structure and blend together at each end of the muscle to form the tendon, which secures the muscle to bone. Often the tendon is rope-like but sometimes it forms a broad sheet called an aponeurosis, e.g. the occipitofrontalis muscle (see Fig. 16.60). The multiple connective tissue layers throughout the muscle are important for transmitting the force of contraction from each individual muscle cell to its points of attachment to the skeleton.</p>
<p>The fleshy part of the muscle is called the belly.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-39b9bce7.jpeg" alt="img-209.jpeg"></p>
<p>Z line Z line Z line
Fig. 16.57 Coloured transmission electron micrograph of part of a skeletal muscle cell, showing the characteristic banding pattern and multiple mitochondria. (Steve G Schmeissner/Science Photo Library. Reproduced with permission.)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="skeletal-muscle-cells-fibres">Skeletal muscle cells (fibres)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#skeletal-muscle-cells-fibres" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Contraction of a whole skeletal muscle occurs because there is coordinated contraction of its individual fibres.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="structure">Structure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#structure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Under the microscope, skeletal muscle cells are seen to be roughly cylindrical in shape, lying parallel to one another, with a distinctive banded appearance consisting of alternate dark and light stripes (Figs 16.56B and 16.57). Individual fibres may be very long, up to 35 cm in the longest muscles. Each cell has several nuclei (because the cells are so large), found just under the cell membrane (the sarcolemma). The cytoplasm of muscle cells, also called sarcoplasm, is packed with tiny contractile filaments running longitudinally along the length of the muscle. There are also many mitochondria (Fig. 16.57), essential for producing adenosine triphosphate (ATP) from glucose and oxygen to power the contractile mechanism. Also present is a specialised oxygen-binding substance called myoglobin, which is similar to the haemoglobin of red blood cells and stores oxygen within the muscle. In addition, there are extensive intracellular stores of calcium, which is released into the sarcoplasm when the muscle is stimulated by its motor nerve and is essential for the contractile activity of the myofilaments.</p>
<p>Actin, myosin and sarcomeres
There are two types of contractile myofilament within the muscle fibre: thick and thin filaments arranged in
repeating units called sarcomeres (Figs 16.56C and 16.57). The thick filaments, which are made of the protein myosin, correspond to the dark bands seen under the</p>
<p>microscope. The thin filaments are made of the protein actin. Where only thin filaments are present the bands are lighter in appearance.</p>
<p>Sarcomeres are bounded at each end by a dense stripe, the Z line, to which the actin fibres are attached. Running up the middle of the sarcomere is the M line, with the myosin filaments projecting out from each side of it. The ends of the myosin filaments overlap with the ends of the actin filaments. This is essential so that they can bind to one another for contraction to occur.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-neuromuscular-junction-qie-s">The neuromuscular junction Qie.s<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-neuromuscular-junction-qie-s" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The skeletal muscle cell contracts in response to stimulation from a motor nerve fibre, which usually synapses with the muscle cell about halfway along its length.</p>
<p>When it is very close to the muscle cell the nerve fibre splits into a sheaf of very fine filaments, which come into very close proximity to, but do not actually make direct contact with, the sarcolemma of a single muscle cell (for a general description of synaptic physiology see p. 157). This area is known as the motor end-plate. Each filament forms a synapse between the nerve and the muscle cell. The neurotransmitter released here is always acetylcholine ( ACh ), which stimulates muscle cell contraction. The synapse between the motor nerve filament and a skeletal muscle cell is called the neuromuscular junction (Figs 16.58 and 16.59).</p>
<p>Skeletal muscle contraction
Release of ACh at the neuromuscular junction generates an action potential that spreads rapidly along the muscle cell membrane. However, in order to activate the contractile machinery inside the muscle cell, the action potential is also conducted throughout its interior through a specialised network of channels running through the sarcoplasm. This releases calcium from the intracellular stores, which triggers the binding of actin and myosin to each other, forming so-called cross-bridges between them. ATP is split to provide the energy for actin and myosin filaments to slide over each other, pulling the Z lines at each end of the sarcomere closer to one another and shortening it (see Fig. 16.56C). This is called the sliding filament theory. If enough fibres in the muscle are stimulated at the same time, the whole muscle undergoes a degree of shortening. The greater the number of individual fibres stimulated, the greater the degree of shortening (contraction).</p>
<p>The muscle relaxes when motor nerve stimulation stops. Calcium is pumped back into its intracellular stores, breaking the cross-bridges between the actin and myosin filaments. They slide back into their resting positions, lengthening the sarcomere and returning the muscle to its original length.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-7c1d1015.jpeg" alt="img-210.jpeg"></p>
<p>Myelin sheath Axon of motor nerve
Skeletal muscle fibres
Myofibrils within muscle fibres
Synaptic knob
Synaptic cleft ACh receptor
Motor end-plate Synaptic vesicle containing acetylcholine (ACh)
Fig. 16.58 The neuromuscular junction.
Motor terminals at motor end-plates
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-a3f91953.jpeg" alt="img-211.jpeg"></p>
<p>Skeletal muscle fibres Motor nerve
Fig. 16.59 The neuromuscular junction. Colour transmission eleotron miorograph of a motor neurone and two of its motor end-plates. (Kent Wood/Science Photo Library. Reproduced with permission.)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="motor-units">Motor units<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#motor-units" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Each muscle fibre is stimulated at only one motor end-plate, but each motor nerve can form multiple motor end-plates and can therefore stimulate multiple muscle fibres. Fig. 16.59 shows an electron micrograph of a motor nerve and two of its motor end-plates.</p>
<p>One nerve fibre and the muscle fibres it supplies constitute a motor unit. Nerve impulses cause serial contraction of motor units in a muscle, and each unit contracts to its full capacity. The strength of the contraction depends on the number of motor units in action at a particular time.</p>
<p>Some motor units contain large numbers of muscle fibres, i.e. one nerve serves many muscle cells. This arrangement is associated with large-scale, powerful movements, such as in the legs or upper arms. Fine, delicate control of muscle movement is achieved when one motor unit contains very few muscle fibres, as in the muscles controlling eye movement.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="action-of-skeletal-muscle">Action of skeletal muscle<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#action-of-skeletal-muscle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>When individual muscle cells in a muscle shorten, they pull on the connective tissue framework running through the whole muscle and the muscle develops a degree of tension (tone).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="muscle-tone">Muscle tone<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#muscle-tone" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>When a muscle fibre contracts, it obeys the all-or-none law, i.e. the whole fibre either contracts completely or does not contract at all. The degree of contraction achieved by a whole muscle therefore depends on the number of fibres within it that are contracting at any one time, as well as how often they are stimulated. This means that in order to increase the strength of a muscle contraction, more motor units must be activated; to lift a heavy weight, more active muscle fibres are required than to lift a lighter one. Muscle tone is a sustained, partial muscle contraction that allows maintenance of posture without fatiguing the muscles involved. For instance, keeping the head upright requires constant activity of the muscles of the neck and shoulders. Groups of muscle fibres within these muscles take it in turns to contract, so that at any one time some fibres are contracted and others are resting. This allows the effort required to hold the head upright to be distributed throughout the muscles involved. Good muscle tone protects joints and gives a muscle firmness and shape, even when relaxed.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="muscle-fatigue">Muscle fatigue<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#muscle-fatigue" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>To work at sustained levels, muscles need an adequate supply of oxygen and fuel such as glucose. Fatigue occurs when a muscle works at a level that exceeds these supplies. The muscle response decreases with fatigue.</p>
<p>The chemical energy (ATP) that muscles require is usually derived from the breakdown of carbohydrate and fat;
protein may be used if supplies of fat and carbohydrate are exhausted. An adequate oxygen supply is needed to release all the energy stored within these fuel molecules fully; without it, the body uses anaerobic metabolic pathways (p. 344) that are less efficient and lead to lactic acid production. Fatigue and muscle pain resulting from inadequate oxygen supply, as in strenuous exercise, occurs when lactic acid accumulates in working muscles. Fatigue may also occur because energy stores are exhausted or due to physical injury to muscle, which may follow prolonged episodes of strenuous activity, e.g. marathon running.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="muscle-recovery">Muscle recovery<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#muscle-recovery" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>After exercise, muscle needs a period of time to recover, to replenish its ATP and glycogen stores and to repair any damaged fibres. For some time following exercise, depending on the degree of exertion, the oxygen debt remains (an</p>
<p>extended period of increased oxygen demand), as the body converts lactic acid to pyruvic acid and replaces its energy stores.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="factors-affecting-skeletal-muscle-performance">Factors affecting skeletal muscle performance<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#factors-affecting-skeletal-muscle-performance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Skeletal muscle performs better when it is regularly exercised. Training improves endurance and power. Anaerobic training, such as weightlifting, increases muscle bulk because it increases the size of individual fibres within the muscle (hypertrophy).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-action-of-skeletal-muscles">The action of skeletal muscles<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-action-of-skeletal-muscles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In order to move a body part the muscle or its tendon must stretch across at least one joint. When it contracts, the muscle then pulls one bone towards another. For example, when the elbow is bent during flexion of the forearm, the main mover is biceps brachii, which is anchored on the scapula at one end and on the radius at the other. When it contracts, its shortening pulls on the radius, moving the forearm up towards the upper arm and bending the elbow.</p>
<p>This example also illustrates another feature of muscle arrangement: that of antagonistic pairs. Many muscles/ muscle groups of the body are arranged so that their actions oppose one another. Using the example of bending the elbow, when the main flexors on the front of the upper arm contract, the muscles at the back of the upper arm must simultaneously relax to prevent injury.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="isometric-and-isotonic-contraction">Isometric and isotonic contraction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#isometric-and-isotonic-contraction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Contraction of a muscle usually results in its shortening, as happens, for instance, to the biceps muscle if the forearm is used to pick up a cup. The power generated by the muscle is used to lift the manageable weight, and tension in the muscle remains constant. In this situation the contraction is said to be isotonic (isomeaning same and -tonic meaning</p>
<p>Table 16.7 Muscle terminology</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;">Characteristic</th><th style="text-align: left;">Example</th><th style="text-align: left;">Comment</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Shape</td><td style="text-align: left;">Trapezius</td><td style="text-align: left;">Trapezium-shaped</td></tr></tbody></table>

<p>Movement Extensor carpi Attached to the carpal bones of the wrist and ulnaris the ulna, and extends the wrist
produced</p>
<p>Number of points of Biceps brachii

attachment

<p>Bones to which Carpi radialis Attached to the carpal bones of the wrist and muscle is attached muscles the radius of the forearm
tension). However, imagine trying to lift an 80 kg man with one hand. Most people would be unable to perform this task, but the muscles of the arm and shoulder would still be working hard as they attempted it. In this situation, because the resistance from the man's weight is too great for him to be moved by the efforts of the lifter, the muscles would be unable to shorten, and the power generated increases the muscle tension instead. This is isometric contraction (isomeaning same and -metric meaning length).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="muscle-terminology">Muscle terminology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#muscle-terminology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Muscles are named according to various characteristics (Table 16.7), and becoming familiar with the principal ones makes it much easier to identify unfamiliar muscles.</p>
<p>The origin of a muscle is (usually) its proximal attachment; this is generally the bone that remains still when the muscle contracts, giving it an anchor to pull against.</p>
<p>The insertion is (usually) the distal attachment site, generally on the bone that is moved when the muscle contracts.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="principal-skeletal-muscles">Principal skeletal muscles<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#principal-skeletal-muscles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This section considers the main muscles that move the limbs, as well as the major muscles of the face and neck, back, chest, pelvic floor and abdominal wall.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="muscles-of-the-face-and-neck">Muscles of the face and neck<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#muscles-of-the-face-and-neck" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These are shown in Fig. 16.60.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="muscles-of-the-face">Muscles of the face<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#muscles-of-the-face" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Facial muscles change facial expression, and move the lower jaw during chewing and speaking. Only the main muscles are described here. Except where indicated, the muscles are present in pairs, one on each side.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-5e64777a.jpeg" alt="img-212.jpeg"></p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="occipitofrontalis-unpaired">Occipitofrontalis (unpaired)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#occipitofrontalis-unpaired" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This consists of a posterior muscular part over the occipital bone (occipitalis), an anterior part over the frontal bone (frontalis) and an extensive flat tendon or aponeurosis that stretches over the dome of the skull and joins the two muscular parts. It raises the eyebrows.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="levator-palpebrae-superioris">Levator palpebrae superioris<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#levator-palpebrae-superioris" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This muscle extends from the posterior part of the orbital cavity to the upper eyelid. It raises the eyelid.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="orbicularis-oculi">Orbicularis oculi<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#orbicularis-oculi" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This muscle surrounds the eye, eyelid and orbital cavity. It closes the eye and, when strongly contracted, 'screws up' the eyes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="buccinator">Buccinator<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#buccinator" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This flat muscle of the cheek draws the cheeks in towards the teeth in chewing and in forcible expulsion of air from the mouth (the 'trumpeter's muscle').</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="orbicularis-oris-unpaired">Orbicularis oris (unpaired)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#orbicularis-oris-unpaired" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This muscle surrounds the mouth and blends with the muscles of the cheeks. It closes the lips and, when strongly contracted, shapes the mouth for whistling.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="masseter">Masseter<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#masseter" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This broad muscle extends from the zygomatic arch to the angle of the jaw. In chewing it draws the mandible up to the maxilla, closing the jaw and exerting considerable pressure on the food.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="temporalis">Temporalis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#temporalis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This muscle covers the squamous part of the temporal bone. It passes behind the zygomatic arch to be inserted into the coronoid process of the mandible. It closes the mouth and assists with chewing.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pterygoid">Pterygoid<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pterygoid" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This muscle extends from the sphenoid bone to the mandible. It closes the mouth and pulls the lower jaw forwards.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="muscles-of-the-neck">Muscles of the neck<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#muscles-of-the-neck" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There are many muscles in the neck but only the two largest are considered here.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="sternocleidomastoid">Sternocleidomastoid<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sternocleidomastoid" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This muscle arises from the manubrium of the sternum and the clavicle, and extends upwards to the mastoid process of the temporal bone. It assists in turning the head from side to side and is also an accessory muscle in respiration. When the muscle on one side contracts, it draws the head towards the shoulder. When both contract at the same time, they flex the cervical vertebrae, or draw the sternum and clavicles upwards when the head is maintained in a fixed position, e.g. in forced respiration.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="trapezius">Trapezius<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#trapezius" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This muscle covers the shoulder and the back of the neck. The upper attachment is to the occipital protuberance, the medial attachment is to the transverse processes of the cervical and thoracic vertebrae, and the lateral attachment is to the clavicle and to the spinous and acromion processes of the scapula. It pulls the head backwards, squares the shoulders and controls the movements of the scapula when the shoulder joint is in use.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="muscles-of-the-trunk">Muscles of the trunk<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#muscles-of-the-trunk" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These muscles stabilise the association between the appendicular and axial skeletons at the pectoral girdle. They also stabilise, and allow movement of, the shoulders and upper arms.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="muscles-of-the-back">Muscles of the back<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#muscles-of-the-back" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There are six pairs of large muscles in the back, in addition to those forming the posterior abdominal wall (Figs 16.61-16.63). The arrangement of these muscles is the same on each side of the vertebral column. They are:</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-fb8f7956.jpeg" alt="img-213.jpeg"></p>
<p>Occipital bone
Ligamentum nuchae Teres minor
"eres
7th cervical vertebra Trapezius
Erector
spinae
12th thoracic vertebra
5th lumbar vertebra
Gluteus
medius
Gluteus
maximus
Latissimus</p>
<p>dorsi
External
oblique
Iliac crest</p>
<ul>
<li>trapezius (see earlier)</li>
<li>latissimus dorsi</li>
<li>teres major</li>
<li>psoas (p. 465)</li>
<li>quadratus lumborum</li>
<li>sacrospinalis.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="latissimus-dorsi">Latissimus dorsi<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#latissimus-dorsi" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This muscle arises from the posterior part of the iliac crest and the spinous processes of the lumbar and lower thoracic vertebrae. It passes upwards across the back then under the arm to be inserted into the bicipital groove of the humerus. It adducts, medially rotates and extends the arm.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="teres-major">Teres major<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#teres-major" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This muscle originates from the inferior angle of the scapula and is inserted into the humerus just below the shoulder joint. It extends, adducts and medially rotates the arm.</p>
<p>Fig. 16.61 The main muscles of the back. Right side.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="quadratus-lumborum">Quadratus lumborum<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#quadratus-lumborum" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This muscle originates from the iliac crest and then it passes upwards, parallel and close to the vertebral column, and is inserted into the 12th rib (Fig. 16.62).
Together the two muscles fix the lower rib during respiration and cause extension of the vertebral column (bending backwards). If one muscle contracts, it causes lateral flexion of the lumbar region of the vertebral column.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="sacrospinalis-erector-spinae">Sacrospinalis (erector spinae)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sacrospinalis-erector-spinae" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is a group of muscles lying between the spinous and transverse processes of the vertebrae (Figs 16.61 and 16.63). They originate from the sacrum and are</p>
<p>finally inserted into the occipital bone. Their contraction causes extension of the vertebral column.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-51a36f21.jpeg" alt="img-214.jpeg"></p>
<p>Transversus abdominis (cut)

Psoas minor

Fig. 16.62 The deep muscles of the posterior abdominal wall. Anterior view.

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="peritoneal-cavity">PERITONEAL CAVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#peritoneal-cavity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
