Disorders of the breast 508
The ability to reproduce is one of the properties distinguishing living from nonliving matter. The more primitive the animal, the simpler the process of reproduction. In mammals, including humans, the process is one of sexual</p>
<p>reproduction, in which the male and female organs differ anatomically and physiologically, and the new individual develops from the</p>
<p>Diseases of the male reproductive system 509</p>
<p>Infections of the penis ..... 509
Infections of the urethra ..... 509
Disorders of the epididymis and testes ..... 509
Disorders of the prostate gland ..... 510
Disorders of the male breast ..... 510
Male infertility ..... 510
Review and revise ..... 510
Q Animations
18.1 Female external genitalia ..... 488
18.2 Vestibular glands ..... 488
18.3 Female reproductive ducts ..... 489
18.4 Ovaries ..... 493
18.5 Menstrual cycle ..... 496</p>
<p>18.6 Ovarian cycle ..... 496
18.7 Breasts ..... 497
18.8 Male reproductive system ..... 498
18.9 Testes ..... 499
18.10 Spermatozoa ..... 500
18.11 Male accessory sex glands ..... 500
18.12 Male external genitalia ..... 501
fusion of two different sex cells (gametes). The male gametes are called spermatozoa (singular: spermatozoon) and the female gametes are called ova (singular: ovum).</p>
<p>The first sections of this chapter explain the structure and functions of the female and male reproductive systems, including the production of gametes. The next sections give</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="chapter-notes">Chapter Notes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chapter-notes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Each of a pair of homologous chromosomes contains genes for the same traits. For example, the ability to roll one's tongue is coded for on a single gene. Because one chromosome of each pair is inherited from the father and one from the mother, an individual has two genes controlling the ability to roll the tongue. Such paired genes are called alleles. Corresponding alleles contain genes concerned with the same trait, but they need not be identical. An individual may have:</li>
<li>two identical forms of the gene (homozygous)</li>
<li>two different forms of the gene (heterozygous).</li>
<li>One copy of the tongue-rolling gene may code for the ability to roll the tongue, but the corresponding gene on the other chromosome of the pair may be a different form and code for inability to tongue roll. This simple example involves only two forms of the same gene but other characteristics are more</li>
</ul>
<p>complex. Eye colour is a diverse trait with a wide range of pigment colours and patterns possible, and is controlled by more than one gene.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="chapter">CHAPTER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chapter" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-reproductive-systems">The reproductive systems<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-reproductive-systems" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>a brief overview of fetal development, and the effects of ageing on reproductive function. Finally, some significant reproductive disorders are described.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="female-reproductive-system">Female reproductive system<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#female-reproductive-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe the main structures of the external genitalia</li>
<li>explain the structure and function of the vagina</li>
<li>describe the location, structure and function of the uterus and the uterine tubes</li>
<li>discuss the process of ovulation and the hormones that control it</li>
<li>outline the changes that occur in the female at puberty, including the physiology of menstruation</li>
<li>describe the structure and function of the female breast.</li>
</ul>
<p>The functions of the female reproductive system are:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>formation of ova</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>reception of spermatozoa</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>provision of suitable environments for fertilisation and fetal development</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>parturition (childbirth)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>lactation, the production of breast milk, which provides complete nourishment for the baby in its early life.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>The female reproductive organs, or genitalia, include both external and internal organs (Fig. 18.1).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="6a69a472">External genitalia (vulva) <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">â–¡</mi><mn>18.1</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\square 18.1</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.675em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">â–¡</span><span class="mord">18.1</span></span></span></span></span><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6a69a472" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-3716ac1b.jpeg" alt="img-241.jpeg"></p>
<p>Uterine tube
Ovary Uterus
Vagina
Ovary
Uterine tube
Uterus
B
Figure 18.1 The female reproductive organs. (A) Viewed from the front. (B) Viewed from the side.</p>
<p>The cleft between the labia minora is the vestibule. The vagina, urethra and ducts of the greater vestibular glands open into the vestibule.</p>
<p>The external genitalia (Fig. 18.2) are known collectively as the vulva, and consist of the labia majora and labia minora, the clitoris, the vaginal orifice, the vestibule, the hymen and the vestibular glands (Bartholin's glands).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="clitoris">Clitoris<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clitoris" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The clitoris corresponds to the penis in the male and contains sensory nerve endings and erectile tissue.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="labia-majora">Labia majora<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#labia-majora" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These are the two large folds forming the boundary of the vulva. They are composed of fibrous tissue and fat, covered in skin, and contain large numbers of sebaceous and eccrine sweat glands. Anteriorly the folds join in front of the symphysis pubis, and posteriorly they merge with the skin of the perineum. At puberty, hair grows on the mons pubis and on the lateral surfaces of the labia majora.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="labia-minora">Labia minora<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#labia-minora" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These are two smaller folds of skin between the labia majora, containing numerous sebaceous and eccrine sweat glands.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vestibular-glands-q18-2">Vestibular glands Q18.2<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vestibular-glands-q18-2" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The vestibular glands (Bartholin's glands) are situated one on each side near the vaginal opening. They are about the size of a small pea and their ducts open into the vestibule immediately lateral to the attachment of the hymen. They secrete mucus that keeps the vulva moist.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="perineum">Perineum<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#perineum" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The perineum is a roughly triangular area extending from the base of the labia minora to the anal canal. It consists of connective tissue, muscle and fat. It gives attachment to the muscles of the pelvic floor (see Fig. 16.65).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="learning-subcones">Learning subcones<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#learning-subcones" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="7">7<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Mons pubis
Hymen Opening of duct of Anus
vestibular gland
Figure 18.2 The external genitalia of the female.
Blood supply, lymph drainage and nerve supply Arterial supply</p>
<p>This is by branches from the internal pudendal arteries, which branch from the internal iliac arteries, and by the external pudendal arteries, which branch from the femoral arteries.</p>
<p>Venous drainage
This forms a large plexus, which eventually drains into the internal iliac veins.
Lymph drainage
This is through the superficial inguinal nodes.
Nerve supply
This is by branches from pudendal nerves.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="internal-genitalia">Internal genitalia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#internal-genitalia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The internal organs of the female reproductive system (Figs 18.3 and 18.4) lie in the pelvic cavity and consist of the vagina, uterus, two uterine tubes and two ovaries.</p>
<p>Vagina <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">â–¡</mi><mn>18.3</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\square 18.3</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.675em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">â–¡</span><span class="mord">18.3</span></span></span></span></span>
The vagina is a fibromuscular tube lined with stratified squamous epithelium (see Fig. 3.39) opening into the vestibule at its distal end, and with the uterine cervix
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-53e85372.jpeg" alt="img-242.jpeg"></p>

Pubic symphysis
Urethra
Sacrum
Uterus
Rectouterine pouch (of Douglas)
Posterior fornix of vagina Cervix
Anterior fornix of vagina
Rectum</p>
<p>Labium minus Labium majus
Anus
Figure 18.3 Lateral view of the female reproductive organs in the pelvis and their associated structures.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="suspensory-ligament-of-ovary">Suspensory ligament of ovary<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#suspensory-ligament-of-ovary" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Fundus of uterus
Ovarian artery and vein
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-6732489a.jpeg" alt="img-244.jpeg"></p>
<p>Ampulla
Vagina showing rugae

(peritoneum)</p>
<p>Uterine artery and vein Cervical canal Cervix

-<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>â‹…</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\cdot</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4445em;"></span><span class="mord">â‹…</span></span></span></span></span>* Mesovarium
Isthmus

cavity</p>
<ul>
<li>Body of uterus</li>
<li>Endometrium</li>
</ul>
<p>Myometrium
Broad ligament
Infundibulum with fimbriae
Round
ligament
Figure 18.4 The fennale reproductive organs in the pelvis.
protruding into its proximal end. It runs obliquely upwards and backwards at an angle of about 45 degrees between the bladder in front and the rectum and anus behind. In the adult, the anterior wall is about 7.5 cm long and the posterior wall about 9 cm long. The difference is due to the angle of insertion of the cervix through the anterior wall.</p>
<p>Hymen
The hymen is a thin layer of mucous membrane that stretches across the vaginal lumen, just inside the external opening. It is normally incomplete to allow for passage of menstrual flow, and is stretched or completely torn away by sexual intercourse, insertion of a tampon or childbirth.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="structure">structure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#structure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The vaginal wall has three layers: an outer covering of areolar tissue, a middle layer of smooth muscle and an inner lining of stratified squamous epithelium that forms ridges or rugae. It has no secretory glands but the surface is kept moist by cervical</p>
<p>secretions. Between puberty and the menopause, Lactobacillus acidophilus, a bacterium that secretes lactic acid, is normally present, maintaining the pH
between 4.9 and 3.5. The acidity inhibits the growth of most other microorganisms that may contaminate the vagina from the perineum or during sexual intercourse.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="blood-supply-lymph-drainage-and-nerve-supply-arterial-supply">Blood supply, lymph drainage and nerve supply Arterial supply<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blood-supply-lymph-drainage-and-nerve-supply-arterial-supply" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>An arterial plexus is formed round the vagina, derived from the uterine and vaginal arteries, which are branches of the internal iliac arteries.</p>
<p>Venous drainage
A venous plexus, situated in the muscular wall, drains into the internal iliac veins.
Lymph drainage
This is through the deep and superficial iliac glands.
Nerve suppiy
This consists of parasympathetic fibres from the sacral outflow, sympathetic fibres from the lumbar outflow and somatic sensory fibres from the pudendal nerves.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="functions">Functions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The vagina acts as the receptacle for the penis during sexual intercourse (coitus), and provides an elastic passageway through which the baby passes during childbirth.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="uterus">uterus<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#uterus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The uterus is a hollow, muscular, pear-shaped organ, flattened anteroposteriorly. It lies in the pelvic cavity between the urinary bladder and the rectum (see Fig. 18.3).</p>
<p>In most women, it leans forwards (anteversion), and is bent forwards (anteflexion) almost at right angles to the vagina, so that its anterior wall rests partly against the bladder below, forming the vesicouterine pouch between the two organs.</p>
<p>When the body is upright, the uterus lies almost horizontally. It is about 7.5 cm long and 5 cm wide, and its walls are about 2.5 cm thick. It weighs between 30 and 40 g . The three main parts of the uterus are the fundus, body and cervix (see Fig. 18.4).</p>
<p>Fundus</p>
<p>This is the dome-shaped part of the uterus above the openings of the uterine tubes.
Body
This occupies the upper two-thirds of the uterus. It is pear-shaped, and narrowest interiorly at the internal os, where it is continuous with the cervix.</p>
<p>Cervix ('neck' of the uterus)
This is the narrowest portion and is usually about 2.5 cm long. It protrudes through the anterior wall of the vagina, opening into it at the external os.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="structure">Structure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#structure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The walls of the uterus are composed of three layers of tissue: perimetrium, myometrium and endometrium (Fig. 18.5).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="perimetrium">Perimetrium<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#perimetrium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is peritoneum, which is distributed differently on the various surfaces of the uterus (see Fig. 18.3). It can be imagined as a blanket draped over the uterus, uterine tubes and ovaries from above, so it mainly covers the anterior, upper and posterior surfaces of the uterus.</p>
<p>Anteriorly, it lies over the fundus and the body, where it is folded on to the upper surface of the urinary bladder. This fold of peritoneum forms the vesicouterine pouch.</p>
<p>Posteriorly, the peritoneum covers the fundus, the body and the cervix, then it folds back on to the rectum to form the rectouterine pouch (of Douglas).</p>
<p>Laterally, only the fundus is covered because the peritoneum forms a double fold with the uterine tubes in the upper free border. This double fold is the broad ligament, which, at its lateral ends, attaches the uterus to the sides of the pelvis.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-7eac2628.jpeg" alt="img-245.jpeg"></p>
<p>Basal layer</p>
<p>Uterine
artery
Perimetrium
Functional layer
Endometrial glands
Columnar
epithelium
Figure 18.5 Layers of the uterine wall. Green line, boundary between the functional and basal layers of the endometrium.</p>
<p>Myometrium
This is the thickest layer of tissue in the uterine wall. It is a mass of smooth muscle fibres interlaced with areolar tissue, blood vessels and nerves.</p>
<p>Endometrium
This is columnar epithelium covering a layer of connective tissue containing abundant mucus-secreting tubular glands. It is richly supplied with blood by spiral arteries, branches of the uterine artery. It is divided into two layers:</p>
<ul>
<li>The functional layer is the upper layer and it thickens and becomes rich in blood vessels in the first half of the menstrual cycle. If the ovum is not fertilised and does not implant, this layer is shed during menstruation.</li>
<li>The basal layer lies next to the myometrium and is not lost during menstruation. It is the permanent layer, from which the fresh functional layer is regenerated during each cycle.</li>
</ul>
<p>The upper two-thirds of the cervical canal is lined with this mucous membrane. Lower down, however, the mucosa changes, becoming stratified squamous epithelium, which merges with the lining of the vagina itself.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="blood-supply-lymph-drainage-and-nerve-supply-arterial-supply">Blood supply, lymph drainage and nerve supply Arterial supply<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blood-supply-lymph-drainage-and-nerve-supply-arterial-supply" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is by the uterine arteries, branches of the internal iliac arteries. They pass up the lateral aspects of the uterus</p>
<p>between the two layers of the broad ligaments. They supply the uterus and uterine tubes, and join with the ovarian arteries to supply the ovaries.</p>
<p>Venous drainage
The veins follow the same route as the arteries and eventually drain into the internal iliac veins.</p>
<p>Lymph drainage
Deep and superficial lymph vessels drain lymph from the uterus and the uterine tubes to the aortic lymph nodes and groups of nodes associated with the iliac blood vessels.</p>
<p>Nerve supply
The nerves supplying the uterus and the uterine tubes consist of parasympathetic fibres from the sacral outflow and sympathetic fibres from the lumbar outflow.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="supporting-structures">Supporting structures<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#supporting-structures" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The uterus is supported in the pelvic cavity by surrounding organs, muscles of the pelvic floor and ligaments that suspend it from the walls of the pelvis (Fig. 18.6).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="broad-ligaments">Broad ligaments<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#broad-ligaments" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These are formed by a double fold of peritoneum, one on each side of the uterus. They hang down from the uterine tubes as though draped over them and at their lateral ends they are attached to the sides of the pelvis. The uterine tubes are enclosed in the upper free border and near the lateral ends they penetrate the posterior wall of the broad ligament and open into the peritoneal cavity. The ovaries are attached to the posterior wall, one on each side. Blood and lymph vessels and nerves pass to the uterus and uterine tubes between the layers of the broad ligaments.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="round-ligaments">Round ligaments<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#round-ligaments" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These are bands of muscular and fibrous tissue between the two layers of broad ligament, one on each side of the uterus. They pass to the sides of the pelvis, then through the inguinal canal, to end by fusing with the labia majora.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="uterosacral-ligaments">Uterosacral ligaments<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#uterosacral-ligaments" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These originate from the posterior walls of the cervix and vagina and extend backwards, one on each side of the rectum, to the sacrum.</p>
<p>Transverse cervical (cardinal) ligaments</p>
<p>These extend one from each side of the cervix and vagina to the side walls of the pelvis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pubocervical-ligament">Pubocervical ligament<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pubocervical-ligament" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This extends forward from the transverse cervical ligaments on each side of the bladder and is attached to the posterior surface of the pubic bones.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="suspensory">Suspensory<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#suspensory" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-63ce6cbb.jpeg" alt="img-246.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 18.6 The main ligaments supporting the uterus. (A) Front and lateral views. (B) The floor of the pelvis, viewed from above.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="functions">Functions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>After puberty, the endometrium goes through a regular monthly cycle of changes, the menstrual cycle, under the control of hypothalamic and anterior pituitary hormones (Ch. 9). The menstrual cycle prepares the uterus to receive, nourish and protect a fertilised ovum. The cycle is usually regular, lasting between 26 and 30 days. If the ovum is not fertilised, the functional layer of the uterine lining is shed, and a new cycle begins with a short period of vaginal bleeding (menstruation).</p>
<p>If the ovum is fertilised, the zygote (p. 503) embeds itself in the uterine wall. The uterine muscle grows to accommodate the developing baby, which is called an embryo during its first 8 weeks, and a fetus for the remainder of the pregnancy. Uterine secretions nourish the embryo before it implants</p>
<p>in the endometrium, and after implantation the rapidly expanding ball of cells is nourished by the endometrial cells themselves. This is sufficient for only the first few weeks and the placenta takes over thereafter (Ch. 5). The placenta, which is attached to the fetus by the umbilical cord, is also firmly attached to the wall of the uterus, and is the structure that supplies the growing baby with oxygen and nutrients, and allows it to get rid of its wastes. The placenta also has an important endocrine function during pregnancy. It secretes high levels of progesterone, which prevents the muscular uterine walls from contracting in response to the progressive uterine stretching as the fetus grows. At term (the end of pregnancy) the hormone oestrogen, which increases uterine contractility, becomes the predominant sex hormone in the blood. Additionally, oxytocin is released from the posterior pituitary, and also stimulates contraction of the uterine muscle. Oxytocin release is controlled by positive feedback (see also Fig. 9.5). During labour the uterus forcefully expels the baby with powerful rhythmical contractions.
uterine tubes
The uterine (Fallopian) tubes (see Fig. 18.4) are about 10 cm long and extend from the sides of the uterus between the body and the fundus. They lie in the upper free border of the broad ligament and their trumpet-shaped lateral ends penetrate the posterior wall, opening into the peritoneal cavity close to the ovaries. The end of each tube has finger-like projections called fimbriae. The longest of these is the ovarian fimbria, which is in close association with the ovary.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="structure">Structure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#structure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The uterine tubes are covered with peritoneum (broad ligament), have a middle layer of smooth muscle and are lined with ciliated epithelium. Blood and nerve supply and lymphatic drainage are as for the uterus.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="functions">Functions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The uterine tubes propel the ovum from the ovary to the uterus by peristalsis and ciliary movement. The secretions of the uterine tube nourish both ovum and spermatozoa. Fertilisation of the ovum usually takes place in the uterine tube, and the zygote is propelled into the uterus for implantation.</p>
<p>Ovaries <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">â–¡</mi><mn>18.4</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\square 18.4</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.675em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">â–¡</span><span class="mord">18.4</span></span></span></span></span>
The ovaries (see Fig. 18.4) are the female gonads (glands producing sex hormones and the ova), and they lie in a shallow fossa on the lateral walls of the pelvis. They are <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>2.5</mn><mo>âˆ’</mo><mn>3.5</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2.5-3.5 \mathrm{~cm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">2.5</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">âˆ’</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">3.5</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">cm</span></span></span></span></span></span> long, 2 cm wide and 1 cm thick. Each is attached to the upper part of the uterus by the ovarian ligament and to the back of the broad ligament by a broad band of tissue, the mesovarium. Blood vessels and nerves pass to the ovary through the mesovarium (Fig. 18.7).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="structure">Structure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#structure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The ovaries have two layers of tissue.
Medulla
This lies in the centre and consists of fibrous tissue, blood vessels and nerves.
Germinal epithelium Cortex Medulla
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-e8216b38.jpeg" alt="img-247.jpeg"></p>
<p>Mesovarium
Ovarian ligament
Primordial follicles
Blood vessels
Ovum
Fibrous corpus albicans
Day 28
Fully formed corpus luteum
Day 20
Developing corpus luteum
Ovum
Ovulation Day 14
Mature ovarian (Graafian) follicle
Day 12</p>
<p>Figure 18.7 A section of an ovary showing the stages of development of one ovarian follicle.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cortex">Cortex<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cortex" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This surrounds the medulla. It has a framework of connective tissue, or stroma, covered by germinal epithelium. It contains ovarian follicles in various stages of maturity, each of which contains an ovum. Before puberty the ovaries are inactive but the stroma already contains immature (primordial) follicles, which the female has from birth. During the childbearing years, about every 28 days, one or more ovarian follicle (Graafian follicle) matures, ruptures and releases its ovum into the peritoneal cavity. This is called ovulation and it occurs during most menstrual cycles (Fig. 18.8; see also Fig. 18.7). Following ovulation the ruptured follicle develops into the corpus luteum (meaning 'yellow body'), which in turn will leave a small permanent scar of fibrous tissue called the corpus albicans (meaning 'white body') on the surface of the ovary.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="blood-supply-lymph-drainage-and-nerve-supply-arterial-supply">Blood supply, lymph drainage and nerve supply Arterial supply<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blood-supply-lymph-drainage-and-nerve-supply-arterial-supply" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is by the ovarian arteries, which branch from the abdominal aorta just below the renal arteries.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="venous-drainage">Venous drainage<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#venous-drainage" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is into a plexus of veins behind the uterus, from which the ovarian veins arise. The right ovarian vein opens into the inferior vena cava and the left into the left renal vein.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="lymph-drainage">Lymph drainage<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lymph-drainage" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is to the lateral aortic and preaortic lymph nodes. The lymph vessels follow the same route as the arteries.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="nerve-supply">Nerve supply<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nerve-supply" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The ovaries are supplied by parasympathetic nerves from the sacral outflow and sympathetic nerves from the lumbar outflow.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="functions">Functions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>At birth the ovaries of a female child hold over a million immature follicles, although many of them die before the onset of puberty. Their maturation is controlled by the hypothalamus and the anterior pituitary gland, which releases gonadotrophins (follicle stimulating hormone, FSH, and luteinising hormone, LH), both of which act on the ovary. In addition the ovary has endocrine functions and releases hormones essential to the physiological changes during the reproductive cycle. The source of these hormones - oestrogen, progesterone and inhibin - is the follicle itself. During the first half of the cycle, while the ovum is developing</p>
<p>within the follicle, the follicle secretes increasing amounts of oestrogen. However, after ovulation, the corpus luteum secretes primarily progesterone, with some oestrogen and inhibin (Fig. 18.9). The significance of this is discussed under the menstrual cycle (see later).
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-f3f70e67.jpeg" alt="img-248.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 18.8 Ovulation. Scanning electron micrograph of an ovum (pink) emerging through the surface of the ovary (brown). (Professors PM Motta and J Van Blerkom/Science Photo Library. Reproduced with permission.)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-8c0d4d35.jpeg" alt="img-249.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 18.9 Female reproductive hormones and target tissues.

Progesterone</p>
<p>Luteinising
, hormone (LH)
V. <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mspace width="2em"></mspace></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\qquad</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0em;"></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 2em;"></span></span></span></span></span>
Follicle stimulating hormone (FSH)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-a2c10a18.jpeg" alt="img-250.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="puberty-in-the-female">Puberty in the female<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#puberty-in-the-female" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Puberty is the age at which the internal reproductive organs reach maturity, usually between the ages of 12 and 14. This is called the menarche and marks the beginning of the childbearing period. Puberty is characterised by a rise in the production of reproductive hormones and initiation of the female reproductive cycle. Ovarian activity is controlled by the gonadotrophins from the anterior pituitary: FSH and LH. Under the influence of the gonadotrophins, the ovaries begin to secrete oestrogens, which are the main stimulus for the development of the physical changes associated with puberty. These changes are also called the secondary sexual characteristics and include:</p>
<ul>
<li>maturation of the uterus, uterine tubes and ovaries</li>
<li>development and enlargement of the breasts</li>
<li>growth of pubic and axillary hair</li>
<li>increase in height and widening of the pelvis</li>
<li>increased fat deposition in the subcutaneous tissue, especially at the hips and breasts.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-reproductive-cycle">The reproductive cycle<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-reproductive-cycle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is a series of events, occurring regularly in females every 26-30 days throughout the childbearing period between menarche and menopause (Fig. 18.10). The cycle consists of a series of changes taking place concurrently in the ovaries and uterine lining, stimulated by changes in blood concentrations of hormones (Fig. 18.10B and D). Hormones secreted during the cycle are regulated by negative feedback mechanisms.</p>
<p>The hypothalamus secretes luteinising hormone releasing hormone (LHRH), which stimulates the anterior pituitary to secrete (see Table 9.1):</p>
<ul>
<li>FSH, which promotes the maturation of ovarian follicles and the secretion of oestrogen, leading to ovulation.</li>
</ul>
<p>FSH is therefore predominantly active in the first half of the cycle. Its secretion is suppressed once ovulation has taken place, to prevent other follicles maturing during the current cycle</p>
<ul>
<li>LH, which triggers ovulation, and stimulates the development of the corpus luteum and the secretion of progesterone.</li>
</ul>
<p>The hypothalamus responds to changes in the blood levels of oestrogen and progesterone. It is stimulated by high levels of oestrogen alone (as happens in the first half of the cycle) but suppressed by oestrogen and progesterone together (as happens in the second half of the cycle).</p>
<p>The average length of the cycle is about 28 days. By convention, the days of the cycle are numbered from the beginning of the menstrual phase, which usually lasts about 4 days. This is followed by the proliferative phase (approximately 10 days), then by the secretory phase (about 14 days).</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-4cd93117.jpeg" alt="img-251.jpeg"></p>
<p>11428
D
Days
Figure 18.10 Summary of one female reproductive cycle. (A) Ovarian cycle: maturation of follicle and development of corpus luteum. (B) Anterior pituitary cycle: luteinising hormone (LH) and follicle stimulating hormone (FSH) levels. (C) Uterine cycle: menstrual, proliferative and secretory phases. (D) Ovarian hormone cycle: oestrogen, progesterone and inhibin levels.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="menstrual-phase">Menstrual phase<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#menstrual-phase" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>When the ovum is not fertilised, the corpus luteum starts to degenerate. (In the event of pregnancy, the corpus luteum is supported by human chorionic gonadotrophin, or hCG, secreted by the developing embryo.) Progesterone and oestrogen levels therefore fall, and the functional layer of the endometrium, which is dependent on high levels of these ovarian hormones, is shed in menstruation (Fig. 18.IOC). The menstrual flow consists of the secretions from endometrial
glands, endometrial cells, blood from the degenerating capillaries and the unfertilised ovum.</p>
<p>During the menstrual phase, levels of oestrogen and progesterone are very low because the corpus luteum, which was active during the second half of the previous cycle, has degenerated. This means the hypothalamus and anterior pituitary can</p>
<p>resume their cyclical activity, and levels of FSH begin to rise, initiating a new cycle.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="proliferative-phase">Proliferative phase<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#proliferative-phase" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>At this stage, one or more ovarian follicles, stimulated by FSH, are growing towards maturity and are producing oestrogen, which stimulates proliferation of the functional layer of the endometrium in preparation for the reception of a fertilised ovum. The endometrium thickens, becoming very vascular and rich in mucussecreting glands. Rising levels of oestrogen are responsible for triggering a surge of LH approximately midcycle. This LH surge triggers ovulation. Usually one follicle ruptures and releases its ovum, which is now called a secondary oocyte. This marks the end of the proliferative phase.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="secretory-phase">Secretory phase<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#secretory-phase" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>After ovulation, LH from the anterior pituitary stimulates development of the corpus luteum from the ruptured follicle, which produces progesterone, some oestrogen and inhibin. Under the influence of progesterone the endometrium becomes oedematous and the secretory glands produce increased amounts of watery mucus. This assists the motile spermatozoa through the uterus to the uterine tubes, where the ovum is usually fertilised. There is a similar increase in secretion of watery mucus by the glands of the uterine tubes and by cervical glands that lubricate the vagina.</p>
<p>The ovum may survive in a fertilisable form for a very short time after ovulation, probably as little as 8 hours. The spermatozoa, deposited in the vagina during intercourse, may be capable of fertilising the ovum for only about 24 hours, although they can survive for several days. This means that the period in each cycle during which fertilisation can occur is relatively short. Observable changes in the woman's body occur around the time of ovulation. Cervical mucus, normally thick and dry, becomes thin, elastic and watery, and body temperature rises by about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>1</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">âˆ˜</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1^{\circ} \mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">1</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">âˆ˜</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span> immediately following ovulation. Some women experience abdominal discomfort in the middle of the cycle, thought to correspond to rupture of the follicle and release of its contents into the abdominal cavity.</p>
<p>After ovulation the combination of progesterone,
oestrogen and inhibin from the corpus luteum suppresses the
hypothalamus and anterior pituitary, so FSH and LH levels
fall. Low FSH levels in the second half of the cycle prevent
further follicular development in case a pregnancy results
from the current cycle. If the ovum is not fertilised, falling LH</p>
<p>levels lead to degeneration and death of the corpus luteum, which is dependent on LH for survival. The resultant steady
decline in circulating oestrogen, progesterone and inhibin
leads to degeneration of the uterine lining and menstruation,
with the initiation of a new cycle.
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>496</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">âˆ§</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">496^{\wedge}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7519em;"></span><span class="mord">49</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">6</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7519em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">âˆ§</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></p>
<p>Table captionAnterior</p>
<p>Table captionpituitary</p>
<p>Luteinising hormone (LH)</p>
<p>Secretes progesterone (and some oestrogen), which support a subsequent pregnancy</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="140dc2cb"><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">â–¡</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\square</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.675em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">â–¡</span></span></span></span></span><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#140dc2cb" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Primary follicle in ovary containing immature ovum
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">f</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">âˆ§</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{f}^{\wedge}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7519em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.07778em;">f</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7519em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">âˆ§</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></p>
<p>Follicle stimulating

<p>Table captionSecretes human chorionic gonadotrophin
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">r</mi><msup><mo>âˆ’</mo><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">âˆ§</mo></msup><mspace width="1em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">r</mi><msup><mo>âˆ’</mo><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">âˆ§</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{r}-^{\wedge} \quad \mathrm{r}-^{\wedge}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8352em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">r</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin"><span class="mbin">âˆ’</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7519em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">âˆ§</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 1em;"></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8352em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">r</span><span class="mord"><span class="mbin">âˆ’</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7519em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">âˆ§</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></p>
<p>Embeds in uterine wall, Menstruation</p>
<p>L J L</p>
<p>Pregnancy
New cycle begins
Figure 18.11 Summary of the stages of development of the ovum and the associated hormones.</p>
<p>If the ovum is fertilised, there is no breakdown of the endometrium and no menstruation. The fertilised ovum (zygote) travels through the uterine tube to the uterus, where it becomes embedded in the wall and produces hCG, which is similar to anterior pituitary luteinising hormone. This hormone keeps the corpus luteum intact, enabling it to continue secreting progesterone and oestrogen for the first 3-4 months of the pregnancy, inhibiting the maturation of further ovarian follicles (Fig. 18.11). During that time the placenta develops and produces oestrogen, progesterone and gonadotrophins. 18.5,18.6</p>
<p>This is summarised in Fig. 18.11. Box 18.1 sums up the reproductive functions of oestrogen and progesterone.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="menopause">Menopause<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#menopause" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The menopause (climacteric) usually takes place between the ages of 45 and 55 years, marking the end of the childbearing period. It may occur suddenly or over a period of years, sometimes as long as 10 years, and is caused by a progressive reduction in oestrogen levels as the number of functional follicles in the ovaries declines with age. The ovaries gradually become less responsive to FSH and LH,</p>
<p>and ovulation and the menstrual cycle become irregular, eventually ceasing. Several other phenomena may occur at the same time, including:</p>
<p>Ovulation
(2017) 11200000</p>
<p>Box 18.1 Reproductive functions of oestrogen and progesterone
Oestrogen
Stimulates development of secondary sexual characteristics at puberty
Stimulates and supports thickening of uterine lining during proliferative phase
Triggers luteinising hormone (LH) surge mid-cycle, stimulating ovulation
Stimulates anterior pituitary secretion of follicle stimulating hormone (FSH) and LH in first half of cycle</p>
<p>Progesterone
Stimulates and supports thickening and increased glandular development of uterine lining during secretory phase</p>
<p>With oestrogen, inhibits secretion of FSH and LH from anterior pituitary in second half of cycle</p>
<ul>
<li>short-term unpredictable vasodilation with flushing, sweating and palpitations, causing discomfort and disturbance of the normal sleep pattern</li>
<li>shrinkage of the breasts</li>
<li>sparseness of axillary and pubic hair</li>
<li>atrophy of the sex organs</li>
<li>episodes of uncharacteristic behaviour, e.g. irritability, mood changes</li>
<li>gradual thinning of the skin</li>
<li>loss of bone mass, predisposing to osteoporosis (p. 468)</li>
<li>slow increase in blood cholesterol levels, which raises the risk of cardiovascular disease in postmenopausal women to that in males of the same age.</li>
</ul>
<p>Similar changes occur after bilateral irradiation or surgical removal of the ovaries.
Breasts <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">â–¡</mi><mn>18.7</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\square 18.7</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.675em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">â–¡</span><span class="mord">18.7</span></span></span></span></span></p>
<p>The breasts or mammary glands are accessory glands of the female reproductive system. They also exist in the male but only in a rudimentary form.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="structure">Structure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#structure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The mammary glands or breasts (Fig. 18.12) contain varying amounts of glandular tissue, supported by fatty tissue and fibrous connective tissue that anchor the breast to the chest wall.</p>
<p>Each breast contains about 20 lobes, each of which contains a number of glandular structures called lobules, where milk is produced. Lobules open into tiny lactiferous ducts, which drain milk towards the nipple. Supporting fatty and connective tissues run through the breast, surrounding
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-e86ea5b0.jpeg" alt="img-252.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 18.12 Structure of the breast. (A) Viewed from the front.
(B) Section viewed from the side.
the lobules, and the breast itself is covered in subcutaneous fat. In the lactating breast, glandular tissue proliferates (hyperplasia, see Fig. 3.29) to support milk production, and recedes again after lactation stops.</p>
<p>Nipple
This is a small conical eminence at the centre of the breast surrounded by a pigmented area, the areola. On the surface of the areola there are numerous sebaceous glands (Montgomery's tubercles), which lubricate the nipple during lactation.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="blood-supply-lymph-drainage-and-nerve-supply-arterial-supply">Blood supply, lymph drainage and nerve supply Arterial supply<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blood-supply-lymph-drainage-and-nerve-supply-arterial-supply" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The breasts are supplied with blood from the thoracic branches of the axillary arteries and from the internal mammary and intercostal arteries.</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;">Box 18.1 Reproductive functions of oestrogen and</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;">progesterone</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Oestrogen</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Stimulates development of secondary sexual</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">characteristics at puberty.</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Stimulates and supports thickening of uterine lining</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">during proliferative phase.</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Triggers luteinising hormone (LH) surge mid-cycle,</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">stimulating ovulation.</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Stimulates anterior pituitary secretion of follicle</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">stimulating hormone (FSH) and LH in first half of</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">cycle.</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Progesterone</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Stimulates and supports thickening and increased</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">glandular development of uterine lining during</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">secretory phase.</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">With oestrogen, inhibits secretion of FSH and LH</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">from anterior pituitary in second half of cycle.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Venous drainage
This is formed by an anastomotic circle round the base of the nipple, from which branches carry the venous blood to the circumference, and end in the axillary and mammary veins.</p>
<p>Lymph drainage
(See Fig. 6.1.) This is mainly into the superficial axillary lymph vessels and nodes. Lymph may drain through the internal mammary nodes if the superficial route is obstructed.</p>
<p>Nerve supply
The breasts are supplied by branches from the 4th, 5th and 6th thoracic nerves, which contain sympathetic fibres. There are numerous somatic sensory nerve endings in the breast, especially around the nipple. When these touch receptors are stimulated by sucking, impulses pass to the hypothalamus and secretion of the hormone oxytocin is increased, promoting the release of milk (p. 238).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="functions">Functions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In the female the breasts are small and immature until puberty. Thereafter they grow and develop under the influence of oestrogen and progesterone. During pregnancy, these hormones stimulate further growth. After the baby is born, the hormone prolactin (p. 237), from the anterior pituitary, stimulates the production of milk; oxytocin (p. 238), from the posterior pituitary, stimulates the release of milk in response to the stimulation of the nipple by the sucking baby, by a positive feedback mechanism.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="spot-check">SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>What is the function of the rugae in the vaginal wall?</li>
<li>What is the function of the middle layer of tissue in the uterine wall?</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="24b60af5">Male reproductive system <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">â–¡</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\square</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.675em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">â–¡</span></span></span></span></span> iss<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#24b60af5" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe the structure and function of the testes</li>
<li>outline the structure and function of the spermatic cords</li>
<li>describe the secretions that pass into the spermatic fluid</li>
<li>explain the process of ejaculation</li>
<li>list the main changes occurring at puberty in the male.</li>
</ul>
<p>The male reproductive system is shown in Fig. 18.13.
The functions of the male reproductive organs are:</p>
<ul>
<li>production, maturation and storage of spermatozoa</li>
<li>delivery of spermatozoa in semen into the female reproductive tract.</li>
</ul>
<p>The urethra is also the passageway for urine excretion.
Right ureter Peritoneum
Deferent duct
Bladder Pubic symphysis Prostate gland Urethra Corpus cavernosum Corpus spongiosum</p>
<p>Gians penis</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-2b851ccc.jpeg" alt="img-253.jpeg"></p>
<p>Sacrum
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">âˆ§</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">{ }^{\wedge}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7519em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7519em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">âˆ§</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> Rectovesical pouch</p>
