<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="learning-outcomes">Learning outcomes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#learning-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="scrotum">Scrotum<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#scrotum" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The scrotum is a pouch of pigmented skin, fibrous and connective tissue and smooth muscle. It is divided into two compartments, each of which contains one testis, one epididymis and the testicular end of a spermatic cord. It lies below the symphysis pubis, in front of the upper parts of the thighs and behind the penis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="e07494c8">Testes <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">â–¡</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\square</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.675em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">â–¡</span></span></span></span></span> i 8 .g<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#e07494c8" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The testes (Fig. 18.14) are the male reproductive glands and are the equivalent of the ovaries in the female. They are about 4.5 cm long, 2.5 cm wide and 3 cm thick and are suspended in the scrotum by the spermatic cords. They are surrounded by three layers of tissue.</p>
<p>Tunica vaginalis
This is a double membrane, forming the outer covering of the testes, and is a downgrowth of the abdominal and pelvic</p>
<p>peritoneum. During early fetal life the testes develop in the lumbar region of the abdominal cavity just below the kidneys. They then descend into the scrotum, taking with them coverings of peritoneum, blood and lymph vessels, nerves and the deferent duct. The peritoneum eventually surrounds the testes in the scrotum and becomes detached from the abdominal peritoneum. Descent of the testes into the scrotum should be complete by the 8th month of fetal life.</p>
<p>Tunica albuginea
This is a fibrous covering beneath the tunica vaginalis. Ingrowths form septa, dividing the glandular structure of the testes into lobules.</p>
<p>Tunica vasculosa
This consists of a network of capillaries supported by delicate connective tissue.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="structure">Structure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#structure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>In each testis there are 200-300 lobules, and within each lobule are 1-4 convoluted loops of germinal epithelial cells.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-dac709ab.jpeg" alt="img-254.jpeg"></p>
<p>Testicular artery and veins
Cremaster muscle
Deferent duct
Skin
Head of epididymis</p>
<p>Tunica vaginalis
Tunica albuginea Tunica vasculosa
Efferent ductules Body of epididymis
Spermatic cord
Tail of epididymis
Lobule
Seminiferous tubules
Figure 18.14 The testis.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-7e4d6fc7.jpeg" alt="img-255.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 18.15 A spermatozoon.
called seminiferous tubules. Between the tubules are groups of interstitial cells (of Leydig) that secrete the hormone testosterone after puberty. At the upper pole of the testis the tubules combine to form a single tubule. This tubule, about 6 m in length, is repeatedly folded and tightly packed into a mass called the epididymis. It leaves the scrotum as the deferent duct (vas deferens) in the spermatic cord. Blood and lymph vessels pass to the testes in the spermatic cords.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="functions">Functions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>spermatozoa (sperm) are produced by the process of spermatogenesis in the seminiferous tubules of the testes, and mature as they pass through the long and convoluted epididymis, where they are stored. FSH from the anterior pituitary (p. 238) stimulates sperm production. A mature sperm (Fig. 18.15) has a head, a body, and a long whip-like tail used for motility. The head is almost completely filled by the nucleus, containing its DNA. It also contains the enzymes required to penetrate the outer layers of the ovum to reach, and fuse with, its nucleus. The body of the sperm is packed with mitochondria, to fuel the propelling action of the tail that powers the sperm along the female reproductive tract.</p>
<p>Successful spermatogenesis takes place at a temperature about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>3</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">âˆ˜</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">3^{\circ} \mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">3</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">âˆ˜</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span> below normal body temperature. The testes are cooled by their position outside the abdominal cavity, and the thin outer covering of the scrotum has very little insulating fat. This exposed position does, however, leave the testis vulnerable to damage and to excessive cold, so a pouch of smooth muscle, the cremaster muscle, wraps around the tunica vaginalis; it extends upwards around the spermatic cord and attaches to</p>
<p>structures in the groin. When it contracts, it pulls the scrotum towards the body, probably for protection. Q 18.10</p>
<p>Unlike females, who produce no new gametes after birth, sperm production in males begins at puberty and continues throughout life, often into old age, under the influence of testosterone.</p>
<p>Spermatic cords
The Spermatic cords suspend the testes in the scrotum. Each cord contains a testicular artery, testicular veins, lymphatics, a deferent duct and testicular nerves, which come together to form the cord from their various origins in the abdomen. The cord, which is covered in a sheath of smooth muscle
(the cremaster muscle) and connective and fibrous tissues, extends through the inguinal canal (p. 462) and is attached to the testis on the posterior wall.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="blood-supply-lymph-drainage-and-nerve-supply-arterial-supply">Blood supply, lymph drainage and nerve supply Arterial supply<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blood-supply-lymph-drainage-and-nerve-supply-arterial-supply" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The testicular artery branches from the abdominal aorta, just below the renal arteries.</p>
<p>Venous drainage
The testicular vein passes into the abdominal cavity. The left vein opens into the left renal vein and the right into the inferior vena cava.</p>
<p>Lymph drainage
This is through lymph nodes around the aorta.
Nerve suppiy
This is provided by branches from the 10th and 11th thoracic nerves.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="deferent-duct">Deferent duct<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#deferent-duct" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Also called the vas deferens, this is some 45 cm long. It passes upwards from the testis through the inguinal canal and ascends medially towards the posterior wall of the bladder, where it is joined by the duct from the seminal vesicle to form the ejaculatory duct (Fig. 18.16). Sperm may live in the deferent duct for several weeks and remain viable.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="93020c8f">Seminal vesicles <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">â–¡</mi><mn>18.11</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\square 18.11</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.675em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">â–¡</span><span class="mord">18.11</span></span></span></span></span><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#93020c8f" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The seminal vesicles are two small fibromuscular pouches, 5 cm long, lined with columnar epithelium and lying immediately posterior to the bladder (Fig. 18.16).</p>
<p>At its lower end, each seminal vesicle opens into a short duct, which joins with the corresponding deferent duct to form an ejaculatory duct.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="functions">Functions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The seminal vesicles contract and expel their stored contents, seminal fluid, during ejaculation. Seminal fluid, which forms <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>60</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">60 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">60%</span></span></span></span></span> of the volume of semen, is viscous and alkaline, to protect the sperm in the acidic environment of the vagina, and contains fructose to fuel the sperm during their journey through the female reproductive tract.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ejaculatory-ducts">Ejaculatory ducts<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ejaculatory-ducts" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The ejaculatory ducts are two tubes, about 2 cm long, each formed by the union of the duct from a seminal vesicle and a deferent duct. They pass through the prostate gland and join the prostatic urethra, carrying seminal fluid and spermatozoa to the urethra (Fig. 18.16).</p>
<p>Ureters
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-34d42607.jpeg" alt="img-256.jpeg"></p>
<p>Bladder
Deferent
duct
Seminal

Ejaculatory duct</p>
<p>Deferent</p>
<p>Prostate gland Urethra
ducts
Seminal

Prostate gland

Figure 18.16 The prostate gland. A. Viewed in situ from the front.
B. Viewed in section from the front.</p>
<p>The walls of the ejaculatory ducts are composed of the same layers of tissue as the seminal vesicles.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="prostate-gland">Prostate gland<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#prostate-gland" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The prostate gland (Fig. 18.16) lies in the pelvic cavity in front of the rectum and behind the symphysis pubis, completely surrounding the urethra as it emerges from the bladder. It has an outer fibrous covering, enclosing glandular tissue wrapped in smooth muscle. The gland weighs about 8 g in youth but progressively enlarges (hypertrophies) with age, and is likely to weigh about 40 g by the age of 50 .</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="functions">Functions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The prostate gland secretes a thin, milky fluid that makes up about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>30</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">30 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">30%</span></span></span></span></span> of the volume of semen and gives it its milky appearance. It contains a clotting enzyme, which thickens the semen in the vagina, increasing the likelihood of semen being retained close to the cervix.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="urethra-and-penis">Urethra and penis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#urethra-and-penis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Urethra</p>
<p>The male urethra provides a common pathway for the flow of urine and semen. It is about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>19</mn><mo>âˆ’</mo><mn>20</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">19-20 \mathrm{~cm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">19</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">âˆ’</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">20</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">cm</span></span></span></span></span></span> long and consists of
three parts. The prostatic urethra originates at the urethral orifice of the bladder and passes through the prostate gland. The membranous urethra is the shortest and narrowest part, and extends from the prostate gland to the bulb of the penis, after passing through the perineal membrane. The spongiose or penile urethra lies within</p>
<p>the corpus spongiosum of the penis and terminates at the external urethral orifice in the glans penis.</p>
<p>There are two urethral sphincters (Fig. 18.17B). The internal sphincter is a ring of smooth muscle at the neck of the bladder above the prostate gland. The external sphincter is a ring of skeletal muscle surrounding the membranous part.</p>
<p>Penis n 18.12
The penis (Fig. 18.17) has a root and a shaft. The root anchors the penis in the perineum and the shaft (body) is the externally visible, movable portion of the organ. It is formed by three cylindrical masses of erectile tissue and smooth muscle. The erectile tissue is supported by fibrous tissue and covered with skin, and has a rich blood supply.</p>
<p>The two lateral columns are called the corpora cavernosa and the column between them, containing the urethra, is the corpus spongiosum (Fig. 18.18A). The penile tip is expanded into a triangular structure known as the glans penis. Just above the glans the skin is folded on itself and forms a movable double layer, the foreskin or prepuce. Arterial blood is supplied by deep, dorsal and bulbar arteries of the penis, which are branches from the internal pudendal arteries. A series of veins drain blood to the internal pudendal and internal iliac veins. The penis is supplied by autonomic and somatic nerves.</p>
<p>Erection of the penis is facilitated by its rich sensory innervation. The diameter of blood vessels supplying and draining it regulates the filling of its erectile tissue and is controlled by the autonomic nervous system. Parasympathetic stimulation leads to filling of the spongy erectile tissue (Fig. 18.18B) with blood, caused by arteriolar dilation and venoconstriction, which increases blood flow into the penis and obstructs outflow. The penis therefore becomes engorged and erect, essential for sexual intercourse.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="ejaculation">Ejaculation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ejaculation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>During ejaculation, which occurs at male orgasm, spermatozoa are expelled from the epididymis and pass through the deferent duct, the ejaculatory duct and the urethra. The semen is propelled by powerful rhythmical contraction of the smooth muscle in the walls of the deferent duct; the muscular contractions are sympathetically mediated. Muscle in the walls of the seminal vesicles and prostate gland also contracts, adding their contents to the fluid passing through the genital ducts. The force generated</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-39a8353c.jpeg" alt="img-257.jpeg"></p>
<p>Corpus
spongiosum

<p>Bladder

Figure 18.17 The penis. (A) Showing the erectile tissues. (B) In section, showing associated structures, viewed from the side.</p>
<p>Blood vessels and nerves
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-fa09766f.jpeg" alt="img-258.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 18.18 The penis. (A) Transverse section, showing the erectile tissues. (B) Erectile tissue (scanning electron micrograph). (B, Susumu Nishinaga/Science Photo Library. Reproduced with permission.)
by these combined processes leads to emission of the semen through the external urethral sphincter (Fig. 18.19).</p>
<p>Sperm comprise only <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>10</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">10%</span></span></span></span></span> of the final ejaculate, the remainder being made up mainly of seminal <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>60</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(60 \%)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">60%</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> and prostatic fluids <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>30</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(30 \%)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">30%</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>, which are added to the sperm during male orgasm, as well as mucus produced in the urethra. Semen is slightly alkaline, to neutralise the acidity of the vagina. Between 2 and 5 mL of semen are produced in a normal ejaculate, and contain between 40 and 100 million spermatozoa per mL . If not ejaculated, sperm gradually lose their fertility after several months and are reabsorbed by the epididymis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="puberty-in-the-male">Puberty in the male<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#puberty-in-the-male" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This occurs between the ages of 10 and 14 . LH from the anterior lobe of the pituitary gland stimulates the interstitial cells of the testes to increase the production of testosterone. Under the influence of testosterone, sexual maturation and development of male secondary sexual characteristics take place, including:</p>
<ul>
<li>growth of muscle and bone and a marked increase in height and weight</li>
<li>enlargement of the larynx and deepening of the voice, which 'breaks'</li>
<li>growth of hair on the face, axillae, chest, abdomen and pubis</li>
<li>enlargement of the penis, scrotum and prostate gland</li>
<li>maturation of the seminiferous tubules and production of spermatozoa</li>
<li>thickening of the skin, which becomes oilier.</li>
</ul>
<p>Deferent duct Seminal vesicle
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-29846e58.jpeg" alt="img-259.jpeg">
orifice
Figure 18.19 Section of the male reproductive organs. Arrows show the route taken by spermatozoa during ejaculation.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="spot-check">- SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol start="3">
<li>Male reproductive fluids pass through the deferent duct and the urethra. What is the main difference in composition of these fluids?</li>
<li>Which compartment in the penis contains the urethra?</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="human-development">Human development<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#human-development" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>define the terms 'blastocyst', 'zygote', 'embryo' and 'fetus'</li>
<li>outline the main stages of embryonic and fetal development.</li>
</ul>
<p>Growth of a new human being begins when an ovum is fertilised by a spermatozoon (see Fig. 1.15), usually in the uterine tube. The resulting cell is called a zygote. As the ovum and spermatozoon each had 23 chromosomes, it has the full complement of 46 chromosomes. The period between
fertilisation and birth (gestation) lasts about 40 weeks. The first 8 weeks of development are called the embryonic period and thereafter the developing individual is called a fetus.</p>
<p>Aided by peristalsis of the uterine tube, the zygote travels towards the uterus, a journey that takes about a week, and by 10 days after fertilisation it is firmly embedded in the uterine lining. During this period, it undergoes rapid and repeated cell divisions; so by the time it implants in the endometrium it has become a blastocyst, a hollow ball of 70-100 cells. The blastocyst contains an inner mass of cells, which develops into the fetus and its amniotic sac, a bag of membranes enclosing it. The outer layer, the trophoblast, becomes an important layer of the placenta.</p>
<p>Nourishment during intrauterine growth
In the early stages, the embryo is small enough for simple diffusion to be adequate to supply the dividing cells but, because embryonic growth is so rapid, this quickly becomes unsustainable and between the 3rd and 10th weeks of pregnancy the placenta (see Fig. 5.44) develops, attached firmly to the uterine wall. The fetus is attached to the placenta by the umbilical cord and absorbs oxygen and nutrients from the maternal bloodstream, as well as excreting its waste products.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-first-3-months">The first 3 months<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-first-3-months" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A newborn baby is made up of trillions of cells and many different tissues, all of which have developed from the single-celled zygote formed at fertilisation.</p>
<p>Differentiation of cells into specialised tissues, and the organisation of these specialised tissues into the body systems, is largely completed in the first 12 weeks of gestation. A 12-week fetus is very similar to a 40 -week fetus, although much smaller.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="later-pregnancy">Later pregnancy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#later-pregnancy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The final 6 months of pregnancy are devoted primarily to the rapid growth of the fetus in preparation for birth and independent life.</p>
<p>Table 18.1 summarises some of the main landmarks in embryonic/fetal development.</p>
<ul>
<li>SPOT CHECK</li>
</ul>
<ol start="5">
<li>What is a blastocyst?</li>
<li>By which stage of embryonic development would you expect to see a beating heart: 1,3 or 5 months?</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="learning-outcomes">Learning outcomes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#learning-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="effects-of-ageing-on-the-reproductive-systems">Effects of ageing on the reproductive systems<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#effects-of-ageing-on-the-reproductive-systems" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe the effects of ageing on female reproduction</li>
<li>describe the effects of ageing on male reproduction.</li>
</ul>
<p>Ageing and reproduction in the female
Usually between the ages of 45 and 55 years, the ovarian supply of oocytes runs out and the oestrogen they release therefore declines, at which point the reproductive cycle is
disrupted and fertility declines towards zero (menopause, p. 496). At the menopause, although oestrogen levels begin to fall, there is a rapid and sustained rise in gonadotrophin secretion, as the anterior pituitary and hypothalamus attempt to maintain activity in the failing ovaries. From middle through to old age, the female reproductive organs, including the breasts, progressively shrink in size. The vulva atrophies and becomes more fibrous, which may predispose to infection and malignant change. The walls of the vagina become thin and smooth with loss of rugae and glandular secretions.</p>
<p>Ageing and reproduction in the male
There is no equivalent of the female menopause in the older male. Although testosterone secretion tends to decline after age 50, leading to a relative reduction in fertility and sexual desire, it is usually sufficient to maintain sperm production and a man may still be able to father a child until extreme old age.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="infections-of-the-reproductive-tract">Infections of the reproductive tract<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#infections-of-the-reproductive-tract" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>list the principal causes of sexually transmitted infections</li>
<li>explain the effects of sexually transmitted infections</li>
<li>describe the circumstances associated with the development of candidiasis (thrush).</li>
</ul>
<p>Many, but not all, infections of the reproductive tract are sexually transmitted.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-81362c47.jpeg" alt="img-260.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 18.20 Gonorrhoea infection. (Dr P Marazzi/Photo Library. Reproduced with permission.)</p>
<p>Sexually transmitted infections
Sexually transmitted infections (STIs) are common in all cultures and an increasing problem in many countries. Microorganisms responsible for STIs are unable to survive outside the body for long periods and have no intermediate host.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="chlamydia">Chlamydia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chlamydia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The bacterium Chlamydia trachomatis causes inflammation of the female cervix. Infection may ascend through the reproductive tract and cause pelvic inflammatory disease (p. 506). In the male, it may cause urethritis, which may also ascend and lead to epididymitis. In both sexes, it is an important cause of subfertility. Chlamydia infection is often present in conjunction with other STIs. The same organism causes trachoma, an eye infection that is the primary cause of blindness worldwide (p. 228), and pneumonia.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="gonorrhoea">Gonorrhoea<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gonorrhoea" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is caused by the bacterium Neisseria gonorrhoeae, which infects the mucosa of the reproductive and urinary tracts. In the male, suppurative urethritis occurs (Fig. 18.20) and the infection may spread to the prostate gland, epididymis and testes. In the female, the infection may spread from the cervix to the body of the uterus, uterine tubes, ovaries and peritoneum. Healing by fibrosis in the female may obstruct the uterine tubes, leading to infertility. In the male it may cause urethral stricture. However, only <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>50</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">50 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">50%</span></span></span></span></span> of females and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>90</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">90 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">90%</span></span></span></span></span> of males experience any symptoms, often leading to a delay in seeking treatment.</p>
<p>Non-venereal transmission of gonorrhoea may cause neonatal ophthalmia in babies born to infected mothers.</p>
<p>The eyes become infected as the baby passes through the birth canal. The disease can also be spread via unprotected oral or anal sex, leading to throat and rectal infections, respectively.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="syphilis">Syphilis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#syphilis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This disease is caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum. There are three clearly marked stages. After an incubation period of several weeks the primary sore (chancre) appears at the site of infection, e.g. the vulva, vagina, perineum or penis, or round the mouth. In the female the primary sore may be undetected if it is internal. After several weeks the chancre subsides spontaneously. The secondary stage, 3-4 months after infection, involves systemic symptoms including lymphadenopathy, rashes and mucosal ulceration of the mouth and genital tract. There may then be a latent period of between 3 and 10 years. If untreated, about one-third of patients eventually develop late-stage disease, which has widespread and devastating effects. Tertiary lesions (gummas) develop in many organs, including skin, bone and mucous membranes, and may involve the nervous system, leading to general paralysis and dementia.</p>
<p>Sexual transmission occurs during the primary and secondary stages when discharge from lesions is highly infectious. Congenital transmission from mother to fetus carries a high risk of stillbirth.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="trichomonas-vaginalis">Trichomonas vaginalis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#trichomonas-vaginalis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This protozoan cause acute vulvovaginitis with irritating, offensive discharge. The infection is usually sexually transmitted and is commonly present in women with gonorrhoea. Males are often asymptomatic.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="learning-outcomes">Learning outcomes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#learning-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="acquired-immune-deficiency-syndrome-and-hepatitis-b-infection">Acquired immune deficiency syndrome and hepatitis B infection<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#acquired-immune-deficiency-syndrome-and-hepatitis-b-infection" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These viral conditions may be sexually transmitted but there are no local signs of infection. For a description of AIDS and HIV see page 418, and for hepatitis B see page 362 .</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="genital-herpes">Genital herpes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genital-herpes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The term 'herpes' comes from the Greek word meaning 'to creep'. There are several types of herpes virus but the main ones associated with genital infections are herpes simplex virus 1 and 2 (HSVl and HSV2). HSV can infect most body cells, including those in the genital tract, and can then establish itself and become latent in the nerves supplying the area. This means that even when the initial infection has subsided, the latent virus can be reactivated and cause repeated episodes of recurrent infection later. Initial infection tends to present as clusters of small, painful ulcers on the external genitalia, often with fever and headache. Patients remain infectious even during symptom-free periods. Babies born to infected mothers can contract HSV, which is a very serious illness in the neonate and can be fatal.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="candidiasis">Candidiasis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#candidiasis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The yeast Candida albicans (see also p. 349) is frequently a commensal in the vagina, as well as other body sites, and normally causes no problems. It is normally prevented from flourishing by vaginal acidity but in certain circumstances it proliferates, causing candidiasis (thrush). Common precipitating factors include:</p>
<ul>
<li>antibiotic therapy, which kills the bacteria that keep vaginal pH low</li>
<li>pregnancy</li>
<li>reduced immune function</li>
<li>diabetes mellitus.</li>
</ul>
<p>In women, persistent itch is the main symptom of vaginal candidiasis, with discharge, swelling and erythema of the vulvar area. It is important to note that Candida can infect almost any body site, given suitable conditions.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-spot-check">I # SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol start="7">
<li>Which organism causes syphilis?</li>
<li>Why is genital thrush associated with broad-spectrum antibiotic treatment?</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="diseases-of-the-female-reproductive-system">Diseases of the female reproductive system<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diseases-of-the-female-reproductive-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe the causes and consequences of pelvic inflammatory disease</li>
<li>outline the causes and effects of cervical carcinoma</li>
<li>discuss the main pathologies of the uterus and uterine tubes</li>
<li>describe the causes and effects of ovarian disease</li>
<li>explain the causes of female infertility</li>
<li>discuss the principal disorders of the female breast.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pelvic-inflammatory-disease">Pelvic inflammatory disease<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pelvic-inflammatory-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) is usually a consequence of STIs and is most common in young, sexually active women. It usually begins as vulvovaginitis and spreads upwards to the cervix, uterus, uterine tubes and ovaries. It can also occur as the result of a surgical procedure, childbirth or miscarriage, especially if some of the products of conception are retained. Complications of PID include:</p>
<ul>
<li>infertility due to obstruction of the uterine tubes</li>
<li>peritonitis</li>
<li>intestinal obstruction due to adhesions between the bowel and the uterus and/ or uterine tubes</li>
<li>bacteraemia, which may lead to meningitis, endocarditis or septic arthritis.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="disorders-of-the-uterus-cervical-carcinoma">Disorders of the uterus Cervical carcinoma<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disorders-of-the-uterus-cervical-carcinoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Dysplastic changes, referred to as cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN), begin in the deepest layer of cervical epithelium, usually where the stratified squamous epithelium of the lower third of the cervical canal meets the secretory epithelium of the upper two-thirds. Dysplasia may progress to involve the full thickness of epithelium. Not all dysplasias develop into malignant disease but it is not possible to predict how far development will go and whether it will remain static or regress. Early detection with a screening programme can allow abnormal tissue to be removed before it becomes malignant. Established malignancy is staged according to how extensive the tumour</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="learning-outcomes">Learning outcomes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#learning-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>is. Stage I refers to disease confined to the cervix. Stages II-IV reflect increasing spread, including involvement of the rectum, bladder and structures outside the pelvis. Early spread is via lymph nodes and local spread is commonly to the uterus, vagina, bladder and rectum. In the late stages, spread via the blood to the liver, lungs and bones may occur.</p>
<p>The disease takes 15-20 years to develop and mostly occurs between 35 and 50 years of age.</p>
<p>The great majority of cases (over <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>90</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">90 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">90%</span></span></span></span></span> ) are caused by the sexually transmitted human papilloma virus (HPV), which is also believed to cause a large proportion of cancers of the penis and vulva. The risk is therefore greatest in women who are sexually active from an early age with multiple partners and who do not use barrier methods of contraception.</p>
<p>Disorders of the endometrium
The general term for inflammation of the endometrium is endometritis, caused by a range of organisms following, for example, childbirth or miscarriage, or by an infected intrauterine contraceptive device. Other more specific conditions include endometriosis, endometrial hyperplasia and endometrial carcinoma.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="endometriosis">Endometriosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#endometriosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is the growth of endometrial tissue outside the uterus, usually in the ovaries, uterine tubes and other pelvic structures. The ectopic tissue, like the uterine endometrium, responds to fluctuations in sex hormone levels during the menstrual cycle, causing menstrual-type bleeding into the lower abdomen and, in the ovaries, the formation of coloured cysts, called 'chocolate cysts'. There is intermittent pain due to swelling, and recurrent haemorrhage causes fibrous tissue formation.</p>
<p>Ovarian endometriosis may lead to pelvic inflammation, infertility and extensive pelvic adhesions, involving the ovaries, uterus, uterine ligaments and the bowel. The condition may also increase the risk of certain cancers, including ovarian cancer.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="endometrial-hyperplasia">Endometrial hyperplasia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#endometrial-hyperplasia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Hyperplasia of the endometrium is associated with high blood oestrogen levels, e.g. in obesity, oestrogen therapy or an ovarian tumour, and may be associated with an increased risk of malignant change.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="endometrial-carcinoma">Endometrial carcinoma<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#endometrial-carcinoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This occurs mainly in postmenopausal women between 50 and 60 years of age. Exposure to oestrogen is the main risk factor. Women who have never been pregnant (nulliparous) or who had an early menarche and/ or late menopause have an increased risk. Obesity is associated with high circulating oestrogen levels and therefore obese people with or without
the related conditions of diabetes and hypertension are also at increased risk of endometrial cancer.</p>
<p>As the tumour grows, there is often ulceration and vaginal bleeding. Endometrium has no lymphatics, so lymph spread is delayed until extensive local spread involves other pelvic structures. Distant metastases, spread in blood or lymph, develop later, usually in the liver, lungs and bones. Invasion of the ureters leads to hydronephrosis and uraemia, commonly the cause of death.</p>
<p>Disorders of the myometrium Adenomyosis
This is the growth of endometrium within the myometrium. The ectopic tissue may cause general or localised uterine enlargement. The lesions may cause dysmenorrhoea and irregular excessive bleeding (menorrhagia), usually beginning between 40 and 50 years of age.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="leiomyoma-fibroid-myoma">Leiomyoma (fibroid, myoma)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#leiomyoma-fibroid-myoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These are very common, often multiple, benign tumours of myometrium (Fig. 18.21). They are firm masses of smooth muscle encapsulated in compressed muscle fibres and they vary greatly in size. Large tumours may degenerate if they outgrow their blood supply, leading to necrosis, fibrosis and calcification. They are more common in Asian</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-fdb6f1fe.jpeg" alt="img-261.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 18.21 Uterine fibroid (fibroid is shown in orange). False colour magnetic resonance imaging scan. (Simon Fraser/Newcastle Flospitals NFIS Trust/Science Photo Library. Reproduced with permission.)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-f2d0f5b7.jpeg" alt="img-262.jpeg">
and black women than in white women, develop during the reproductive period and may be hormone-dependent, enlarging during pregnancy and when oral contraceptives are used. They tend to regress after the menopause. Large tumours may cause pelvic discomfort, frequency of micturition, menorrhagia, irregular periods, dysmenorrhoea (painful menstrual periods) and reduced fertility. Malignant change is rare.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="disorders-of-the-uterine-tubes-and-ovaries">Disorders of the uterine tubes and ovaries<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disorders-of-the-uterine-tubes-and-ovaries" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="acute-salpingitis">Acute salpingitis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#acute-salpingitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Salpingitis is inflammation of the uterine tubes. It is usually due to infection spreading from the uterus, and occasionally from the peritoneal cavity. The uterine tubes may be permanently damaged by fibrous scar tissue, which can cause obstruction and infertility. Infection may spread into the peritoneum and involve the ovaries.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ectopic-pregnancy">Ectopic pregnancy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ectopic-pregnancy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is the implantation of a fertilised ovum outside the uterus, usually in a uterine tube. As the fetus grows, the tube may rupture and its contents enter the peritoneal cavity, causing acute inflammation (peritonitis) and potentially fatal intraperitoneal haemorrhage.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ovarian-tumours">Ovarian tumours<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ovarian-tumours" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Most ovarian tumours are benign, usually occurring between 20 and 45 years of age. The rest occur mostly between 45 and 65 years, and are divided between borderline malignancy (low-grade cancer) and frank malignancy.</p>
<p>Ovarian cancer is associated with developed societies, higher socioeconomic groups and, in some families, a genetic susceptibility. Pregnancy or use of the contraceptive pill has a protective effect. Most malignancies of the ovary arise from epithelium but some arise from the germ cells of the ovary or from stromal cells.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="metastatic-ovarian-tumours">Metastatic ovarian tumours<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#metastatic-ovarian-tumours" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The ovaries are common sites of metastatic spread from primary tumours in other pelvic organs, the breast, stomach, pancreas and biliary tract.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="female-infertility">Female infertility<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#female-infertility" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This common condition may be due to:</p>
<ul>
<li>blockage of uterine tubes, often the consequence of PID and/or STIs</li>
<li>anatomical abnormalities, e.g. retroversion (backward tilting) of the uterus</li>
<li>endocrine factors - any abnormalities of the glands and hormones regulating the menstrual cycle can interfere with fertility</li>
<li>low body weight, e.g. in anorexia nervosa, or severe malnourishment; this may be associated with low leptin levels (see Table 9.4)</li>
<li>endometriosis.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="disorders-of-the-breast">Disorders of the breast<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disorders-of-the-breast" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mastitis-inflammation-of-the-breast">Mastitis (inflammation of the breast)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mastitis-inflammation-of-the-breast" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is usually associated with lactation and breast feeding, and may or may not involve infection. Usually only one breast is involved. Non-infective mastitis is the result of milk stasis in the breast and causes swelling and pain. Infection (usually by Staphylococcus aureus) can occur if the nipple is damaged during suckling, allowing bacteria to enter and spread into the system of milk ducts. The condition generally responds well to treatment but can progress to more serious complications such as abscess formation.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="tumours-of-the-breast">Tumours of the breast<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tumours-of-the-breast" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="benign-tumours">Benign tumours<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#benign-tumours" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Most breast tumours ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>90</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">90 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">90%</span></span></span></span></span> ) are benign. Fibroadenomas are the most common type and occur any time after puberty; incidence peaks in the third decade. Other benign tumours may be cystic or solid and these usually occur in women nearing the menopause. They may originate from secretory cells or fibrous tissue, or from ducts.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="breast-cancer">Breast cancer<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#breast-cancer" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Breast cancer (Fig. 18.22) is the most common cancer worldwide in women and the incidence is increasing. Important risk factors include increasing age (up to about 70 years, after which the incidence declines), high alcohol consumption and obesity. Women with an early menarche, late menopause and no pregnancies also have an increased risk because they experience more reproductive cycles with the monthly oestrogen surge associated with ovulation. A genetic component is also likely, with close relatives of breast cancer sufferers having an elevated risk of developing the disease. In <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>5</mn><mo>âˆ’</mo><mn>10</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">5-10 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">5</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">âˆ’</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">10%</span></span></span></span></span> of cases the disease is linked to the presence of one of two faulty genes, BRCAl and BRCA2. Women carrying one of these genes have a very high <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>80</mn><mo>âˆ’</mo><mn>90</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(80-90 \%)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">80</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">âˆ’</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">90%</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> chance of developing breast cancer, and there is also increased risk of ovarian and bowel cancer. The average age at which the disease appears in women carrying these genes is significantly lower than in those without the gene.</p>
<p>The tumour most commonly occurs in the upper outer quadrant of the breast. There is fibrosis around the tumour and this may cause retraction of the nipple, and necrosis and ulceration of the overlying skin.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-c6c350a0.jpeg" alt="img-263.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 18.22 Breast cancer. (Mid-Essex Hospital Services NHS Trust/Science Photo Library. Reproduced with permission.)</p>
<p>Early spread beyond the breast is via lymph to the axillary and internal mammary nodes. Local invasion involves the pectoral muscles and the pleura. Blood-spread metastases may occur later in many organs and bones, especially lumbar and thoracic vertebrae.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="i-spot-check">I # SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol start="9">
<li>What is a leiomyoma?</li>
<li>Why do women with a large number of sexual partners have an increased risk of cervical cancer?</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="diseases-of-the-male-reproductive-system">Diseases of the male reproductive system<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diseases-of-the-male-reproductive-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>outline the causes and effects of penile and urethral infections</li>
<li>describe the main pathologies of the testis</li>
<li>discuss the principal disorders of the prostate gland</li>
<li>list the main causes of male infertility.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="infections-of-the-penis">Infections of the penis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#infections-of-the-penis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Inflammation of the glans and prepuce may be caused by a specific or non-specific infection. In non-specific infections.
or balanitis, lack of personal hygiene is an important predisposing factor, especially if phimosis is present, i.e. the foreskin is tight and does not retract properly. If the infection becomes chronic, there may be fibrosis of the foreskin, which increases the phimosis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="infections-of-the-urethra">Infections of the urethra<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#infections-of-the-urethra" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Gonococcal urethritis is the most common specific infection. Non-specific infection may be spread from the bladder (cystitis) or be introduced during catheterisation, cystoscopy or surgery. Both types may spread throughout the system to the prostate, seminal vesicles, epididymis and testes. If infection becomes chronic, fibrosis may cause urethral stricture or obstruction, leading to retention of urine.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="disorders-of-the-epididymis-and-testes">Disorders of the epididymis and testes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disorders-of-the-epididymis-and-testes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="infections">Infections<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#infections" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
