<p>Non-Specific epididymitis and orchitis are usually due to spread of infection from the urethra, commonly following prostatectomy. The microbes may spread either through the deferent duct or via lymph.</p>
<p>Specific epididymitis
This is usually caused by gonorrhoea spread from the urethra.
Orchitis (inflammation of the testis)
This is commonly caused by mumps virus, bloodborne from the parotid glands. Acute inflammation with oedema occurs about 1 week after the appearance of parotid swelling (parotitis, p. 350). The infection is usually unilateral but, if bilateral, severe damage to germinal epithelium of the seminiferous tubules may result in sterility.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="undescended-testis-cryptorchidism">Undescended testis (cryptorchidism)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#undescended-testis-cryptorchidism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>During embryonic life the testes develop within the abdominal cavity, and normally descend into the scrotum prior to birth. If they fail to do this and the condition is not corrected, infertility is likely to follow and the risk of testicular cancer is increased.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hydrocele">Hydrocele<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hydrocele" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is the most common form of scrotal swelling and is accumulation of serous fluid in the tunica vaginalis. The onset may be acute and painful or chronic. It may be congenital or be secondary to another disorder of the testis or epididymis.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-a2051de5.jpeg" alt="img-264.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="section-4-protection-and-survival">SECTION 4 Protection and survival<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#section-4-protection-and-survival" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="testicular-tumours">Testicular tumours<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#testicular-tumours" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Most testicular tumours are malignant, and are the most common malignancies in young men. They occur in childhood and early adulthood when the affected testis has not descended or has been late in descending into the scrotum. The tumour tends to remain localised for a considerable time but eventually spreads in lymph to pelvic and abdominal lymph nodes, and more widely in the blood. Occasionally, hormone-secreting tumours develop and may cause precocious development in boys.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="disorders-of-the-prostate-gland">Disorders of the prostate gland<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disorders-of-the-prostate-gland" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="infections">Infections<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#infections" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Acute prostatitis is usually caused by non-specific infection, spread from the urethra or bladder, often following catheterisation, cystoscopy, urethral dilation or prostate surgery. Chronic infection may follow an acute attack. Fibrosis of the gland may occur during healing, causing urethral stricture or obstruction.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="benign-prostatic-enlargement">Benign prostatic enlargement<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#benign-prostatic-enlargement" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The prostate gland surrounds the urethra (see Fig. 18.19) and so hyperplasia of the gland obstructs the flow of urine, causing urinary retention. Incomplete emptying of the bladder predisposes to infection, which may spread upwards, causing pyelonephritis and other complications. Prostatic enlargement is common in men over 50 , affecting up to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>70</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">70 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">70%</span></span></span></span></span> of men aged over 70 . The cause is not clear.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="malignant-prostatic-tumours">Malignant prostatic tumours<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#malignant-prostatic-tumours" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Seven per cent of all cancers in men are prostatic carcinomas. Risk increases with age; the trigger for malignant change is not known, although there is believed to be a hormonal element. Initially, the growing tumour usually causes symptoms of urinary obstruction, but it spreads quickly and sometimes presents with symptoms of secondary spread, e.g. back pain from bone metastases, weight loss or anaemia.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="disorders-of-the-male-breast">Disorders of the male breast<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disorders-of-the-male-breast" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="gynaecomastia">Gynaecomastia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gynaecomastia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is proliferation of breast tissue in men. It usually affects only one breast and is benign. It is common in adolescents and older men, and is often associated with:</p>
<ul>
<li>endocrine disorders, especially those associated with high oestrogen levels</li>
<li>cirrhosis of the liver (p. 363)</li>
<li>malnutrition</li>
<li>some drugs, e.g. chlorpromazine, spironolactone, digoxin</li>
<li>Klinefelter's syndrome, a genetic disorder with testicular atrophy and absence of spermatogenesis.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="malignant-tumours">Malignant tumours<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#malignant-tumours" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These develop in a small number of men, usually in the older age groups. One per cent of all breast cancers occur in men.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="male-infertility">Male infertility<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#male-infertility" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This may be due to endocrine disorders, obstruction of the deferent duct, failure of erection or ejaculation during intercourse, vasectomy, or suppression of spermatogenesis by, for example, ionising radiation, chemotherapy and other drugs.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="spot-check">SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol start="11">
<li>What is a hydrocele?</li>
<li>What is the name given to benign breast enlargement in men?</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="review-and-revise">Review and revise<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#review-and-revise" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Complete the following statement:</p>
<ol>
<li>The vaginal wall has three layers. The inner lining is
made of _ squamous _; the
middle layer is made of <em>; and
the outer layer is _ tissue. The walls of
the vagina form</em>, folds that allow it to
expand during sexual intercourse and childbirth. At its superior end the_projects into the vagina.</li>
</ol>
<p>Choose one answer to complete each of the following statements:
2. Leiomyomas are also called: <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mspace width="2em"></mspace></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\qquad</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0em;"></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 2em;"></span></span></span></span></span>
a. Adenomyomas
b. Fibroids
c. Uterine cysts
d. Hydroceles.
3. The corpus cavernosum surrounds the: <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mspace width="2em"></mspace></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\qquad</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0em;"></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 2em;"></span></span></span></span></span>
a. Penis
b. Corpus spongiosum
c. Epididymis
d. Urethra.
4. The ejaculatory ducts are formed by the union of:
a. Ureter and urethra
b. Deferent duct and duct from seminal vesicle
c. Prostatic duct and seminal vesicle</p>
<p>d. Prostatic duct and urethra.
5. Benign prostatic hypertrophy:_
a. Obstructs the urethra
b. Predisposes to malignancy
c. Is rare in older men
d. Is the result of a viral infection.
6. Classify the structures in the following list into internal or external genitalia:</p>
<p>Labia majora_
Vagina
Labia minora_
Uterus_
Uterine tubes
Clitoris_
Hymen
Ovary
Vestibule
For a range of further self-assessment exercises on the topics in this chapter, visit Evolve online resources: <a href="https://evolve.elsevier.com/Waugh/anatomy/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">https://evolve.elsevier.com/Waugh/anatomy/</a></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="140dc2cb"><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">â–¡</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\square</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.675em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">â–¡</span></span></span></span></span><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#140dc2cb" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This page intentionally left blank</p>
<p>This page intentionally left blank</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="answers-to-self-assessment-questions">Answers to self-assessment questions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#answers-to-self-assessment-questions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="chapter-1">Chapter 1<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chapter-1" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="spot-check">Spot check<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Differentiation is the specialisation of cell structure and function to carry out particular functions. For example, nerve cells transmit electrical impulses; muscle cells contract.</li>
<li>Arteries carry blood away from the heart.</li>
<li>A neurotransmitter is a chemical released by a nerve ending that enables it to transmit electrical impulses to the next nerve or an effector organ.</li>
<li>The body is upright with the head facing forward, the arms at the side with the palms facing forward, and the feet together. Using the anatomical position enables consistent description of body parts and their interrelationships.</li>
<li>The axial skeleton consists of the skull, vertebral column, sternum and ribs.</li>
<li>The liver is situated in the right hypochondriac region.</li>
<li>At maturity, many organs, including the heart and kidneys, have 'spare capacity' that gradually declines in later life, meaning that significant tissue loss is needed to impair body function.</li>
<li>Congenital conditions are present at birth; acquired conditions develop after birth.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="review-and-revise">Review and revise<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#review-and-revise" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Arteries, veins, capillaries.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Puberty, menopause.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>b.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>d.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>F.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>T.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>(a) 4 , (b) 8 , (c) 7 , (d) 3 , (e) 2 , (f) 6 , (g) 9 , (h) 10 , (i) 5 , (j) 1 .</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>(a) 7 , (b) 5 , (c) 2 , (d) 1 , (e) 6 , (f) 8 , (g) 3 , (h) 4 .</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="chapter-2">Chapter 2<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chapter-2" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="spot-check">Spot check<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>There are three isotopes of hydrogen. Isotopes of the same element have the same number of protons but different numbers of neutrons in their atomic nuclei.</li>
</ol>
<p>The most common isotope of hydrogen has one proton in its nucleus (all atoms with one proton in the nucleus are, by definition, hydrogen atoms) and one orbiting electron. Deuterium has one proton, one electron and one neutron. Tritium has one proton, one electron and two neutrons.
2. The body fluids contain buffers, which resist changes in pH by mopping up excess or <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mtext>w&nbsp;</mtext></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{OH}^{\text {w }}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7376em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">OH</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7376em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">w&nbsp;</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> ions. These excess ions are then disposed of by the organs of excretion, most significantly the lungs and the kidneys.
3. Amino acids contain a hydrogen ion, an amino group (NH 2 ), a carboxyl group <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(\mathrm{COOH})</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">COOH</span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> and a variable side chain, and so contain nitrogen, carbon, oxygen, hydrogen and sometimes other atoms such as sulphur. Monosaccharides, on the other hand, contain only carbon, hydrogen and oxygen, usually in the fixed ratio of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>:</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>:</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1: 2: 1</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">:</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">2</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">:</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span></span> and arranged in
a ring.
4. Enzymes are biological catalysts that speed up chemical reactions in the body. The enzyme molecule contains an active site, to which the reactants bind. In catabolic reactions the reactants are bound together into a larger product, whereas anabolic reactions break the substrate into smaller molecules.
5. When body temperature starts to fall, the temperature regulatory centre in the hypothalamus detects the change and responds in several ways.</p>
<p>One response involves activating shivering to generate extra heat. The skeletal muscles are the effectors, as they are responsible for generating the heat to reverse the fall in body temperature. When body temperature returns to within the normal range, this too is detected by the hypothalamus, which then turns the shivering response off (negative feedback).
6. This process is osmosis. A hypotonic solution has more water molecules (i.e. is more dilute) than the contents of the red blood cell. To equalise water concentrations on either side of the red blood cell membrane, water enters the cell, which swells and may burst.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="review-and-revise">Review and revise<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#review-and-revise" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Nucleus, protons, neutrons, electrons, negative.</li>
<li>ATP, ribose, phosphate, adenine.</li>
<li>a.</li>
<li>d.</li>
<li>(a) <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>b</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mn>2</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>c</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mn>5</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>d</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mn>4</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>e</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mn>3</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mn>5</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mn>1</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1,(b) 2,(c) 5,(d) 4,(e) 3,(f) 5,(g) 1,3</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal">b</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mord">2</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal">c</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mord">5</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal">d</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mord">4</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal">e</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mord">3</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10764em;">f</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mord">5</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.03588em;">g</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">3</span></span></span></span></span>.</li>
<li>(a) <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>6</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>b</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mn>3</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>c</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mn>1</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>d</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mn>1</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>e</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mn>5</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mn>2</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">6,(b) 3,(c) 1,(d) 1,(e) 5,(f) 2,(g) 4</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">6</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal">b</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mord">3</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal">c</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal">d</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal">e</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mord">5</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10764em;">f</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mord">2</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.03588em;">g</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mord">4</span></span></span></span></span>.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="chapter-3">Chapter 3<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chapter-3" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="spot-check">Spot check<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Particles too large to cross the plasma membrane are engulfed by cytoplasmic extensions, forming a membrane-bound vacuole inside the cell. Lysosomes then adhere to this and release enzymes that digest the contents of the vacuole.</li>
<li>Interphase is the period between two cell divisions and has three separate stages: the first
gap phase <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">G</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(\mathrm{Gi})</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Gi</span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>, the synthesis <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(\mathrm{S})</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathrm">S</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> phase and the second gap phase <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">G</mi><mn>2</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(\mathrm{G} 2)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathrm">G</span><span class="mord">2</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>. This is followed by mitosis, which has four stages: prophase, metaphase, anaphase and telophase.</li>
<li>Mucous membrane is made from epithelial cells interspersed with mucussecreting goblet cells.</li>
</ol>
<p>Mucus keeps the surface moist and protects it from mechanical and chemical damage. Mucous membrane lines the gastrointestinal, respiratory and genitourinary tracts.
4. Secretions from exocrine glands are released into hollow organs either directly or through a duct. Secretions from endocrine glands are called hormones; they are released into the capillaries surrounding the gland and travel to their target tissue in the bloodstream.
5. Apoptosis.
6. Venous blood from most of the alimentary tract passes through the liver for processing in the hepatic sinusoids before returning to the heart. Any escaped cancer cells, either on their own or inside tiny thrombi, may lodge there and later divide, causing secondary tumours.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="review-and-revise">Review and revise<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#review-and-revise" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Cytoplasm, cytosol, organelles.</li>
<li>Centrioles, mitotic spindle.</li>
<li>Epithelial tissue (epithelium), connective, muscle, nervous.</li>
<li>c.</li>
<li>b.</li>
<li>F.</li>
<li>T.</li>
<li>F.</li>
<li>(a) 5 , (b) 1 , (c) 2 , (d) 4 , (e) 8 , (f) 7 , (g) 6 , (h) 3 .</li>
<li>(a) 7 , (b) 6 , (c) 5 , (d) 2 , (e) 1 , (f) 8 , (g) 3 , (h) 4 .</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="chapter-4">Chapter 4<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chapter-4" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="spot-check">Spot check<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>As immunoglobulins (antibodies), transport - e.g. of hormones in the plasma, and as enzyme inhibitors in the regulation of enzyme activity.</li>
<li>Water <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>90</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(90 \%)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">90%</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>.</li>
<li>The red blood cell is flexible to squeeze through narrow capillaries. Nearly all of the internal space is packed with haemoglobin for gas transport. Biconcave discs increase the surface area to volume ratio for efficient gas diffusion. The flattened disc shape allows stacking in the bloodstream for smooth blood flow.</li>
<li>The ability of a cell to migrate actively through an intact capillary wall.</li>
<li>A platelet plug is a soft, temporary mass of platelets formed in rapid response (within a few minutes) to blood vessel injury. As clotting proceeds, it is converted into a sturdier, more stable clot, mainly by the deposition of fibrin strands.</li>
<li>This autoimmune condition is a form of anaemia caused by autoantibodies against intrinsic factor (IF) and the gastric parietal cells that produce it. Without adequate IF, vitamin B 12 , essential for red blood cell production, cannot be absorbed.</li>
<li>In this inherited disorder, abnormal haemoglobin molecules change shape when bound to oxygen, which in turn distorts the red blood cell. The irregular shape of</li>
</ol>
<p>sickled cells greatly increases turbulence in the bloodstream and damages them, leading to early haemolysis and anaemia.
8. Leukaemia is a malignant proliferation of white blood cell precursors in the bone marrow, crowding out erythrocyte and thrombocyte precursors and leading to anaemia and also prolonged clotting times.
9. Chronic myeloid leukaemia.
10. Fat absorption is reduced in coeliac disease; this can lead to deficiency of the fat-soluble vitamins, including vitamin K , which is required for clotting factor synthesis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="review-and-revise">Review and revise<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#review-and-revise" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>Haem, four, iron, oxygen, 280, liver, bilirubin.</li>
<li>d.</li>
<li>b.</li>
<li>c.</li>
<li>(a) 3 , (b) 5 , (c) 4 , (d) 2 , (e) 6 , (f) 1 .</li>
<li>(a) 3 , (b) 8 , (c) 6 , (d) 1 , (e) 5 , (f) 9 , (g) 2 , (h) 7 , (i) 4 .</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="chapter-5">Chapter 5<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chapter-5" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="spot-check">Spot check<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>From outside to inside: the tunica externa supports, protects and isolates the vessel from adjacent structures; the tunica media contains mainly elastic tissue in larger arteries, but mainly muscle in small arteries (arterioles) for control of blood flow and blood pressure; the tunica intima (endothelium) is a smooth, low-friction lining a single cell thick, which minimises blood turbulence, and releases important chemical factors to reduce the risk of inappropriate blood clotting.</li>
<li>Both are permeable vessels whose thin walls consist of a layer of endothelium a single cell thick sitting on a basement membrane; they are important in the exchange of substances between the blood and the tissues. Sinusoids are more permeable than capillaries, though, and are found in organs such as the liver, where it is important that the blood comes directly into contact with the local tissues.</li>
<li>The heart sits immediately behind the sternum, occupying the lower part of the mediastinum, with its lower portion (the apex) tilted to the left. The apex sits directly on the diaphragm. Running behind the heart are the aorta, the trachea, the oesophagus and the vertebral column. Laterally lie the lungs and the pulmonary</li>
</ol>
<p>arteries and veins. The superior and inferior venae cavae are also immediately adjacent.
4. The sinoatrial node acts as the heart's pacemaker and generates the electrical signal that triggers each heartbeat. When it fails, its pacemaker function can be taken over by another area of the heart, usually the atrioventricular node, which will keep the heart beating but at a significantly lower rate.
5. Systolic blood pressure is the peak pressure produced in the vascular system by ventricular contraction. Diastolic pressure is the lowest pressure, when the heart is actually resting, but pressure
is maintained by vascular tone (i.e. the degree of constriction of the blood vessels).
6 . When blood pressure rises, stretch receptors (baroreceptors) in the walls of the aorta and carotid arteries are stimulated, increasing their input to the cardiovascular centre in the brain stem. The cardiovascular centre responds by slowing the heart down and dilating blood vessels (increased parasympathetic and decreased sympathetic activity), which lowers blood pressure.
7. A pulse rate below 60 beats per minute.</p>
<p>8 . Ascending aorta, arch and descending aorta.
9. The blood travels through two separate capillary beds between the arterial and venous circulations. In the hepatic portal system, blood flows through the
gastrointestinal capillaries, absorbing products of digestion, then through the hepatic portal vein, which breaks up into capillaries in the liver before finally returning to the venous circulation in the hepatic vein.
10. The placenta is a pancake-shaped organ, weighing about 500 g at maturity; it is about 20 cm wide and 2.5 cm thick. One of its flat faces is firmly anchored to the wall of the uterus, and extending from the other face is the umbilical cord containing the umbilical arteries and vein, which circulate the fetal blood through the placental villi. As the fetal blood passes through the placenta, it picks up oxygen, glucose and other nutrients from the maternal blood, and excretes wastes.
11. The ductus venosus is a short vessel linking the umbilical vein, carrying oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus, and the inferior vena cava; it bypasses the fetal liver.
12. Age-related reduction in heart muscle strength and blood flow can be minimised by lifestyle factors such as regular exercise and healthy diet.
13. Compensation refers to the compensatory mechanisms activated when blood flow to body organs falls in the early stages of shock. These help to maintain blood pressure and flow, and include sympathetic stimulation, increased heart rate</p>
<p>and contractility, increased respiratory effort and vasoconstriction in non-essential organs. As long as these measures maintain adequate circulation to the tissues, the shock is said to be compensated.
14. Anaphylaxis leads to the release of large amounts of inflammatory mediators such as histamine and bradykinin into the bloodstream. These chemicals cause widespread vasodilation and increased vascular permeability, and so can drastically reduce blood pressure very quickly. They also cause bronchoconstriction, preventing adequate gas exchange in the lungs.
15. A thrombus is a static blood clot. An embolism is a solid mass of material, such as a fragment of a blood clot or a globule of fat, travelling in the bloodstream.
16. Ischaemia is impaired cell function caused by inadequate oxygen supply and the accumulation of wastes, and it may be reversible if not too severe or too prolonged. Infarction means cell death due to inadequate blood supply.
17. A fatty streak is the initial stage of a plaque, in which fatty material is deposited along the wall of an artery. As it grows into a mature plaque, it becomes much thicker, accumulating additional fatty material infiltrated with fat-laden macrophages (foam cells) and smooth muscle cells. Its cover (cap) is rough and can rupture, causing thrombosis.
18. A varicose vein is a stretched and bulging section of vein, usually in the leg, in which the valves have failed to prevent backflow of blood. The pooling
blood stretches the vein, so the valves become less and less effective and the veins progressively more and more distended.
19. If the left ventricle is not pumping out the blood being delivered to it, the pressure inside the left ventricle will start to rise, backing up through the left atrium and the pulmonary veins, and finally into the low-pressure pulmonary capillaries. When pressure rises here, fluid is forced into the alveoli, causing pulmonary oedema.
20. The liver produces most plasma proteins, which maintain the osmotic pressure of the blood. If the liver fails and plasma protein production falls, the osmotic pressure also falls and fluid moves out of the bloodstream into the tissues and body cavities, including the abdominal cavity.
21. A heart murmur is an abnormal heart sound made by a faulty heart valve, commonly an atrioventricular valve.
22. The antibodies to the bacterium produced in response to the throat infection can attack and damage heart tissue, including the valves and the myocardium, leading to rheumatic heart disease.</p>
<ol start="23">
<li>Primary hypertension (about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>90</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">90 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">90%</span></span></span></span></span> of cases) has no single identified cause, whereas secondary hypertension is due to another condition.</li>
<li>Retinal capillaries can be viewed directly through an ophthalmoscope.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="review-and-revise">Review and revise<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#review-and-revise" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>Four, atria, ventricles, septum, atrioventricular, endocardium, myocardium.</li>
<li>Right subclavian; right axillary; right brachial; right radial, right ulnar; right palmar; right digital arteries.</li>
<li>b.</li>
<li>d.</li>
<li>c.</li>
<li>a.</li>
<li>c.</li>
<li>d.</li>
<li>b.</li>
<li>Right atrium, right atrioventricular valve, right ventricle, pulmonary artery, pulmonary capillaries, pulmonary vein, left atrium, left atrioventricular valve, left ventricle, aortic valve, aorta, systemic arteries, systemic capillaries, systemic veins, right atrium .</li>
<li>(a) <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>4</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mn>5</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mn>7</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mn>8</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">4,5,7,8</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8389em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">4</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">5</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">7</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">8</span></span></span></span></span>; (b) <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mn>3</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1,3,6</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8389em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">3</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">6</span></span></span></span></span>; (c) 2 .</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="chapter-6">Chapter 6<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chapter-6" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="spot-check">Spot check<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>The right lymphatic duct.</li>
<li>Three of: valves; compression from adjacent skeletal muscle; fall in pressure in the thoracic cavity during
inspiration; action of smooth muscle within lymph vessel walls.</li>
<li>A lymph node is roughly bean-shaped, and somewhere in size between a pinhead and an almond. Each node is contained within a capsule; lymph enters through</li>
</ol>
<p>multiple afferent lymph vessels but drains away through only one efferent vessel. The interior
of the node is made up mainly of lymphatic tissue, subdivided by trabeculae.
4. As sinusoids are very permeable, this allows the blood cells to come into contact with the splenic pulp, which can then extract old or damaged cells and destroy them.
5. Surgical removal of the breast (mastectomy) usually includes adjacent lymph nodes, which interrupts lymph drainage and causes lymphoedema of the arm.</p>
<p>6 . Pathogens draining from the site of infection enter the lymph and are carried to local lymph nodes, where they can establish themselves and cause a degree of inflammation (lymphadenitis).
7. Poorly differentiated cells mean faster development of the disease and a poorer prognosis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="review-and-revise">Review and revise<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#review-and-revise" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>Oval, 200, capsule, hilum, splenic, stomach/ pancreas/large intestine and left kidney.</li>
<li>Cervical, axillary, inguinal.</li>
<li>d.</li>
<li>c.</li>
<li>a.</li>
</ol>
<p>6 . (a) <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mn>4</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mn>7</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mn>8</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">3,4,7,8</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8389em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">3</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">4</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">7</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">8</span></span></span></span></span>; (b) <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mn>5</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2,5,6</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8389em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">2</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">5</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">6</span></span></span></span></span>; (c) <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mn>2</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1,2,3</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8389em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">2</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">3</span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="chapter-7">Chapter 7<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chapter-7" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="spot-check">Spot check<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Movement of ions (principally <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">âˆ§</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{Na}^{\wedge}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8251em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Na</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8251em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">âˆ§</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">âˆ§</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{K}^{\wedge}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7519em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">K</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7519em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">âˆ§</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> ) across nerve cell membranes enables generation of the action potential. At rest the nerve cell membrane is polarised, i.e. it has a different charge on each side of the plasma membrane. When the membrane is stimulated, the permeability to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">âˆ§</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{Na}^{\wedge}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8251em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Na</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8251em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">âˆ§</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> immediately increases and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">âˆ§</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{Na}^{\wedge}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8251em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Na</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8251em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">âˆ§</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> floods into the cell, causing depolarisation, which generates the action potential. The wave of depolarisation quickly spreads distally, transmitting the impulse. floods out of the cell, restoring the original charge of the membrane. The original levels of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">âˆ§</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{Na}^{\wedge}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8251em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Na</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8251em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">âˆ§</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> and inside and outside the cell are then restored by the action of the sodiumpotassium pump.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The nodes of Ranvier, present in myelinated nerves, allow 'saltatory conduction' of action potentials, where the action potential leaps from one node to the next. Saltatory conduction is faster than simple propagation, also known as continuous conduction.
the method of conduction used in unmyelinated nerves.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is continually secreted by ependymal cells in the choroid plexuses into the ventricles of the brain. The arachnoid villi in the venous sinuses act as valves, pushing CSF back into the blood when the CSF pressure is higher than the venous pressure so that CSF volume remains fairly constant.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Motor areas direct movement of the skeletal muscles; sensory areas receive and interpret impulses, enabling sensory perception; and association areas are involved in higher mental functioning, e.g. reasoning, judgement and emotional responses.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The brain has considerable cognitive reserve and memory may not be affected, although commonly it becomes harder to access more recent memories. Some older adults are susceptible to severe and progressive cognitive impairment, e.g. dementia.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>6 . A child's skull is not completely ossified to allow for growth of the brain, so accumulation of fluid can force the skull bones apart and enlarge the cranium. In the adult - ossified - skull, this is not possible and an increase in cerebrospinal fluid volume (hydrocephalus) will increase intracranial pressure.
7. There is progressive degeneration of neurones that use dopamine as their neurotransmitter, especially around the basal ganglia. The lack of dopamine, which gives fine control to muscle movement, causes the signs and symptoms of Parkinson's disease, such as slow movements and difficulty initiating them, shuffling gait and stooping posture, lack of facial expression and muscle tremors of the extremities.</p>
<p>8 . Both are caused by the herpes zoster virus. Chickenpox is usually contracted in childhood and can be reactivated as shingles throughout life. Chickenpox can be contracted from someone with shingles but not vice versa. After the infection has resolved, the virus may remain dormant in the posterior root ganglia and become active again, causing shingles years later.
9. Myelin in central nervous system nerve fibres is progressively and irreversibly lost (demyelination). Typically, there are periods of relapse, interspersed with remission. Ongoing loss of nervous tissue impairs vision (blurring and double vision are common), causes weakness (sometimes paralysis) of skeletal muscles and incontinence, and disrupts sensation.
10. An intervertebral disc has a soft core called the nucleus pulposus, which is surrounded by an outer layer of cartilage, the annulus fibrosus. When a disc</p>
<p>prolapses, there is herniation of the nucleus pulposus, which causes the annulus fibrosus to
protrude into the neural canal and compress the spinal cord.
11. Compression of a facial nerve causes unilateral drooping and loss of facial expression. Bell's palsy is thought to be caused by viral inflammation and usually resolves spontaneously in a couple of months.
12. Dietary deficiency of folic acid at the time of conception is associated with spina bifida. It may also be associated with exposure to X-rays and maternal rubella during fetal development.
13. Neurones do not normally have the capacity to multiply, whereas the cells of the other structures are all able to replicate.</p>

<p>Chapter 8</p>
<p>Spot check</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Also known as the auditory canal, this S-shaped tube collects, funnels and transmits sound waves to the middle ear. The lateral third contains hairs that trap foreign bodies and ceruminous glands (modified sweat glands) that secrete earwax, which contains lysozyme (a bactericidal enzyme).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The vibrations generated by the tympanic membrane (eardrum) when sound waves strike it are amplified and transmitted across the middle ear by movement of the chain of three ossicles.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The walls of the fluid-filled utricle, saccule and ampulla of the semicircular canals contain hair cells
that are the sensory receptors of balance. As the head moves, resultant movement of the perilymph and endolymph in the vestibule and semicircular canals stimulates the hair cells, generating nerve impulses in the vestibulocochlear nerve. These impulses are conducted to the cerebellum, where they are integrated and processed with visual and proprioceptor impulses so that balance is maintained.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Constriction of the pupils, convergence of the eyes and increase of the refractory power of the lens.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Reflex closure when touched or when bright light shines into the eyes protects the internal structures, while blinking spreads tears and oily secretions over the cornea, keeping the anterior structures moist.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The sense of smell.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Sweet, sour, bitter and salt.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Presbyopia.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Also known as serous otitis media, glue ear is a collection of serous fluid in the middle ear cavity.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>This type of hearing impartment arises from abnormality of the nerves of the inner ear, cochlear nerve or auditory area of the cerebrum (compare with conductive hearing impairment).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Opacity of the lens that impairs passage of light waves thorough it, especially when it is dark or the light is poor.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It is the only source of arterial blood to the eye.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Myopia.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="review-and-revise">Review and revise<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#review-and-revise" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>Roof, olfactory bulb, olfactory tract, cerebral cortex/ cerebrum.</li>
<li>Otitis media, auditory tube, pus, tympanum/ tympanic membrane.</li>
<li>a.</li>
<li>c.</li>
<li>F.</li>
<li>T.</li>
<li>(a) 3 , (b) 6 , (c) 8 , (d) 1 , (e) 4 , (f) 7 , (g) 5 , (h) 2 .</li>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="chapter-9">Chapter 9<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chapter-9" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="spot-check">Spot check<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>The anterior pituitary is supplied with blood from the pituitary portal system, which contains releasing and inhibiting hormones secreted by the hypothalamus. These influence secretion of other specific anterior pituitary hormones into the bloodstream.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Calcitonin.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>When blood calcium levels are low, parathyroid hormone (PTH) secretion is stimulated. PTH
increases blood calcium levels by releasing calcium stored in bone by stimulating osteoclasts (bone-destroying cells) to release calcium from bone tissue, and by increasing its reabsorption from the renal tubules.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Glucocorticoids, mineralocorticoids and sex hormones (gonadocorticoids).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Glucagon.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>6 . Night time.
7. Placenta, intestinal mucosa, kidney.</p>
<p>8 . Any two of: stimulation of intestinal secretions, contraction of smooth muscle and essential role in blood clotting.
9. Type 2 diabetes.
10. Diabetes insipidus.
11. Any six of: high metabolic rate, weight loss with good appetite, anxiety, restlessness, tachycardia, palpitations, atrial fibrillation, feeling warm, heat intolerance and exophthalmos in Graves' disease.
12. A benign parathyroid tumour.
13. Hypertension, adiposity of the face, neck and abdomen, muscle wasting, osteoporosis and pathological fractures, hyperglycaemia and glycosuria, thinning of the skin, peptic ulceration.
14. They secrete the sympathetic hormones adrenaline (epinephrine) and noradrenaline (norepinephrine), which cause these effects.
15. Glucose is not normally present in urine, as it is all absorbed by the renal tubules. In DM, some glucose remains in the renal filtrate, increasing the osmotic pressure. Less water is reabsorbed and the volume of urine is therefore increased (polyuria). Polyuria leads to dehydration and thirst (polydipsia), which is quenched by increasing fluid intake.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="review-and-revise">Review and revise<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#review-and-revise" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
