<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="chapter-10">Chapter 10<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chapter-10" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="spot-check">Spot check<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Ethmoid (septum, lateral wall and roof), vomer (septum), maxilla (floor), sphenoid (roof), nasal
(roof), frontal (roof), palatine (floor), inferior concha (wall).</li>
<li>This area of specialised epithelium is found in the lining of the roof of the nose. It detects molecules of odorous materials and transmits nerve signals along the olfactory nerve to the brain, where the sensation of smell is perceived.</li>
<li>The lingual tonsils are found on either side of the base of the tongue (see also Fig. 6.7), the pharyngeal tonsils lie in the nasopharynx and the palatine tonsils are in the oropharynx.</li>
<li>The middle ear and the nasopharynx.</li>
<li>The epiglottis, thyroid, cricoid cartilages (all single) and the arytenoid cartilages (paired).</li>
</ol>
<p>6 . Sound, including speech, is generated by vibrations of the true vocal cords. Pitch is determined by
the length and tightness of the cords. Volume is determined by the strength of vibration of the cords, so the more forceful the air flow, the louder the sound.
7. The tracheal cartilages are C -shaped, with the oesophagus sitting against the gap at the back, allowing the oesophagus to expand comfortably when swallowing.</p>
<p>8 . This is ciliated columnar epithelium containing goblet cells for mucus production. The cilia sweep the blanket of mucus along with adherent particles towards the mouth for swallowing.</p>
<ol start="9">
<li>The apical surface covers the lung tips and the base is the inferior surface, which sits on the diaphragm. The medial surfaces face into the mediastinum, and the hilum of the lung is found here. The costal surfaces are the broad outer surfaces of the lungs that lie immediately below the ribcage.</li>
<li>It allows the lungs to expand during inspiration, and also to return to their original size by elastic recoil during expiration.</li>
<li>It allows for adjustment of bronchiolar diameter, to regulate airflow through different areas of the lungs.</li>
<li>The main cell type is squamous epithelium, which is only one cell thick. The outer surface of each alveolus is wrapped in a dense network of blood capillaries to maximise gas exchange. Macrophages are also found in the alveolar wall, for defence, as well as septal cells, which produce surfactant.</li>
<li>Contraction (and descent) of the diaphragm, and contraction of the external intercostal muscles, which lifts and expands the ribcage.</li>
<li>The inspiratory and expiratory reserve volumes.</li>
<li>Found on the surface of the brain, and also in the aorta and carotid arteries, these chemoreceptors are very sensitive to even slight increases in carbon dioxide levels and stimulate breathing in response. They also respond to falling oxygen levels, but oxygen levels have to fall significantly before this triggers these chemoreceptors.</li>
<li>The cartilages associated with the ribcage, e.g. the costal cartilages, become stiffer and the respiratory musculature becomes weaker with age, in line with a general decline in age-related muscle strength.</li>
<li>Both are viral but caused by different groups of viruses. Influenza is much more severe and runs a longer course than a cold; it is associated with muscle pain, high temperature and an increased risk of secondary bacterial chest infections.</li>
<li>Airflow through obstructed airways is reduced or even stopped altogether, meaning that the volume of fresh air reaching the alveoli falls. This leads to accumulation of carbon dioxide in the distal airways and alveoli, and a reduction in the pressure gradient between the air in the alveoli and the bloodstream. As the pressure gradient reduces, diffusion also reduces and less carbon dioxide passes into the bloodstream for excretion.</li>
<li>This is air in the tissues of the chest; air can leak into the tissues from damaged alveoli or from the external environment if the chest wall is damaged, e.g. by a broken rib.</li>
<li>Asbestos, especially blue asbestos, fibres are so tiny that they can travel all the way through the respiratory tree to the alveoli, where they trigger a protective</li>
</ol>
<p>inflammatory response, mediated by alveolar macrophages. This can lead to progressive fibrotic changes that destroy lung tissue and increase the risk of a certain form of lung cancer, mesothelioma.
21. Lobar pneumonia refers to disease restricted to a discrete lung lobe or lobes, whereas bronchopneumonia is diffuse infection spread throughout lung tissue.
22. This is reactivation, after a variable period, of latent tuberculosis that has not been resolved from the initial (primary) infection.
23. Usually centrally, in a main bronchus.
24. The lungs of a premature baby may not have developed sufficiently to produce surfactant in sufficient quantities to keep the alveoli open, so large sections of the lung can fail to expand at birth.
25. This is due to penetrating injury that damages the pleura and opens up the pleural space, sucking air into the pleural space (because the intrapleural pressure is lower than atmospheric pressure) and collapsing all or part of the soft lung in the region of the breach.</p>

<li>
<p>The portal vein enters, carrying blood from the stomach, spleen, pancreas and small and large intestines through the liver on its way back to the heart. The hepatic artery enters, carrying oxygenated blood. (Venous drainage of the liver is through the hepatic veins, which do not leave via the portal fissure.) The left and right hepatic ducts leave the liver, transporting bile to the gall bladder, and lymph vessels leave, draining lymph to the abdominal and thoracic lymph nodes</p>

<li>
<p>Anabolism means synthesis of larger molecules from smaller ones and usually requires adenosine triphosphate (ATP). Catabolism involves the breakdown of large molecules into smaller ones, often releasing energy that can be used to synthesise ATP.</p>

<li>
<p>Filtration, selective reabsorption, secretion.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Autoregulation is independent of nervous control and maintains renal blood flow at a fairly constant level across a wide range of systolic blood pressure (80-200 mmHg ). Renal blood flow (and glomerular filtration) only becomes impaired when systolic pressure drops below about 80 mmHg , e.g. in severe shock.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>As urine accumulates, the ureters, which are inserted obliquely into the posterior wall of the bladder, are compressed, preventing backflow.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The detrusor muscle forms the middle layer of the bladder wall. It consists of smooth muscle fibres and elastic tissue, and when the muscle contracts, the bladder empties.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>External urethral sphincter.</p>
</li>

<p>6 . To establish continence (conscious bladder control), it is necessary to learn to control the external urethral sphincter and override the innate spinal reflex until it is convenient to pass urine.

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="review-and-revise">Review and revise<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#review-and-revise" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

</ol>
<p>8 . (a) 3 , (b) 5 , (c) 8 , (d) 7 , (e) 2 , (f) 1 , (g) 6 , (h) 4 .</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="chapter-14">Chapter 14<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chapter-14" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="spot-check">Spot check<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>It provides a physical, fairly waterproof barrier against entry of microbes and damage by, for example, chemicals and physical agents; specialised immune dendritic (Langerhans) cells phagocytose invading microbes that do enter through the skin; abundant sensory nerve endings enable reflex withdrawal from harmful stimuli, e.g. heat; and the pigment melanin protects against ultraviolet rays in sunlight.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Core temperature below <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>35</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">âˆ˜</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">35^{\circ} \mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">3</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">5</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">âˆ˜</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Inflammation, proliferation, maturation.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Sebaceous glands secrete sebum, which provides some waterproofing. They become more active at puberty but their activity declines with ageing, so that the skin of older individuals is less able to tolerate excessive moisture.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Malignant melanoma.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="review-and-revise">Review and revise<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#review-and-revise" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<li>Superficial (epidermal), partial thickness, full thickness.</li>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="answers-to-self-assessment-questions">Answers to self-assessment questions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#answers-to-self-assessment-questions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="chapter-15">Chapter 15<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chapter-15" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="spot-check">Spot check<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Chemotaxis is the active movement of defence cells like neutrophils towards a target such as a bacterium, so that it can attack and destroy it by phagocytosis.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Increased temperature tends to inhibit bacterial growth and activity, and enhances the activity of phagocytes.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Each immune cell or antibody is designed to target one specific antigen.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Regulatory T-cells mediate immunological tolerance,
i.e. make sure that the immune response does not direct itself against host tissues. Cytotoxic T-cells are the soldiers of the immune system and directly kill target cells.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Type I hypersensitivity (allergy) is an immediate response to an allergen, involving the release of large amounts of histamine. Type IV hypersensitivity is a much slower-onset response and involves abnormally active T-cells, which cause chronic inflammation and tissue damage.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>HIV targets the immune system, particularly CD 4 T-cells, which means that infected individuals are at increased risk of other infections. Their immunocompromised state allows normally non-pathogenic organisms to establish themselves and cause opportunistic infection.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="review-and-revise">Review and revise<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#review-and-revise" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>20 , immune complexes, bacteria, binds to and damages bacterial cell walls, binds to bacteria and stimulates phagocytosis, stimulates chemotaxis.</li>
<li>a.</li>
<li>a.</li>
<li>c.</li>
<li>(a) <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mn>3</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mn>4</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mn>6</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mn>7</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2,3,4,6,7</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8389em; </ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="chapter-16">Chapter 16<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chapter-16" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="spot-check">Spot check<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Osteoblasts are found in the membranes covering and lining bone and are active in bone building and repair. As they lay down new bone and become encased within it, they differentiate into osteocytes. Osteocytes are mature bone cells that monitor and repair bone and live individually in pockets called lacunae within the bone. If bone is damaged they de-differentiate into osteoblasts again to participate in the repair process.</li>
<li>Lengthening of long bones stops when the cartilaginous epiphyseal plates at either end convert to bone. This happens at puberty when levels of the sex hormones (testosterone and oestrogen) rise.</li>
</ol>
<p>Puberty occurs later in males than females and so bones generally have more time to keep lengthening; therefore male adult height is, on average, greater.
3. Squamous suture (with the temporal bone), coronal suture (with the frontal bone), sagittal suture (with the other parietal bone) and the lambdoidal suture (with the occipital bone).
4. This is C7. In common with other vertebrae, it has a rounded body and two transverse processes, and a foramen for passage of the spinal cord. The posterior (spinous) process is large and prominent, and is easily felt through the skin at the base of the neck.</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>On the scapula; the acromion process is the highest point of the shoulder, easily felt under the skin.</li>
<li>The two arches of the foot, the transverse and longitudinal arches, are the curved shapes formed by the bones of the foot. They are held in these curves by the ligaments and muscles of the foot. The arched design of the foot allows it to act as a lever to propel the body forwards in walking and running, and absorb the shocks associated with these movements.</li>
<li>In rotation the whole structure turns around a central axis, like a pencil being rolled between the palms. In circumduction one end of the structure is fixed and the other end draws a circle.</li>
<li>The glenoid cavity also has a rim of fibrocartilage, which makes it deeper, but the shoulder joint depends heavily on a sturdy sleeve of ligaments and muscles to keep the joint in place. Important structures include the glenohumeral and coracohumeral ligaments and the rotator cuff muscles.</li>
<li>A motor unit is a motor nerve and all the skeletal muscle fibres it supplies. It can be small (nerve and a few muscle fibres), giving fine control, or large (nerve and thousands of muscle fibres), giving large-scale, powerful movements.</li>
<li>The origin of the muscle is the attachment closest to the midline, and is usually the end of the muscle that is fixed (kept stationary) when the muscle contracts. The insertion is the attachment farthest from the midline, and is usually the end that moves when the muscle contracts.</li>
<li>Vitamin D. Lack of this vitamin leads to poor bone mineralisation. In children, this leads to bowing of the lower limbs because the bone contains a higher proportion of collagen and is unable to support the weight of the upper body. In adults, whose bones have reached their full length, poor mineralisation leads to osteomalacia, with increased risk of fracture.</li>
<li>A malignant bone tumour.</li>
<li>Deposition of urate crystals in the joints leads to acute inflammation, which can cause permanent damage if prolonged.</li>
<li>The median nerve, as it passes through the carpal tunnel in the wrist, formed by the flexor retinaculum stretched across the front of the carpal bones.</li>
</ol>
<p>Compression of the nerve causes tingling, pain and paraesthesia of the fingers.
15. Acetylcholine (ACh) receptors at the neuromuscular junction. This means a loss of function of skeletal muscles because the ACh released by the motor nerve cannot activate contraction of the muscle.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="review-and-revise">Review and revise<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#review-and-revise" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="chapter-17">Chapter 17<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chapter-17" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="spot-check">Spot check<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Histones are support proteins incorporated into the highly folded DNA molecule.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Guanine.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>UAACUG.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Codon.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Because the two gametes (a sperm and an ovum) that fuse at fertilisation to make a new cell, which will develop into a new human being, must each contain only half the normal number of chromosomes ( 23 instead of 46 ).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Prior to the first meiotic division the replicated chromosomes exchange genes between themselves. This means that the four chromatids now have a new combination of genes and are all different from each other.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The chance is <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>100</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">100 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">100%</span></span></span></span></span> because, although the child may receive the recessive non-tongue-rolling gene from the mother, they are also guaranteed to receive a dominant tongue-rolling gene from the father.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The chance is <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>0</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">0 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">0%</span></span></span></span></span> because both parents must have two copies each of the recessive o gene, so do not have an A gene to pass to a child.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A mutated gene that promotes cell growth and prevents cell death, but can cause cancerous changes in the cell.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The gene that produces phenylalanine hydroxylase is faulty and the affected individual does not produce
the enzyme, meaning they cannot metabolise phenylalanine, which accumulates in the bloodstream and causes a range of problems including nervous system damage.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="review-and-revise">Review and revise<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#review-and-revise" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>Single gene, phenylalanine hydroxylase, phenylalanine, tyrosine, nervous.</li>
<li>b.</li>
<li>d.</li>
<li>c.</li>
<li>(a) <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>b</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mn>4</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>c</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mn>6</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>d</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mn>5</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>d</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mi>l</mi><mo separator="true">,</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2,(b) 4,(c) 6,(d) 5,(d) l,(f) 3</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">2</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal">b</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mord">4</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal">c</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mord">6</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal">d</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mord">5</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal">d</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.01968em;">l</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10764em;">f</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mord">3</span></span></span></span></span>.</li>
<li>
<ol start="7">
<li>RNA; 2. DNA; 3. Both; 4. RNA; 5. Both; 6. DNA; 7. DNA; 8. RNA; 9. DNA; 10. RNA.</li>
</ol>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="chapter-18">Chapter 18<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chapter-18" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="spot-check">Spot check<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Rugae are folds in the vaginal wall that expand during childbirth to accommodate delivery of the baby.</li>
<li>The myometrium, the uterine muscle, which contracts during childbirth to expel the baby.</li>
<li>The deferent duct carries sperm from the testes.</li>
</ol>
<p>The seminal vesicle and prostate gland add their secretions as it passes into the urethra.</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>Corpus spongiosum.</li>
<li>The stage of fetal development when the zygote is a hollow ball of 70-100 cells.</li>
<li>One month.</li>
<li>Treponema pallidum.</li>
<li>Antibiotics kill the natural bacterial flora of the vagina, allowing other organisms, including Candida albicans (which causes thrush), to proliferate.</li>
<li>A benign tumour of muscle. When it is found in the uterus, it is called a fibroid.</li>
<li>Up to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>90</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">90 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">90%</span></span></span></span></span> of cases of cervical cancer are due to infection with human papilloma virus, which is sexually transmitted.</li>
<li>Accumulated fluid within the tunica vaginalis of the scrotum.</li>
<li>Gynaecomastia.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="review-and-revise">Review and revise<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#review-and-revise" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>Stratified, epithelium, smooth muscle, areolar, rugae, uterine cervix.</li>
<li>b.</li>
<li>d.</li>
<li>b.</li>
<li>a.</li>
<li>Internal: vagina, uterus, uterine tubes, ovary.</li>
</ol>
<p>External: labia majora, labia minora, clitoris, hymen, vestibule.
This page intentionally left blank</p>
<p>This page intentionally left blank</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="glossary">Glossary<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#glossary" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Abduction Movement of a body part away from the midline of the body
Abscess Pus-filled cavity within tissue Accommodation Focusing adjustment of the eyes to view close objects</p>
<p>Acid Substance that releases hydrogen ions in solution Acidosis Situation when blood pH falls below the normal pH range</p>
<p>Action potential Electrical current (impulse) conducted along a nerve cell (neurone)
Active transport Movement of substances across a cell membrane, up the concentration gradient, and requiring energy Acute Of sudden onset</p>
<p>Adaptation Lessening of response by sensory receptors to prolonged stimulation
Adduction Movement of a body part towards the midline of the body
Adenosine triphosphate (ATP) Molecular store of chemical energy for chemical reactions Adhesions Fusion of two separate tissue layers with fibrous tissue, usually following inflammation Adipose tissue Fat tissue Aerobic Requiring oxygen Aetiology Cause of a disease Afferent Carrying or travelling towards an organ Afterload Resistance to blood flow from the heart, determined mainly by the diameter of the arteries Agranulocyte White blood cell with no granules in its cytoplasm (i.e. lymphocytes and monocytes)</p>
<p>Alkali Substance that accepts hydrogen ions in water or solution
Alkalosis Situation when blood pH rises above the normal pH range
Allele Form of a gene carried on a chromosome Allergy Targeting and destruction of harmless antigens by the immune system, often with detrimental effects on normal body tissues</p>
<p>Alveolar ventilation Amount of air reaching the alveoli with each breath
Alveolus (pL alveoli) Air sac in the lungs; also, milk-secreting sac in the mammary glands Amino acid Building block of protein</p>
<p>Anabolism Synthesis of larger molecules from smaller ones
Anaerobic Not requiring oxygen Anaphase Third phase of mitosis Anaphylaxis Severest form of allergy, with multiple, potentially fatal, systemic effects Anastomosis Joining of two tubes, e.g. (i) in blood vessels where there are no capillary beds, (ii) following surgery</p>
<p>Anatomical position Position in which the body is upright, with the head facing forwards, the arms at the sides with the palms of the hands facing forwards, and the feet together; term used to maintain consistency of anatomical descriptions Aneurysm Weakness in the wall of an artery Anion Negatively charged ion Anterior (ventral) Describes a body part or structure lying to the front</p>
<p>Antibody Defensive protein synthesised by
B-lymphocytes in response to the presence of antigen Antigen Protein that stimulates the body's immunological defences</p>
<p>Antimicrobial Substance or mechanism that kills or inhibits growth of microorganisms</p>
<p>Appendicular skeleton (cf. axial skeleton) Shoulder girdle, upper limbs, pelvic girdle and lower limbs Arrhythmia Abnormal heart rhythm Arteriole Small artery</p>
<p>Artery Blood vessel that carries blood away from the heart
Articulation Joint
Atrophy Decrease in cell size resulting in shrinkage of an organ or body part Auditory Related to hearing</p>
<p>Autoimmunity Targeting and sometimes destruction of one's own or 'self tissues by the immune system Autoregulation Ability of a tissue to control its own blood supply independently Autorhythmicity Ability of a tissue to generate its own electrical signals</p>
<p>Autosome Any one of the chromosomes in pairs 1-22 (i.e. all but the sex chromosomes)</p>
<p>Axial skeleton (cf. appendicular skeleton) Skull, vertebral column, sternum (breastbone) and ribs</p>
<p>Bacterium (pL bacteria) Single-celled microorganism, common in the external environment; some bacteria can cause disease</p>
<p>Baroreceptor Sensory receptor sensitive to pressure (stretch)
Basal metabolic rate Energy use of the body when at rest in a warm environment, without having eaten for 12 hours</p>
<p>Benign Non-cancerous or non-serious condition for which treatment may be required Blastocyst Hollow ball of cells that embeds in the uterine wall during fetal development Blood-brain barrier Collective term given to the physiological</p>
<p>adaptations in the central nervous system that prevent many blood-borne substances from accessing it</p>
<p>Bradycardia Abnormally slow heart rate Bronchoconstriction Narrowing of the larger airways and bronchioles</p>
<p>Bronchodilation Widening of the larger airways and bronchioles
Buffer Substance that resists a shift in the pH of body fluids Capacitance vessel Vessel that can expand to contain large quantities of blood at low pressure (veins) Capillary Tiny blood vessel between an arteriole and a venule, which has leaky walls to allow exchange of substances between the blood and tissues Carbohydrate Any of a group of organic compounds that includes the sugars and starches Carcinogen Cancer-causing substance Carcinoma Tumour arising from epithelial tissue Cardiac Of the heart</p>
<p>Cardiac output (CO) Amount of blood ejected by one ventricle every minute: <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mo>=</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{CO}=</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">CO</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span></span></span></span></span> heart rate <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>Ã—</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(\mathrm{HR}) \times</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">HR</span></span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mord">Ã—</span></span></span></span></span> stroke volume <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(\mathrm{SV})</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">SV</span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span></p>
<p>Catabolism Breaking down of larger molecules into smaller ones
Catalyst Substance that speeds up a biochemical reaction without taking part in it Cation Positively charged ion</p>
<p>Central nervous system Brain and spinal cord Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) Fluid bathing the brain and spinal cord</p>
<p>Chemoreceptor Sensory receptor sensitive to chemicals in solution
Chemotaxis Movement of a cell towards a chemical attractant
Chondrocyte Mature cartilage cell Chromatin Uncoiled state of chromosomes during interphase</p>
<p>Chromosome Sausage-shaped structure consisting of a tightly coiled molecule of DNA visible at the end of interphase</p>
<p>Chronic Long-standing or recurring Cilia (sing, cilium) Microscopic cell extensions for moving materials through the lumen of a tube Circadian rhythm Regular, predictable fluctuation of a physiological function over a 24 -hour period Circumduction Movement of a body part to describe a cone shape</p>
<p>Citric acid cycle (Krebs) Important sequence of aerobic metabolic reactions in cellular energy production Coagulation Blood clotting</p>
<p>Co-dominance Situation when more than one form of a gene is dominant Coitus Act of sexual intercourse Commensal Harmless microorganism that lives in the body or on its surfaces, which may bring advantages to its host, e.g. by producing vitamins or by preventing the growth of pathogens Communicable Describes a</p>
<p>disease that is transferable from one person to another Compliance Stretchability of a tissue Compound Molecule containing more than one element Concentration gradient Situation where two areas of, for example, liquid have different concentrations of a solute Congenital Inherited</p>
<p>Constriction Narrowing of a tube or vessel due to contraction of circular muscle in its wall Convergence Turning of the eyes inwards to focus on a close object</p>
<p>Cortex Outer layer of a gland or structure Costal Related to the ribs
Cytoplasm Contents of a cell except the nucleus (i.e. cytosol plus organelles)
Deamination Removal of the amine group from an amino acid
Deep Describes a body structure or part that is not close to the body surface
Defaecation Expulsion of faeces from the rectum Deglutition Swallowing Dehydration Excessive loss of body water Deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) Molecule in which the genetic code is written, and packaged into chromosomes in the nucleus Diapedesis Movement of an independently motile cell from one place to another Diaphysis Shaft of a long bone Diastole Resting period of the heart or its individual chambers</p>
<p>Diastolic blood pressure Pressure recorded in the systemic circulation (often at the arm) when the pressure is at its lowest, corresponding to relaxation of the myocardium; the lower of the two measurements used to denote a blood pressure recording</p>
<p>Differentiation Process of cell specialisation Diffusion Movement of substances down a
concentration gradient, which does not require energy or the presence of a membrane Dilation Widening of a tube or vessel due to relaxation of circular muscle in its wall Diploid Describes a cell with 46 chromosomes, the whole complement of 23 pairs Distal Further from the origin of a body part or point of attachment of a limb Diuresis Passing of urine</p>
<p>Dominant In genetics, the preferential expression of one form of a gene over another Efferent Carrying or travelling away from an organ Elasticity Ability of a tissue to stretch and recoil to its original length or shape</p>
<p>Electrolyte Inorganic ion in body fluids, which conducts electricity
Element Chemical whose atoms are all of the same type Embolus Blood clot or other substance that travels in a blood vessel and may lodge there, blocking a smaller vessel</p>
<p>Embryo In humans, the developing offspring in the first eight weeks of development after fertilisation, following which it is referred to as the fetus</p>
<p>Endocrine gland Ductless gland that secretes a hormone that travels to its target organ in the bloodstream</p>
<p>Endogenous Internal, produced by the body Endothelium Epithelium lining blood vessels Enzyme Protein substance that speeds up (catalyses) chemical reactions</p>
<p>Epidermis Outermost layer of the skin Epinephrine Another term for adrenaline Epiphysis Each end of a long bone Epithelium Tissue that lines and covers most body organs</p>
<p>Equilibrium State of physiological balance or equivalence
Erythropoiesis Production of red blood cells Essential nutrient Nutrient that must be eaten in the diet</p>
<p>Eversion Turning the soles of the feet outwards Exocrine gland Gland that secretes its product into ducts for transport</p>
<p>Exocytosis Process by which materials are expelled from a cell
Exogenous External; not produced by the body
Expiration (cf. inspiration) Physical process of breathing out
Extension Increase in the angle between two bones, straightening a limb
External respiration Exchange of gases in the lungs Extracellular Outside a cell Extrinsic pathway Clotting process triggered by damaged extravascular tissues Facilitated diffusion Form of diffusion that requires carrier proteins for transfer of substances across cell membranes</p>
<p>Faeces Waste product of digestion excreted through the anus
Fascia Fibrous membrane that supports, covers and separates muscles
Fertilisation Penetration of an ovum by a spermatozoon to form a zygote that can grow into a fetus Fibre Muscle cell; in nutrition, the indigestible part of the diet also known as non-starch polysaccharide Fibrinolysis Breakdown of a blood clot Fibroblast Connective tissue cell that produces collagen fibres</p>
<p>Filtration Movement of small molecules, by hydrostatic pressure, through a selectively permeable membrane Fistula Abnormal passageway between two organs or an organ and the body surface Flagella (sing, flagellum) Long cell extensions used for cellular propulsion</p>
<p>Flexion Reduction of the angle between two bones, bending a limb
Follicle Small secretory gland</p>
<p>Gamete Ovum or spermatozoon (reproductive cell)
Gastric Of the stomach
Gene Area on a chromosome that codes for one particular protein Genome All the genes in a cell Genotype Genetic make-up of an individual Gestation The process of intrauterine development, between conception and birth Glia Nervous tissue that supports neurones Globulin One class of plasma protein, including antibodies Glucocorticoids Group of steroid (fat-based) adrenal cortex hormones essential for life Gluconeogenesis Production of glucose from non-carbohydrate molecules Glucose Simple sugar used by cells for energy Glycogen Very high-molecular weight form of glucose used for storage</p>
<p>Glycolysis Anaerobic breakdown of glucose to release some of its stored energy Granulation tissue Newly formed repair tissue following tissue damage</p>
<p>Granulocyte General term for a white blood cell without cytoplasmic granules Granulopoiesis Production of white blood cells Gustation Taste</p>
<p>Haematemesis Vomiting of blood Haemolysis Breakdown of red blood cells Haemopoiesis Production of blood cells Haemorrhage Profuse blood loss Haemostasis Cessation of blood flow Haploid Describes a cell with 23 chromosomes (half the total chromosome complement)</p>
<p>Hepatic Of the liver
Heterozygous In genetics, describes a form of a gene on one chromosome that is different to the form of the same gene on the other chromosome of the pair Highdensity lipoprotein Lipid/protein complex in the bloodstream that is important in transporting cholesterol to the liver for disposal Hilum Indented area of an organ where blood vessels, nerves and ducts enter and leave Homeostasis Maintenance of a stable internal environment</p>
<p>Homozygous In genetics, describes a form of a gene on one chromosome that is the same as the form of the same gene on the other chromosome of the pair Hormone Substance secreted by an endocrine gland that is transported in the blood and acts on specific target cells elsewhere in the body Hydrophilic Water-loving Hydrophobic Water-hating</p>
<p>Hydrostatic pressure Pressure exerted by a fluid on the walls of its container, e.g. by blood on the walls of blood vessels</p>
<p>Hypersecretion Abnormally high secretion of a body product, e.g. a hormone
Hypersensitivity Abnormal immune response directed against either a harmless antigen (allergy) or a "self antigen (autoimmunity)</p>
<p>Hypertension Abnormally high blood pressure Hypertonic Describes a solution with a solute concentration higher than body fluids Hypertrophy Increase in cell size resulting in enlargement of an organ or body part Hyperventilation Abnormally high respiratory effort, associated with loss of excessive amounts of carbon dioxide</p>
<p>Hyposecretion Abnormally low secretion of a body product, e.g. a hormone Hypotension Abnormally low blood pressure Hypothermia Abnormally low body temperature (core temperature <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&lt;</mo><msup><mn>35</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">âˆ˜</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&lt;35^{\circ} \mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&lt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">3</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">5</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">âˆ˜</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span> )</p>
<p>Hypotonic Describes a solution with a solute concentration lower than body fluids Hypoventilation Abnormally low respiratory effort, associated with retention of carbon dioxide Hypoxia Inadequate levels of oxygen in the tissues</p>
<p>Iatrogenic Describes a condition resulting from a healthcare intervention
Idiopathic Describes a condition of unknown cause Immunity Body defence mechanisms against a specific disease</p>
<p>Incontinence Inability to control the voiding of urine Infarction Death of a region of tissue due to interruption of its blood supply Infection Invasion of body tissues by pathogenic organisms</p>
<p>Inferior Describes a body part or structure that is closer to the soles of the feet
Inflammation Non-specific tissue response to damage Ingestion Taking in of substances orally, i.e. through the mouth</p>
<p>Insensible water loss Loss of water through the skin and respiratory tract
Insertion (cf. origin) Point where a muscle is attached to the bone it moves
Inspiration (cf. expiration) Physical process of breathing in
Integumentary Of the skin
Internal respiration Exchange of gases in the tissues Interphase Phase of the cell cycle when there is no division</p>
<p>Interstitial fluid Fluid situated between body cells, also known as tissue fluid
Intracellular Inside a cell
Intrinsic factor Protein secreted by the stomach required for absorption of vitamin B 12 Intrinsic pathway Clotting process triggered by damaged blood vessels</p>
<p>Inversion Turning of the soles of the feet to face each other</p>
<p>Involuntary Not under conscious control Ion Charged atom (which has either lost or acquired electrons)</p>
<p>Ionising radiation Radiation that generates ions when it passes through atoms, and can damage cells by changing the atoms in the molecules that make up living tissue, e.g. X-rays</p>
<p>Ischaemia Impaired blood supply to a body part Isometric Describes muscle work where the tension in the muscle rises but the muscle does not shorten, e.g. if trying to lift a weight that is too heavy to move</p>
<p>Isotonic Describes muscle work where the muscle shortens as the tension rises, allowing, for example, a load to be lifted by the arm; in chemistry, solutions with a solute concentration the same as body tissues</p>
<p>Isotope Form of an element that has a different number of neutrons from the principal form</p>
<p>Karyotype Photographic presentation of a cell's
chromosomes as matched pairs in descending order of size
Lactation Production of breast milk Lateral Describes a structure further from the midline or at the side of the body Leukocyte General term for a white blood cell Leukopenia Low blood white cell count Ligament Band of connective tissue that binds one bone to another</p>
<p>Lipase Enzyme that breaks down fat Lipid General term for any substance that does not dissolve in water but dissolves in non-polar solvents like alcohol</p>
<p>Lipolysis Breakdown of fat
Low-density lipoprotein Lipid/protein complex in the bloodstream that is associated with deposition of cholesterol in arterial walls</p>
<p>Lumen Central passageway within an internal tube or duct
Lymph Watery fluid drained by the lymphatic system from the tissue spaces Lysis Destruction of a cell, e.g. haemolysis Lysozyme Antimicrobial enzyme present in some body fluids</p>
<p>Macrophage Phagocytic cell usually found in connective tissue Malignant
Cancerous Mastication Chewing Meatus Opening into a passage Medial Describes a structure that is nearer to the midline</p>
<p>Median plane Imaginary line that divides the body longitudinally into right and left halves Mediastinum Region between the lungs, containing the heart, great vessels, trachea and other important structures</p>
<p>Medulla Inner layer of a gland or structure Meiosis Process of cell division by which gametes are formed</p>
<p>Melaena Blood in the faeces
Menarche Onset of puberty in females, marked by the start of menstruation
Menopause Time of the female lifespan when reproductive function ceases Menstruation (menses) Regular shedding of the uterine lining, usually monthly, during the reproductive period of the female lifespan Metabolic pathway Sequence of metabolic steps in cellular biochemistry</p>
<p>Metabolism All the chemical reactions that take place within the body
Metaphase Second phase of mitosis
Metastasis (pL metastases) Secondary deposit from a primary malignant tumour Microbe Microorganism, e.g. a fungus, bacterium or virus</p>
<p>Micturition Passing urine
Mitosis Process of cell division giving two identical daughter cells
Mole In chemistry, the quantity of a substance representing its molecular weight in grams Motor nerve or neurone Efferent nerve that carries impulses from the central nervous system to muscles or glands</p>
<p>Mucosa or mucous membrane Lining of body tracts Mutagen Any substance that causes mutation Mutation Genetic change that arises during cell division Myelin Eatty substance that surrounds the axons of myelinated nerves</p>
<p>Myofilaments Intracellular protein threads within muscle cells, made of either actin or myosin, responsible for muscle cell contraction Necrosis Cell death caused by an injury or a pathological condition</p>
<p>Negative feedback (cf. positive feedback) Control mechanism that resists and reverses any change from normal in a physiological system Neoplasm New growth, which may be benign or malignant</p>
<p>Nephron Structure in the kidneys responsible for the formation of urine
Neuromuscular junction Synapse between a motor nerve and a skeletal muscle cell Neurone Nerve cell</p>
<p>Neurotransmitter Chemical that transmits an impulse between one nerve and the next, or between a nerve and the neuromuscular junction Non-specific defence Defence mechanisms of the body that are effective against different types of threat, e.g. the skin, inflammation, complement Norepinephrine Alternative name for noradrenaline Nucleotide Building block of nucleic acids Nutrient Any substance that is digested, absorbed and used to promote body function Oedema Tissue swelling due to collection of fluid in the intercellular spaces Olfaction Sense of smell Oncogenic Cancer-causing</p>
<p>Organ Body part, composed of different tissues, that carries out a specific body function Organelle Intracellular structure that carries out a specific function</p>
<p>Organic Molecule or substance containing carbon
Origin Point of attachment of a muscle to a bone that moves least during muscle contraction Osmoreceptors Specialised sensory receptors sensitive to solute concentration</p>
<p>Osmosis Movement of water down its concentration gradient across a semipermeable membrane Osmotic pressure Pressure exerted by water in a solution</p>
<p>Ossicles Bones of the middle ear: hammer, anvil and stirrup
Ossification Production of bone tissue Osteoid Organic constituent of bone tissue Osteon Structural unit of compact bone Osteopenia Age-related bone degeneration Ovulation Release of a mature ovum from the ovary Oxidative phosphorylation Aerobic, high
energy-generating metabolic process of cellular respiration
Oxyhaemoglobin Oxygenated form of haemoglobin
Parasympathetic nervous system Division of the autonomic nervous system that prepares the body for 'rest and repair'</p>
<p>Parietal layer (cf. visceral layer) Layer of serous membrane lining a body cavity Parturition Childbirth</p>
<p>Passive transport Any form of transport within the body that does not require the use of energy Pathogen Microorganism capable of causing disease Peptidase Enzyme that breaks down protein Peripheral nervous system Nervous tissue that is not part of the brain or spinal cord Peripheral resistance Force against which the blood has to push to move through the arterial circulation, determined mainly by the diameter of the arterioles Peristalsis Rhythmical contraction of smooth muscle in the walls of hollow organs and tubes, e.g. the alimentary canal</p>
<p>Phagocytosis Defence mechanism by which body cells consume and destroy foreign materials; 'cell eating' Phenotype Expression of the genes in an individual, e.g. hair colour, height, etc.</p>
<p>Phospholipid Fat-based molecule containing phosphate, essential to the structure of the cell membrane
pH scale Scale of measurement of acidity or alkalinity Pinocytosis Ingestion of small vacuoles into a cell; 'cell drinking'</p>
<p>Plasma Clear, straw-coloured liquid portion of the blood
Plasma protein Any one of a group of important proteins synthesised by the liver and carried in the plasma, with diverse physiological functions, e.g. as antibodies or clotting proteins</p>
<p>Platelet (thrombocyte) Small cell fragment involved in blood clotting
Pleural Related to the lungs
Plexus Network formed by a collection of nerves or blood vessels
Polymorphonuclear leukocyte General term for a white blood cell with an irregular nucleus (i.e. basophils, eosinophils and neutrophils)</p>
<p>Polyuria Production of large quantities of urine Positive feedback (cf. negative feedback) Control mechanism that increases and accelerates any change from normal in a physiological system; much rarer than negative feedback control Posterior (dorsal) Describes a body part or structure lying to the back</p>
<p>Preload Amount of blood in the ventricle just prior to ventricular contraction, determined mainly by venous return</p>
<p>Presbycusis Irreversible hearing loss, usually due to ageing, which results from degeneration of the cochlea and begins with an inability to hear high-pitched sounds</p>
<p>Presbyopia Stiffening of the lens, usually due to ageing, which impairs the ability of the eye to change focus (accommodate)</p>
<p>Pressure ulcer Damage to superficial tissues caused by prolonged pressure and interrupted blood supply, usually over a bony prominence Primary wound healing Simple repair of relatively minor tissue damage Prognosis Likely outcome of a disease Prophase First phase of mitosis Pronation Turning the palm to face backwards Protein Large polypeptide</p>
<p>Proximal Nearer the origin of a body part or point of attachment of a limb</p>
<p>Puberty Stage of life in males or females when reproductive maturity is achieved Pulmonary Of the lungs</p>
<p>Pulse Pressure wave generated by the heart, felt along an arterial wall where that artery lies close to the body surface</p>
<p>Pulse pressure Diastolic blood pressure subtracted from the systolic value Pyrexia Fever</p>
<p>Pyrogen Substance that causes fever Radiation Transmission of energy in waves Receptor Molecule, usually on the cell surface, that detects and responds to chemicals in the cell's external environment, e.g. a neurotransmitter. Also, a sensory nerve ending that detects physical changes in the local environment, e.g. a baroreceptor measuring pressure</p>
<p>Recessive In genetics, a form of a gene that can only be expressed if it is present as two identical forms on the chromosome pair</p>
<p>Refraction Bending of light rays as they pass through a lens, e.g. the lens of the eye Renal Of the kidneys</p>
<p>Resistance vessel Blood vessel, usually an arteriole, with a thick layer of smooth muscle in its tunica media, which constricts or dilates to regulate blood flow and blood pressure Reticulocyte Immature red blood cell Retroperitoneal Lying behind the peritoneum Ribonucleic acid (RNA) Molecule used to transfer genetic instructions from DNA to cytoplasmic ribosomes</p>
<p>Rotation Movement of a body part around its long axis Rugae Folds in the internal surface of a hollow organ when the organ is relaxed Sagittal plane Imaginary vertical line dividing the body into right and left halves, either down the midline (midsagittal) or on either side of the midline (sagittal)</p>
<p>Salt Product of a reaction between an acid and a base</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="56b34c82">Saltatory conduction of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">âˆ§</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">{ }^{\wedge}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7519em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7519em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">âˆ§</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> nerve impulse<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#56b34c82" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>along a myelinated nerve axon, from one node of Ranvier to the next
Scar tissue Non-functional tissue that replaces damaged tissue
Secondary wound healing Repair of tissue after extensive damage; a more complex and intense process than primary wound healing Semipermeability (selective permeability) Property of cell membranes that allows passage of some substances but not others</p>
<p>Senescence Cell ageing and the decline in function that accompanies it</p>
<p>Sensory nerve or neurone Afferent nerve that carries impulses to the central nervous system Serous fluid General term for protein-containing fluid secreted by certain membranes, e.g. serous pericardium and visceral pleura Sex chromosome X or Y chromosome (pair 23)</p>
<p>Sign Abnormality observed by people other than a patient
Simple propagation Continuous conduction of an impulse along a non-myelinated nerve fibre</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="sliding-filament-theory-accepted-mechanism-by">Sliding filament theory Accepted mechanism by<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sliding-filament-theory-accepted-mechanism-by" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>which actin and myosin filaments within muscle cells slide over one another to permit muscle shortening (contraction)</p>
<p>Specific defence mechanisms Immunity; the body's protective mechanisms raised against a specific threat or antigen</p>
<p>Sphincter Circle of muscle surrounding an internal passageway or orifice, used to regulate passage through the opening</p>
<p>Spinal reflex Involuntary, usually protective, action controlled at the level of the spinal cord (i.e. independent of the brain)</p>
<p>Squamous Flattened (epithelial cells)
Stratified Describes tissues that have several cell layers Striated Describes the microscopic appearance of a striped pattern on skeletal and cardiac muscle cells Stroke volume Volume of blood ejected by the ventricle when it contracts</p>
<p>Superficial Describes a body part or structure that is near the body surface
Superior Describes a body part or structure that is closer to the top of the head Supination Turning the palm to face forwards</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="sympathetic-nervous-system-division-of-the">Sympathetic nervous system Division of the<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sympathetic-nervous-system-division-of-the" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>autonomic nervous system that prepares the body for 'fight or flight'
Symptom Abnormality described by a patient Synapse Junction between a nerve and the cell it supplies</p>
<p>Syndrome Collection of signs and symptoms that tend to occur together
Systemic circulation Blood supply to all body organs except for the pulmonary arteries and veins Systole Contraction period of the heart or its individual chambers</p>
<p>Systolic blood pressure Pressure recorded in the systemic circulation (often at the arm) when the pressure is at its highest, immediately following ventricular contraction; the higher of the two measurements used to denote a blood pressure recording</p>
<p>Tachycardia Abnormally fast heart rate Telophase Fourth (final) phase of mitosis Telomere Non-coding section of DNA that caps and protects the ends of each chromosome Tendon Band of fibrous tissue connecting muscle to bone Teratogen Any substance or agent known to cause abnormal fetal development Thrombosis Inappropriate, pathological formation of stationary blood clots within blood vessels Thrombus (pi. thrombi) Stationary blood clot Tissue fluid Fluid between body cells, also known as interstitial fluid</p>
<p>Tolerance Ability of the immune system and its defensive cells and mechanisms to identify, and not attack, 'self tissues</p>
<p>Tract Bundle of axons in the central nervous system Transcription Production of messenger RNA from DNA</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="glossary">Glossary<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#glossary" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Translation Production of protein from messenger RNA
Transverse plane Imaginary line slicing the body into an upper and a lower part
Trophic hormone Hormone released that causes the release of a second hormone
Trophoblast Outer cell layer of the blastocyst that forms the placenta
Tumour Mass of cells growing outside the body's normal control mechanisms
Tunica adventitia Outer, supportive lining of blood vessels
Tunica intima Lining of blood vessels (also called endothelium)
Tunica media Middle layer of tissue in larger blood vessels
Urine Liquid waste product made in the kidneys
Vasoconstriction Decrease in diameter (narrowing) of a blood vessel
Vasodilation Increase in diameter (widening) of a blood vessel
Vein Blood vessel that carries blood towards the heart
Venule Small vein
Virus Non-living particle, which may be capable of causing disease
Visceral layer Layer of serous membrane covering a body organ
Voluntary control Conscious control of a body function
Zygote Fertilised egg formed by fusion of an ovum and spermatozoon</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="normal-values">Normal values<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#normal-values" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Note. Some biological measures have been extracted from the text and listed here for easy reference. In some cases, slightly different normal values may be found in other texts and used by different medical practitioners.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="metric-measures-units-and-si-symbols">Metric measures, units and Si symbols<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#metric-measures-units-and-si-symbols" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;">Name</th><th style="text-align: left;">SI unit</th><th style="text-align: left;">Symbol</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Length</td><td style="text-align: left;">metre</td><td style="text-align: left;">m</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Mass</td><td style="text-align: left;">kilogram kg</td><td style="text-align: left;"></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Amount of substance</td><td style="text-align: left;">mole</td><td style="text-align: left;">mol</td></tr></tbody></table>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;">Pressure</th><th style="text-align: left;">pascal</th><th style="text-align: left;">Pa</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Energy</td><td style="text-align: left;">joule</td><td style="text-align: left;">J</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Decimal multiples and submultiples of the units are formed by the use of standard prefixes:</p>
<p>Prefix Symbol
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>10</mn><mn>10</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10^{10}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">10</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> mega M
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>10</mn><mrow><mo mathvariant="normal">â€²</mo><mo>âˆ§</mo></mrow></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10^{\prime \wedge}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7519em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7519em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">â€²</span><span class="mord mtight">âˆ§</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> kilo k
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>10</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">âˆ§</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10^{\wedge}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7519em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7519em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">âˆ§</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> hecto h
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>10</mn><mo mathvariant="normal" lspace="0em" rspace="0em">â€²</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10^{\prime}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7519em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7519em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">â€²</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> deca da</p>
<p>10-' deci d</p>
<p>10-2 centi c</p>
<p>10"Â® milli m</p>
<p>10"Â® micro</p>
<p>10"Â® nano n</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="conversion-of-kpa-and-mmhg">Conversion of kPa and mmHg<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#conversion-of-kpa-and-mmhg" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>(e.g. for capillary pressures)
mmHg kPa</p>
<p>10.13
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>7.5</mn><mspace width="1em"></mspace><mn>1</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">7.5 \quad 1</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">7.5</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 1em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span></span></p>
<p>354.7</p>
<p>253.3</p>
<p>152.0</p>
<p>101.3</p>
<p>Hydrogen ion concentration <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(\mathrm{pH})</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">pH</span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="some-normai-plasma-levels-in-adults">Some normai plasma levels in adults<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#some-normai-plasma-levels-in-adults" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<p>Calcium 2.12-2.62 mmol/L 8.5-10.5 mg/100 mL</p>
<p>Chloride 97-106 mmol/L 97-106 mEq/L</p>
